A Meandering Historic Walks. Walked the Gothic Quarter (the old city) twice during a three day stay. The area has many winding streets, full of history and great shopping. This is where you find the Cathedral, Picasso Museum, Mercat de St. Caterina and several museums. Highly recommend you take a guided tour of the area or use a good guidebook so as not to miss many of the important historic venues.

My FAVORITE spot in Barcelona. Visited Barcelona for a short romantic getaway and felt inlove for the city. My favorite area of the city was in fact the gothic quarter, the jewish quarter (el call) and surrounding areas. Fascinating, don't miss it! Lots to see and to stroll around.

just wander and wonder. This area is a feast for the eyes and soul (and stomach!) We love just drinking in the beauty, stopping for a drink or bite in any of the delightful cafes or bars and in general just soaking up Barcelona. Do it!

Historical District With Lively Life. In general, old-city of european cities don't have lively life, however Gothic Quarter is not like that...I'll suggest you to get lost in this quarter and walk in every streets of it, enter different passages etc. You won't feel sorry for that...
Barrio Gothico. One of Europe's most interesting middle age quarter .. in a city full of treasures, the Barrio Gotico around the splendid cathedral is a joy to visit and enjoy

Barcelona - probably the most beautiful city I've ever visited. My wife and I were repeatedly warned about pick pockets and thieves in Barcelona, so maybe we were careful but we had no problems of that type. I found the city charming, the architecture stunning and the general ambiance very relaxing. Dinner at the Black Cat restaurant was so good we went twice, the cathedral is amazing and even if you have no religious beliefs whatsoever it is a must - it's more like something Disney has dreamt up than a Church, The Park Güell is amazing too, with plenty of Gaudi's work sprinkled through the park.

Get lost in interesting shops, restaurant and Gothic Architecture.. I have walk through this area of Barcelona twice and I must say it always interesting and inspiring. Through the tight streets with little worry of traffic and going through the shops, some touristy some just fashionable is always fun. The architecture and streets make you think of centuries gone by and what is must have been like 400 hundred years ago. In the area you will also find a cathedral and public buildings as well as ancient ruins. If you are in Barcelona save a day for this treat.
Strolling nice experience.. You have to walk down the streets and alleys of the Gothic Quarter if you are in Barcelona . The little shops as well as the small eating places are charming.

Relaxing typical place. Getting lost in the sreets of the Gothic Quarter is a must in Barcelona. Especially in the evenings where the weather is super nice and all the locals are out and the shops are opened. So much history.

a great way to start the day. A great way to start exploring the Barri Gothic quarter is from the Cathedral of Santa Eulalia.To get the best photos of the Cathedra’s front facade (which was only built 135 yrs. ago to a 15th century design) you must get there early, before the street market in front opens. Walk up the right side of the Cathedral and you will come across an abundance of gothic buildings, including the picture post card covered stone bridge build in 1928 over the Carrer-del-BisbeYou are now entering a very busy and popular tourist area, most of the street are vehicle free, making it easy to discover the many gothic style churches and small squares lined with old homes with their stone doorways..
Fun to explore. This was our favorite part of Barcelona to just explore and spend time wandering around! Great churches, museums, shops, food!

Lots to do here. Our hotel was in the Gothic Quarter. The promenade was all decorated for Christmas. It was stunning at night but it got extremely crowded. The old cathedral was right around the corner and there was a Christmas market going on the two days we were there. They were also celebrating St. Lucia so children were lining up for that. This is considered the center of old Barcelona. It starts at Las Ramblas and goes all the way down to the harbor.

Journey to the past. Fall in love with Barcelona ' s Gothic Quarter, prepare your self to walk and get lost among its charming allies. Meanwhile you discover some of the most amazing places to eat, drink.
Central Area. Our hotel was in this area and it was very central to all we wanted to see and do and all bus & metro services.

Within Walking distant from my Hotel Le Meridien. Lots to do and see in the Gothic Quarter. Christmas Market as well as Restaurants and Shops and Churches and Museums. I liked all the shops and so many different types of foods available.

Barri Gotic is a place that you must see when you visit Barcelona!. Barri Gotic, near the Rambla and also not far from the Rambla Del Mar is a place that you must see when you visit Barcelona. You find many local shops and also many small restaurants.
Good walk. If you are around Barcelona you should have a short walk of 2 hours to see the Gotic Barri where you will find very interesting buildings and churches.
Magical place . Just walking around this neighbourhood you can enjoy the buildings and feel the history, great little restaurants and cake shops everywhere.

Best Part of Barcelona. There are so many great parts of Barcelona including the beach area, the Olympic sites and Las Ramblas but my favourite part is the Gothic Quarter. You can explore narrow little streets where you will find shops, restaurants and tapa bars. Sometimes the streets will open up into a square with a church or food market. It is just fun to walk around and enjoy this area. It is safe and less expensive than some of the more touristy areas like Las Ramblas . There are some good hotels in and near the Gothic Quarter.

nice. A wonderful place. I am not going to repeat all the obvious things. The first time I would go without any guide, even completely alone, and get lost there and see where it leads me. Almost everybody speaks English so you can always ask for your way. The second/third time I would take a tour. I never took a walking tour, I took a Segway tour. The good thing about it was that you get to be MORE a parrt of everything. If you"re riding something, you are one of those who have to negotiate their way not only in the narrow streets but also between all cyclists, vans, skaters, dogs, bikers, motorbikes etc. And they have to negotiate their way with you. A perfect example oh human cooperation. And nobody gets angry with each other, except for some tourists :)I felt completely safe all the time. I walked around late at night, alone, nobody bothered me. Nothing got stolen although I am not particularly careful with my things and guides and waiters constantly lectured me about it. Some people ask for money but if you say no, they leave you alone immediately. All the small alleys are also perfectly safe, at least for me.The place is full of dogs, many of them run free. I love the pet-friendlyness of Spain.The crowds on Saturday nights can be a bit overwhelming though.

Do a free walking tour!. The Gothic Quarter is best experienced by getting into any free or paid walking tour, the local guide will walk you around streets, lanes and alleys and their interesting facts and accompanying history will mesmerize you!
Great to walk around. Join the walking tour and you'll learn a lot more than just strolling around yourself. It is a great place in Barcelona for a walk.

Very Cool, nothing like it. It seems daunting because of the narrow craggy streets and twisty lanes. We took a walking tour of this area before we went exploring. Take a day to just roam the area. It is filled with the magic of Barcelona. The creativity and the history will inspire you to dig deeper and appreciate the storied past and the spirit that keeps this place humming. I would recommend a tour but be aware of your space. It is crowded with tours and some large groups seemed to take over the street. We had a small group and our guide was super conscious of common courtesies to others. We stopped in at some beautiful churches and were able to admire the relics. The shops are artsy and contemporary. Sadly, not crazy about tapas but we were able to find some lovely spots to eat and then tasted our way through many delicious bakery shops lining the streets.
Great to see historical architecture. One great thing about Barcelona you don't have to walk very far to see unique and historical buildings.

A happening area. Set among old buildings and many shops/cafes/restaurants, this is a nice place to visit and see. The interior is a beautiful church with sculptures and places to see and rest your feet and mind. Be sure to be dressed conservatively. What I also appreciate are the many alleyways that you can go down and the surprises you will find. Take time to explore and go in without a plan and you will be pleasantly surprised. I would walk and walk and walk and take in all the different sites.

A nice place for walking. This place is nice for walking and feeling the spirit of Barcelona. Beautiful buildings, restaurant, shops, museums. If you want have a good evening then this place is definitely for you (and La Rambla is much more noisy and crowded).

My fav part of Barcelona. Barcelona is a amzing place, so much to do and see and eat and drink. This was my favorite area just because of how cool and beautiful the buildings are. There are plenty of local spots, tourist spots and amazing places all around. Obviously a must see when in Barcelona

A favourite place. A trip to Barcelona is not complete without a trip to the gothic area. The little alleys wind there way around this fascinating area which is full of little shops and places to eat. Don't for get to look up as it is amazing, a trip around here can help you imagine what it must have been years ago, just heaving with history.

The Gothic Quarter (Barri Gòtic) is one of the most famous landmarks in Barcelona. El Barri Gòtic (Gothic Quarter) is located in the center of Ciutat Vella (Old City), in the area between La Rambla and Via Laietana, and from the seafront up until Ronda Sant Pere. It is one of the most famous landmarks in Barcelona. This District is made up by a fusion of buildings, from Roman settlements to 20th century structures, and the overall atmosphere is gothic-like. The Gothic Quarter is easily recognized by the antique aspect of the buildings, its narrow streets and the near absence of traffic. Many of the streets are for pedestrians only and are built like a well-organized labyrinth, many of them leading to small squares.Main places to see in the Gothic Quarter:Cathedral of Santa Eulàlia. Barcelona’s main Gothic Cathedral is located in the heart of the City, between Vía Laietana and La Rambla.Bisbe Irurita Street. This gorgeous pathway leads from the Cathedral to the Sant Jaume Square, and has one of the most photographed bridges in Barcelona.Sant Jaume Square. The administrative heart of Barcelona. Here are located both the Palace of the Generalitat (Government) and the City Hall.Church of Santa Maria del Pi. The 14th Century Gothic Church, along with its 54 meter high tower, which can be viewed from La Rambla, is one of the most incredible structures on the District.Plaça Reial (Royal Square). One of the biggest tourist attractions in the Gothic Quarter. Is an animated square, just off La Rambla boulevard. Lined with palm trees, bars, restaurants, outdoor cafes and street lamps designed by Antoni Gaudi, it is a popular meeting point and one of its liveliest nightlife spots.Plaça del Rei (King’s Square). One of the most beautiful corners of old Barcelona, the 14th Century square houses the Museum of History of Barcelona.
Lose yourself for a day in ancient streets. Street walking along the old and narrow streets.Find good restaurants and shops.A bit on the tourist side.Still, highly recommended.

Wonderful place to explore. Agree with previous reviews that this is a wonderful place to just walk and explore. Fantastic cafes and restaurants and amazing architecture. We walked along the alleys every night of our trip and each time saw something new. Lovely atmosphere

Best quarter in Barcelona. It is my favourite quarter in Bcn. If visiting, you CAN'T miss Plaça del Rei and all its buildings, the Cathedral and all the surronding squares (st. Felip Neri, specially), the amazinch arch in carrer del Bisbe, the shops and bars at carrer de Banys Nous and the nearby streets, Plaça del Pi, carrer Ferrar and some hidden amazing spots, such as Temple d'August and the CC Pati Llimona... Just walk and get lost, it is an amazing area!!

A day to walk a drink and eat tapas all day. This for teenagers until over sixties, a beautiful part of Barcelona. Safe to wander all day and party all night, Hidden tapas bars and restaurants that are much better value than the touristy Ramblas.
Wish to get lost?. Looking for amazing atmosphere, little designer's shops, romantic restaurants? You'll find it for sure in the Gothic Quarter's alleys.

Walk your feet off!. If you enjoy wandering with no destination other than to stumble upon a new experience, then this is the area. Tapas, wine, true artists, hidden plazas, narrow alleys, few if any buskers, photo ops galore. Watch a delivery van negotiate a medieval corner while pedestrians walk behind, beside, and in front while skateboarders and scooters slip past. Sounds frantic but it's not since you're part of the show!

Get lost in the alleys and small roads. Great place to visit, very traditional feel and look. Small alleys and roads. Local Cafes and Shops. If you are in and around the Gothic Quarter the Barcelona Cathedral is a muse see, especially as it's so close by. Great little ice cream shops and restaurants

Interesting, bespoke and incredible atmoshpere. This feels like "real" Barcelona, full of artists and musicians. Great museums, tight little streets and stacked full of atmosphere. A real treat; highly recommend getting lost for a few hours here.
Great walking area. We stayed in this area. Very beautiful. Lots of shops and cafes. Museums, and cathedrals all in this quarter. Best place to stay in the city.

European Village Expeirence. So interesting and diverse. Combination of ancient and modern and lots of nice art surprises. We had a quick orientation from our guide which was great. It could be a little challenging to figure out the first time but definitely worth it.
Nice for a walk. It is romantic for a walking tour and it is close to the picasso museum to combine.Good to eat there too.

Amazing spirit of an old city. Lot of thieves . Used to live there for very first 3 days in Barcelona. But moved to Eixample after our flat was rubbed (we used to live on Carrer de la Portaferrissa 21) proffesional thieves stole my proffesional photo equipment in my photo bag + Mac book pro laptop, go pro, iPad and iPhone for a total amount of 11500 euros. But the quarter by itself is cool, with so many interesting buildings and nice bars, restaurants. It has some special spirit of an old city with this narrow streets and tons of people. Photographers will love it. To bad that I have left without a camera and can use only an IPhone exploring those district.

Hotel based here. We were really pleased our hotel was in this part of Barcelona. The little streets are great to wander with nice little shops. You can wander round forever and not come across the same place. All sides edge busy plazas so need to worry about getting lost. Saturday night is packed with locals so very busy. But there is no problem. If crowd gets too much you can nip down a side street .

Spectacular Architecture.. We walked to the Gothic Quarter from our hotel, the Le Meridien, which is on Las Ramblas. It is an easy walk, and definitely worth it to just stroll around and see the medieval buildings and streets. We walked during the day and did not feel unsafe or uncomfortable in any areas.
Great Old Town. There is not much to say about the gothic quarter in Barcelona. Go there, it is lovely and you won't be disappointed.

Lovely to wander. Enjoyed the Gothic Quarter. I must say though in December a lot of the smaller shops were closed. It is a bit of a maze so need good map reading skills if you are worried about getting lost.
Amazing. Nice walk around, plenty of bars and restaurants around. The old streets are a bit freaky at night time

Marvelous Walking Tour. The walking tour was the perfect way to experience this ancient quarter of Barcelona, winding your way through the narrow streets with their many twists and turns, sights, sounds and aromas.We were there on a bright overcast day -- it would be a very different experience in the rain.

Nice medieval tangle.. The best way to enjoy this sun blocking area is with either a guide or a guidebook plus map.It contains the 3 main churches of the Medieval period:Rich man churches- Santa Maria del Pi and the CathedralWorking class churches Saint Filipe Neri and Santa Maria del Mar.Two Jewish districts- El Call Major and El Call Minor.The Lotja- Stock Exchange turned Art SchoolThe MUHBA Museums- Place Del Rei, Vai Sepulcral Romana, El Call, August TemplePicasso Museum, Frederic Mares MuseumPlaca Real with Gaudi's Lamp Posts.The Ramblas- The riverbeds.

Huge Gothic Quarter. It's hard to visit Barcelona without a stroll through the Barri Gotic, and you shouldn't. It's the second largest medieval core in Europe and has been inhabited since Roman times. You'll see all sorts of layers upon layers here and for a North American, one of the most interesting aspects is how lively and in continual use the entire area is. It's worth it to arrange a walking tour.

History Reeks. This place is amazing, he gothic church, the narrow streets, the shops, the antique market; everything about this place is amazing. A must see. There is something on every building and corner to look at

No Rambling Required. Right in the heart of Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter, Shopping Areas all in minutes walking distance. The Hotel was a delight in every way. This is how a hotel should be run, with superb facilities, staff, Wi-Fi and particularly the beds. Only real criticsm id the poor choice of English Speaking TV Channels, but that apart, next time we are in Barcelona, this is the one hotel I would book.

Well worth a visit . Spent a couple of days wandering around and saw something new each time. Would recommend a visit day and night time. Lots of side streets leading into open areas good Xmas market next to the cathedral. The cathedral is a very good place to visit and you can go to the roof and see the surrounding area.
Lovely place. I loved this part of town and spent lots of time looking up at the architecture. Lots of things to do round here with las rambles close by.

Kept coming back. This was our favourite place in Barca. The buildings are beautiful and the bars less touristy than the adjacent Las Ramablas. Lots of good rock bars to be found. (Go exploring, get lost here).
Interesting for History buffs.. I would go with a guide because you have to understand the history to appreciate the city and its architecture.
Lovely area of Barcelona . This was my favorite area of Barcelona, it was cute quaint and historical. I recommend taking a walking tour through it if you can!

The other face of Barcelona. Once you have done the Gaudi homeworks in Barcelona, you have to come here.
This is the historical part of the city. It was so beautiful and you could walk and seeing the hidden little streets with shops, restaurants and cafes. :-)
MUST SEE IT! :-)
Explore gothic quarter. If you have time, go explore the charming old narrow streets of the gothic quarter which has plenty of shops, restaurants and bars.

Beautiful. Lovely area in the city and well worth finding these hidden little streets and literally see where your feet take you.
Every street you stumble upon something new and it gives the city a more quaint feeling with real character and the sort of place you find the real unusual quirks of shopping in a big city.
Eye candy. Everywhere you look, you will find amazement. I was so impressed with the architecture. I loved St Lucia's Christmas market.
lively area. a place always entertaining, lively, variety of shops, pubs, bars and restaurants, many small museums,

Beautiful part of town. A fascinating part of town filled with history, quaint narrow streets, old fashioned shops and many great sites to photograph.
Look up and around and you will see amazing architectural details that gives you a true sense of place. A beautiful part of town that it worthwhile visiting.

Could stay there for hours and hours.. Walked there for five hours annd still wanted to do more The old lands, cathedral, souvenir shops, cafes with churros and hot chocolate, unesco heritage sites, xmas market, beautiful courtyards, Gaudi experience, i just can go on and on ! Felt blessed to be there. Forgot the name of a cafe which served right on the back of cathedral where there were carols being sung while we had coffee, amazing experience . Restaurants on placa de reial are very good... I cant believe o forgot to notice the name so cant leave the review :(

Fascinating historical area in Barcelona. As diverse as Barcelona is, this area of the city presents a fascinating walk back in time to the origins of the old city, and includes excellent historical destinations. In addition this area has become an emerging area for new and progressive retail outlets, with small stores offering high quality goods and services.

Fira de Santa Llúcia (xmas market). fira de Santa Llúcia is a beautiful xmas markets in Barcelona outside the Cathedral in the Gothic quarter. Its typically Spanish, or Catalan rather and is full of Christmas decorations and relics for nativity scenes, very traditional. It runs from early December until Christmas Eve and is certainly worth a visit when you are in Barcelona in December, you can visit the xmas market and have a walk around and through the Cathedral. You'll find plenty of Tió de Nadal known simply as Tió (a big piece of cut wood) is a character in Catalan mythology relating to a Christmas tradition widespread in Catalonia. Another charming Catalan tradition is to add a funny character called 'caganer' to traditional nativity scene — you know, the usual suspects of Mary, Joseph and the shepherds gathered around the baby Jesus in his manger — There’s no delicate way of putting this so the most polite translation is “the defecator” as, despite an innocuous-looking appearance from the front, its buttocks are bare with each one containing a small, brown deposit beneath.
Beautiful. When I visited this area, I was struck by the old buildings and overall, old-world feel this quarter had to offer.
Worth visiting. Gaudi architecture is always fascinating and worth visiting. Do spend time wondering inside looking at the marvellous art work.

Great night. My frienss and I got to the Gothic Quarter by night already, but the magic was still there. Everything had a more mysterious way! The opera singers in the street are a must by now, I guess and since it was christmas the lights and the market were really beautiful

A step back in time to the Middle Ages. Excellent walk through time in this neighborhood of narrow streets. Make sure you look all around, especially up because you could miss a lot of the architecture other wise. The centerpiece is the cathedral which is a beautiful example of that time period. This is the only "cathedral" in town, even though the Basilica of the Sagrada Familia, is more "famous". Don't miss the wooden door with the bronze hand print in the middle.

Best of Barcelona here in the Gothic Quarter. This is a remarkable part of Barcelona showcasing its history, politics, art, culture spirituality, traditions and cuisine. Some Roman walls are found here as well as medieval buildings and narrow alleyways from a history that includes the Phoenicians, Visigoths, Romans, Turks, Moors and French amongst other civilizations influencing Barcelona. The politics of Catalonia are evident in their flags everywhere. The art of Gaudi is seen in the lampposts he designed for the Plaça Reial, or in Picasso's museum or in the Castellers sculpture at the Plaça de Sant Miquel. There is the historic and dominant Cathedral of Santa Eulàlia and 3 basilicas in this area, the most inspiring of which is the Basilica of La Mercè. The elegant city hall is here topped with the 2 flags, the wax museum close to Columbus statue and of course the Grand Royal Palace. Catalan traditions include the sardana dance usually seen in front of the cathedral or the many statues of St. George, the dragonslayer whose day is April 23, celebrated with roses for women and books for men. Of course, no mention is complete without talk of tapas, had everywhere in side streets but best away from Las Ramblas. Two famous places are El Gran Cafe and Les Quatre Gats. Two other gems are the Jewish quarter and the Palau de Musica but my favourite place was Museu de'Historia de la Ciutat a subterranean exhibit of Roman ruins - free on Sunday afternoons after 3. This area is accessible from the Liceu or Jaime Metro stations. Be careful about your possessions. This place is renowned for pickpockets....
Fabulous. We stayed in this neighborhood for two nights -- walk any direction down the charming streets to find a variety of shopping and dining. Loved it.

christmas market. We stayed just across the road so visited the Christmas market well worth a visit so different from others I've been too not a bit commercialised and very local absolutely lovely. such shame we couldn't bring back a tree and some mistletoe!
Must to see!. Impossible grandeur of buildings. The atmosphere of the Middle Ages. Very interesting walk especially late at night .....

Best neighborhood in Barcelona. Loved getting lost in the alleys and passageways. Make sure you visit all the churches including the Cathedral, Maria del Pi, etc. The Christmas Market is charming. Great shopping and restaurants.

just walk around and enjoy!. Start from the Cathedral and go through the narrow streets and walk around. look at the buildings and feel the atmosphere. You just need to try to imagine how life was going on in the past here and then you will be taken back in time. Try it!
Nightlife. Quarter full of restaurants and bars. Recommendable for dinners. Safe in general although you find some extrange characters every now and then...

Great area. Well worth a look
Lots of little alleys to explore and always something different around the corner.
The cathedral is lovely

Beautiful. A beautiful part of Barcelona that is a must when visiting. Very well sign posted for all the attractions and there are lovely shops in the narrow alleys. The cathedral is beautiful and well worth the money.

Best area for bars and restaurants and an authentic experience. We stayed in this area and were not disappointed. The narrow cobbled streets hold lots of great little bars and restaurants that were full of Spanish people. Prices were reasonable and the choice of tapas was amazing.so glad we didn't stay around rambles as that had a more seedy tourist vibe. It is very easy to walk from here to most tourist sites

Typical old town of major cities. Great to wander around looking at the little shops and architecture. Markets, art, churches, museums, and history abounds. The Christmas market was going on and it lacked a little variety with most of the stalls focusing on nativity items or holiday decorations. There was some beautiful art being sold, too.

Walking Adventure. Wife and I were walking the city and our trip to the Gothic Quarter was a highlight. The area offers so much to see and do and has to be a major area to see on any visit to Barcelona.

Time travelling in barcelona. This is the best way to see and learn the history of the town and the whole Catalan region. Excellent to walk around as it is very condense. A lot of sight to see and visit like the cathedral and a whole choice of places to grab a bite, dine, have a drink or coffee. Very close to central metro stations too and neighboring the "Rambla" and "El Born". Most touristic and best place to mingle with locals and tourists areas respectively.
Wonderful architecture and great shops.. This district has a beautiful history nice architecture. Many beautiful buildings, small and unique shops, and a lot of beatiful and different bars and cafes.

Special Place. Amazing architecture. Great eating places. Interesting shops. Cathedrals. Christmas markets. What else do you want? Wander across from La Rambla and enjoy the best part of Barcelona. Get lost in the alleys and the nooks and crannies. Churros and Hot chocolate in a cafe in a plaza. Great must do and see activity. Everybody deserves a day in Barri Gotic.
Take a map and wander.... Wandering around Gothic quarter takes you to another place and time. Better to go with a guide as you wont miss some hidden spots and learn a bit of history.
a "must" visit. lots of narrow streets with good shops and excellent restaurants. Easy to walk there just off La Rambla, and it seemed safe enough walking around at night.

Watch your wallet and purse. The Gothic Quarter is the old section of Barcelona between Place Catalunya and the harbor. It is a "must see" for every tourist from Boise to Bavaria and for every pickpocket from Bucharest to Burgas. The latter come here for the crowds of easy marks, narrow streets, and ineffective laws. Purse snatching is a petty crime that will get you hauled off the street for a while, but rarely long enough to interfere with your work schedule. So pickpockets are everywhere. The best defense is to keep your purse over your shoulder or your wallet in an inside pocket. Don't dare put backpacks down to tie your shoe and when in an outdoor cafe, anchor one strap under the leg of your chair. When someone bumps you, immediately bump back and go on the defensive. Pickpockets usually work in teams with one to distract you and the other to rob you--then both disappear before you know it. Barcelona is a very civilized and friendly city except for this plague of locusts; and until the laws make purse snatching a major crime, you had best beware when in the Gothic Quarter.
Wow!. Could have spent days on this property. Too much for one persons eyes and photos do not do it justice. breath taking.

Full of interest. Its a few years since I've been to Barcelona & I can say that this area feels a much safer place to be. Very touristy but nevertheless full of interest. Must have the worst Christmas market I've ever seen though.
Nice!. It's actually the old city of Barcelona with many tiny shops and real small streets...You can find anything you want there!

Fascinating collection of buildings.. One walk around is not enough , around Cataluyna Sq.and everything leading from there is amazing . Beautiful shops, parks , cafes , Plaza's Good info centre under the square.But its wandering the winding and interconnecting streets that is the wonder of the place.Look up from time to time . The buildings are magnificent.

Best Area!!. With all the hidden nooks and crannies, great shops, fascinating history and old world feel the Gothic Quarter must be explored and experienced both day and night. Do a food and wine tour with someone who knows all the best places to see, eat and drink. Loved it!!
Amazing. This is an amazing church. Extremely busy thou. A must see, lots of photo opportunities. Lots of stalls outside.

Really interesting. This area is a great mix of interesting old architecture down little alleyways, new fancy shops, lovely cafes and bars and restaurants. Nice relaxing areas to be found too. Great if you fancy a day of shopping!
Wonderful part of Barcelona!. Wonderful part of Barcelona. Suggest you to go for a walk, and to try some traditional wine and Serrano ham in local taverns.

November is great time to visit Barcelona. Wandering through the narrow streets of the city, eyeing the bakery windows and enjoying the beautiful balconies and plazas was a photographer's dream. I was there in early November without the crowds and pickpockets. On this Sunday morning there were people headed to the cathedral, which is worth a visit as well.

Unreal area with actual gothic feel.. Usually these sort of areas in cities are dull and boring, but i felt that this authentically felt gothic. There were a lot of narrow gothic streets with small shops selling artisan items. There are some pretty awesome churches and statues on display too.
Must do. You have to wander round here and get lost, the shops, bars, narrow streets and atmosphere are all great. Do it both by day and night. Just immerse yourself and enjoy.
Sums up Barcelona market streets. Its a place with extremely narrow lanes and tons of artists and performers. Even though small, the charm of this place is pretty enormous.
Must to see in Bcn. The most famous district of the old town and maybe of the whole city perfect for shopping and walking without a specific direction

Worth a visit. Our hotel was on the edge of this area, and we spent many hours wandering around the many winding streets. There's so many shops, restaurants and bars to choose from. At night the streets look lovely lit up with all the Christmas decorations too.

Do it yourself. . There's no need to pay for a guided tour. Just have a walk around the narrow streets and soak in the atmosphere. Stop at a bar for a beer, hot drink and tapas. Some of the bars and restaurants are quite expensive in thid select arra do beware! You can't miss the old church and cathedral which are the top two attractions (and both free). Its a small area! Also plenty os small museums including the Picasso gallery.

So much to see and do! Walk around by foot. We stayed in the area of the Gothic Quarter and loved it. English was spoken fluently and we had no problems with shops and restaurants. If you are looking for a area to stay, being in walking distance around the Gothic Quarter is perfect! While walking around the Gothic Quarters remember to look up, side ways and all ways as there is many interesting sights even up on the roofs. A wonderful experience being around the area

The place to be. At first we were disappointed that our hotel was in the Gothic Quarter as we had wanted to stay in El Born. Wow, would that have been a mistake. El Born is nothing but a big tourist mall. Sure, the architecture is wonderful; but, you get the same wonderful buildings in the Gothic Quarter without all of the tourist traps.

Lovely!. Our hotel was in the Gothic quarter (we stayed in Barcelona last weekend) and we enjoyed wandering around. The cathedral is in this area, although it's worth noting you can't just get in at any time. The guards on the doors were quite grumpily turning people away when we arrived, but a polite question to one of them elicited the opning times. It's stunning from the outside, gargoyles and unicorns in abundance!

Relaxed all day walk! . Take your time look and admire the buildings pop in and out of little shops stop and chat to the locals, wear sturdy shoes as some of the streets are uneven, find a lot of hidden treasures to pass the day away!
Love walking round and exploring. Never get bored of walking around this area exploring new bars and shops. Plenty, and I mean plenty of bars!!
Authentic and astmospheric - the real Barcelona. A must see. Getting lost within the tiny side streets, finding little boutiques and cafes along the way....perfect
Nice place to walk by. This is a nice place to walk by. It's close to the cathedral and the roman walls and I would say that you definitely should stop by these sights if you're visiting Barcelona.

Allow a couple of hours. If you don't duck into the churches or museums, you'll still need 1-2 hours to explore the maze of narrow streets in the gothic quarter. We peaked in all the churches and spent about 2 hours and only did half of it. The highlight was definitely the Barcelona Cathedral. Though a bulk of our time was spent exploring and discovering.
A must visit . This definetly is the must visit place when in Barcelona. It's got so much character and is beautiful with lots of history.

One of my favorite areas!!. A must go in Barcelona.. really a MUST go!!! Appreciate Catalan architecture and culture while strolling around this awesome barrio. I am sure you wont want to miss it out ;)

Make sure you get lost in here....priceless feeling!. I liked the fact that the people of Barcelona try to retain the beauty of the old town as it was. You can find really small shops. Mainly hand made goods are sold here but unfortunately there are a lot of souvenir shops too. Totally unique, it's easily distinguished as the most beautiful and interesting district of the city.Municipal cleaning services are working day and night and they really do a great job, as I never felt that any place was dirty because of the crowd visiting it.Really busy district...

Fascinating part of old Barcelona. Take time to wander through this ancient part of Barcelona. It will amaze you with the tiny alleys and streets. Every turn presents a delightful surprise. Don't miss walking this area of town.

Interesting place to explore. Interesting place to explore and it contains a number of interesting sites that you can visit. If you were going to visit all of these, I would allow at least half a day (a full day would be better). Make sure that you take a map!

Loved walking around. It was great walking around Barrio Gothic not knowing where to go. Each turn was a discovery of plazas and statues and squares. Nice picture of old Barcelona. Lots of restaurants and shops. Wear comfortable shoes, cobblestones could be hard to walk on.

The neighborhood is worth exploring!. We went off the beaten path and were able to enjoy the local color and cuisine at local eateries. We'd definitely follow our nose and look beyond the tourist area!

Tapas yourself silly. If you love your food - hammer this place. We spent days exploring alleyway after alleyway and shovelling plenty of outstanding Spanish grub down.
We skipped the guided tours and just explored it ourselves, stumbling upon cathedrals, museums and of course hundreds of tapas bars.

beautiful plaza. we passed by this plaza 2-3 times daily when going out from our BB to markets, shopping or architectural site visits. We always get drawn to either small band playing, guitarist or singer. its a very active plaza with lots to see but has calmness that make everyone to feel safe in.

Spend a day getting lost in these streets.. The old quarter of Barcelona (Gotic & Born) is a wonderful maze of narrow streets and plazas filled with history, beauty, local flare and great places to stop for a bite of food or shopping. Take one of the free walking tours (they run on tips) and learn the history and secrets of this fascinating quarter.

Walk around Gothic Quarter Barcelona. Enjoyed a wander down narrow streets with transcript links across them super architecture. Spotted a church to St Christopher built and used since 1503 . Main cathedral has fabulous finials and carvings (only viewed from outside sorry no photo ). Some large public buildings like General's Pslace faced a wide square . We were there on a Sunday and quite a few small shops open in side streets while main streets stores were closed

Fabulous History. The Barri Gotic is well and truly worth a visit as it is the heart of Barcelona. Try to see it through a free walking tour (Travel Bar is terrific) to make sure that you really get the fascinating history of the Visigoths, Carthaginians, Romans etc. Supposedly named after Hannibal's father who was a Roman officer there.
Old Barcelona. A variety of things to see and do here. Visit the cathedral, some museums and some old streets with shops. It's very touristic and beware of pick pockets ..but it's atmospheric.
Great walking and Dining. The Gothic neighborhood is a easy, visually appealing area with restaurants that cleverly use the old buildings to present good food and wine.

Fun Part of Barcelona. This area was very unique and full of history. I took the free Orange Donut walking tour that explored a lot of the interesting things to see and explained the history of the area. Also had great shops, bars and restaurants.
Fascinating. We found the Gothic quarter by rambling down the narrow streets - once there, there was so much to see - can't wait to go back - you could spend days among the old buildings

Absolutely astonishing. So beautiful everywhere around there. The little alleyways, the artists on every corner to the little cafes. I recommend you just get a city map and just walk around the city and simply discover it!

Good walking barrio. Great place to walk around aimlessly. Quaint shops and vermut bars. Very nice tapas bars that get booked reaaly fast. Do some homework to research best tapas place to eat at and make a reservation. Nice flamenco place too in the area. Use the tourist info office to make reservations.The gothic cathedral charges 7 Euro not very welcoming. The plaza in front of it is very welcoming and nice.

Must do!. The Gothic quarter holds such an intrinsic part of Barcelona's history ...from the times of the roman Emperor Augustus to Columbus and the age of Discovery! If you read up beforehand, it is an adventure to get lost through the narrow streets of this neighbourhood - we loved seeing the back alleys! but on our Gothic tour, learning of the various influences on the city's amazing culture was well worthwhile - we were already loving our visit to Barcelona, but the guided tour took our appreciation of this part of the world to a new level entirely! Dont skip this one!!
a must see. this whole area, we stayed right in the heart has so much to see, explore every alley! and dont forget to take your map!!!

Old quarters at their best. I personally loved the Gothic quarters of Barcelona. Unlike in some Italian cities, the building are extremely well preserved, and maintained.You could walk for hours in there and still discover some nice little corners with a little cafe or little hidden shops offering something interesting to sell.Do not miss it for anything. That's the whole charm of Barcelona.

8 weeks in Barcelona, my favourite "barrio". I've been in the city for 8 weeks on vacation, never took a taxi and only a couple of times I travelled bye tube I mostly walked because I wanted to know the city before leaving and who knows when and if I might come back (last time was 15 years ago!).I found the Gothic "barrio" very misterious, interesting and for sure my Barcelona this time favourite, last time was Barceloneta for obvious reason if you come from a sea place.Do not miss it!
Must go.... I enjoyed walking the streets of Gothic Quarter. We stop to eat some tapas and beer on a very hot day! We also enjoyed the street musicians.... I really love it!

Our favourite part of the city. Ancient history, atmospheric winding streets, art and boutiques and when you're tired, plenty of cafes and restaurants to rest and revive. Even the buskers played classical music. We ended up this area more than any other during our week in Barcelona. A definite must see and do.
Fascinating history. We took a walking tour of the Gothic Quarter which was very worthwhile in terms of information and identifying points of interest which we'd have otherwise missed.

Enjoyable walk. Every time you turn into a corner you see something interesting. Best of all, it's free! Enjoy the walk and discover street musicians, quaint shops, and hole in the wall cholaterias that serve yummy chocolates and churros. Or just sit on a bench to rest a bit and people watch. Good place to spend an hour or two.
Nice at night...... Go to olympic port if u wanna have fun..... the place is cool to walk at night but not too much fun to party unless you wanna enjoy a couple of drinks

Slightly Eerie at night but Amazing. I had ventured out in this part on a walking tour at night. I had a fantastic experience, felt surreal walking around this region. Would love to go back again very soon!

Walking in a dream at night. I think this quarter is perfect to go for walks deep in the night, if you are lucky, it is late enough and you choose the right tiny streets, tourist will disappear and leave place to a magical atmosphere which takes you to old times: I love it.

Very interesting. We bought a guided tour on Viator, and it was a good choice. The guide was great, spoke English well and showed and explained all the important stuff to us. Time and money well spent.
nice to walk around. This part of the city is really cosy with all of its little bars and resto's and cute little shops. We walked there for hours.

Amazing area of Barcelona. Not to be missed, an amazing place to wander around with the spectacular Cathedral and lots of little winding, ancient streets. Plenty of places to eat and drink, museums and individual shops.

The best area to visit in Barcelona. Strolling around the old Barcelona and going for local tapas in small family run place is the best experience in Barcelona, much better than being pickpocketed when on the rambles full of touristy stuff..

Amazing Architecture . I would highly recommend visiting the Gothic Quarters in Barcelona to anyone interested in Barcelona's history and early architecture. The taxi's will drop you off in the Gothic Center square which is a great starting point. You can do a guided walking tour of the area or explore on your own. This area gets very busy during the peak tourist season so I would recommend going during the slow season if possible. Keep an eye on your belongings for this area is know for pick pocketing however I had no problems.Great shopping, restaurants and fancy hotels to choose from. I would recommend wearing good shoes because it's a lot of walking and the sidewalks and roads are all cobblestone and can be uneven ground. Gothic Quarters was definitely a highlight of my trip!Sarah H.

So much to see & so little time!. We had a walking tour of the Gothic Quarter, but came back to see more. There are lots of little cafes & plazas along the way. The character of an area like this cannot be replicated.

Favorite area of Barcelona . I fell in love with the Gothic Quarter. It ls like traveling back in time. There are literally hundreds of lovely one of a kind shops and amazing restaurants. There are coffee shops, romantic restaurants, pastry shops, pubs, and so much more. I spent time there by myself several evenings and felt very safe. It is well lit and there are many people of all ages dinning and wondering around the district.
Top Barrio. One of the best neighborhoods in Barcelona, for shopping, drinks, and food. A definite must for anyone visiting bcn.

Twisting streets and back alleys house a lot of artisans. If you're looking for something authentically Barcelona, you need to go to this area and visit the small shops, as recommended to me by Feliciano Dominguez, a Professional Tourist Guide Catalonia. Not only is there historic value but there is a lot of restaurants in addition the shops, old churches, etc. Definitely a place to see and stop.

Day trip. Great place for a lazy walk and a mini adventure. We loved all the coffee shops and local stores . The Gothic Quarter is a beautiful area to visit .
Lots of street entertainment to enjoy.

Picturesque. Amazing area to stroll around. Don't plan you visit here but loose yourself in the narrow allies and you will discover wonderful patios and plazas. It is very busy during the day, but radiates a great medieval atmosphere at night or very early in the morning.
Beautiful old town. A maze of old streets with a beautiful old cathedral little shops and tapas bars around every turn well worth a visit
Intruiging adventure. A safe area and worth going down the different alley ways to explore. Loads of different squares, independent shops and bars and great architecture and ironmongery.

Nice area for a stroll. This is a wonderful Barcelona neighborhood in which to spend several hours strolling. There are lots of interesting shops and restaurants and the Cathedral is a worthwhile visit.

Excelent zone to walk. If in Barcelona, you have here an excellent zone to be visited by foot, a lor of restaurants with tapas and sangria, you have cathedrals to visit, small Streets with a lot of small shops.
Nice. It is very nice walking through the little allies little cute shoes , very nice boutiques at night it seems like the place cones to life
Magical attraction. This area of Spain is so beautiful at night , the lights and ambience around this area makes the visit worth while.

visit at night!. i don't suggest people to spend too much time for Gaudi's buildings. why not spend more time wander around the blocks of streets such as the Gothic Quarter? good place to do people watching and sit down for a coffee. A visit at night may give you a different feeling when it's less crowded. the buskers' guitar music made me feeling a travel in time!

CHARMING!!. I Loved this area of Barcelona and spent a lot of time here. Charming streets, and during the day where there are little festivals hidden within charming plazas throughout the area. At night, it has a whole other feel and it is beautiful, especially around the cathedral. This was my favorite place to spend my time in Barcelona.

Barcelona's picturesque Old Town. It is a very nice set of streets full of bars, cafeterias and all kinds of shops. If you go to Barcelona you should non-doubtedly visit the Gothic Quarter, since it's a really beautiful place with great atmosphere, lots of people and lots of things to do. Very easy to access using the subway (Drassanes station).

Great day spent there. We spent all day by walking in the Gothic Quarter. For me it has everything, atmosphere, cute places to sit and relax, excelent places to eat and buy presents (not classic souvenirs). We were there in November, it was the reason the streets were not crowded by people, what more in some parts we were alone.

"Fascinating backstreet labyrinth". The labyrinth of the Gothic Quarter spreads over some 2 square miles from the central park to, beyond its western side, the chaotic Rambla. This whole area consists mostly of narrow pedestrian streets and alleyways. Some are dimly lit at night and directions come be confusing so, if you are going to wander around like a tourist in the evenings, a map would be useful. There are tapas bars and restaurants in abundance, many of which have excellent ambience and are generally very good value. A lot of these have outside heating, so it is nice to sit and watch the world go by as you enjoy being served by the generally very pleasant waiters. Visit the Born Cultural Centre near the park - a restoration project of the old market building, the central area has been excavated to show 300 year old remains of old Barcelonian houses - the centre has an interesting bookshop an excellent cafe for an evening stop for hot chocolate and local nougat, a speciality of Barcelona.

Auditions for buskers!. Yes it's true. Top class musicians vie to gain a plot in the Old City area of the Gothic quarter. They are all excellent; from opera singers, to brass groups, to classical guitarists, and the reason is that before the Council grants them a plot, they have to pass an audition!. The Cathedral is in the old city area and is resplendent with its recently re-furbished facade. Ideally follow a guide round this area to discover e.g. the old horse crossing - Barcelona's predecessor to traffic lights!, and many other fascinating details which otherwise one would miss. The atmosphere in the large Cathedral square is of warm enthusiasm for such a fascinating place. There are good hotels here too.

Old town with lots to do. One of my favorite spots in Barcelona. The Picasso museum and Barcelona cathedral are located here as well. There are lots of places to grab a cup of Expresso and snack on tapas!
Eat, drink, shop. narrow streets, tons of places to eat, shop, drink. Keep track of where you are, easy to get lost, but no big deal.

Interesting. It was lovely just walking around the old quarter looking at the small and varied shops taking ones time having a coffee where or when it suited and espying restaurants for the evening meal
Wander these streets. Beautiful architecture. You can stumble upon add fresh fruit vendor, souvenir shop, or another place that boasts the Catalonian history.

Magical. The Gothic Quarter is a must see in Barcelona and hard to miss. Just walking around and admiring the architecture is a wondeeful experience. La Boqueria market just of Las Ramblas is close by and you get a feel of what Barcelona must have been like during that time. The cathedral is worth seeing too!La Plaça Reial is wonderful and some lovely restaurants around the square.A must see!

Narrow winding musical streets. We saw an exquisite opera street performer, a soprano, singing arias as well as popular songs behind the cathedral. I literally could not move away. I was hypnotized by her voice. It struck me that this kind of thing just *happens* in the Gothic quarter. She wasn't the only musician around blessing us tourists with art. The buildings here are art too. As a Middle Ages lover, I was thrilled by this place. Narrow streets, tall stone buildings and sculpted facades make me happy!

Great to go there and get lost in the streets!!. I loved to go there without knowing very weel what to expect and just walking around the streets and enjoying the buildings and the streets...then finishing the visit with the Cathedral, magical place from the outside and inside, FREE!!

Don't miss this area!. After buying tickets to jump on the Metro, we all spent a wonderful Sunday afternoon wandering around Barcelona's gothic quarter. It was the most wonderful experience - full of cute winding alleys, beautiful buildings and lots of secret areas to explore. Lots of dancing and cultural happenings outside the cathedral drawing huge crowds...and so nice to see people sitting outside in the late October sunshine enjoying a drink whilst perched on the nearest wall or steps...and not a sign of unruly, unsightly drunken behaviour - which would probably be the case if this able to be done in London! As with advice given to tourists in any other busy area of any city, just keep bags safely close to you and make sure wallets and purses are secure at all times - we didn't have any problems but with so many huge crowds of people, it's only sensible to protect your belongings wherever you are!

Nice walking area. Everyone should at least take a walk in Old Town Barcelona and this area. The Cathedral is beautiful and there are plenty of squares for dining or people watching. We were in this area twice.

Loved it!. I was unsure of my choice to come to Barcelona after only seeing the Rambla my first day. It's was so Vegas or Miami. But the Gothic Quarter was full of what I love in an adventure in Europe. Old, old buildings, small winding streets, unique little shops tucked in wherever there's room. Fewer and more serious tourists, more interested in history than shopping. I had a great day, following Rick Steve's walking tour then wandering off on my own. Recommend to travelers with a reverence for the old vs the new.

As various as one could wish. This is a neighborhood of small, narrow, crooked streets and tons of tourist shops. Tourist shops may be regrettable, but the small, narrow, crooked streets contain so much more. It's a real neighborhood, for one, and there's nothing thousands of tourists can do, really, to change that. There are real buildings, some of them from hundreds of years ago; there are real shops where real neighbors shop. It's littered with gothic architecture, in a way that used to be true for Paris, but which is now extremely difficult to find in that post-Haussmann city. In the Barri Gotic, you can get the flavor of 12th or 13th century (or 14th) Europe over an impressively large area.Well, if you're a tourist, and you're in Barcelona, you're inevitably going to go to the Barri Gotic no matter what. What you might not do is really get down and walk down every single street and go into every single church or every single other architectural delight in this neighborhood. Believe me, this area is crammed with so many interesting things, you could spend your whole time here and not even get close to exporing the whole place. But I highly recommend giving it a good try. And, what's more, the Born is as interesting and various a neighborhood as Gotic, and it's right next door. Good choice you made to come to Barcelona!

Walking tour of the Gothic quarter. This was hands-down one of the best walking tours I have ever been on. The guid was very knowledgeable and friendly. The area is beautiful and filled with tons of history and wonderful people. I would highly recommend it!
Pretty cool . Amazing to look at but pretty crowded which means it is slow to get a good photo and properly look at certain things. Worth visiting though
Everywhere you look, it's magic. I mean it. The barri gotic is such a great place to roam around, just walk, without any purpose other than enjoying a great day in Barcelona

Old Barcelona. here you can feel how it looked to live within Roman walls and what was the life on old BArcelona. Engage in free walking tours and feel this special part of the city which will take you back couple of hundred of years. You can sit in the Placa where king and queen were siting or where Columbus came from his voyages to tell them that he has found new world (or India as he tought).

Old part of city with narrow streets. I loved the atmosphere in this city quarter, old part of city with narrow streets full of life.Lots of shops, restaurants, bakeries. We saw street performers dancing tango on little square

Best area to stay in, in Barcelona. We stayed on Casa Estape in a modernist flat whose façade, foyer, and stairwell were so beautiful. It is presently being renovated. The Gothic quarter is near so much that can be walked to, or are just a short cab or metro ride away. The old Jewish quarter, the cathedral, (and great market next to it weekends), the Palau de Musica which is so awesomely exquisite, La Boqueria (fabulous food market), Barri de Gracia, El Born, Las Ramblas, places like Casa Batllo, La Pedrera are within walking distance if you have the stamina to do so. My husband and I are in our sixties and found it no problem to walk with a couple of cab rides. Also don't miss the Basilica de Santa Maria del Pi which had a Catalan Market and art market next to it, and the oldest street in Barcelona.
Ideal situation. Loved strolling through the narrow streets and soaking in atmosphere.. very upbeat vibrant feel especially around the Cathedral square
Wow! Very impressive!. It's a must see for yourself. Amazing building so much history. The architecture is very impressive.
Intresting area. Well worth a look around visit the many passages where there are lots of interesting places to eat drink and shop to you drop.The cathedral is well worth a visit.

we did the Rick Steves walking tour and it was informative and fun. St. Ann's Church is a simple 12th-century Gothic church that I liked. The cathedral was very good and the view from the top is excellent. There is an elevator.

Treasures around every corner. This was the highlight of our evenings walking the narrow streets and discovering restaurants, shops, art and music. It was delightful and filled with every age of person.
Medieval Walk. This is a walk thru the old part of the city with many interesting sites including the Cathedral. It is a relaxing walk thru the narrow streets with plazas and open markets.

Old city. A great place to wander around and get lost. The streets are very narrow but charming. There are many places to get something to eat or just snack on. The buildings are historic and every turn is a new adventure. I would recommend this area to anyone visiting Barcelona.

Architecture of Barcelona. Every building you pass inspires you to rech for your camera...Barcelona surely be one of the most photographed cities. A fabulous mixture of Gothic, Art Deco and Modernism...along with well maintained/restored ancient and historic constructions..
Great food and shops. Fun to walk around in the old district. Some of the best restaurants in town, charming shops, great street musicians.

Very pleasant to wander around. Spent a very enjoyable morning walking around the Barri
Gothic. There was plenty to see and do and I felt very safe (although, as always in Barcelona, I was very careful with my bag). Lots of photo opportunities and picturesque, narrow streets.

Worth having a wander. This quarter is just off la Rambla and includes lots of narrow streets and shops. It's well worth having a walk around for something very different to the bigger and busier squares.

Interesting to compare this old section to some of the smaller cities we went to. Get a good map, take the Red Bean free tour and then stroll and eat around this section. It is not like an old section in Toledo, Seville or other places I have been to but it was nicer than I thought
A different view of the city. Narrow street churches full of live a different site of the city that is definitely worth seeing wonder around the streets for an hour and explore the old flavor

So amazing!. we stayed in the wonderful H10 Montcada, right in the Gothic Quarter.This area of Barcelona, is so beautiful, full of character, clean, and safe.So many wonderful streets, and courtyards to intrigue and explore.Individual shops and cafes, simply to people watch is lovely.The area around the Cathedral also provides a wonderful canvas for performers, and musicians, and adds to the ambience of the area.

Beautiful gothic buildings. Lovely way to spend the evening strolling through all the little ally's looking at buildings and shops. We found 2 squares one was full of places to eat and drink whilst sitting outside watching the world go by, the other was lit up blue with a spotlight we thought it may have been a projection type show but we went back every night and didn't see anything happen, so we don't know what this was for.

just get lost in the quarter. we rented an apartment in the quarter for the month of October.....truly came to love the area.........great restaurants, just wander down any street and you will find shops to visit, buildings to marvel over, churches to visit....oh, so much to enjoy.
Walking tour. Most enjoyable, great guide & without the tour would not have known the area existed. Learnt a huge amount
Nice city part. Great place to walk around and look at buildings. There are a lot of shops with a big vararity of goods. Great restaurants both expensive and cheaps
Delightful place to stroll. We enjoyed strolling through the narrow streets, open squares. Loved the ancient feel of it. One of the most memorable places we visited.
Get lost and enjoy. Spend and afternoon meandering through the network of small alleys and cobbled streets of the gothic quarter. You won't be disappointed.
Everything one needs to experience. The winding streets and alleyways, shops and tapas restaurants, plazas with eating and drinking establishments and spirit of Barcelona reside right here.

amazing. very interesting way to spend the evening ambling round looking at the shops and the buildings. beautiful town square where u can sit out and eat or drink whilst people watching and enjoys the sights and sounds.

A-maze-Ing!. Mis-spelling is deliberate so please pardon the pun. This is a real rabbit warren of an area with new delights at every turn. It was difficult to know where to look next - up or down, side to side . . . Just brilliant!

Top most place to visit in barcelona. Gothic Quarter is a very old, charming place. It has a great feel and you can just roam for hrs admiring the structures, window shopping, eating at the small cafes and outlets. If you go with a local guide, you will even understand some good history around some of the structures. We went there 2-3 times during our 4 day visit.

I loved this place. We were drawn in by wandering down the pretty little side streets from Les Rambles. It's brilliant. So vibrant, so many things going on and it feels like you're discovering a hidden side to Barcelona. It's definitely worth visiting because of the feel of the place.

Old world charm.. This area is certainly a world away from modern mainstreet, with its narrow streets indispersed with more open areas. However, taking the time to just wander and soak in the atmosphere is well worth doing.

Little streets, shops, cafes and a wonderful cathedral. The gothic quarter is a maze of little streets, shops, cafes, restaurants and am amazing cathedral in the middle of it. Really enjoyed wandering round this area and stopping at a cafe and people watching. Very popular and busy.

Strp back into history. While Barcelona is "Touristville". I loved this area. Mazes of streets, with locals and shops and the buildings are wonderful.
Our hotel recommended a restaurant PLA , finding it was have the adventure and the food was marvelous.
Nice area to stroll around. I spent a couple of hours wandering around and looking in little (touristy) shops. Nice architecture.

Lots af things to walk to. We always look to stay where we can walk to and easily enjoy interesting and historic activities of the destination. Barcelona's Gothic Quarter has tons of restaurants, shops, parks and interesting streets to entice.

Well worth a visit. We simply loved the Gothic Quarter. We walked all around it and visited all the churches etc. Lovely narrow streets, restaurants and an eerie feeling all around. A must visit. I was warned not to come here at night.
Lovely. Some beautiful buildings. Well worth a visit especially after sundown. Great just to wander and pop into the various bars for tapas and a glass of something.

The salt on your bread.. After visiting several Gaudi buildings, I somehow felt myself as a chocolate lover who overstuffed herself. I just wanted something salty. The Gothic Quarter was a perfect change. The winding narrow streets, where some can easily be lost, end up in charming sunny plazas.My favourite place was the Viceroy’s Palace. The graceful arches, the noble staircase surmounted by a fantastic coffered ceiling, the St George door recently made but quoting history, all of them made the visit enjoyable.The Gothic Cathedral of Barcelona dominates its area, and that is the place where I managed to lose myself. Even to be lost was fun.Of course we went to see all of the must-see places, the Carrer del Bisbe, which isn’t old, but so iconic, that everyone take a picture of it (including me). Visiting the Placa Reial was just by accident, but we fell in love with it right away We strolled on the decorative narrow lane the Carrer de Petritxol to arrive to Basilica Santa Maria del Pi. It is situated on the Plaça del Pi, a delightful plaza in the “Barri Gòtic” of the city. On thePlaça de Sant Jaumein in the amid of the Gothic Quarter. There're two impressive palaces are full of history. The City Hall and the Palau de la Generalitat de Catalunya are facing to each other and we were fortunate to observe them . These to impressive palaces are full of history, The Gothic District is the heart of the city,and just as beautiful and important part of Barcelona as the Gaudi buildings.Just don't forget to visit the Picasso Museum..

A Barcelona must! . This is such a lovely part of the city, the real heart, just wander around and take it all in, the sights, beautiful architecture, smells from little tapas bars, just picturesque, tiny little streets opening into huge squares with massive cathedrals and churches just tucked in amongst everything! And best of all it doesn't cost anything to see!
A must in Barcelona. A must to do when in BarcelonaSpend an afternoon walking and have diner at Pla in the barri gothic.
Great for history buffs. Really amazing buildings, would however recommend taking a guided tour to understand the significance of it all. Well worth taking the time to see this

Time trip. Just a walk back in time, to the Gothic neighborhood of the city. Old buildings, narrow streets and a very unique atmosphere. Huge churches and hidden squares are the surprises it has to offer. Also some great local shops and the Wax and Picasso museums

A maze of fascinating streets, restaurants and shops - keep your map handy. After touring the Gothic Quarter with a guide, we went back the following evening for tapas and found its narrow streets and twists and turns a challenge, albeit a rewarding one. The abundance of restaurants, shops and opportunities for people watching was dizzying. In fact, we walked so much, we decided to take the subway back to a stop closer to our hotel. Incidentally, the subways are easy to negotiate. If you're going to be in the city for a few days, I recommend that you buy the 10 ride ticket for about 10 euro. My daughter and I shared it and saved ourselves money as well as shoe leather, One further piece of advice - definitely go to the Gothic Quarter, but keep your map or your GPS handy.

It is he only lace I would live if stay fior good in BCN. Beautiful buildings with gothic decoration , a strange feeling in the air when hanging around this barri , n other barry in BCN hase same charme !

Very interesting. Gothic Quarter needs a visit of a few hours. This is really a medieval buil quarater with narrow stretts and many shops. You can find good tapas restaurants. There is a free guided tour offered by Runner Bean Tours that is informative of this quarter. Do not hesitate.

A non negotiable for a journey to barcelona. A gorgeous and stunning gem of Barcelona that is a must for anybody who is over there. The architecture is simply breathtaking and the cathedral is a wonder to behold - words cannot do it justice! The narrow and winding streets are a fun way to get lost around Barcelona and continuously stumbling upon hidden gem after hidden gem is not a bad way to spend a holiday!
Barcelona Gothic Quarter. Was amazing, the architecture, the history. We were there 8 days and could have stayed longer. Stay in rather area and just roam around!

If the walls could talk!!!. It's like stepping back in time.... Enchanting and mysterious. Beautiful arcitecture and narrow cobblestone streets . Lots of little authentic shops and Tapas bars. Church courtyards with outdoor cafes and live music . Would highly recommend it! Quieter than Las Ramblas!

Sense of history and good shopping. Walking through the Gothic Quarter feels like walking back in time, and you can imagine living in the times of the building of the Cathedral of the sea. At the same time there are great opportunities for eating, drinking and shopping.
this is the heart of BCN. plan on walking around , no agenda plan 3-5 hours and wind up and down the streets and shops , stop a few times for tapas and cava

Catacombs of shops and culture. We visited the Gothic Quarter during a free Barcelona walking tour and were transported back in time. We took a cooking class actually around one of the corners in one of the small shops but there were clothing shops and excellent specialty restaurants and bakeries hidden along the alleyways and narrow streets. This part of the city of Barcelona made real to us the age of the city. We absolutely loved it.

Must go. If you want to see a place that can be one thing during the day and another completely different at night time this is the place to go. During the day, shopping, sporadically stops for coffe and tapas are fine, but you must explore the quiet streets- you will find hidden gems. At night, explore the quiet bars in side streets, find the salsa bars, drink a chupito and keep going. It never ends! Don't forget to tip the waiters/waitresses!
A must do when in BCN. Get lost int the Barri Gotic, take a stroll through narrow streets and enjoy a coffee or Tapas and a good whine in one of the many bars.
Old and Interesting!. Nice walk to take.. You can do with the free walking tours. Nice place to visit.. And its near Las Ramblas!

Strolling through the streets, priceless.. Strolling through the streets of the Gothic Quarter is an experience that feeds your soul. The secret is not to get caught up in the hustle and bustle of tourists rushing from one sight to the other. Just "pull over to the side" and look at the shops, door knobs, detailed entrances and meander from street to street!

Fun to get lost in!. This is a pretty cool area, full of history, shops and eateries. Bring a map, but get the most out of it by booking a tour through any of the tourist information offices. Fun places to see (old roman city gate, Picasso museum, Museum of the History of Barcelona...all awesome!) Great places to eat whatever you like, and.....chocolate! Churros and chocolate-just do it and diet later. Trust me on this. Oh, and Brunell's, next door to the Picasso museum, has fantastic traditional Catalan pastries and chocolate, too.Many of the streets actually end up at a major street, such as Via Laetana or Las Ramblas so it's not like you won't be able to find your way out again.

A must see if in Barcelona. The Gothic quarter is one of our favorite places we went in Barcelona. Wandering the quaint narrow streets was great experience. Seeing the little shops and restaurants is interesting. We found a wonderful little restaurant for lunch - La Cassola. Don't ask me how to find it though. Easily can spend 4 hours to a day just wandering through it.

Nice Set of Streets to Shop and Get Lost Through History!. These small, narrow streets are full of history as well as shops that sell everything from groceries, souvenirs, to high end clothes and jewelry. The good thing is that almost each shop employee is pretty proficient in English to help you if you have questions. Highly recommended!

Great place to roam!. The area is a great place to walk around and see the city. The streets are narrow with many different shops, restaurants, and bars. We had a great time at night hopping around different restaurants and bar. The streets are labyrinth like and it feels like you're in a maze at times.
So Much to See. The whole area is a delight and shouldn't be kissed. Wander round the ancient, narrow streets, shop or visit the cathedral.

Great to get lost in. I recently visited for a long weekend and stayed in the Gothic Quarter. I spent a whole day just wandering the area. The buildings are amazing and there is something new around every corner. Be sure to bring the camera.

Must do in Barcelona . If you want to experience the history of Barcelona you must spend a morning or afternoon wandering the streets of barri gottic. Plenty to see and experience...highly recommend you stop at the out of the way bars for a vino, vermouth and tapas to add to the fun.

Walk through history. Gothic Quarter is beautiful and historical. Enjoy the walk through narrow streets during daytime but avoid poorly lid streets at night. Lots of places for tapas and shopping. Take a walking tour from the Palau de Musica.
Visit there!. It is in Jaume area and till arrive you pass many destination to have pictures. Enterence is 7 euro per person. Should be visited.

A real maze full of suprizes. Take your time walking along the streets of the Gothic quarter. There you'll find endless opportunities to shop for local souvenirs at bargain price. Don't forget to ask for a reduction, the competition is fierce and prices magically drop once you walk out the stores. Build like a grid the Gothic Quarter is filled with architectural treasures and boutiques. A must see!

beautiful. beautiful great location so many places to eat all people are friendly and helpful the old streets are amazing dont be afarid to venture down those little allyways there amazing and lead to amazing cafes and restraunts and the shopping wow
Quaint Neighborhood!. Enjoyed the 'hood a great deal. Near metros and buses, restaurants, museums, shopping. A nice place to walk.
AMAZING. Amazing and unique architecture, easy to get there by foot from the center. You could make there huge amount of beautiful pictures! Was there with boyfriends, really enjoyed it.
fantastic! very beautiful buildings. in my opinion, one of the most interesting parts of Barcelona. it is full of mystery, history and quiet elegance.
nice walk. You can have a very nice walk with the narrow streets, antique sellers, nice designer shops and cosy cafees. A must see area in Barcelona.

Gateway to the Ancient Roots of the City. We did a free (pay what you wish) guided tour which was helpful. This is an area of old poorly marked streets with incredible charm and mystery. Spend at least three hours wandering.
Living history. One of the most beautiful old towns of the world. Living, breathing history every where. Each turn provides a new stunning view.
Great walking tour. A wonderful walking experience. great tapas bars and shopping; just fun to be a apart of the area. Stop and get a glass of wine and watch the activity.
Fabulous walking area!. Our apartment was situated close by so we enjoyed the view from our roof top and also by foot; a great experience!
Lovely walk. A really pleasant walk, wonderful cafes with reasonable prices and beautiful buildings. We enjoyed Placa Real and Barcelona Cathedral is not to be missed.

Gothic Quarter and Respect to Great Creativity. One must go and see that monument of Barcelona city.It is impossible not to feel respect to that architecture of the building and as a temple of religion

A curiosity shop!. If you enjoy a stroll and have time on your hands, this area is worth a visit. Full of what seems like never ending side streets, it contains qwerky, curiosity shops as well as many museums including the chocolate museum.

Great architecture. I'd been to Barcelona twice, but never walked around the famous Gothic Quarter. I finally spent time walking around it this last time I went to the city, observing the amazing architecture, and understanding a bit of the history of this incredible city. This is a place that can't be missed.
Loved the narrow lanes. And the little plazas with cafes. You never quite knew what you were going to see around the corner. Charming! I loved walking through the Barri Gotic.
Interesting and charming. Interesting little streets and alleyways. Charming bars and restaurants. Beautiful cathedral. Delightful ambience.

Enjoy Meandering through Medieval Barcelona. One must walk through Barri Gotic to understand how Barcelona started in medieval times. Wander through the narrow streets, lanes, and alleys, through the Roman ruins, the Jewish quarters, basilicas, and homes with various influences from ancient times, Moorish times, the Renaissance, Baroque, classical, and modernistic styles unique to Barcelona. It is amazing. Reading books is great, but actually walking through history come alive is something else.

Spend some time here. One of our favourite parts of our visit to Barcelona was wandering around in the Barri Gotic. There are many old churches, unexpected squares and fascinating old buildings. Strolling here is never dull.
Did A Walking Tour. Great way of learning a bit of history about the areas you are walking in. Runner Bean tours did a great job. So many boutique shops too.
