Take the time. Nice area to explore. Nice cafés, restaurants, boutiques. Interesting architecture, alleyways, side streets. Shade from the sun :). Near the cathedral. Easy to get to and a nice break from the Ramblas. Near Placa Riel. Nice cocktail , lunch site
interesting area.. We would have hoped that more had been preserved but it was very interesting to see. narrow streets like a maze.

Must see!!. Great place to visit if you like history. A must see historical museum that takes you underneath the city. You can see how the Romans lived their life in early Spain. Many great restaurants and bars throughout the gothic quarter. Please visit, you won't regret it just prepare for a lot of walking, bring comfortable shoes.

Interesting. Erm yeah so we got lost down one of the little alleys and turned a dodgy corner where we were greeted by prostitutes, men with no teeth and people blatantly dealing drugs - this was at 2pm! So just stick to the busy spots day or night and I'm sure it will be fine. We also ended up in an amazing outdoor market selling lots of goodies from chorizo to fresh smoothies.

Awesome. Close to the center and El Born. Gothic Quarter is something you imagine out of a movie. It's very nice to walk around and just take in the architecture. Very touristy, but if you're visiting Barcelona, it's not to be missed!

A world in Barcelona. This is a very nice part of the town combining different styles of shops, but the arquitecture is very nice, I would recommend to go there early morning and in the evening before the sun goes down cause you will have to completely different impressions of the same place.

Best bit of Barcelona. Avoid the tourist trap that is the Ramblas. The Barri Gotic is the real historic Barcelona. Small, winding, labyrinthine streets opening into little squares, hidden churches, and some great cafes and restaurants. Love it!
Very Touristy !. Great shopping, but probably more pricey than other areas ! Very interesting buildings and a lot of life !

Don't miss this gem.. I spent two full days just wandering the streets here, and it was magical. Ditch the map and just wander. You won't believe the tiny little streets that twist and curve and who knows what fantastic things just appear? This street too congested? Take a left. Or right. Instant change. There are free walking tours also so whether you have a little or a lot of time, don't miss it.

The most interesting area in Barcelona. You can get lost and wander through this district for hours. Lots of secret little bars and tapas restaurants, amazing cathedrals that can appear from nowhere, and great architecture along the way. Worth a lazy stroll or too!

Glorious Gothic. Fabulous place to stay as the architecture is amazing and there is so much to see - buildings, shops, cafes, winding streets filled with antiques and lots of squares where you can eat, drink and watch the wonderful world go by
Wonderful. Have a stroll throughout this part the city. Enjoy the cathedral and all of the shops on the small streets. A must

Narrow streets, interesting squares, a lot to see. I could walk around El Gotic all day! There was a lot to see and do. We passed many interesting shops, cafes, markets and more. There were narrow streets full of character, plazas and squares with great terraces and surprises around every corner.It never felt too crowded and it's an area that is a must see in the city.

Trendy boutique shopping.. With the exception of a few of the standard "souvenir" shops we found the most unique clothing, art, and gifts. Surrounded by historic buildings. A few peasant beggars but they looked like Hollywood extras.

just wandering around. old town, just wandering around. Be it you stay nearby, or cutting through to visit different attractions. take your time if you are not in rush, into small lanes, shops, etc. It is fine to get lost, just to have GPS or map so as to bring you back on track.
Wow.... Go and get lost in this part of the city. Marvel at the lovely arches and the way that iron has been manipulated to be something beautiful.

Medieval. Mix of small narrow alleys and large Squares and Marketplace. Mix of small local shops and large international brands.
Dining tip: Go where the locals go! Much better and cheaper. .
Gothic Quarter. I loved all the little shops and the character of this area. A little like Venice! My favourite area of Barcelona.

Well Preserved. The Gothic Quarter - in the busier months - is worth visiting either early or late in the day. To be honest before 10:00 am is ideal, as a lot of people go for a pre-dinner walk as the sun is going down. The quarter is extremely well preserved. The main street is the more modern shopping area. Explore the small streets off to the sides. The Cathedral is a "must see" according to most guides - although it is not that different from a lot of other large cities and there is scant information available. The history museum is the find of the area. Amazingly extensive Roman remains under the city. Stunning and hardly anyone seems to know that they are there.

Historical & modern at the same time. A real sense of history but not claustrophobic in the narrow alleys and streets. A great sense of wondering what's round the next corner. Best to visit when you don't have to be anywhere else soon, i.e. just stroll and enjoy!

A must see and be in Barcelona. We stayed at the Mercer hotel within Barri Gotic and enjoyed every moment walking around in the narrow streets (you would not think that cars could drive here, but watch out). with it small squares, small shops with and restaurants/bars. When we were there they celebrated Saints Just ( on the square named after him) with live music, local food and quite a party. A thing that a lot of people miss when they are in Barri Gotic is to visit the Roman town that has been excavated under Museu d'Histroria de la Ciuat located at the street called Llibreteria. A very very interesting experience where you also learn a lot about how Barcelona has developed . Once you have paid the entrance fee it gives you access to all museums in Barcelona that are managed by MUHBA (Museu d'Historia de Barcelona)
Hours spent wandering. We spent hours wandering throught the little streets. The architecture was beautiful. Our feet tired at the end of the day.
walking trought Barrio Gotico. Nice walking tour, you will see gotic streets, monuments, cathetral, many shops, nice markets, flymarkets, handmade. And you will feel Barcelona.

Worth several days just wandering around!. The Gothic Quarter is a lovely part of Barcelona's old city. On our recent visit we stayed 11 nights in an apartment half a block from the Barri Gotic and spent several days just wandering around the streets, or walking through on our way to other sites. We especially enjoyed walking around the Call, the ancient Jewish Quarter. We saw a lot but missed lots - looking forward to our next trip to Barcelona.

A memorable walk through a medieval time period. It's just something you have to do when staying in the beautiful city of Barcelona. A walk through this part of town is like stepping back in time. There is so much architecture that is split between Gothic and Roman structures. We started out at the Barcelona Cathedral and made our way through Placa Nova to Carrer del Bisbe. This road leads you to Plaça del Rei where you'll see the royal palace. This is where you will find the museum that is dedicated to the history of Barcelona (MUHBA). I can't remember where we went from there, but it was an awesome walk with many photo opportunities. I highly recommend it. There are also many cafés and restaurants near by. It's just a great atmosphere all around.
Interesting Architecture. Take a guided tour so they can tell you the history behind these magnificent buildings. The centuries old streets are loaded with stories and legends.

Don't worry about getting lost!. A mass of small streets, connecting passages and varying sized squares, many are free from traffic although not bikes. Aspects of Roman ruins lie next to museums and churches, plenty of examples of past history. Relatively easy walking but watch the cobblestone footing.
you should have been all parts. my exactly the favourite place. just enter and follow your heart.and pls do not forget raise your head...

Informative But Long. We took a walking tour of this area for two hours. Each of us was given earphones and were able to hear the guide clearly throughout the tour. It was informative but a bit long. Wear comfortable shoes, carry a water bottle, and get in shape. You will be om your feet for some time.

always more surprises. The area is a wandering maze of streets. The bars on windows can be initially off putting but the more you wander through the more you see all of the hidden things; hidden workshops, daycares, and every day life happening behind the walls. The shops paint their security pull downs so there are colorful murals often referencing the shop purpose. It seemed like each day, depending on day of week and time of day, different restaurants and shops were open, so there was always something new.

Loved it so much, we returned again and again.. We did a Context Travel tour of this area and if you get the chance, please do it! Every corner you turn has a history and a story that you just don't know unless you take a guided tour like this.

get lost and enjoy. You need to get literally get lost in the Gothic quarter. Fantastic atmosphere, wonderful places to eat and drink. Very vibrant and cheerful. You need to take your time and explore every corner it is really worthy.

Get Lost from the Present . A beautiful area of old streets starting from the side of Barcelona Cathedral, stay a little under the famous walkway which you can hear someone playing his classical guitar, give some of your loose coins as a sign of appreciation.

Best Area of Barcelona. Although you want to see La Ramblas, the Basilica of Sagrada Familia and some other sites, you COULD really just stay in the Gothic Quarter and be perfectly happy in Barcelona. We also stayed in an apartment in the gothic quarter, so really got the full experience. The restaurants are wonderful, churches are beautiful, and there are also museums, great shops, and antique bazaars. This is just fun!
Lots little streets full of facinating sites. We loved the tiny street and vibrant street life. Visited the Jewish quarter. Very interesting and educational.
Stroll and Shop. We took our time winding through the narrow streets and soaking in a different era. Lots of interesting architecture and shops.

Magical backstreets, squares, buildings!. A must see if you go to Barca. We thought it would be a few streets of old buildings...how wrong we were! Miles of twisty, atmospheric Gothic streets, every turn seems to find something new. Cobbled streets, squares with churches, courtyards, boutique shops, restaurants and cafés, a wonderful cathedral...I could go on. Also great at night, with the lights on.You can walk and walk (like we did) or take a saunter and indulge in the coffee shops and tapas, well worth a visit.Hint - take comfy shoes!

Average, not a must do. We visited the Gothic Quarters on a walking tour and while it is a good walk around in narrow lanes and old buildings and churches with distinct history, if u r bushed for time it's not a must do

Great Neighborhood. We stayed in the Gothic Quarter while visiting Barcelona. There are tons of restaurants, shops, street vendors and performers. It is a great place to walk around and enjoy. So glad we stayed here.

Great area. We loved the Gothic Quarter. Lovely little old streets with masses of little quirky shops and bars. They all have shutters on the front all grafittied which makes them more interesting but at night when they're all open the place comes alive with smells, sounds and fun. Good area to stay.
Get lost in tiny streets. The old section of Barcelona with winding narrow streets, tiny stores for everything, cafes, restaurants for just a few and wonderful architectural details everywhere.

Don't leave Barcelona without a visit to Barri Gotic!. There are so many wonderful little bars, tapas restaurants and quirky little shops in Barri Gotic, it would be a crime not to spend at least a whole day, if not a couple of days here, when in Barcelona! If you can stay in the area, I highly recommend it as the nightlife here is also fantastic. Loved all the high buildings, winding streets and old churches too, there is a lot of soul to this part of the city.

Watch the world go by. Took the Red Line Bus tour, (fantastic), saw The Gothic Quarter and decided to go back and explore more. Best decision ever. Just off Los Rambles found this little square, beautiful buildings, balconies, restaurants and cafes. Sat and watched the street entertainers and had a very relaxed lunch. All the narrow streets and squares are like stepping back in time.
Back in time. Fascinating place, visit early and take your time to look around. Sometimes it feels like your walking in circles but what does it matter? You will see new things every time

A Visual and Historical Treat. I am a poor photographer, but even with my dinky cell phone I managed to take evocative pictures of the Gothic Quarter. This section of the city is chocked full of historical and cultural buildings all back lit by the small shafts of Barcelona sunlight that slice through the alleyways. You will want to visit this area to get a feel for what it was like to live in a city in medieval Catalonia. One way into the Barri is off the Ramblas. Once inside, you can wander for a long time through the narrow streets that open up into open air squares with cafes. At night, these places are lively establishments, with concerts and flamenco dancing. They are lit up by open fires that beckon the traveller to sit and stay a while. The beautiful medieval Church Santa Maria del Pi has nightly guitar concerts for a fee of $10 and is located off the Placa del Pi in the Barri Gotic. The architecture of this quarter dates back to the early Roman days of Barcelona. There is an intact wall at the Roman entrance of the Barri. The Jewish section or, el Calle, is the most fascinating part of the Barri, with its very narrow streets where the rooftops almost touch. Europe's oldest synagogue, Sinagoga Major de Barcelona was rediscovered during an excavation and has been open since 2002 as a museum. Worth a visit. Around the streets of the Barri Gothic, you will see a story of the city, from the Roman founding to the coat of arms of the Inquisition, which is still intact on the walls of buildings and a reminder of the brutality of medieval life. The bricks stolen from Jewish cemeteries embedded in the walls for Churches are another reminder of the brutality of the middle ages and the massacre of Jews in Barcelona is 1390 and their eventual expulsion in 1492. Moving forward in time, the Royal Palace where Isobel and Ferdinand received Columbus after his journey to the new world is found within in a central square of the quarter. The painting of their meeting and the palace was made famous by Euguene Delacroix. There are also some nouveau creative gems to behold in the Barri Gothic, as a touch of Barcelona's love for modern art can be viewed on doors and windows. Even the famous graffiti artist, Abraham Clet has left his mark in the district. There are many tours available to help guide you through the labyrinth of streets. I strongly advise that you choose one that will take you to the parts you want to see and also to take the time to wander at will.
Wonderful architecture. Wandering round the Gothic Quarter is fascinating - but easy to lose your bearings! Lovely old buildings and streets.
Best part of Barcelona. Wonderful. Great historical landmarks - church from the 13th century, Jewish quarter. Wonderful restaurants as well.

wander for an afternoon. Wander through the streets of this area & to the Gothic Cathedral. The cathedral is built with such detail, look out for the Gargoyles at roof level there are so many different animals depicted.
Lots of street cafes in the area for much needed refreshment.

Amazing. This is the most amazing church I have ever visited! A must see! Incredible architecture both inside and out. Continues to be a work in progress. Looking forward to visiting when it's completed in 2026.

Gives you a real feel for the Old Barcelona!. Loved staying in this area, it gives you a real feel for the Old Barcelona, lots of characterful streets and alley-ways. Just a matter of carefully researching for a suitable apartment to rent. Bare in mind the buildings are old and can have antiquated plumbing.

Use Rick Steve's walking tour. We used a walking tour described in Rick Steves' book on Spain.If you are in town on a Sunday, visit the *other* cathedral in Barcelona, located in the Gothic Quarter, between 1100 and 1300 hours to view a live band and hundreds of dancers performing the Sardana, a traditional local dance.We stayed in the quarter at Hesperia Barri Gotic, and ate all but one of our meals in the many little plazas in the quarter.Picasso's museum is also a must-see in the quarter.Charming small streets, well lit and felt safe to walk through at any time of night.

Beautiful, quaint, amazing. Loved the gothic part of Barcelona for its beautiful ornate architecture, great restaurants, quaint shops and a few great tattoo parlors. I would recommend spending more than one day here.
Very nice old European feel!. You have to love the old streets, all the terrific buildings and charming scenes you see. Evening can be special depending upon who is playing guitar down what alley!

This was our first stop - Good Choice!. We took the Excellent metro line to the Jaume stop and there we were at the old wall. Our intent was to see the Cathedral, but that didn't happen that day. We stumbled through streets and lanes and nooks and crannies. We saw things, like the Temple of August and the museums we would return to but this was about adventure and discovery. To have this treasure in the heart of Barcelona with so many portions intact is remarkable. I was surprised how busy but not packed it was that day. When we did La Rambla it was more of a forced march for all the people. This was busy in a good way. people could get by and there was space to stop and look at things, ornamentation work, shops, etc without causing a roadblock. We probably went back through there three more times on missions but what a great place.

Don't miss Gothic Quarter. This is one of the most interesting areas and a must when visiting Barcelona. So many astonishing alleyways with little shops, cafes and restaurants. An area full of surprises and lots of history to discover. You might get lost a little. Have fun and enjoy!
a must to visit. great attraction and even with limited mobility easy to get around.the tour by local 'rickshaw' enabled a much wider view to be taken and enjoyed when walking a slight problem

Hidden Secrets. The Barri Gotic is very interesting from an historical perspective, with its ancient structures, museums and whatnot, but it is also a very interesting place to go out. The area is filled with small, informal bars and restaurants that attract very lively but easy-going clientele. So feel free to tour during the day, but go back at night for a little adventure :-)

Small beautiful gaps. Barri Gòtic is a MUST-DO in Barcelona! It´s so nice with it´s small little gaps and all the shops in between. There are also some nice boutiques. Some of them are quite expensive. But if you are a lover of Vintage-shops - this ist your place! I´ve never seen more beautiful ones anywhere. There´s a shop for everything you are looking for.

Interesting walk about. This is probable the nicest neighbourhood in central Barcelona. Here you can find really good restaurants and many small shops that sell good that you will not find anywhere in the world. The atmosphere is cosy and you feel the history in the building all around you.
Most walk around here if you are in Barcelona. Always fun and interesting to walk around the neighborhood here and see the gorgeous architecture. Lots of life and lots of little stores and cafés.

Barri Gotic stays in my dreams. I'll admit that Barcelona felt right to me when I read about it before coming here years ago, and I assumed it be the same in person. Fortunately, it was. It is. Getting lost in Barri Gotic is an important part of every visit. It leads to one fantastic discovery after another, from great bars that don't open until most of us are in bed to secluded restaurants that open just as late and where you're the only visitor. It can happen. It's an ancient part of the city, and that makes it a neighborhood worth getting to know.

The old Barcelona. Beautiful, breathtaking piece of history in Barcelona. The magnificent buildings and small narrow alley/streets will take you back 100s of years. Don't miss the Cathedral. Don't miss just walking around this area!
Great area. We loved walking around the Gotic quarter. Roman ruins, beautiful churches, nice restaurants, shopping. Very interesting area.

Old world charm. Many, many small winding streets with many, many, many small shops. Even in this central high-tourist area many shops close from 1 to 5 pm +/-. Not enough shops subscribe to the VAT refund program.
Must see. We loved the gothic quarter. It oozes history. Don't miss the ruins of the old Roman city which are underneath the royal palace and are incredibly interesting and extensive.

Walk along with history. Barcelona is full of fascinating history and sadly pick pocketers as well. Well that is always with all the beautiful places and it comes together. I love the walking between the narrow passages the local history, the visuals that reflects the incidents that happened. It will be a joyful and heart touching ride through the history up and down. Try to find a good tour guide and also do a little research on your own, it will add flavors to your trip. Get a good walking shoe, don't forget to try Tapas, pinchos and also keep an eye on the surroundings. There is so many histories in every corners and trust me all of them will hold you till the end.
A great place to stroll in early dawn hours. During the day it is a lovely place to walk but with too many tourists. Early light is a great time to meander no the who,e place is yours
lots of things to do and see. Very cheap to eat and drink, shopping is also very cheap. Would recommend a few hours to fully appreciate the scenery

Worth a stroll. This is much nore attractive than las Ramblas and definitely a more memorable place to visit in this fine city. Walkng around the Gothic quarter and checking out the Gaudi architecture were the highlights from this city of character

Very Atmospheric!. Very, very atmospheric, though there are many pockets within the quarter that are totally deserted (no shops, cafes, graffiti, ). Just get lost in the lanes, and discover something new around the corner. I discovered a wonderful handmade chocolate shop.

a trip back in time. Not to exclude everyone, but this journey took us to a synagogue from the 12th century. It was hidden, as the streets were built on top of old buildings, until the 1990's when workmen realized they were excavating on top of a building. They stopped immediately and found the synagogue. It was then that a donor gave enough money to rebuild what was left. You walk steps to get inside, no ramp for the disabled, and there a lovely girl, Carmen, gave us a tour, very short as not too much is left. She then took us inside of what remained of the actual sanctuary (where the men prayed) and gave the most interesting talk. The women's sanctuary is behind a wall where a restaurant now stands. Even of you are not of the Jewish faith, I heartily recommend this stop on El Call St, as it is a very interesting part of history. Keep yours eyes open as you walk down the street as you can easily miss it. It is near the cathedral, which, is a must stop also.

FUN TO EXPLORE. This part of Barcelona is a must see for anyone visiting. Lots of history and winding streets - interesting shops - touristy for sure, but that's to be expected. You can then end with a lovely stroll up La Ramblas! Start with the Cathedral - that will set the scene perfectly and what a magnificent site that is!

Decent walk but can be skipped in the interest of time. We walked through the Gothic Quarters - narrow streets, old town feeling, antique shops. But honestly, I didn't think the experience was really great. Can easily be skipped if you are short of time.

Don't miss this but don't be in a hurry. I loved wandering through here exploring all the little shops and points of interest. You can't get away from the tourists (or the potential of being pick pocketed, so be aware), but it doesn't take away from the delightful experience if getting lost and discovering all the little tapas bars, cafes, shops, old buildings and just the feeling of history ... Love it.
a little beauty of Barcelona!. We enjoy walking around the Gothic Quarter, nice shops,cafes, sweet shop and remember to have tapas! Take your time to walk and look around!

Charming and Amazing. Kind of Barcelonas own version of Paris's Latin Quarter, but maybe even older and nicer in some areas? I discovered Amazingly charming tiny tiny streets and passages leading you to various churches, squares and weird and wonderful little plazas. It is old, it is authentic and it is charming. It offers loads of resturants, bars and small designer boutiques as well as hotels-so it is never enough time to explore it all-although i guess it is packed and very crowded in the middle of summer-so I was happy not to be in a hotel there- I preferred to walk around during the daytime and retreat back to the quieter area of my hotel.

Central, exciting locale in Barcelona. Gothic Quarter is absolutely the best, most central location to stay in Barcelona. You are connected to the pulse of the city, being near the beach and all the cultural activities.

This is where you need to stay in Barcelona!!!. This area of Barcelona is an easy jumping point to explore all over!! A morning or evening stroll will leave you amazed by architecture and things to do. So many sites, cafes, restaurants, bars, and honestly the VIBE i think is amazing!!! Barcelona is one of my favorite places i have traveled and its where you leave a little piece of you. Book great budget hotels early or even VRBO, airbnb or homestayaway apartments!!! The hostels are pretty cool and easy going as well.but of course outside exploring main attractions...EAT and this Barre will give you so many choices to do so!!!
Great walking around the quarter. Enjoyed the time we spent walking around the quarter. The cathedral visit was good and we continued around observing the shops etc.

Delightful. As part of a tapas walking tour, we had an evening stroll through the Gothic Quarter that was enjoyable in every respect. From Las Ramblas to the Bouqueteria to the ancient churches and the cobblestone streets and plazas, Barri Gotic was vibrant, interesting, and filled with interesting shops, good restaurants, and wonderful tapas bars and with an abundance of charm. The place to see and be seen in Barcelona!

Great area to stay in. Centrally located to everything: the metro, shops, cafes, restaurants, La Rambla, and 30 minute walk (10 minute taxi) to great beaches. Water a bit chilly at the end of May, but kids not out of school yet so wasn't overly crowded. Expect to see some nude sunbathers (young and old).

Awesome.. Liked everything about this area.Old and untouched.The buildings and Catalunyan way of life.Didn't spend as much time here as we would have liked.Would like to get to learn more about the area.

Favourite place in barcelona. The gothic quarter is a really quaint interesting area with lots of lovelt buildings with facades and antique balconies with great photograpic potential. It was an area we went back to a few times on our 6 day stay...you always find or stumble onto something interesting at each turn of the corner whether its a gourmet chocolate store or antique silversmith or local designers making handmade leather shoes you are sure to find something interesting without even looking. Lovely antiquated streets full of character.

Nice area to walk and explore, however very touristic and crowdy.. The Gothic area is the old town of the city. The architecture, the streets and area is really beautiful for walking and exploration. The area looks like it remains on 19th century. Top monument is the cathedral. However the area is very crowdy so try to avoid the peak hours. Also is very touristic, meaning that for food and drinks you might have better options at the new area and the street of Rambla Catalunia. (No La Rambla, is an other street parallel to Grasia avenue)

Absolute top spot to stay in Barcelona. We hired a self catering apartment in Career Nou de Sant Francesc in Le Rambla and enjoyed every minute - wonderful atmosphere, great shops, buildings, walking etc. So close to everything we wanted to see and within walking distance of the other things we wanted to see.
Cathedral captivating. Amazing cathedral and ancient cobblestone streets to wander about...found great restaurant on side street and people watched during lunch.

Cobblestone streets. Our hotel was located in the Gothic Quarter so we spent much of our 3 days in Barcelona exploring the side streets which were mostly cobblestone. We did get lost several times but always found our way back. Many restaurants and shops. We found the best bakery that sold churros and hot chocolate. Their hot chocolate is more what I would call chocolate pudding and you dip the churros into it- ummmmm- delicious!! If you visit Barcelona, this area is a must see.
Stay in this neighboorhood.. Get lost! You'll find quaint and interesting places to dine and shop. The picasso museum is in this neighborhood, and I highly recommend a visit.

Central visiting area of Barcelona. We stayed in the Gothic Quarter which was a gathering place for activities in the Cathedral Square where there were variously school musical performances and worker demonstrations on successive days. It is a central tourist area with its many old narrow walking streets and numerous shops and restaurants. Definitely an interesting place to explore.
Architecture!!. We did a tour through the area so much history and information.Some top attractions here just off the La Ramblas.

Perfect place to get lost!!. This is one of my favourite places in the world. It reminds me of great times and it 's always alive! It has a lot of tourist focused shops and bars but you can still find its character when you walk a bit deeper into it and start to get a bit lost :) There is a great relaxed atmosphere specially at night!! I hope to be able to go back very soon..

Check out the cathedral then the small streets. A real gem. Much more impressive than its counterpart area in Madrid. Cathedral is a real gem. Walking the small old cobblestone streets you can find lots of little gems including some interesting art galleries.
Wonderful area with character. Great place to walk around and just soak in the character during the day. Not sure I'd walk around it at night.

Quaint and Interesting. Brilliant for shopping and eating. You can spend hours navigating the narrow streets full of boutique shops, cafes and restaurants. You can also see street performers in the plaza square. It was the delightful to have experienced the real, old Barcelona. Although a map maybe needed.
Loved it. Did a walking tour through the tourism board - I highly recommend this tour. gives a fascinating insight to the different levels of history. Roman- Medieval - Gothic.
bus trip. I found this area fantastic mix of old verses new buildings lovely photos of the area a lot to take in needed more time
History Lovers. If you wanna be taken back in time, this is a lovey must see. Taken from the main strip into the hidden court yards and lane ways. Just beautiful.
Old Barcelona. The oldest part of Barcelona with the cathedral and Roman remains is well worth a visit. Just wander round and think of what B used to be like.

Great to walk around. Great to walk around and find lots of weird and wonderful sights. Lots of tourists around the main attractions so be prepared to walk lots. Shops are geared toward either quirky or touristy. if you visit the cathedral bear in mind you will have to cover up.

Just walk up and down. Architecture is an item in this place. Enjoy it and let your feet lead you to anyplace.
Bars, restaurants, night clubs, shopping, everything that atracts a tourist. Clean and safe, you'll like it as much I did.
Great walking tour. Took a walking tour with Tapas and Wine tours. Lots of history and good information, stopped twice for a break with tapas and wine. Excellent tour. Would do it again.
Unique neighborhood. Unique area with a few things to do. There are a couple beautiful churches as well as a shops and restaurants. We stopped just at the travel bar for a couple drinks.
Great walking place. Lots of little shops, bars and galleries. We enjoyed the time browsing and talking to folks. We felt safe there.

Loved Barri Gotic area!!!. This area was one of our favorites..... we bought tickets to the Bus Turistic and hopped on and off of it all day. We hopped off in the middle of this area and spent the whole afternoon walking up and down the narrow streets and visited the Cathedral Barcelona. We found our favorite little locals tapas bar ever.... the locals and the bartender were so nice and friendly. It was one of my favorite days in the city :)

Brilliant. Beautiful side streets with some gorgeous shops, bars, restaurants and entertainment. In the square it didn't seem to have the perfect Spanish tapas restaurants, it catered more for those not interested in trying out local cuisine. The bars however were fantastic.
Enchanting. Old part of barcelona.lovely to walk in it...some archeologycal interesting paths ,underground...every corner offer surprizes

Fascinating. Beautiful architecture well worth taking a walking tour. The main city street Ramblis is very busy but needs to be appreciated. I also suggest the open market with the seafood and deserts.

fun shopping. there are so many quaint shops in this area but they close for siesta. we rented a bike and rode around the narrow streets. one night there were people singing opera out side the cathedral, very cool.
Get lost rambling.... This quarter with its charming streets and little boutiques is soooo much fun. We liked getting lost and seeing all the quaint alleys and courtyards.

Gothic, impressive with a twist of WOW. You can get twisted up and say where are we? It seems like your in Italy in the Spanish quarter, wait, ding..Lol. This is the Gothic quarter in Barcelona within walking distance of La Rambla and I really like it. Very cool old Gothic buildings that can lead into small plazas with shops and musicians playing and singing in the plazas. Truly enjoyed it.

Atmosphere. A superb area packed with interest - architecture, vibrant life. I have been several times and loved it, but I was apprehensive at first, wondering just how to look out for thieves, given that we were a family group with children. Robbery this time was in the crowded metro though, entirely the fault of my son-in-law trusting his back pocket. The Barri Gotic robbery was an earlier visit when my husband making a phone call in a square at night (back pocket again - will these men never learn?) had his purse taken. There was a most entertaining pursuit, me after the thief but husband standing there. I kne I couldn't catch him, but my voice could. I would run about 20 steps then let out an operatic scream. I was enjoying myself enormously though If I had thought I could catch him, I would have stayed put,. We raced into the side streets, then he sped off. When I finally got back I asked my husband why he had done nothing. He said that it was irritating because he liked the purse, but there was only the equivalent of 30 p in it. I'm telling this because other travellers may find a moral in it, or probably not.
old historic lanes. brilliant place to visit. it will take you back in time it can be done with the Picasso museum as it hardly few minutes walk. old architecture and lanes will be amazing to see

Gothic atmosphere. The narrow streets and the Gothic architecture transport you directly to the Middle Ages. Try to get lost in the numerous back alleys, and you can imagine what it was like to live back then.
Gothic Quarter. Loved this place/area. The streets are awesome, the ambiance is great, food great. It's very picturesque. Just strolling along all these walled streets was fantastic, even at night.

LIVING HISTORY. To walk around this area of living history was so wonderful! This old medieval city is still alive and well with restaurants and shoppes, museums and churches and markets. Walking the maze of narrow streets is a bit confusing yet exciting.

To miss the gothic quarter is to miss Barcelona. Can't imagine visiting Barcelona and not strolling through the narrow, midieval streets of the gothic quarter. This is one of the better examples of a European old town that I have seen. Narrow, angled streets going every which way, begging to be explored. A real treat.
Maze of streets!. An essential area to visit. Bars, restaurants, shops, architecture ...Lovely. You never know whats going to be in the next street!

Unique Place. A very unique place, different and interesting. Lots of history around that medieval building and remains from the Ancient Roman times. Is a great place to learn the history of Barcelona

Get Lost!. The streets are a maze and there is something down nearly all of them. Spoke to a local who said they still go wrong! Plenty of places to eat, drink, shop or just look at. Take a map, and at night politely refuse to buy beer on the streets. Other than that, enjoy.

Such amazing stories hidden behind those ancient walls. My two twenty-something sons and I took a walking tour of the Gothis Quarter and Jewish sites with the wonderful Abel. He was not performing nor selling, just telling us terrific and fascinating stories about who once lived where, how historical events and leadership affected people primarily in the 13-15th centuries. Along the way, we learned other aspects of Barcelona's fascinating history. Our private tour was like a special history lesson, replete with visual and personal reflections. We were completely pleased!

Old charm. Nice to walk around the different quarters with narrow streets, and allies. Lots of shops, market, plazas, church, etc... All connected and lead to the La Rambla strip. Busy place full of tourists day and night. Plan accordingly for a meal because almost all restaurants are full especially around dinner time.
Ideal walk through Gothic Quarter. The architecture of Saguda Familia continues, as well as these great homes and streets. Enjoy the journey, and take lots of pictures.

Great place to wander and get lost in the beauty. I came here because I wanted to visit the Cathedral, but it was difficult to figure out where to go on the map I had because it didn't have all the street names. So I decided to just wander around and see what I found, and I'm so glad that I did. You'll want to look at every single building that you pass by, from the bottom to the top. Around every corner is breathtaking. I only spent a few hours here since I had 2 days to spend in Barcelona but I will definitely be back.And yes, I found the Cathedral. :)

Gothic Greatness. Beautiful and historical area of Barcelona. Easy walking distance to museums and the waterfront.We would definitely stay in this area again. Lots to do,easy access to transportation.
Stepping Back in Time. Narrow streets. Barcelona's early Jewish community resided near Placa de St. Jaume. Gothic church was amazing. Oldest part of the city. Roman city walls still visible.
Fun. We love walking in this area and visiting the small restaurants and tourist shops and just people watching.

Ambience Abounding. This is the place to amble in Barcelona. Down narrow laneways. Occasional encounters with tour groups on parade behind guides with fluffy toys on sticks. They march on. A place to find a quiet corner bathed in sunlight and an opportunity to pause for a coffee. And lots of fascinating small boutiques, micro cafes and neighbourhood necessities. Look up and there may be washing hanging out or an ancient piece of architecture.

Just Stroll. Barri Gotic was 100m from our hotel so we strolled round it 1 - 2 hours every day for 5 days and still didn't see everything it had to offer. An amazing maze of tiny streets, tapas bars, modern restaurants, old quaint shops next to modern cafes, etc, etc. Most days and every evening there was a concert/folk group etc to be found in one of the squares

Unparalleled Beauty Around Every Corner!. This is the Old City of Barcelona, and it's gorgeous beyond description. Upscale shops, a wide range of restaurants, churches, markets... a mix of tourists and locals. Can't be beaten! According to our guide, a two bedroom apartment goes for about $700/month, making it expensive for locals but not so for expats. If we could speak Catalan, we'd consider moving in a heartbeat.

Perfect place to get lost . I loved the antiques shops, rows of boutiques and great little eateries. This part of the city feels like your seeing the artistic side while experiencing traditional Spanish culture. One of my favourite places to spend a day.

A bit underwhelming. In thre guide book it was described as very narrow. I thought it was pretty normal.We did find the synagogue door that is unmarked but was the one and only once. Some cute shops, found some antiques. No lodgingThat I could see. Glad I made the walk.
Very old and a must visit.. Hotel was located in area. Food, shopping, just enjoy the History of the city. Streets are clean and even washed by the city. Just a lovely area to see.

Great for foodies. A lovely area to stroll around and shop and eat - try Cal Pep for amazing seafood. Also 7 Portes for lunch - Art Deco ambiance, amazing pastas. Have fun at a patio seat in the evening - we enjoyed the people-watching and fine tapas. There are many to choose from, we moved from place to place and tried different tapas at each bar.

You could walk around for hours!. Amazing part of Barcelona. The tiny streets, so many little shops and bars. I absolutely loved Barri Gotic and it is definitely worth it to take at least 2-3 hours to walk around in the tiny streets and alleys, it feels like you are back in time!

Not much to see. Found it on the city map, then went to look for it, some buildings ok but generally nothing you cant see in heaps of other cities, if you want to see old roman buildings why not go to Rome.

Interesting area to wander through. The gothic quarter is full of old narrow streets opening onto wider squares, it is lively, interesting, with plenty of places to stop for a coffee or a glass of wine whilst watching the world go by. The ancient Roman walls and gates are still visible as are parts of the old aquaduct, you get can get a very good sense of the size of the old Roman settlement.

what a contrast. Barcelona is just full of fantastic and beautifully coloured buildings and the gothic quarter is no exception. If you like your old buildings and appreciate different types of architecture then you must visit the Gothic quarter.
Fascinating a old city. We liked the old Cathedral and the Picasso museum especially. With the comparisons of the early and developing works of Picasso and Dali. The audio systems were excellent.

Amazing history. Recommend a tour guide or good guide book. So much to see from Roman walls, to ancient temple columns to medieval Jewish Quater to Catholic Cathedrals to war bombed-schrapnel walls . History goes on and on. Incredible small roads and alleys that open to inviting squares with restaurant tables or to massive cathedrals. Incredible .

This area is Amazing!. So many shops and cafes and things to look at! You literally can just 'get lost' wandering around looking at everything. Got some great things to take home. Even some nice dress shops there and picked up a couple of things on sale. A must see in my opinion!
Lots of interesting shops and sites. So much to see here, the architecture, the funky and unique shops, the interesting food (Cannibis gelato anyone?) It was worth exploring for a few good hours.
Walk Backwards Into Medevil History. Walk during the early morning and early afternoon into an authentic world of narrow streets and secrets.
Interesting place to browse around. Full of history and traditional character. Lots of interesting boutiques. Romantic stroll along the narrow streets.
Enjoyable. Loved walking around, and taking the bike tour. Lots of food and fun. We were cautioned about pickpockets but didn't have any trouble. Not all of the locals were pleasant but we'd go back.
Character and style. I loved the atmosphere, the food and the character of the buildings. Spent many hours every day wandering round this area.
Medievel Barcelona. We did a self-guided tour of this area. We happened upon Roman columns, small pathways and the Barcelona Cathedral. So different from the rest of the City.
Get lost in the narrow streets!. So many things to see!!! Try and get lost in one of the streets and be surprise what pops up next! Highly highly recommended!

Charming. The Barri Gotic is a great area to wander around just off La Rambla but quieter and more relaxed. The square in front of the cathedral is an entertaining place for people watching and the streets around it have unusual little shops. Good restaurants are also here.

Meeting history. In the core of the gothic area you will find plaza deal rey where Columbus met the king and the queen of Spain after his return from the Americas... The spot is almost in its original shape, so when you talk there you will tramping in the very tiles that Columbus walked.
Old Barcelona. Living history in the centre of the city. Great place to stroll around, soak up the sites and atmosphere of the old quarter of the city.

Great architecture. The cathedral was amazing and location handy to everything
Some nice bars and restaurants too. There was a real buzz about the place

Give yourself a chance. At first,it could be scary ( depends what time you get there). Relax,it is safe. Have an espresso and enjoy the life,the accent and cool down.Who's in a hurry?
Couple of cups of wine (or espresso),tapas and you're on vacation!!!! Barcelona is a great city

Great just to wander. Just immerse yourself in the surroundings and be content to be a tourist. A real gem, but easy to get distracted and wander off looking at yet more stunning architecture round the corner
another world. Barcelona has so much to see - but the Gothic area is definitely one of the main areas I would recommend checking out. the narrow windy streets full of tapas bars are amazing.
Take a walk down an alley way. The architecture is amazing, the little alleyways are secret and take you back to another time. It is just a great place to explore.

Lovey area to stroll around in. We spent a couple of hours just soaking up the atmosphere of this area. Were going to do an organized walk but opted to do our own thing instead. The Roman influence if evident there and we also visited the Cathedral while there.
Goottilainen kaupunginosa. Beautiful Place with it's many nice restaurants and cute little shops. Nice details in the buildings.

Historic section with many bars and restaurants. The Gotic Quarter is a maze of narrow streets and alleyways. The streets are filled with small shops and bars and restaurants. The Quarter is convenient to the harbor, La Rambla, and many of the most interesting tourist sites. Beware, the Quarter is very crowded and can be loud and rowdy at night.
Gothic cathedral. Gothic area is a must visit lots of food music and charm. The cathedral is well worth a visit we went at tea time and the atmosphere was brillant
Amazing. There was so much to see and so much to do. We were there for 5 days and we were on the move constantly. Make sure you take the time to explore the gothic area

Narrow and Windy. If you're looking for a relatively safe place to stay near, choose the Gothic Quarter. The streets were really small and narrow, which made it easy to get lost in. The quaint nature of this neighborhood made for a real Spanish experience. Would reccommend!
not to be missed ancient city. Narrow cobbled streets, plazas, museums all over, and fabulous musicians play the best mini concerts, for your change

Wonderful place to explore. This is such an interesting district where every alley that you turn into has something interesting to see or photograph. It is really wonderful that Barcelona is able to preserve much of its heritage and buildings to maintain its old world charm. This is one city that is easy to fall in love with.

Great place to stay and walk around!. Tons of shops and restaurants. Lots of cathedrals. Plenty of night life. Picasso Museum.
Tip: Choose your hotel in this section of Barcelona.

If you only have time for one neighborhood.... This is a place to wander around narrow streets that defy logic for layout. Every type of shop from souvenirs to high-end clothing and accessories. Restaurants and tapas bars everywhere. Turn a corner, and you will encounter a majestic church or museum, or a simple plaza. Don't worry about getting lost: eventually you will find your way back to La Ramblas.

A marvellous maze of alleyways and tiny bars and shops,. My hotel was right in the middle of the Gothic Quarter and so I was surrounded by the sights and sounds. It was actually fun getting lost in the maze, you never knew what great little new place you were going to find around the next corner.

Not to be Missed... Romantic and enchanting. This was our fav sector of the city.., narrow winding streets, great food everywhere, variety of architecture. The food market was amazing... You could stay there for hours. We returned at some point in each day we were in the city.

Atmospheric, dramatic & fabulous. You can literally get lost in the wonderful, winding streets of the Gothic Quarter. Its sandstone buildings with overhanging ironwork balconies, so close together that you could (probably) touch hands with someone on an opposite balcony. The place is buzzing with independent shops, bars and restaurants - a real place to escape everyday life.
Fantastic place to stay. Stayed here through airbnb. Fantastic place in the heart of the gothic quarter! great shopping. Great food (Sensi has the best tapas) it's in the heart of everything!
Love the Gothic Quarter. Barcelona is one of my favorite cities, and I always head to the Gothic Quarter to find cozy little bars, cute and different shops and beautiful buildings.

great walk but crowded with tourist groups. The old city with it's narrow streets and historic buildings is fascinating. In the evening it looks quite mysterious and by day it's a great walk in the shadows of the tall buildings. If you enjoyed Carlos Ruiz Zafon's books you'll enjoy this!A bit of a downside is the sheer amount of tourist groups that come to the City by Cruise ship. In the narrow streets a bigger group of people has a clogging effect sometimes. But nevertheless: AMAZING and BEAUTIFUL by night and by day!

A step back in time. This area is one of our favorite places to walk through in Barcelona. The architecture is amazing and the area is alive with great places to eat and many places to shop. It is worth your time to wander the streets and take in the beauty of all that can be seen.

Wander, wander and discover. Get lost in the Barri Gotic. Every street is different. Great for small scale shopping in very small shoe, clothes, hat, electronic... well almost everything you can imagine. Lots of places to dine or snack. You often get pleasant beezes from the harbor. I highly recommend the small Roman cementery just of Las Ramblas, the much larger Roman archeology underneath the history museum, and the museum for the early years of Picasso. All budgets are covered! Walking is free. Snacks are inexpensive. But there are also serious places to eat like Los Caracolles , designer clothing, and art work.

Dark and amazing structures. While visiting Barcelona and wandering around, we actually by accident came upon this area. Although we did not go into any of the buildings, the architecture was amazing!

Great shops and restaurants in medieval quarter. Spend an afternoon exploring the beauty of these winding streets and alleys. Window shop your way through and return in the evening to enjoy a restaurant with Flamenco.

Culture abounds. Love spending time in the Bari gothic quarter, walking up and down the narrow little passages and stopping at small little bars for a drink. The area stretches from the middle of La Rambles down to the beach area. The nearer you get to the front the more authentic the bars and eateries including a tapas bar that it apparently visited by Bono whenever he is in the city. Just a word of warning the area can be a little shady late on with some dodgy individuals hanging around the little passages.

Superb shops, bistros, and tourist attractions(roman ruins and cathedral). truly enjoyed the many shops and bistros
At night this place becomes a tourist nightmare
Skateboarders crashing into people, bikes careening down small
Alleyways
Think Times Square at night
Safeguard your person and valuables
Daytime its 5*

Barri Gotic is my fav quarter in BCN. there are many hidden restaurants, outside-cafés, fabulous little shops - and all those old buildings and churches (especially La Catedral de la Santa Creu i Santa Eulàlia) are simply amazing!

Love exploring in this area. This is typical of Spanish gothic streets of old. Can look a bit rough for some, but we love exploring all of the narrow streets and old architecture. Lots to look at, lots of people, shops restraints etc. noodle around at hour leisure. Amazing what you will find and it is a photographer delight. Don't be put off by the sometimes seedy looking streets especially at night, just be aware.
Great selection of restaurants. Some great restaurants here, the tapas choice is exquisite and delicious. Also, the architecture is absolutely beautiful. Absolutely recommend.

The heart of Barcelona. We chanced upon the gothic quarter during our wanderings and had to force ourselves to leave it again a few hours later. The street performers, the buildings, even the cafes were all wonderful. One street performer in particular was singing opera, and had a huge crowd of people enjoying her music. Enter this area with time up your sleeve, enjoy the cheapest coffee in Barcelona, and leave with great memories and great photos.
Lovely little lanes. Lovely area with little lanes leading off and full of beautiful shops and bars to visit. Very interesting buildings and had a lovely feel about the area!
A marvel. Here you may experience a real time travel to the past. Very well preserved and you may see buildings from 1300. Wander through the buldings and houses, you will enjoy it

A medieval marvel. This is a wonderful neighbourhood for just wandering around. So much of Barcelona's history is found in this area, along with museums, art galleries, street performers, cava bars, tapas bars, all kinds of restaurants, and more. A great place to spend a day just people-watching and having a great time.

My favourite part of Barcelona. In this area every single side street is just as beautiful as the other. It is unbelievable during the day and you definitely must visit it for a wander if you are in Barcelona. The buildings are honestly unreal and you would be missing out if you didn't see it. I probably wouldn't stay in this area due to issues with pick pocketing and I'm not sure what it would be like at night.

Of historical interest. This was our first exposure to the narrow streets that we found were common in the old sections of other Spanish cities. The streets eventually break out onto plazas where there is more light and space. Buildings look like walls (three or four stories high) that just happen to have windows and heavy wood doors in them. Barely enough room to walk four abreast in many places. Watch out for the occasional motorbike navigating the corridors. When we visited around nine o'clock on a Friday morning, most merchants had not yet opened their stores, so we did not get to see the variety that other reviewers have encountered.

Nice to visit, but stay elsewhere. This is the old Barcelona, with narrow winding streets filled with tourists. Reminds me of New Orleans, the French Quarter. The Cathedral of Barcelona is worth seeing, even if not among the most spectacular in Europe.

Beautiful streets. I walked around the gothic quarter for over an hour just admiring the architecture and taking pictures.
If you like to shop, theres also tons of little shops and stores to check out.
A trip to Barcelona is not complete without checking Barcelona's gothic quarter.

Barcelona's beautiful old town... . In the centre of the city... Close to all the other attractions... This part is beautiful with its narrow roads and it's small shops... You will enjoy every second walking in that area

Full of charm. This is a very distinct area of the city. It is full of windy, narrow streets, unexpected twists and turns, and great little places to stop for a quick copa. Make sure to leave enough time to wander,
great atmosphere. Multitude of shops, cafes and interesting sights. A place to wander and sit around over coffee. The heart of the old city.

Ancient and fascinating!. This warren of ancient streets was by far my favorite section of Barcelona. Easy (but fun) to get a little lost. Lots of shops, tapa bars, restaurants, museums and historical sights.

Imagination goes beyond!. Doesn't matter if you go walking, biking or by segway: don't miss the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona.
There, you will find street art, and be able to see how was the life centuries ago and probably get amazed by the architecture.

get lost in the small streets. yes, the title says is all, small hallway all around and inside this lovely quater with little shops, bars, restaurants... just wander around the area, you will not be disappointed!

The old world!. This is an amazing area with great shops and fantastic restaurants! There are so many things to see and do, and if you are a history buff you will get lost in the museums and underground cities that still exist under the streets! Learn about the original city of Barcino and it's history, only in the Gothic Quarter!

All the history and shopping you could want!. Be prepared to walk and look. Every turn has something to see. Be aware of the crowds and the need to avoid the United-licensed street traders but otherwise enjoy the atmosphere and sense of Spain.

Take your money, your best walking shoes & your apetite. Its the center of town, easy to walk to , not far form the water. You won't get lost, the streets are narrow, cobble stoned, winding but still easy to navigate. Lots of small boutiques, leather shoe shops even made to order shoes shops, museums small & large, street entertainers. Then there are the small bakeries and restaurants for every budget. Visitor information center at the heart near the government office in case you do get turned around.

Captivating space. Ok so it takes you back in time and it's a relaxing and cool place. I walked twice inside it and I don't think I got to see everything. I also enjoyed some red wine and olives and some potato/egg cake :) or "torta española". Unique experience.Oh and check out the street artists, they're pretty good.

The best area in Barcelona. Spent the day with good walking shoes a camera and a map and went exploring. Located just off Las Ramblas, it's filled with old buildings narrow winding streets and more, something at every turn. There's both small and larger plazas with cafes, tapas, music, happy people travelling and finding their way around the place. Home to the Cathedral, Royal Palace, City Hall and more. A must go to place if your Barcelona.
Labyrinth of small streets. Favourite highlight of Barcelona. Maze of streets with unique shops, bars restaurants where we spent hours wandering.

A Great Place to Roam. A gentle walk through the narrow streets of the Gothic Quarter is a great way to discover the oldest part of Barcelona with glimpses of Roman ruins amid the streets of the mediaeval city. Take time to browse the market in front of the cathedral and then roam through the network of alleys before checking out the Town Hall, cathedral and cloister.
What a treasure!. It is the whole atmosphere which again and again keeps me captured. Before the Olympic Games in BCN it was even better because less commercial.

for me, the best tour in Barcelona. We have wandered for three days through the Barrio and we enjoyed every bit of it. Just get loose and admire the streets, the famous and neglected palaces , the small gardens hidden within them and the hundreds of nice bars/restaurants at every step. History, culture and good life: what more do we need?

Still love wandering around there. Eventhough the Barri Gotic has a surplus of Indians and Asians running their shops there, the atmosphere still has the cool and avant garde air it is famous for. Especially if you take 1 or 2 of the narrow alleys crossing the main tourist rivers.
Historical. This was the highlight of our visit to Barcelona. We could easily have spent a week looking through this area with all its interesting history.
Very interesting. Cathedral of the sea. The narrow streets. The interesting architecture. Watch your personal belongings.
As it was in the old days. I could enjoy the atmosphere of old days. The buildings were really gothic and the shops along the narrow aisles were also enjoyable feature.
As always a wonderful place to visit. I think I like the Gothic section the best--never very crowded and so much to see and admire. Good choice.

Meander the streets for the real taste of the city. Amazing area to roam. Could not believe the mix of people, businesses and tapas bars.
Don't forget to return at night, a completely different vibe and crowd.

great place to spend the day. Walking around and getting lost in this little quarter is a lot of fun. Tou eventually stumble onto little boutiques and pastry shops that are gems. Much preffer walking around the gothic quarter than la rambla...less noisy and more interesting

Wandering in Time. This is truly like stepping back in time and wandering through the old streets and among the buildings. It was particularly interesting looking at how the Roman remains were built into later buildings
A great place to stroll, shop and eat. We spent hours walking through the ally's and streets. Very old and historic buildings and cobblestone streets. A lot to see, lots of shops and restaurants.

Wonderful place to walk around in. It's a charming place! While the rest of Barcelona is more "modern", this place remains quaint. Add to that a charming and bustling street life with street performers, street food, you've got magic!

Just get lost. The twists and turns in this beautiful area of the city will leave your head dizzy. Where am I? Somewhere in the center...and signs pop up on street corners to help you regain orientation. A good map of the city center is with the Free Walking Tours brochure. Getting lost though was never so much fun! One problem though in Barcelona is the lack of public toilets - so plan your stop for a coffee/beer/tapas well.

avoid the tourist traps!. the barrio gótico has some great hidden (or not so hidden) gems... but it also has its fair share of tourist traps and tacky places... for restaurants, be sure to check out "agut" and "pla" - for bars, try "small bar" and "ginger"!

Very nice area. Very nice area where you can really enjoy to walk. I recommend it to all architecture-lovers. But beware, at times of the day (more in the afternoon) there are too many people, so for me it was better to visit it in the evening.
Easy to get lost but you will be found. Wandering around the Gothic Quarter was full of pleasant surprises with the variety of shops, cafes, street musicans and the historic buildings.
Great part of the city to explore!. A very beautiful part of the city worth the visit. We went there on several occasions, getting lost in the streets and finding great small shops!

Old and attractive neighbourhood.. By showing this place to all my nort-european customers, I always get the same comment: it really " smells old " The ultra narrow streets, the shops, the monuments give an idea of about the City used to be centuries ago,
Great for Eating. Great place to eat and see the sights just off La Rambla very easy to find with lots of restaurants in the square

stroll around..... ...and you'll see new things around every corner. Plenty of small shops, bars and restaurants.
The small streets protect from the sun and the heat of the day.
fun. Better and safer than La Rambla. A lot to see and a nice place to mingle with locals. Good tapas, nice restaurants and bars.

Photo heaven. we so enjoyed walking around this area. so much history.
Architecture in these old buildings is like nothing else
Gothic Quarter. This is the place to stroll and soak in the narrow-alleyed, cobblestoned culture. Many other attractions co-located. Many restaurants. Endless shops.
A must. We are history lovers so we decided to explore as much as possible the Gothic Quarter. We loved it. We highly recommend you spend at least half a day here.

get lost in the side streets. this can be reached very simply from La Rambla and each little side street holds different treasures. it is easy to get lost and find your direction after wandering through the area . the sounds and smells are unique giving you a longing to return. see how the local people work and play, listen to the Catalan language and the Spanish language and try to spot the differences. Stop under a tree lined avenue for a drink and just enjoy the visit.
Stayed here. I loved this area of the city. It is so historic and beautiful. All of the streets are small and full of different places to eat or get drinks. It has a great atmosphere and a lot to do.

Endless maze of streets to explore. You could happily wander here all day discovering hidden courtyards, churches and little shops and cafes of all sorts. Far more interesting than the crush and tat of La Ramblas

Neat architecture depicting another time.. Hook up with a walking tour and you will not be disappointed. A tour guide can show you things that you would not notice on your own if you went there without a guide.
Make sure if you are there on Sunday that you take the time around noon to watch the Barcelonans dance in front of the Cathedral.

Amazing. It feels like you are stepping back in time, the buildings, streets, squares and alleyways give you a real feal for the Barcelona of old. Hundreds of small and medium shops and restaurants mean you can spend days here and not see it all.
An absolutely beautiful place that will live in my memory for a long time.

Not as great as the hype. After hearing so much about the gothic quarter, I was expecting a lot. But, after traveling throughout much of Catalonia, I can tell you that other smaller towns have just as interesting streets in their old town sections with a lot less crowds. If you are only going to be in Barcelona, it's worth a look, but I wouldn't want to spend a lot of time there. It's a shame that you have to pay to go in just about every church and building.

Love This Area!. You can walk all day, in and out of local shops, having coffee, eating tapas, taking in the culture - it's beautiful! There is however this unappealing odor that is somewhat sewage related that appears every now and then. Other than that, it's a wonderful day.

Wander aimlessly. The lane ways, twisting and turning through this area provide such unexpected pleasures...here a shop selling handmade ladies' shoes, there an artisan spice shop. Some lanes are dead ends, some open into an open courtyard. Around a bend you find a huge ancient church. Take time and don't rush through, there's something interesting to keep you occupied for hours. A wonderful area of Barcelona!
Amazing work !. Brilliant architecture, narrow lanes, cobbled road..it was a good walk around the Gothic Q to experience Barcelona history.
city break. We stayed in this area and the buildings are great the small side streets hide some wonderful bars and resterants if you just explore them

Take a stroll. We spent a lot of time in the Barri Gotic, visiting places such as the Cathedral and the Picasso Museum, eating at the great restaurants (Plaza Real for example), visiting the shops and just strolling through the old city. A must if you are in the beautiful city of Barcelona.
historcal. Very old area but every church and building around charges an admission fee. But go and walk around and see the old city.

Go back in History!. Great place to walk around and experience historic barcelona - MUHBA (Museu d'Història de Barcelona) has marked out places of interest. We loved the architecture and feel of narrow cobbled winding streets with its shops (such a sharp contrast to Passieg De Gracia or Eixample) and all the great history to soak in. Must visit while in Barcelona!

A must in Barcelona. You must spend at least a few hours walking this area. Its one of the best in the world, in my opinion. Plenty of history and architecture to admire and also great side streets, hotels, pubs, and shops. Much of it is not touristy. You could spend at least a day here and never pass the same spot. Put it on your list!

Fun to wander but crowded and beware thieves. You can't help but find yourself wandering around the streets in the Gothic Quarter. You'll have a great time if you just turn down a random street, follow it, and see where it leads and what you'll find along the way!It IS very crowded (it doesn't seem to matter what time of day) and thieves thrive in crowds. Mind your belongings and have a buddy watch your back, don't walk around with your map out looking lost, and just explore.We took a free tour of the Gothic Quarter with Runner Bean Free Tours and it was excellent. Recommend you do this your first day in Barcelona.

Great people watching . The Gothic Quarter had some interesting people watching to take in. Try to go at night and during the day, it will seem like two totally different places. It honestly wasn't what I thought it would be after hearing people rave about it. It's a bit seedy and dirty and just seemed like your basic city street in an older part of town. There are a few good restaurants we stopped at but they were all restaurants we looked up before hand. Try to research the restaurant if you wish to dine in the Gothic Quarter because many are tourist traps. It's worth strolling through but it was just average to me, no great architecture or significant point of interest, strictly people watching.

Enchanting. Our first three days in Spain were here in the Barri GothicThe narrow streets the fabulous eateries and don't forget the markets which we felt was more reflective of the food styles Loved the cycling which gave us a general overview .Highly recommend this
Oozing history. So much to see just simply walking about in one morning. Monuments Churches and museams on every corner amidst wonderful craft shops and resterants.

Something Around Every Corner. A maze of tiny streets with something around every corner to see. You can really imagine being in medieval times. Simply wander around the streets at your leisure, no need to hurry just watch out for vehicles of all kinds trying to negotiate the narrow lanes.
A must see city break. Lots to see, try and get off the main walkway and you'll find lots of wee alleyways with quaint and unusual bars and shops, even irish bars!!!
could wander for hours. every time you turned a corner or meandered down a path you will suddenly come upon a wonderful sight - either a hidden photo opportunity or a culinary gem , enjoy

Fun to wander the streets. Like the Casco Viejos and Casco Antiguas of other Spanish cities, the Barri Gotic has a lot of narrow winding streets with many small shops and cafes. It is a lively neighborhood with an appealing atmosphere.

Lovely atmosphere. Great place to walk! The architecture is amazing and the streets are so clean. Felt totally safe and everyone we asked directions from were very helpful and friendly from shop keepers to taxi drivers.

Little englanders tour barcelona. Few words to describe the whole Barcelona experience,magnificent,beautiful,grand,lovely.if you get the chance go you will love the place I did and so did my friends.put gothic quarter to start the review its all brilliant.
Worth the visit. We visited multiple times to walk around, shop and eat in the various squares. Was enjoyable to relax with tapas and wine and people watch!

Meander thru centuries. The meanderIng streets transport you from the modern era to centuries past. The cathedral dates from the 11th century and there's a synagogue from Roman times. Take a walk and enjoy the neighborhood.

So much to see and do!. Absolutely loved everything about this place - charming, interesting, fantastic architecture, museums, a cathedral, lots of winding streets to nosey about in, lots of restaurants and bars and the people were all very friendly.
If you get tired of the city life the beach is a 20 minute walk away!

Small streets big treats. I enjoy going off the main thoroughfares and the Gothic quarter enables that. If you like small independent shops then this is great. Wander slowly and take in the old world charm look at the architecure sample the many delights and relax
So nice and cosy. We lived there and liked it very much. The ambience was cosy, lively and few cars because of the narrow streets.

History. Walking the streets of the Gothic quarter was awesome, coming from a new country like New Zealand with very little history it was fabulous to explore how people lives centuries ago, just a superb adventure.

Get lost in the maze of wonderful streets. If you like to wonder and come across great small eateries, places to drink, non-chain shops and generally get lost in a maze of streets, this is definitely the place - one of my favourites in the city and had the best tapas ever at Roma Reial. There is also much history and architecture to enjoy.
Nice area. Go there and have a drink buy your souvenirs and eat good food.Nice place to stay too.The main road Rambla is full of people and the Catalynia Squere is there too.Very nice place

Amazing Place to Stay. We booked a hotel in the Gothic Quarter for five nights after a trans-Atlantic cruise to give us the opportunity to learn about this city. It was a perfect location for us. The narrow, winding streets, old buildings, excellent restaurants and frequent historic locations make the district a perfect place to use as a home base.We were within 5 minutes of the Cathedral and Placa Catalonia where all the action starts. Tours and site visiting were simpler because we were at the staring points of several activities.
Beautiful. I like architecture, so walking through this community was a joy. So beautiful. People stopped and helped me understand more about the area (in Spanish, but I can speak it so I was fine).
Fanstastic. Highly recommended for great food, nice little shops and bars. Walking around the little squares you will also see great photographic oppertunities.

Extremely interesting Gothic Quater. By far the best part of Barcelona for me....every day visited was a different experience.....so much to see....the architecture was amazing...the people so friendly....just lived the feel and vibe....

Some fantastic buildings and walkways. Gives you a real feel of the old Barcelona. There is no end of interesting architecture, buildings, bars, shops as you wonder up and down the narrow alleyways that open on to small and large squares.
Gothic Quarter Review. Impressive, beautiful, amazing are the first three words that come to mind. If you love history, architecture, urban design, this place you must see.

One of the best spots in Barcelona. Just walking around the Gothic Quarter is fun to do - taking in the sights, allowing yourself to get lost in its streets - there are so many great restaurant sights and everything feels enchanting and old and special. We were lucky enough to say in the BG and were thrilled at our dumb luck!

Gem of Barcelona. This is Barcelona's birth place, started by the Romans it is Barcelona's most historic neighbourhood. Highly recommended to walk around in Barri Gotic and you will find a 3rd century synagogue in El Call, the administrative offices of the autonomous government of Catalunya, Palau de la Generalitat, the Barcelona City Hall, Roman Temple of Augustus, it is a sight every block, and more...
Can't wait to go back. We loved the Gothis quarter. Beautiful architecture, loads of excellent musicians and loads of atmosphere

Spend the day here for shopping and enjoying the beautiful neighborhood. We visited the gothic quarter during the day and regret not spending the entire day here exploring. There are so many streets to walk down, most of them filled with shops, cafes, and restaurants. I read a description regarding this area, and it mentioned the "haunting architecture" this neighborhood has to offer- just beautiful. It has an old world feel to it, from the narrow streets lined with ancient buildings to the iron lamp posts located throughout the quarter. There is almost no car traffic within the quarter which made it that much more enjoyable. We stopped here after visiting La Boqueria, and had a great time walking throughout the quarter. The beach is located nearby, so one could see how an entire day could be spent in this area. I definitely recommend strolling through here during your stay!

Get there earlier. Was interesting, but not something to write home about. Lots of nice little piazzas around which would have been nice to stop and have a drink at if we weren't already on way to something else.

Absolutely stunning quarter, great atmosphere. I have been to Barcelona 4 times; it is my favourite city in the world. The Gothic Quarter is a must see when here. It has Roman architecture, infused with Spanish as well. There is music, culture, history, shopping, eating all intertwined in this quarter. Go get lost in it's streets! There is beauty at every corner. If your lucky you will stumble upon the quarter during their outdoor market- lots of antiques, super cool.
Dangerous. Never go in the nigth, only during the day. Full with bad people that only want to robb your money or sale you some drug.If you go with girls,don´t even thi nk have this adventure.
Very atmospheric. If you've read Carlos Ruiz Zafon then you know what I mean. I was expecting to run into "The Cemetery of Forgotten Books" around the corner. We had great churros and chocolate.

Enjoyed Picasson Dali art museum. Expensive but worth it if you really enjoy history and art. I was not aware of Dali as much. Going thru the exhibits, I learned so much and admired the unique art style.
