A great place to get lost. This area of Barcelona is a great place to get lost in. There are tons of shops, cafes, and a labyrinth of side streets. The old school architecture is awesome to take in. I would suggest going during the day but the night time is very fun as well. Just be careful because there are some unscrupulous folks preying on tourists at night. Make sure to stay in well lit areas, mind all your belongings, and use your best judgement.There is plenty of public transportation nearby. Make sure to bring some comfy shoes because you will be walking a great deal.You will enjoy this are because it has a life pulse of its own and is very laid back.
A nice place to walk in. A beautiful place to talk a walk in, it's an ancient place that has a huge cathedral where you can enter and take some beautiful pictures

Amazing. Walking through the small winding alleys gave me the feeling of being back in time. I loved just roaming and not worrying about where I was going. You eventually find your way to a major street or if not, you can easily find someone who speaks English to guide you out.

Get lost for a while. Make your way off La Rambla and into this warren of alleyways and corridors. You will probably get lost or at least a bit disoriented but that's half the fun. Artisans, tapas bars, quirky stores and tourist kitsch all coexist harmoniously. Great way to spend a couple of hours.

Great place to explore. What a beautiful and magical place to go exploring.
You can get lost for hours roaming in the laneways. While there are some shady characters wandering around the gothic quarter as long as you are aware of your surroundings you will be fine.

Lovely place to get lost in. A very busy area of Barcelona and with good reason. We didn't pay for a tour, we wandered around and got lost in the area.
The churches are definitely interesting to see and the little shops and cafes are a must to visit.

so much to see. wander through alleys that connect to restaurants-shops-Picasso museum-in summer-there are street performers everywhere-the Hotel Colon is wonderful and overlooks a beautiful square with restaurants and freshly baked goods in the morning-so much to see right here and the on and off bus stops right there
Mesmerising. Pretty narrow streets and nice little shops, this place shouldn't be missed out. Great for taking pictures and stopping for a drink in one of the cafes.

Nice. Nice for walking, feels more safe in the area near Born, the Las ramblas side at night is too confusing with al the people and more turistic also. The narrow streets are very enjoyable to walk and there are good places to eat a do some shoping.

Wonderfully Atmospheric. I don't know what it is with Spanish cities but many seem to have these fantastic old neighbourhoods. Barcelona's Barri Gotic is up there with the best. Go back in time and lose yourself in this wonderful maze of old streets and alleyways.
Be sure not to miss the Cathedral, Palau de la Musica Catalana and the fabulous Placa Real.

wander as you will. We walked around the Barri Gotic on our last visit to Barcelona. We had tapas, drinks, I bought some adorable outfits for the grandchildren at Kabraloka that had been hand decorated by a man sitting in the back of the shop. Our necks hurt from looking up at the cool buildings and old architecture.Definitely spend time here when in Barcelona.
lovely to walk around. great to stroll around, stop for a bite or wander into alternative little shops... best bars, squares, churches etc... a must when in Barcelona!
Get lost!. How wonderful it was, just to go up and down the narrow streets, pop in a shop or a restaurant and see all tourists do the same.

Great Area of Barcelona. A pleasure to walk around this area. Great architecture, many shops and restaurants. I would recommend taking a tour but if not you can walk here for hours and just enjoy the atmosphere. IMO restaurants in this area are better than on The Ramblas.

Great place to take a stroll, to eat and to do lots of shopping. I took a guided tour by runner bean tour. For families and it made us enjoy more this beautiful area.loved the food, shopping and views, including the great Cathedral
Awesome design. Beautiful building...love the surrounding...sadly i come during labour day and there were a lot of people.

Fantastic walk back in time. Fantastic walk back in the Gothic Quarter, side streets, plenty of restaurants, the original cathedral and the old Roman walls. Bring a map, just in case you need it, easy to get lost in exploring and not remember the direction back to La Rambla.
One of the best neighborhoods in Barcelona. Gotic´s narrow streets are fill of life. it is like walking inside a time machine going back in time. I loved it. A must go when in Barcelona.
Best Area of Barcelona for Visitors. This area of Barcelona is the one which has the best location for visitors as it is so central for the sites and has a huge selection of shops and restaurants.
Nice quarter inBarcelona. Nice quarter in Barcelona with a lot of shops and restaurants. You can walk here for several ours and just enjoy the atmosphere.

Multiple attractions around. I would suggest potential visitors to walk and explore the place. Santa maria del mar and Cathedral de Barcelona are present in this area!! Don't miss tasting the ice-creams!!

Do NOT skip this under any circumstances!. This was honestly my favourite part of my visit to Barcelona. Barri Gotic is beautiful to walk, the architectural styles from different periods of time meld together in an amazing way and the historical aspects are very interesting as well.Though I'm sure people will have a great time strolling through the gothic quarter by themselves, I would personally recommend seeing Barri Gotic while in Runner Bean Free Walking Tour (or of course any other tour of your choice), since the information that will be given to you will make the experience so much more memorable. At least, that's what I did!

Best central happening location in Barcelona. Great restaurants around every corner and perfect access to everything including shopping, metro lines, the beach and fair walking distance from many key tourist sites in Barcelona.
Fun and Amazing!!. Great place to walk around during the day and the night. Lots of good bars, restaurants and shops. Good for families and couples
Gothic Quarter. A must see when visiting Barcelona. Did the free walking tour which was very informative. Lots of shops, restaurants sightseeing in the old section of Barcelona.
Nice interesting adventure. Nice place to walk around and window shop or look around interesting shop. Lots of place to stop off for refreshments. Bit different after dark however !

A nice place to wander. Hopped of the City Tour bus here and wandered through the narrow streets. Quite busy near the Cathedral but generally a good place to explore the architecture and little tapas bars
Marvellous Buildings. Lovely buildings on every corner, wonderful architecture everywhere. Narrow little streets full of character. Spent a pleasant hour wandering round.

Must see. Definitely a must see .
FREE and beautiful
Loads of eateries so go hungry
The architecture is breathtaking
😍😍😍😍

gothic ...... It is a very long walk if you want to pass all the alleys , it is a big challenge to not get lost ! They have about a thousand shops with everything you want and don't want .
It was nice I recoment it for relaxing walk

A great place to wander around finding small shops and location, great architecture. We stayed in the Gothic Quarter, in H10 Raco Del Pi, best decision ever as we were bang in the middle. The Gothic Quarter is vibrant with so many cafes, shops and great things to see. You could wander for hours around the small streets, taking hundreds of fantastic photos (I know I did!) Lots of graffiti on the shutter doors of shops when they are closed, I thought they were fantastic myself! Being right in the middle means you can always pop back to the hotel to refresh and then off you go again. Very close to Las Ramblas which is a bonus. Also only a stones throw from the main bus route to the airport. We didn't feel threatened or scared in this area, it seemed so safe. Lots of police presence which helped too. So glad we stayed in the Gothic Quarter, if you choose here, you wont be disappointed!
Lovely area. Fantastic buildings museums and the cathedral Excellent views from the cathedral roofReally good atmosphere in the whole area
Visit the Gothic Quarter for sure!. Loved all the hidden little passages and the churches. It was fascinating to walk thru and window shop. Such a darling area!

A top must see for Barcelona. You cannot possibly visit Barcelona without strolling through the narrow streets of the Gothic quarters. Find food for all your creative spirits and check the outlay of some of the little shops...just too wonderful and the minds behind must be remembered as creative souls making food,clothes,crafts,interiors and others.No bling ...just soul...I loved it! Though they say one must look out for pick pocketers,and I can imagine why...I never felt unsafe as a solo traveler. At night though...I was in other more open areas! Visit the many churches and Cathedral in area,also the Picasso museum and Frederic Mares is a must...and many more in same area.

Great shopping and restaurants. The architecture is, of course, awesome but so is the shopping!
Take a day--cause you will need it to negotiate all the streets and plazas.

Magical. Have visited the Barri Gotic many times and always find new things to see, new experiences and find new friends. It is a wonderful place that seems to attract the most interesting and fun people - love it!

Best place ever. Where to start...the lane ways that go off in every direction. The little bars and food places. The feeling like you are in another world..well you are in another country. Just love love love this area.

A MUST visit. This area we set aside for a full days visit. We walked and walked. The narrow streets wind around the quarter with side streets that unfortunately we had to miss. There were many retail shops, cafes, bistros and assorted professional people. The history of the area is incredible. Think kings and queens. The Spanish Inquisition, along with churches and cathedrals. If you love history this is the area to visit in Barcelona. You may think it's all about Gaudi but it's much more than he.
Loved it. I could have spent all day here wandering the streets and pretty much did, great little shops with crafts and foods, nook and cranny streets it was great. I will be back.
A fun walking experience. This is medieval, with narrow streets. There are fun cafes and bars. This is a fun area to walk around and people watch.

Read about the streets. Read about the streets and the history before you come. We enjoyed the neighborhood because we had just finished reading Cathedral by the Sea as well as several travel guides. All of the small museums are gems worth a pause, and to see Catalonians break out in dance in Placa St. Just is a treat.
must see. nice place.Ticketing queue can be long on sundays.good piece of architecture with features of age old history

Typical but crowded. Obviously one of the best place in Barcelona, but as you have lots of bars and nightlife places this is not as clean as you will expect. Narrow streets, where the soul of the city lies, are a wonderful maze. Just walk and forget about the heavy traffic and pollution of the city. Picasso museum is a must.

Beautiful. This city is beautiful behind every corner you find a new breathtaking street/park/building. The small alternative shops are also a pleasant change from the famous chains that rule the citries nowadays.
Charming. Old Barcelona is a lovely area. I had heard that it can be a bit doggy but I certainly did not think so

Barcelona Turisme--Walking Tours. We did two tours offered by Turisme, Gotic & Picasso. Both were excellent and highly recommended. Approximately two hours in duration, led by very knowledgeable guides. Picasso included entry to the Museum with great insights by the guide, 42 Euros for two of us. Gotic was 30 Euros. Both were arranged on-line so a 10% discount was available. Be sure to bring a copy of your confirming e-mail.

Where it all started. This is the oldest part of the City where the Romans chose to settled; therefore the area is full of history. It is a pedestrian area and walking is what you need to do to explore and discover the beauty and history all around. Get a good map and explore the court-yards of many of its buildings, go into the Cathedral, do not forget to visit Santa Maria del Mar, Casa de l"Ardica, Plaza del Rei, Plaza de St Jaume, museum of City History, artis café Four Gates, and more. There are a few areas where you can rest and have an outdoor drink or meal. Most of the attractions, are free, of course there are others where you need to pay a fee (museums).
Nice but not extraordinary. Compared to similar areas in Madrid, Seville and Granada, we honestly weren't that wowed by this district. More commercial than historical.

Narrow medieval streets in abundance. This area gives a good feel as to what it could have been like living here several hundred years ago. As well as providing plenty of artisan and specialist shops. Also having got here, why not continue down to the beach if the sun is shining.And, if you like that sort of thing, there is a Starbucks in the area.

Avoid rush hours, let the map at the hotel. It's a must go. You have to wander the Gotic, you have to sit in Plaza San Felipe Neri (the only calm place. It has magic, specially at night), look up for the gargoyles around the cathedral, look for the hidden places, you'll find little bars, shops, museums, etc... And watch your purse!! Don't dress/act as a tourist if you don't want to have nasty surprises. Don't be all the time with a map in your hands, relax, let your mind and your body wander around the nice little street,... It's a safe place, anyway.

Forget your maps and guide books and just lose yourself in the Gothic Quarter. Sometimes it's really nice to just get lost and have no plans, no direction, no itinerary or even a clue what you want to see.....just explore your surroundings. Like the souks of Marrakech, the Barri Gothic is just somewhere you can walk for hours, lazily sip a glass of wine and watch the World go buy or explore the many quaint little gift and boutique shops. A very enjoyable way to spend a day in Barcelona.

Key to Understanding the Culture and History of Barcelona. So many buildings and streets to document the history of this amazing city, particularly for the years when infrastructure such as clean water, sewage, and other essential services were non-existent. Suggest doing this with a tour guide to get the most out of it.

Love!!!!. This place is amazing! There's just something about it which makes you want to keep exploring the little alleyways. The buildings are gorgeous. A lot of cute bars and tapas bars. Right by La Rambla so you may as well have a wonder through :)
A must see. . Another fantastic area of Barcelona. Just do it!!!Visit Cathedral and just wander. The whole place is a complete wonder.
Nicer in the day time. This area is a maze of alleyways with shops & bars, lovely in the day time but looks different by night, I felt a bit nervous in some areas once it was dark

Barri Gotic Walk. We did the Barri Gotic walk as laid out in Rick Steve's. Nice walk but probably best done with a tour guide who could spin some tales.We did visit the Cathedral and it was free...but it is not noteworthy except for the Crypt of St. Eulalia. Believe it when the guide books say the dress code is enforced - we saw several young women in shorts escorted back out the door.The best part of the walk was the singers and musicians playing in an alcove on Carrer Dels Comtes on the east side of the church. Drop some coins in the collection box.

Needs some cleaning. The walk is always nice and cool on hot days. The smell is terrible! People need to clean the streets!Too many restaurants, shops and cafes do destroy the impression someone would expect.

Lovely atmospheric area. We ended up in the Gothic area by accident one day while exploring nearby. I loved the narrow streets and quaint shops of the area. The whole place was bustling with activity but unfortunately we didn't stay around for as long as I would have liked.
great to explore. Excellent place to just walk around and explore the old city and view some of the museums, art galleries and quirky little shops. Definitely recommend.
Charming and Beautiful. Booked the Sandeman's free walking tour and walked aroung Barri Gitic and Borm for a few hours. it was charming with all sorts of intersting churches and shops.

where Barcelona began. one can find vestiges going back to Roman days here. but the big attraction is the Cathedral. But Gotic is also a place to wander medieval cobbled streets, stop for drinks, coffee, or tapas; select souvenirs, buy postage stamps!, mail postcards!, cigars and smokes; have a meal, get fresh pastries as we did for dessert and next morning's coffee. A picture perfect view at every turn. we even caught a morning socialist protest against greedy banks!

A beautiful walk back in time. Just strolling down the winding streets and taking in everything around you is amazing. A lot of history to experience and a fun place to people watch. Many shops and cafes to check out. Try a fish pedicure for relaxation!
Great atmosphere and shopping. Loved the feeling on these little old streets, there's lots of interesting shops and restaurants too! Bring your camera.

Great neighborhood for walking around. A great area to walk and take in the antique neighborhood. Was a pleasant experience just to walk through the winding streets and feel as though you had gone back in time! Bustling with people, but a great place to walk around.

Facinating. My favourite part of Barcelona so much to see beautiful old buildings ...interesting restaurants and bars changing atmospheres throughout the day well worth a visit...but be aware some of the narrow streets can be a little confusing when it's late and dark ...and a little spooky ha

Stepping back in time. This area of Barcelona is fantastic. Walking through this maze of little streets and alleys and discovering the history and some little curious. We thoroughly enjoyed this area of Barcelona. It holds interest for all ages.

nice old quarter. Barri Gotic is the center of Barcelona with little streets and old buidlings. But the real old houses are reare to view, beacuase many buildings are renovated or chenged over the centuries. Around the cathedral there are some original left overs and near Jaume1 are some rsidues of the old roman wall. The historic museum of barcelona is also very interesting. Many little shops are located here and many little tapas bars and restaurants. But some of them are very touristic.
Barcelona by Segway. Interesting and informative,beautiful city. We toured the city centre on a segway and had such a great time.
Walking tour. Had booked a free walking tour. Brill guide full of enthusiasm and knowledge. Really enjoyed the history and the buildings/area.

I wanted to move there!!. This area of Barcelona is not to be missed. Winding, narrow streets through building after building after building, all of which seem to be classical studies in architectural form and Grace. Tiny tapas bars, art galleries, artists at work, the occasional gelato shop, friendly shopkeepers, cathedrals, great restaurants, roman walls all blend together to gift the traveler an experience not soon forgotten.

Historical Old Barcelona. It was lovely to visit this part of Barcelona and compare it with the Ramblas and the designer shops of Passeig de Gracia The Cathedral is a beautiful building, whilst the Gothic quarter is filled with narrow winding streets of lovely old historical buildings and quaint shops and restaurants. Well worth a visit to see the new and old side by side
Good area. Lots of places to eat, snack, drink. Pleasant streets without vehicles. Lots of landmarks. This is one of the great sights of Barcelona and must be enjoyed thoroughly.
Peaceful, Mysterious The Place-to-be. Narrow and curved ways with delightful shops, artists, Tapas Bars and excellent Catalonia Dinners. Home of the Mercer ***** Hotel.

Gothic Quarter - Best historic section of Barcelona. Lots of history - roman wall, cathedrals, great restaurants off the beaten track. Make sure you stop and see the Roman columns form 100 BC off of the Sant Jaume Sqaure. Closed on Mondays at 2:00, so go early.

Great walking tour. We walked by ourselves although would recommend going with a guide for a more informative tour. We read all there was to read on the plaques, but really you would need a guide to the history of the area.
Guided tour with Barcelona Dreaming. We had a 2-hour guided tour through Barcelona Jewish quarter. The guide was great, well worth the money and time spent.
Fun area. I love the Gothic architectural style, the small streets and the many restaurants and shops in this district

GET LOST. We loved the Gothic Quarter so much, we returned twice, just to wander around, allowing ourselves to get lost, as we strolled through the winding alley's and in and out of the little galleries, stores and restaurants. This area of Barcelona is the heart and soul of the city, filled with architectural treasures, courtyards, fountains, unexpected surprises. Some of the cities oldest and best Tapas can be found here. Great shopping, from Tourist Shops to Chocolate Shops, Clothing to Antiques. In the evening the winding and narrow streets come alive with troves of locals mixing with tourists. Many tapas restaurants are so crowded that they spill out into the street, loud and noisy, fun and rowdy. We recommend this experience to everyone who visits Barcelona!

Magical narrow streets, old buildings. If you don't mind walking, I strongly recommend Gothic Quarter. Take a walk in and out of narrow streets, there is a lot of detail in every little street to take in, from gothic street lights to run down buildings, beautiful balconies, a smell of history and a little bit of deprivation. Get lost in the magic of narrow streets.

Walking paradise. If you enjoy architecture, surprises around corners, historical areas, shopping possibilities - this is a strollers' paradise. The area is complex in mapping, but very straight forward when it comes to pleasant options. Thoroughly enjoyed our time admiring the building construction features - my wife liked the shops :)

Fun place. Great food and bars in the area. Easy to get around.Architecture is wonderful.Stopped in several neighborhood bars and had a bit of wine and tapas..people friendly and you feel safe in the area.

Loved this area. Spent a lot of time in this area on our visit to Barcelona. Loved the narrow streets as you never knew what to expect when turning the next corner. Great little tapas bars and quaint shops.

Quaint. If architecture and history is your thing, then you'll find this area highly interesting. The buildings are exactly as they were many years ago, with narrow and windy lanes.Great place for wandering and letting your imagination take you back in time.Recommended.
Worth. It's worth a visit to Barri Gotic. It stretches from La Rambla to Via Laietana, and from the Mediterranean seafront to Ronda de Sant Pere. It used to be a roman village earlier.
Quaint and interesting. Lovely little shops and quaint streets - well worth a visit. Plenty to see including the picasso museum, santa maria cathedral and little boutiques

Must do..take time to walk it. Start at the Cathedral. Opens at 8 and no cost or no question. Tower climb is closed at the moment. Walk the guide book Gotic walk, easy flat walk and not too busy early morning. Loads of choice of cafes, get down to the curvy roof of the Caterina Market for great coffee and interesting shops. Then walk up to the Palau de la Musica to finish off.

Must visit. This is truly a maze where you will find historical treasures and sights at almost every corner of the narrow streets. Beautiful architecture with lovely small shops and restaurants. There were street performers, including opera, and the natural stones from the walls provided excellent acoustics. Don't worry too much about following a map. Just walk and wander, and you'll somehow end up in La Rambla!

Barrio Gótico. It is interesting area to walk around, to get in the inner yards, churches. But by night this place changes, got a feeling it is a bit unsafe there. Try to get to place at day time, it is definitely a place not to miss to get get a full impression what Barcelona is.

Get Lost in a Medieval Maze!. Barcelona is one of my favorite places on earth and it is mostly because of this neighborhood. Every few blocks you come across another plaça and everywhere there are bars, restaurants, shops, street performers and people. This is a great place for a tapas crawl, bar hopping or just people watching. To me, this IS Barcelona!

Loved the architecture and the neighborhood feel. Took a walking tour of the area as recommended by the hotel concierge, and similar to what was outlined in the National Geographic book on Spain. Great architecture, waited in a short line and went inside the cathedral. Take the elevator ride to the top, it is worth the views. Lots of small shops, restaurants and tapas bars. A lot of it is closed on Sunday, so other days might be better. Several museums to visit as well, but we did not have time to stop at them. Walked down to the port area and returned along the Ramblas. The Barri Gothic is definitely less touristy than the Ramblas. Locals advise to ignore the gypsy beggars because they are controlled by organized crime.
Well worth a visit.. We hopped off the bus here. A very beautiful cathedral and an interesting area to stroll with lots of nice restaurants.

A must see. The Barri Gotic is a quarter in Barcelona with nice narrow streets. Be careful for pickpockets, but you should see this. It's very beautiful, there are several shops and nice pubs and restaurants. Also some beautiful churches and if you are lucky you will see local people dancing on a square.
Just wandering...... Just wandering around the little narrow streets us interesting enough but with so many little shops and bars to explore its les it even more interesting

Gothic quarter fun. We were there for a tasting tour which was wonderful and went back the next night for more tapas! It was saint George's day, so the celebrating was such fun-- spontaneous dancing in the streets, singing and overall happiness. It was great to be a part of it!
Gotic - great. Visit the covered market, fantastic and with locals using the restaurants you won't get ripped off (as in La Rambla)
wonderful architecture. Sit in front of the cathedral and watch people and performers. Stroll along the narrow paved streets and browse the specialty stores. Lots of tapas bars in this area.

Character. Small narrow streets, a step back in time, lots of little shops, cafes and bars. Nice to look up at all the buildings, get a nice medieval feel. Located just off las ramblas, very easy to find.
Lovely, and historical.. We lived the museum, cathedrals, and historical sites. There is tourist shopping, and be careful due to pick pockets.

Entertaining, informative tour in the heart of Barcelona - highly recommended!. We took the free tour of the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona about two months ago (19th February), but it is only now that I can find time to write about it. We had a short, 4-day stay in this beautiful city, and this tour was one of the most memorable events of our stay. Our guide Yana was brilliant. She gave us lots of information about the history of Barcelona in an emotional and entertaining way. The area that we walked through had the special magic of layers and layers of history and culture. So if you plan a trip to Barcelona, don't miss this tour!

Fun to Explore!. Loved exploring the narrow alleyways full of historical Catalan architecture, Roman ruins, street musicians, shops & cafes. Just be careful of pickpockets & keep your wallet or purse secure.
Very cool old part of the city. Loved this area. It is more traditional and close feeling. The old streets and buildings are fun to stroll around on and explore. Definitely worth visiting this.

Take a taxi tour and stop at the sites you want to see. This is an ideal walking area or we did a taxi tour with my older parents. The taxi took us to see several of the gothic sites and was able to drive right up onto the sidewalk so my parents could get out and see everything without tiring out. Our cost was 50 Euro an hour plus 10% tip.

Great area to wander in. Lots of narrow streets, packed with tiny shops selling all sorts of things (some more touristy than others). It's just a fun place to wander around window shop. Plenty of places to grab a bit to eat, as well.

Take a guided tour. Wonderful, interesting area and you will get a lot more out of it by taking a guided walking tour. The streets are narrow so be prepared to be patient and polite to accomodate the traffic.
easy find. Very easy to find, just of La Rambla, pleasant stroll back in time, quaint squares and old buildings.
Great Area. Walking distance to the Ramblas. The Barri Gotic is filled with wonderful shops, great restaurants and easy access to many historical sights.

Nice but not unique. It was nice walking through the Gothic Quarter but it wasn't as amazing as I was expecting. There were a couple of nice cafes and pastry shops along the small alleys that served very good pastries.
Great location in the city. Narrow, winding streets..True medieval feel...Perfect location for a home base in the city for those who like to walk everywhere.
A must see!. Barcelona has some of the most impressive architecture. You will find so much of this at the Gothic quarter. It also has great bars and tapas too!
Lovely area. Lovely area for wandering around the narrow lanes and seeing all the buildings. You can easily lose a couple of hours wandering here.m
The old side of the city!. A great place taking a walk! The beautiful old buildings, the streets the shops the nice small cafes and restaurants... every corner that you turn brings a new surprise!!

Sensuous strolling. One of Europe's best ancient city quarters. Everything we came across was fabulous- the shops, cafes, art galleries, street performers, monuments, public buildings. One of my favourite places, right up there with Paris and Venice.
Amazing place. Great place to walthrough the alleys on a late afternoon and to add to all the small shops. We walked through the quarter almost 2 times each day.

Wander through the quaint streets!. We spent a few hours here taking in the sights, we visited the cathedral, and then spent time wandering through the streets, stopping at the boutique shops restaurants and cafes! Great for people watching. Really great to see with something different around each corner, filled with street artists and musicians - a must whilst visiting the city.

Wonderful wandering.. The Gothic Quarter is a wonderful area to wander around for those who don't mind being lost. The narrow lanes open out into quiet squares, usually with a church and coffee shop. Just when you think there is no end to it you find yourself on a main thoroughfare and not lost at all.Most squares do have signposts directing you to points of interest and showing you which way to go. The whole area is fascinating and easy to spend hours exploring. One real benefit of Barcelona is that the footpaths use flagstones rather than cobbles so much easier walking than some places.

Great place to wander. You could spend hours in this area and never get tired of wandering through the narrow streets and sitting in the small squares watching street acts- music dance. Lovely shops and buildings, nice bars/restaurants. I would love to go back.

old Barcelona. I like its narrow streets, small shops and cafes, great Cathedral... this part of Barcelona is old but alive . it has its own taste and spirit. If you like such things, go there for sure and listen to heart of Barcelona.

The heart of Barcelona. This is a must see. There are so many shops and restaurants, you could spend a month in the Gothic quarter.The history of the GQ dates back to Roman times.There are many beautiful historic churches to see and photograph.

Walking tour. Instead of being part of huge group following lady with the umbrella, try getyourguide.com. I took walking tour of barre gothic for one and half hours. Great guide and we all spoke English so guide didn't have to translate everything . there were only four of us, so it was very personal. If there was anything special we wanted to see, he showed us. I had just read the book Shadow of the Wind ,set in this quarter, and I wanted to see some of the places mentioned In The book. He shows me all of these.Tour was free, but you pay at end what you can.After tour stayed to explore.Later visited Picasso museum located In this quarter. Get your ticket in advance on line,in hotel, or tourist info center. Museum much better than I had expected. Timed entry made it not so crowded. You get a good perspective of how he developed before moving to Paris. Before you go, check for special exhibits in museum. You will need ticket in advance.

Delightful ......but. Like the other reviews I had a lovely time getting lost in the side,streets.However later on in the night someone wouldn't stop pestering me and tried to trip me up.It is very quiet down some of these alleyways.It's nice to be away from the crowded Ramblas so please don't let this put you off.It must have been past my bed time.

Best part of Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter is the oldest part of Barcelona with narrow little streets from Roman and medieval times. Great area to walk and explore with museums, shops and restaurants. My favorite part of the city.

Like nowhere I've ever seen. So much to see and do here. We were on a tour with a guide - a real advantage. He knew all of the places to see and go. So many fabulous little stores and cafes. Tons of historic landmarks. Definitely visit!

Everything you need. Do not eat in the square or on la ramblas food awful and over priced just have a drink if you must. Whole area busy but fabulous plenty to do with lots of restaurants and bars. The main cathedral is breathtaking and free they charge 3euro to go to the roof top but it is so worth it the views are amazing

worth the visit. an interesting section of old Barcelona (actually the medieval city) that is fun to walk through with wonderful facades and dramatically small streets. Fairly well touristed, though this can be fun since there are some very good street musicians.

So many little alleyways opening onto grand squares.. Loved it - a couple of mins stroll from Las Ramblas this area is full of quaint cobbled streets with small shops and restaurants which open onto grand squares surrounded by more restaurants. A lovely atmosphere by day or by night. The cathedral is also located in one of the squares.
Don't miss it!
Barri Gotic. I liked everything...streets, old beautiful churches, restaurants, little shops, tapas, iberico ham, sangria...

Take a walking tour. The Gothic quarter is pretty small but with all the winding streets and little alleys, very easy to get lost. I would piggy back a walking tour. Admire the buildings and architecture, eventually you will end up back at Catalunya. A lot of shopping along the way too
chose anything, any restaurant. any restaurant is good choice , there is no chance you make mistake, atmosphere is right and you just must want to have fun and have good companions with you.

Best location for touring. This neighborhood has the most interesting attractions and you can walk to all of them. A multitude of restaurants and sights, local tours, cafes and Tapas restaurants. Shopping is also exceptional. A great base for exploring all of Barcelona.
Nice. I liked it but it's a bit poor area and dirty. Other than that walking in the streets and admiring the architecture and facades of the old building is a nice experienc

Loose yourself - and bring cash. I love loosing myself in this area. The little winding streets, plenty small shops with anything you never knew you needed and dozens of chocolate shops and sweet shops. Not to mention trinkets, shoes, clothes, ceramics....You name it, they sell it.Although it may be confusing at first to try and navigate (forget the maps), once you get the hang of the corners of the area, it get's really easy to navigate from Las Ramblas or the seafront. Or just go back to Las ramblas and try again.

My favorite area in Barcelona. This was one of my favorite parts of town. The. Architecture, shopping and little cafés were all charming. The roads were winding and the people were fun and friendly. I would definitely visit that neighborhood again.
A Lovely Maze. Spent four days getting lost in these wonderful streets, A new delight around every corner. Loved Mingus Bar but had trouble finding it each day.
awesome. great history, food, and shopping. better than paris or nice. took a pedicab tour of the old sections. a must. ask for robert. nothing i disliked.

Old Barcelona . Sometimes the streets are so tiny here that two people can hardly pass. Charming old town in the day becomes rather dangerous place to walk alone in the night. It's pretty great to sit it in the bar in the evening with sangria though
Must view. Stayed on the edge of this quarter and all the back streets and alleys are worth a visit .many cafe etc to people watch and places to eat.

Favorite part of Barcelona . Found ourselves back at Gotic Quarter everyday. Thoroughly enjoyed getting lost in the alleys and the nice break from the sun. Great shopping, even better food. Definitely a must see spot!
Nice place to wander around. Great pieces of architecture and really picturesque buildings around...nice boutique shops...good for people watching when you get tired...

Favorite Part of Barcelona. We love the narrow streets and local shops although this area is changing with respect to crowds and small shops disappearing. Wandering from plaza to plaza, getting lost (but always coming out on a plaza or street you recognize). The Runner Bean tour was excellent.

Very central and pretty area. As we were staying in this area, we visited it quite well. It is indeed very central and accessible to La Rambla, the Cathedral, the various small and delightful squares, the market La Bouqueria and many other places. I would definitely go back there next time I visit Barcelona.
WOW. Beautiful area!!! Must see if you enjoy old architecture!!! Friendly service in most shops and cafes.

Classic Barcelona old-city neighborhood. This is a must-visit area for any trip to Barcelona. Many charming narrow old world streets with small shops and restaurants. Great area to wander around and explore, with a great buzz and energy from both locals and visitors. Plenty of tourist attractions to plan your stroll around.
A taste of the old days. Strolling in the Gothic Quarter lets you feel how Barcelona was in the old days. Also, you can enjoy some nice shows of the locals in this area.
like the old towns. I enjoyed walking thru the old town - like other old towns in Spain. It was very crowded - even in April - so just be prepared.

Lose ourself in the history of Barcelona. I love walking around the streets of the Barri Gotic. You never know what you are going to find....a little pasta place where they make their own pasta, the old show shop...a constant discovery.

Chilled out place for shoppers and travellers. If you are looking for a place buzzing with people having loads of good restaurants, cafes and shops, this is the place. The best place to buy souvenirs.

Charming medieval quarter. As we stayed in Barri Gotic throughout our stay in Barcelona, this was a point of reference to the rest of the city"s landmarks and quarters.We entered it at the break of dusk and once accomodated, went on explore it by evening and night. Barri Gotic offered charming little narrow streets with old, medieval houses and passages leading to surprising squares, churches, domes and administrative buildings.Given the houses were somewhat tall and the streets narrow, sun could barely get in and this provided a lot of shade - which is especially enjoyable in hotter months.Not only is the Gothic Quarter enchanting by itself, its location is very convenient, too- 5 min from the port, 10-15 to the beaches and 5-10 min walk to Las Ramblas and around 15-20 min to the bus station. Loved the mix or locals and few tourists, which might have been due to the season we visited (March), thus maintaning the genuine medieval feel.

Beautiful!. A maze of streets which are delightful to wander through!The architecture is stunning & the shops are worth a visit. We enjoyed this area both during the day and at night. We found delightful restaurants serving very tasty cuisine and at extremely reasonable prices. A must when in Barcelona

Great place to get lost in. Barcelona is a very easy city to walk around as you seem to be unable to get lost as all the streets end up at the sea. the only place that you might and should get lost is the old city and especially the Gothic part of it. amazing small stores everywhere.
Beautiful! . Spend one morning of my holiday walking around the Gothic quarter and thought it was absolutely beautiful!! Really enjoyed walking around the area and exploring!

We stayed in a small third floor walk up. I think we were there about six hours a day. It is a very entertaining neighborhood. We happened to arrive on the day before the Festival de Merce and it was extremely fun and interesting. We jumped on buses easily, usually found what we were looking for, if not we found something else. I love tapas, breakfast, lunch and dinner. :)

Charming place with lots of quaint shops. We spent a lot of our trip in Barri Gotic, especially at night. You can wander for hours and not really know where you are. The streets are narrow and dark and twisty, but there are shops on almost all of them. And it's not tourist-y stuff- there's clothing, leather bags and shoes, art, jewelry, pottery, toys, etc. The architecture is delightfully medieval, as if you are in a movie. Really unique place.

Great walking tour. I'd recommend having a travel book with you when you take this walk. There's a lot to see around this area, would definitely do this walk again on my next trip. The Roman Temple of Augustus is on this route and it can get pretty crowded in there- it's a small room but worth seeing. The Church of Saint Felip Neri is worth seeing if you're interested in the Spanish Civil War history. It has damage on the front from one Franco's bombs.

Beautiful.. This quarter is just near the hotel where I was staying beside the Cathedral. It is a maze of streets and it is easy to get lost! However, most people speak English and are very obliging. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants. There is also a tourist information office.

A place with an atmosphere. The quarter is a good place to get lost in. Just relax and let your legs carry you where they wish, there is always a nic e angle and new excitments. The narrow streets are elcoming at daytime as well as evening. It feels safe to wander around. The little tapas bar are welcoming. Watch where the locals are sitting....
Gothic Quarter + Cathedral. Gothic Cathedral Free entry and worth it. Narrow streets, shops, bars, Placa Reial and La Rambla a definate to go to.
Found a Gem. Walking back to our hotel and we found the Barri Gotic! There was music and dancing to watch. Beautiful art galleries and much more. Lots of fun

The most beautiful place in Europe. My most favorite place in Barcelona, let alone Europe. The beautiful tightly knit squares and alleys, alongside plaza and courtyards were amazing. Amazing restaurants (we really enjoyed La Hacienda!), great nightlife, and a fantastic place to get lost in (you really can though!), a must see for anyone visting Barcelona

An idea of what it was like in medieval times. I stayed in an apartment in Carrer Serra for four days which had the advantage of being in walking distance of everything I wanted to see including Parc Guell (which is a 1hour walk and not for the faint of heart).Being able to walk around these narrow streets for a few days gave me a real sense of timelessness, I felt a little of what it would have been like to live in an old city where space was so precious.The streets will open up on into squares which give a idea of the communal nature of that culture which is still in evidence today eg in Plaza George Orwell there are many shops as you would expect as well as a child playground which was well patronized. Many other squares had works of art.The Barri Gotica is about a 15 minute walk to the beach, but the two areas are separated by centuries.

Explore and wander. This area is like a rabbit warren of many narrow alleyways and street. There are many little boutique shops to explore alongside tapas bars to try. It is just of La Rambla but you could be miles away from the hustle bustle of this main street. In the heat of the day it is a cool place to wander, you never know what will be round the next corner

Walk and walk. Spend a couple of hours wandering around this fasinating area glance up as often as you can to look at the beautiful archetecture. Pop into a bar for a beer and tapas. This area is amazing there are a lot of churches to explore, some charge a small fee. there are also lots of little squares that you come across and its nice to sit and watch the world go by.You will enjoy the Barri Gotic
Tourist tourist tourist. It's fine, but if you want to go from tapas to tapas, and bar to bar, you will be better served staying in El Born or Barceloneta. That said, it does beat La Ramblas.

an old part of the city with many narrow streets. This part of the city needs renovation. A lot of small and narrow streets are bordered by old buildings. There are a lot os small shops, many of them closed because of the economic crisis.It is a nice area to walk around.

Atmospheric. Just a great place to stroll and soak up the atmosphere. Plenty of little shops and cafes but the narrow, winding streets are enough to please in themselves. Walking some of them feels like traveling back in time.
Fun area to visit. The narrow streets, the unexpected corners and fountains make for a fun stroll. It's amazing how the plants grow on these little balconies that hardly get touched by the sun.
The way to lose and find yourself.. To know the city better you may just walking through the historical places as The Gothic Quarter. The spirit of time lives there.

recommended! don't miss it.... The street's are very crowded interesting and beautiful both sides.
recommended!
don't miss it, . ...

Do a real walking tour, or follow a good guide book. I've been to the Gothic Quarter a number of times, but this time, I had a tour by an architectural historian. I strongly recommend this. Your hotel can give you information. The quarter is so interesting but unless you really know your art history, the layers of Roman to medieval to later structures may elude you.
free walking tour is the way to go. learned so much. many hostels or companies off a free (tips only) walking tour. so much history. beautiful old streets. would exlore this area again.

busy exciting and a sense of history. a lovely part of the city brimming with atmosphere and history. The city cathedral is outstanding - worth visiting the roof area after 1pm daily for fantastic high view of the city. Head to this area for churros and chocolate for breakfast.

A great area of Barcelona. Well worth walking through this area. Much nicer area than the main tourist hubs.
Great shops, variety of restaurants.
Highly recommended.
Narrow Streets full of surprises. One can feel the vibations of history among its narrow streets while discovering some new surprise around every corner. Just go and explore!
Gothic Area , Barri Gòtic. This was a very pleasant area, with narrow streets and cosy and nice tapas bars, boutiques and people. Try itot !!

Just walk slowly!!. A memorable visit to the ancient heart of this beautiful throbbing city. Walk the alleys and get lost:) Buy the ice cream here it's amazing. The shops are typically touristy but if you can ignore this it is a worthwhile few hours

Lots to do but be careful visiting at night. Lovely area with a totally different vibe to the rest of the city. Lots of small, family run restaurants and bars. Prices are good value as well. However, at night, especially in the areas closer to La Rambla prices go up considerably so check on prices before ordering. Also lots of people pushing booze or other items on passing tourists. Further away from the Rambla area the better it gets.

Best of Barcelona. When I think of BCN I always imagine Barri Gotic. It's the most charming part of the city. Full of little shops which never last a long time (they may be gone by the next trip to BCN). At night it becomes dark and quiet and is full of dealers and pickpockets. I like that atmosphere too... (however quite a few locals and tourists avoid going there after 12PM)

Local time-travel. Barri Gotic is the largest surviving medieval quarter in Europe today, even though the authenticity and age of some of the buildings have been disputed and heatedly debated.The quarter stretches along La Rambla down to the seafront and back again along Via Laietana. Within the quarter there are many noticeable landmarks strewn out in the maze of old streets, which is quite unlike the much more regulated newer Barcelona surrounding it.You can of cause go for the mako landmarks such as Catedral de la Santa Creu i Santa Eulàlia (Barcelona Cathedral) which is a beauty of a classic, Gothic cathedral (admission fee). Plaça Sant Jaume is another place (you can be lucky to see the Castell sometimes during festivals).But a favorite pastime is just strolling the streets, try to get a glimpse inside some of the fantastic courtyards and cloisters hidden there and enjoy some of the more expensive shops in Barcelona.Barri Gotic is not only for tourists, actually you'll find many local in the narrow streets and squares in the quarter.Unfortunately, due to it's popularity it's also a place where you can be subjected to pickpocketing and petty theft - but if you follow some simple guidelines for not parading open bags, wallets in back pockets, and the like it is no problem at all.An enjoyable place, which you shouldn't miss.

A must. This is old Barcelona. Lovely for an afternoon stroll, but do beware of pickpockets. They are everywhere, and very active. I was lucky, but many others get cleaned out.The architecture is amazing, and here are many beautiful shops and cafees.

Lots of small shops,tourists and interesting buildings..... There is much to see in this district including the cathederal, the Picasso Museum and many interestingsmall streets. Good to wander through for a while, but there are so many other things to see and do in Barcelona.

Barcelona and Catalan culture epitomized. By far the Barrio Gotico was my favorite part of the Barcelona experience. The deeper you venture into the Barrio Gotico, the more interesting it becomes. Every twist and turn brings you amazing new sights and smells: incredible bakeries, restaurants, stores and architecture. Also, on Saturdays and Sundays there is a beautiful local Art Market and Farmers market in Placa Del Pi (just a short walk off of La Rambla into Barrio Gotico)

Heart of Barcelona. Everyone needs to visit the center. Walk the streets Christopher Columbus did and see the magnificent Cathedral. Every corner has something cool...shops, restaurants, people wandering. An awesome visit.

Avesome atmosphere, many placecs to see. search for some streetart.. I love every quarter of Barcelona, every one has its own spirit. Very special atmosphere, many good places to eat, nice markets, plasec to visit such as Picasso museum and more and more and more. You can also find some good streetart and road-sign art, be attentive.
Beautiful Cathedral. Outside and inside of the cathedral is very beautiful, I enjoyed the historical architecture in old Barcelona.
Lively and interesting. A bustling district filled with masses of tourist, gives one a feel of the city. Plenty of shops, restaurants.

walk walk walk and eat. great quarter to walk around in and take every little street you meet. ther eis so much happening when you look up since you see how everday life unfolds. there isa need for great walking shoes but luckily there is lots of good places to eat and drink around the Gothic quarter
History mixed with great shopping. Well worth a visit in the morning to visit and experience the history of the area. Plan a visit for later in the day for shopping and drinking.
Dark roman inspired streets. This area is the old part of the city with lots of alleys, shops, churches, and surprises at every turn. Very medieval and romantic.
Beautiful, festive and fun!. We wandered through the winding streets all afternoon. Got a little lost but that was part of the fun!

You must visit. An area that you certenly have to visit. You have to walk a lot in the small streets and discover in each one of them a lot of new goodies its time. Try to visit the area during day or after noon and avoid it at night. Even if Barcelona is not a dangerous city there is a microcriminality in the area at nights so you have to be carefull.
Best to take in with a walk. Beautiful views of buildings, best taken in with a walk - suggest a SELF PACED walking tour e.g. rick Steve's
Unbelievable. We went down and around different quarters and alleys that in the United States you would be afraid to around each turn was a different restaurant or shop that was utterly fantastic

The old town.. the heart of Barcelona. When you visit that quartier, you will feel what Barcelona looked like centuries ago. Narrow streets, building almost touching each others!. Lots of handcraft shops, cafes and restaurant. in almost every corner you will listen or see fantastic performances of artists too.

Interesting small shops. Narrow streets with interesting shops full of treasures, something a little bit different, lots of vintage stores and interesting gift shops, lovely places to eat. So nice to escape from the more commercial shopping areas. Well worth a visit. As in most big cities be extra vigilant with your bags and valuables, unfortunately there are a lot of pickpockets around. Enjoy but be careful.

A place to get lost in.... Walked down via Laeitana to the cathedral, then spent a merry hour or two poking round the various alleyways, looking in quirky shops and generally getting lost. Beautiful architecture; watch out for delivery vans and the odd car down the narrow streets.

Authentic quarter of Barcelona, be aware of pickpockets. This barrio in Barcelona offers the most varied selection of bars, shops, restaurants, and also petty crime (mainly at night). So be aware of pickpockets in big crowds during the week-end.

Visit in the daytime. We visited here at night and although we loved the area everything was closed and we didn't get a chance to go back. There were a few buildings we would have loved to explore properly. Having said that it was a beautiful evening with opera singers on the corners of streets filling the air with their wonderful singing. Not to be missed

Step back in time. We enjoyed finding all this area had to offer. Little shops and restaurants on narrow streets. Very eclectic area. You'll find different stores along these narrow passages. It's like stepping back in time.

Beautiful. The gothic quarter is well worth a visit. The cathedral is beautiful. Visited 4 April, was ceremony on in the cathedral and it was lovely and peaceful. The cafe's around the quarter are lovely and very reasonable. Would definitely visit again.

Get lost And Enjoy. We love places like this and liken it to Corfu town. There is a myriad of side streets packed with little shops and cafes that burst out into sunlit squares. This is the real Barcelona which the locals are worrying about loosing to touristy shops

Loads of nooks and quiet corners. History and charm at its very best, you cant help stopping in your stride and looking around you, I find something new everytime I go. I love the Cathedral and Plaza Real. The little cute shops and stores and tapas bars, you could wander for hour and hours. Dont forget the Market its well worth a visit.

Explore the beautiful streets around this area. There is something to see no matter what street you walk down.. The buildings and churches in this area are stunning. Very safe and clean streets with something to see all around you.
Nice neighbourhood to stroll around. this is a nice area to walk around see or visit a few things. A drink or tapas at one of small squares makes it nice.
Beautiful old streets. A lovely area to walk around in and includes sites like the Museum and La Cathedral. Some nice places to eat and boutique stores.
Great sites. An oldy worldy experience with quaint alley ways and classic buildings, mixed with good shopping. The Cathedral is impressive.
Amazing place. A lovely place to walk and walk all day set and have a coffee or a drink and you can feel the history in the area

Entertaining!. Fun place to let yourself get lost in the winding narrow streets and stumble upon many wonderful shops, cafe's, pop up artist stands, buskers, and amazing architecture! Every new corner or turn you take leads to something new and exciting! Enjoy!

Nice quarter to walk and shop!. We walked and walked and walked. And we didn't stop because there were so many little streets to experience, shopping opportunities and amazing food experiences waiting us in every nook and corner. Must experience this place when in Barcelona!
Have a pair of good walking shoes on!

If you have the time ... Wander. This will be like everyone else's review .. great place to eat, wander and find some hidden jewels by walking off of the main walkways. Again as another reviewer says ... cheaper than La Rambla
Place to stay. Loved the proximity to all things Barcelona. Rented place with lots of amenities nearby. Reasonable cost.
Different!. A different approach of Barelona. It takes you to the origins of this big and prosperous city and you'll understand better the environment of the rest of the town.
walking delight. Take your time to wander the small streets and lanes. Lots of interesting buildings to look at. Great vibe
A step back in time, with great shopping. The Gothic area is really spectacularly preserved, but now has all kinds of great restaurants and cool hipster shops. Enjoyed just wandering around.
Get lost in the alleys!. We loved the narrow alleys, shops, tapas bars, health foods, restaurants, markets and churches - have fun - get lost!
good place to walk, shop, eat. We walk there one day &one night, it is a nice place to spend your time.the prices of shops &restaurants is lower than la rambla, but overall high.
Wander around where centuries meet!. Just wander where centuries meet! New fashion, souvenir, coffee houses all mixed in med-evil surrounding alleys.. Charming!
This is the real Barcelona!. Just get lost, explore and have fun. Great shops, food and drinks. In some corners ans allies it will take you back 500 years...
just get lost. the gothic is a wonderful combination of beautiful architecture and vibrant culture. there is great food and drink to be found here too, just wander and drink it in.

could spend days there!. We spent a full 2 days wandering around the narrow cobblestone streets, and exploring the historical buildings, fantastic shops, and restaurants/parlors that served the famous Spanish jamon or tapas
good atmosphere round here. lovely area, you can chill here or even hit some of the bars. nice mix off places and worth visiting
A nice little place. Another interesting walk in Barcelona down near the Catedral. Also worth checking out the Jewish quarter
Fab. Old cobbles, small boutiques, impressive architecture, narrow alleys, churches, Roman walls, beautiful squares, cafes, bars etc. take a camera and spend the day wandering xx
Lose yourself. Love wandering around all the narrow shop filled streets. Walking back in time. Liked he interesting stores and plazas. Was a bit crowded.

You must not miss this area. The architecture is just wonderful, of course. Take your time and enjoy the street performers, too. We saw a hilarious mime performing near our restaurant, Bar Pi. Take a guide book or map, at least, so you don't miss what's just around the next corner. We enjoyed strolling this area for a few hours. We got lucky in early May to see the parade of the Catalan country people in their decorated wagons with the work horses. Way cool if you can time it right.
Fantastic area. We loved this part of the city, lovely narrow pedestrian streets, boutique shops and places to eat. Churches and places of interest around each corner.

Atmospheric. We went at the end of November when all the Christmas lights were up. Every which way we turned there were decorations which made the whole area look lovely during the day or night. There are so many turnings and shops, bars and restaurants it's well worth a wander around to get a bit of a feel for the atmosphere.

Great part of the city. Loved getting lost in the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona! It is best to not go with too solid of a plan and just walk up and down the streets. Great shops, but can get a little busy when you get close to Las Ramblas.

Amazing.. This area is one of the most stunning places I've been. You can spend hour upon hour walking through these stunning streets. With it's amazing architecture and plenty of shops, café's and bars make sure your wearing comfy shoes, as you could be there all day.

Cathedral and culture.. In this area visit the imposing Barcelona Cathedral and many museums including Museum of Chocolate, the Picasso Museum, the Museum of Catalan History and others. Take in the atmosphere in the maze of old narrow streets.

Beautiful magnificent buildings. You should not go to Barcelona and not see these beautiful magnificent buildings, beautiful streets. An under appreciation from the locals of what they got - when it comes to culture this city has nothing to envy any other country. This shows the culture of Cataluna and the beauty it has.
Lovely lively area. Enjoyed strolling the old alleys to see all the different buildings. Lots of bustle but not too crowded, over Easter weekend. Plenty of bars, restaurants, and shops.
A place to wander. Narrow streets, lovely buildings, some splendid churches and decent cafes and bars, the Barri Gotic really gives a flavour of the origins of the city.

Look up!. I've lived in the Gótico for over a year now (and visited it 14 times before moving) and a piece of advice I would like to give everyone visiting: don't just stop to take pictures of things in front of you, but look up too! You'll be amazed by how gorgeous the balconies and adjoining stonework are. Each building seems to be different, and that's because unlike what you would easily assume, they have mostly been built between 1600 and 1930, and thus each have their own time's style. Not surprisingly, the narrow alleys sometimes are home to the most surprising buildings, and you'll often run into hard-to-find-again bars and restaurants where you'll mostly encounter locals. It's a different side of Barcekona, just steps away from the paths all tourists take. Explore and enjoy!

Best Area in My Opinion. My favorite area of Barcelona. Incredible architecture all around, quirky shops along side familiar high street names. Every type of restaurant imaginable and genuinely the best place to get lost just wandering the narrow city streets and taking it all in. Absolute feast for the senses.
Wonderful place. to walk around. Discover old buildings, fantastic shops, coffee shops, markets, restaurants. Everything your senses desire, you will find it here

Normal neighborhood. I just walked through this. Basically I was not very much impressed. It was still nice though but I have to stay, there are much better attractions that I would prefer to spend more time than coming here. But if you wanna quickly see and walk through, than that would be alright.

Where we spent most of our time. Beautiful area, quirky little streets,
Amazing cathedral right in the middle with amazing roof top views over the city
Narrow streets opening to pretty squares. Liked the cathedral area and walking round some of the shops. However some of the streets were dirty. Restaurants really interesting
Two thumbs up. We saw great sites. There were lots of high-end/brand name stores. There different places to eat at. The city was clean and beautiful!

Getting away from the main pulse of Barcelona. Went there with my family during Easter. Really nice to see all the old buildings and narrow alleys. Old restaurants and a few guitars playing in the distance made this sunny afternoon even better! A must if you want to cool down, love architecture and/or history.
Good walk through Gothic Spain. Fascinating walking tour through the Gothic Quarter. Book a tour with a Spanish guide, they will tell you more than the guide books.

Gothic church disgrace. Having sampled Gaudis in the morning without any issues, we decided to visit the gothic area and focussed on the Cathedral... My partner being a practising Catholic understands the policies and covered up her shoulders due to wearing a vest top only to be told is disgusted Spanish tongue you cannot come as you are showing your legs!!! Sorry, when it's hot normal people wear shorts which she wore... Topped off by the beggars the area is going down hill.. Just being honest..
Beautiful !. Beautiful quarter in the city of Barcelona, very special with lots of history, good restaurants, the catedral and soemtimes even a flee-market. worth going

Gotta go there!. Go in the daytime, so you don't get lost! The streets are kind of like alleys, they wind here and there. This is where you really get a feel for Barcelona. The architecture and restaurants are incredible.
It is worth seeing. It is very beautiful, a lot of interesting places, streets and various institutions, we did not have a whole day to get around everything we promised to return)

Quaint old streets to wander. Finding wine bars and cafes were a haven in bad weather, but wandering aimlessly taking in ancient history from cathedral down was great, especially when coming across squares (placas) and statues. Great atmosphere - little sunlight.
Get lost!. Lose yourself in this labyrinth of winding lanes and alleys. There are bars, cafes, shops and restaurants. Don't forget to look up, some of the buildings are besutiful

Very Interesting Walk. While in Barcelona we spent an afternoon wandering the streets of the Gothic Quarter. It was a very entertaining afternoon filled with interesting architecture, shops, people, and restaurants. Has a very cool vibe. Well worth a walk.

Great place to visit. Complete - it has shopping area, cafe's hotels, walking distance to Las Ramblas and it has the gothic architecture. Its old matched with the new. Blended really well. You will enjoy this place.

Fantastic for wondering. plenty of shops , bars and cafes makes a great days wondering around the tight ancient streets. Plenty to see in gothic architecture and plenty of shops selling trinkets ....a real gem for the interested
Interesting part of Barcelona. Old buildings, churches from yesteryear, little alleys interesting shops. A must do whilst in this city. Choose a walking tour and you will get the full story.
Cool but crowded. We found that a rainy day in this neighborhood is the best bet. It makes for excellent photography and takes away some of the people. Can be a bit claustrophobic when crowded.

Medieval atmosphere. Amazingly preserved medieval buildings. Interesting architecture, museums, beautiful cafés and restaurants and very lively nightlife. El Barri Gòtic is the place to be for all the hours of the day

Walk in History. This area is filled with small shops and restaurants and surprises around every corner - and there are plenty of corners. The streets here are the small twisty ones that you would think of when picturing Spain. The building are gorgeous and atmosphere is serene. To me this was the heart of Barcelona.
best to walk around. old, really old town that has its history. walk around end explore. let loose yourself and then find small tapas ...
best to walk around. old, really old town that has its history. walk around end explore. let loose yourself and then find small tapas ...

Beautiful Bohemian Paradise. We stayed in this area but visited all of Barcelona, hands down best area to stay in, lively and bustling in the day and night, full of cute bars, restaurants and boutiques, LOVE IT!

Stroll the wide avenue and experience Barcelona. Great walking area. We actually walked all the way to the beach from here. The architecture was great. The small shops that line the area are great. The restaurants was good too. Keep an eye on your wallet especially when visiting the market. The small side streets are definitely worth a visit too. Good shopping and interesting views of the real side of Barcelona.
Fantastic buildings and brilliant shops. Great area for everything! Fantastic restaurants, shops, people watching in the many squares and the romance of walking round just observing all.
Love this walking area. Good spot to get a hotel.. Great area to walk and see the history of Barcelona. You can walk to the Arc De Triompf fro here or to the shopping square. Great ambience.

Best part of Barcelona. Amazing day or night. Grab some tasty churros from down Carrer Banys Nous. Friendly staff and great drinks at Stoke Bar. If you need a tour guide drop me an email. jobsinbcn [@] gmail.com

Amazing place to get lost and absorb the atmosphere. Great place to simply wander round and take in the sights.Can highly recommend one of the free walking tours (you'll find them online) which takes a couple of hours and with a knowledgeable guide you get a real insight into the history of the place.Highly recommended.

Great for a wander day or night. Charming area, full of old narrow winding streets and little shops with a whole variety of different wares. Do be careful of the ever present pick pockets. One trick is for someone to stop and ask you a question, whilst another gets into your bag.
A unique place. Great place to just wander...lots of little streets and alley ways. Out of the way Tapas Bars etc Its a lot different to other parts of this city.

Wonderful history. These ancient narrow streets near the port of Barcelona hold a wealth of history and many beautiful buildings. You may end up with a stiff neck from continually looking up; some of these streets have never seen sunlight. The area gives an insight into what most medieval cities looked like before developers got their way. There are many fine bars and restaurants but if you find your way to the Museu Picasso there is a lovely little bar across the way called Bar del Pla; great tapas and good draught beer.

Narrow winding streets, lots of shops, good things to eat, lots of people, so good people watching. There are narrow winding streets from medieval times. One really nice thing about this area is the paving is not 'cobblestone' but almost tiled, so it is smooth and easy to walk on. Of course the smoothness means there are lots of bikers and skateboarders but it is all good. There are many many small shops and restaurants to find. We found good chocolate and good food and good wine. Lots of people are walking by so it is also great for people watching. There is also still areas where the Roman aqueducts are visible, just incredible. The area felt safe to wander with plenty of police and other security.

you get the most without a plan in mind. My family loves this place. There are small alley ways intertwine each others. Each corner has some sort of history you can make up and have fun with family or friends. We had a lot of fun doing this and walk through this area with any specific plan in mind. We do have something in mind - do not follow the crowd. Make sure you visit the 4 Gats (4 Cats) cafe, where Gaudi dined.

Get lost, have a coffee, people watch and find yourself again. Take a morning or afternoon and just wander. At street level, there are shops etc but look up, look up always in Barcelona and you'll get a real view of the city. Interesting, lots of quirky shops, restaurants and cafes at street level and good views above.
Love a Gothic area!. Took a walking tour with a local guide. I would have loved a more in-depth history of the area. Beautiful, though, and very interesting mix of cultures.
Interesting. Walking around the small streets and finding art galleries or small shops is so much fun. It is really one of the best places in Barcelona

A Lovely, Fascinating Area to While Away Many Hours. We loved the time spent in the Gothic Quarter - yes it is heavily touristed but with good reason because it's a characterful area full of historical interest, great eateries and many good shops

Fun place to walk!. Narrow streets, follow Rick Steve's walking guide or another if you'd like to know a bit about what you're seeing. Watch your purse/bag, there are a lot of pick pockets in the city.
Gothic quarter.. Beautiful Cathedral set in a pleasant square. good place to people watch while enjoying a coffee and brandy!

Tourists love it for a reason. I was prepared to feel that the Barri Gotic was worth a half a day -- just to get a feel of it -- but that it would be too touristy for me. Yes, it does draw tourists, and retailers are happy to oblige. However, the narrow streets with surprise openings onto charming squares with a cafe, the pulse of history and the joy of just following your nose to wander is part of a great vacation to me. We were there in early March, before the big tourist season, so I'm sure there are more crowded experiences. We walked to our hotel from dinner one night when all the stores had closed. The people who lived there came out, their dogs ran around the empty streets and greeted friends, and we saw that the area also housed residents who called it home. The streets are closed to cars during the day, but on off hours the stores and restaurants need supplies and all the deliveries begin.I'm glad our hotel was near the quarter and we enjoyed cozy little cafes for dinner, easy stops for gelato or a mid-day snack, there's a cake cafe for a leisurely dessert with tea or coffee -- cafes are set up for you to just grab something very small and then linger and enjoy.

Wow, just wow. If you do visit Barcelona, you have to visit the Gothic Quarters, you will be greater by the simple, flea market- look alike area, where antiques are being sold, anything from a necklace to a vynel record from the 60s. On the left is the gothic church, take a tour and take lots of pics, it's well worth it. Exit on the back and you will be in the allies of the ancient remains of the Romans and gotica, let your self go, tour around, get lost and enjoy the experience. I really loved it and will sure visit it again

The most beautiful part of Barcelona. Absolutely the heart of old Barcelona with many many charming small and narrow streets, plazas and stunning Barcelona Cathedral (go there at night also and listen to the wonderful Spanish guitar in front of the cathedral). Almost next to the cathedral there is a small art gallery with modern sculptures and paintings. Could walk there endlessly. Oh, and there are many small souvenir shops as well as perfect cozy cafes and restaurants both inside and outside. Go there and feel yourself in medieval times.
a must do. thanks to Ian , our free guide, we discovered a lot of interesting places , hided in the old center of Barcelona
Cool section of Barcelona!. We had a great time in this area- cool architecture, small shops, nice cafes. A fun afternoon of wandering!

Lovely. It was nice to wander around here, we went into the church, lovely and only 7e entry, very busy bustling area beware beggars though but saying that they are all over any way, If you like Gothic style architecture then this area is for you :-)
Great walk. I love the narrow alleyways and old buildings. A walk around here should be high on anyone's list of things to do in Barcelona

Atmospheric. It's worth, weather permitting, just strolling around, but make sure you look up to see the fabulous architecture. Plenty of cafes, try the Sangria. Go down the side streets, so dark but steeped in history!
great shops. You can wander round the Gothic Quarter for hours and always find different shops and eating places.

Picturesque!!. Lose yourself in the narrow alleys lined with Gothic style buildings that look straight out of a movie set. Go during daytime to take photos, and at night to have fun! Travel in groups or meet new people who are here for the same purpose- do not miss this attraction when in Barcelona.
The history on the streets. The history on the streets The most trendy place in Barcelona has develop a proper environment the is recognized as a coolest one.
Old Espanya. Quaint and away from the designer stores etc. Lots of lovely little individual shops with authenticity. Lovely little bars and squares.

Great area to walk around and soak it all in.. The architecture and history of this area is fantastic to view. The area is open with lots of stores to shop and look. Many restaurants and bars to grab a drink and some Tapas. Nice way to break up the walking. Because walking is what you do, lots. Chekc out some of the Roman ruins.

And we stayed there. Loved the food, the buildings, the ambience and the happiness of this beautiful area. To realise that families live there today and to see school children playing soccer in the square and hear mums calling their children in for dinner made it seem so alive.

Full of culture and atmosphere. Contains lots of genuine bars, restaurants, shops and bakeries, but also a lot of stuff put thereto server the tourists. Nice to walk around most evenings and during the day.
Let your mind wander back in time!. Walking through narrow cobbled streets with tall walls, juliet balconies climing up them with some amazinf gothic arcitechture!
Try the Rick Steves Walking tour. We saw some Roman pillars inside a small courtyard over 1700 yrs old! Get the book for Spain, tear out the page and do the walk - take about 2 hours.

Outstanding. You can walk around this old quarter for hours, coming across all sorts of shops both old and new. Then a small square with cafes or bars opens up, take a rest. Larger squares open into a myriad of restaurants, some with entertainment in the square. If you see something, get it then, you may not find this shop again. Brilliant.
Old style neighborhood. A really old style neighborhood with lots of small shops and cafes. Worth a visit to walk around and take photos.

Europe, the way you hope it will be. Narrow passages, hidden turns, old architecture renewed with modern conveniences, cozy bars, and eye catching shops -- all can be found in the Barri Gotic. You can get lost, find yourself on a small plaza, take a new side street, and return to the place you began. Barcelona's cathedral is in the center and La Rambla is nearby.
