Amazing. From the Roman ruins to the church where geese have been for 1000 years. It was a glorious wander. I'd like to spend a lot more time there

Typical Barcelona. The area east between Playa Cataluna and the waterfront is packed with restaurants and shops worth a visit. I believe it is a typical area for this city. Many excellent restaurants can be found here. Don't let the narrow alley's discourage you, there are a lot of interesting gems to be found.At the south side you will find the waterfront area, nothing gotic about that, quite modern actually, but still worth to visit.
Gorgeous Area. Just stunning places to see around this area. Breathtaking buildings in the middle of shops and hotels

Quite enchanting. The narrow lanes with the typical gothic architecture and a certain gothic aura around it will certainly impress you, walk around the streets or visit the boutique shops and art galleries - either ways you will love it.Don't forget to keep your money close to your chest- u might loose it to pick pocketer...or one of the shop keepers :-)
can't get enough. You can go there anytime, and see beautiful shops, small streets, restaurants, and unique street views.

A Must in Barcelona. Gothic Quarter ( Barri Gotic) is a must in Barcelona. The small medieval streets, leading to the cathedrals, lot of the very best restaurants in Barcelona, and the feeling of the old Barcelona gives you a perfect imperession of the city.Definetely worth seeing and basically unavoidable, every tourist will end up here, due to the location - by the La Rambla.

Best place to stay and play. We stayed near the Gothic Quarter and went there every day during our week in Barcelona. Great restaurants and bars plus fab architecture. Make sure you find all the bars and restaurants down the lane ways. All the best are hidden!
Gorg. This was my fave part of Barcelona. Although it was touristy, it was a lot less than las ramblas. The areas has a lot of history and beautful landscape. The nigh life is also awesome!

Realistic Time Travel. As an American, you simply can't experience this back home. The streets, alleys and cobble stones of the Barri Gotic have much to offer. I took a tour through this old city center and learned a great deal. There's fresh fruit sold everywhere, and you get to see the old churches, tiny homes and a labyrinth of streets that never surprise as you turn each corner. This place provided the perfect excuse to get lost in a bit of history and truly immerse yourself in an unknown world.

Absolutely Beautiful. This is the neighbourhood in which we stayed, and I really would recommend it. It felt a little less tourist-y to stay there, if you don't mind it being a bit rough around the edges. There are some absolutely beautiful buildings, we spent most of our mornings just walking around and seeing what we could find. You can fall upon some really cute cafés and cocktail bars that have that individual feel.
Loved it. I really enjoyed walking around the area. Would definitely visit the area again if I travel back to Spain.

Walking through Robert Hughes' book, "Barcelona". Several Spanish-speaking guides/Spanish instructors took me on tours of the old quarter, the remains of the Ribera neighborhood, and Barcelonetta. There was enough left that at times I felt I was walking through Robert Hughes' fantastic history of Barcelona.

Fascinating. Lovely winding streets with little shops and squares, loads of little street cafes and tapas bars, easy to get lost but you always end up at a main road making it easy to navigate around.

One of my favourite parts of the city. Have a wander around Gotica and soak up one of the most atmospheric parts of the city. If you're there on a Sunday during the day at the square next to the cathedral, you'll catch everyone dancing.

Charming, essential Barca!. A wonderful Rabbit warren of narrow streets, beautiful atmospheric buildings, steeped in history, shops, bars, you never know what's down the next street, the best fun you can have getting lost!

Nice. The place is nice, but personally we preferred to go around other neighborhoods.
Make good choice of the street you visit, some nice some not

Bustling and atmospheric. A warren of dark, narrow streets full of life and history. This is the kind of place you want to give yourself a few hours to get lost and wander around. Good shops, good restaurants, and a good sense of what it must have been like to live in a late medieval city.
Narrow. I am pleased we did the Gothic Quarter, although I thought, there would be more of it !! But still we worth a look, the street are so narrow, fantastic buildings.
Barri Gotic. This is a dense, warren-like neighborhood. It's easy to get lost in it's streets, which is half the fun of exploring it.

Lovely quarter to walk in. This is a really lovely area to walk. It has lots of restaurants and souvenir shops. We joined the free walking tour and the tour guide explained everything we needed to know for example the dark history about a building and the stairs where galileo's idea that the world was round was dismissed by the king. I recommend to join a tour when visiting this area as there are a lot to learn here.

Great architecture, trendy shops. The Barri Gotic is a really lovely area that has loads of history and little winding streets filled with cool and trendy shops.If your hotel is here you can walk all over the coolest parts of Barcelona, including the marina.
So much to look at!. So much to see in this area! Lot´s of beautiful buildings and details, like a fairytail! Nice restaurants and cafés everywhere!

Beautiful, must see. The Gothic quarter is a must see for any visitor to Barcelona. In fact, during my 5 day stay, i went to this area at least 3 times and was fascinated each time. The charm is very difficult to describe in words or to capture in a picture- one needs to walk the narrow streets, take in the atmosphere, listen to the sounds and linger a bit in a coffee shop or restaurant. This place is full of amazing narrow streets, beautiful gothic architecture, quaint shops and plenty of restaurants. Highly recommended.

Simply picturesque!. Walking the small/very small old streets of this quarter is simply picturesque! Amazing to look at the streets, the old house, so many shops, bars and restaurants to enjoy and visit.
Lovely. Fabulous area to visit....easy to find ..we wandered around looking at the architecture....sat and had a glass of wine and some tapas at a lovely corner cafe...really pleasant

Walking in history. It is incredibly atmospheric walking the narrow streets of the Gothic quarter. You get lost very easy but eventually you come out somewhere more navigable, and there are all sorts of interesting shops along the way, from high end clothing shops to bars and cafes and kitschy trinket shops. But it's the architecture itself, the narrow streets and curves and shadows and the way the sound and light bounce around the streets that makes it magical and fun.

An Authentic Old Town. Compared to historic districts in other cities, Barcelona's Gothic Quarter retains somewhat more integrity. It is chock full of interesting shops and a variety of dining options---not your run of the mill souvenir/trinket shops and tourist trap restaurants. The winding streets are intersected by intriguing alleyways which often open onto a delightful courtyard filled with tables and bordered with restaurants. It can get crowded and noisy on the main drags but filled with quirky charm and surprises at every turn.

Quirky.. Loved to wander through the Gothic quarter and managed to get totally disorientated a few times. Some great little places to eat or have a pre-dinner drink. Will definitely revisit any time I revisit Barcelona.

Small streets to get lost. well there are many things to see in the Gothic area including making sure that you keep your wallet safe. Nice to walk around during the day and the evening to discover lots of different small restaurants to try
Fantastic Area. We came back to this area every day of our stay. We ate and shopped here, took a historical walking tour, and visited the nearby food marketplaces.
Love wandering around the Barri Gotic. A beautiful neighborhood in the heart of Barcelona, the Gothic quarter is a wonderful labyrinth to get lost in. Great architecture, interesting people.
Interesting area of city. Very interesting area of the city, with much narrower streets etc. Well worth a wander through, especially visitng the church Santa Maria......very calming, beautiful place
Really Enjoy Old Cities. Just wandering and looking beyond the tourist shops - art, history and architecture abounds. Love, love, love the feel of this part of Barcelona.
Worldly. Loved the feel of this area. Lots of alfresco cafés, bars etc. just a great place to stroll around. A photographers dream. The buskers/street art are just amazing
A must see. Easy to miss , but the cathedral should be seen along with all the narrow architectully lovely streets

Great place to stay. A good base to stay as close to all other areas, so much to see, great restaurants. Worth going to the Museum behind the cathedral with the roan remains. Beware of thieves, we were approached by some ladies offering us flowers, No charge! as it was a fiesta time! they then wanted 1cent as a good luck token, luckily some plain clothed police nearby who explained that this was to get us to get our wallets out so they could steal from us. Leave most of your cash in the hotel safe!

The real Barcelona - a rabbit warren of streets. Forget La Rambla, this (and the neighbouring Born district) is the real Barcelona - a veritable maze of narrow streets, passageways and squares where I'm sure you could wander for a month and never take the same route twice. The Cathedral is here, as is the city hall (in Plaça Jaume), together with lots of specialist shops, cafés, bars, churches, street musicians, magicians (no, really), Picasso's childlike frieze on the art college and the nearby open-air antique market in the Plaça Nova. Take one of the free walking tours (twice a day from the Plaça del Angel, next to Jaume I metro station) and let the knowledgeable and enthusiastic guide (assuming you have the same one as me ) tell you a little of Barcelona's history - colourful, sad, thought-provoking and optimistic by turns - rather like the Barri Gotic itself, in fact.

A must see place to visit in the late afternoon. I would recommend visiting the Gothic Quarter in the late afternoon, when the softer light caresses the imposing buildings within Barri Gotic while buskers serenade your gentle stroll
Great atmosphere, beware of pickpockets. Very atmospheric old Roman buildings with trendy shops and restaurants.Got ripped off for 70 Euors on the street next to the cathedral - beware!

Just impressive. Impressive, especialy at night. Choose narrow back streets where there are almost no people. Nothing scary, at least it was for me, but wery interesting. You may happen on some antic shop, singer of old ballads or an old workshop.
Amazing buildings. if you love old buildings and the quality of workmanship.... treat yourself and take a stroll in the old quarter.... Its free!

Visit day and night excellent. It looks spooky by night and very nice and bright by day. Worth a visit. A lot to explore. Didn't know where to look first. So much to see. Enjoyed our visit in the Gothic Quarter.

Amazing area of Barcelona. I stayed with some locals who were living in an apartment in the Barri Gotic so it helped a lot and felt more like we were part of the city. Rather than just borrowing the top layer. It's an amazing old part of the city and has a distinct smell. I'm not what the accommodation is like but I would definitely recommend staying in or near this area. It's close to loads of other things too, within walking distance.
Just walk and walk. The best place to walk and wander around from one alley to another. Don't worry about getting lost. nice streets , great food, lots of shopping places. just stroll around.
Great spot for some discovering.. Nice area to walk around and explore. The Cathedral and several other points of interest in the area as well and worth a visit.

Must go area. I loved the area with all the restaurants, shops and the street life. You get to see street performances, people having fun in the street, we really leaved the holiday mood here. Also there are a lot of buildings with old architecture that you can see. This is a must go area

Walk through 500 years of history. It is as great as it sounds...and if you are into Gothic...this is it. It reeks of Old Europe, almost claustrophobically small alleys creeping through the Dark Ages...Awesome...!! Lots of old Chapels, Cathedrals and Town Squares....not too long of a walk, just right....as all of the Walks through Barcelona.

An amazing walk down narrow streets in Barcelona. The gothic quarter contains a cathedral and then when you walk down the narrow streets, you come to various shops and is one of the best ways to explore the streets of Barcelona. We ended up at a Gelato shop (Amorino's) which was a truly amazing find and I had to find it again before we left for another ice cream. My kids loved the ice cream here. The gothic quarter looks like the old Barcelona. Walking down each narrow street here is a must. Exploring shops and window shopping in the myriad shops here is truly a great way to explore Barcelona.

Old Barcelona. We intentionally chose a hotel in the Gothic Quarter in order to be in the middle of history. The whole area is filled with historical buildings, churches, and narrow streets that are typical of that era. There are all sorts of bars and restaurants and tons of shopping, all in a tightly compacted area that is easy to walk in.
Historic Neighborhood. What an interesting neighborhood! History all around! It is a fun section of the city-lots of shops plus the cathedral, market, and museums.

A favorite!. This area is awesome. Aside from a break from the fancy architecture from other parts of downtown Barcelona, the shops are awesome with little finds everywhere. The small streets are charming and eventually when you turn a corner you will find a hidden medieval wall/church/building hidden between more modern ones.
Worth a visit. Lovely to walk around and enjoy the atmosphere and narrow streets. You can really feel what it would have been like in years gone past.
These streets are made for wandering. Wonderful narrow lanes, fun to just wander down. Interesting shops and good restaurants. Charming area well worth a visit.
Lovely neighbourhood.. Just a very nice neighbourhood to walk around, have a coffee in a square and some tapas and cava in one of the many restaurants.

Get lost wandering around. Located in the centre of the Barcelona, there are so many small streets with so much character. There are also lots of small shops, restaurants and bakeries. We went without a map and a few churches and cathedrals can "pop up" seemingly out of nowhere. It's a lovely area and at night it was beautiful with the Christmas lights.
Wonderful. Enjoyed the food and atmosphere. The jam and other meat dishes were delicious. You should not ask for 50 characters or more. It's rude.
Nice to walk around. This is a nice area to walk around. The streets are small and you feel like you are in the old city.
Wonderful are so typic !. We have loved wandering accross this area, with narrow streets, beautiful shops and delicious restaurants. During the nights with the lights its even more beautiful !
Interesting Area. Located in the center of Barcelona, the Gothic Quarter is a great place to wonder and spend couple hours.

Walkers rule. The narrow streets mean that though the Barri isn't barred to cars, there are almost none at all there. It is easy to walk and to wander, but take a map or be prepared to get a bit lost.

Venice without the water!. To us this place felt like Venice without the water - tiny narrow streets for foot traffic only, lots of lovely eclectic shops and restaurants. We loved wending our way through and will be back for more tomorrow!

Amazing. Stayed here for three days between Christmas and New Year. The narrow alleys are a great place to get lost - jammed with tapas bars, restaurants and shops and hung with Christmas lights. No need to book to eat in most places. I recommend taking the time to also learn about the long and rich history of this part of Barcelona.

Tons and Tons of Shops & Fun. Just a fantastic place to walk around and see the sights - while it's obviously packed with tourists, it's also packed with authentic barcelona. From churches to tapas, give yourself time to stroll and snack.

An Exciting Adventure. This area of Barcelona is a real adventure into history, unique shopping and true Catalan cuisine. There really is something exciting to see down every alleyway and around each corner. You will need to take your time as there is so much to see! It is also worth taking your time to look up at the fantastic buildings and the amazing architecture. There is also an amazing fresh food market not far from the Cathedral and we also discovered a little mentioned ancient market destroyed by Philip V (undercover and with useful information). If you are looking for something a little different and quirky then the Gothic Quarter is the place to go.

Go back in time. Spend time just walking the area without a plan. Feel the time/space of centuries past. Navigating through the narrow streets of the earliest walled areas of Barcelona is unforgettable.

"alleys". explore every alleys coz their is something in every inch of it,,,,,beautifully structured buildings everywhere(literally in every corner),,,,,,,you'll never get lost......there are different placas here,a cathedral as well.....tapas are much cheaper in here.....GOTHIC QUARTER/BARRI GOTHIC is at you left when facing LA RAMBLA from Placa Catalunya....
Great walk. Barcelona in general is a great place to just walk around for hours. The Gothic Quarter is full of great little places and amazing architectural details. Take your time.

Go down every alley you see!. There is something around every corner and down every alley! We had such a wonderful time exploring all the little alleys and streets. You need a few days to really see everything.

A place out of time. Can't go to Barcelona without visiting and exploring the Gothic Quarter. Be sure to check out the narrow back streets and have a nice lunch at the lower level restaurant at the Hotel Ohla (not a misspelling).
Beautifully decorated for Christmas. Easy walking along Las Ramblas, Placa Catalunya, and side streets. Little shops and restaurants to discover and easy to find your way around.

beautiful area. Nice area with outstanding atmosphere, lots of lovely boutiques, nice small pubs, tapas bars. The only thing i didnt like (or the only thing you have to pay attention to) the pickpockets. There are millions of pickpockets there.
Medieval Ramble adjacent to La Rambla. Find time in the day to explore the network of ancient streets and the boutique shops and bars that fill them.

Why I Fell in Love with Barcelona. It took all about 1 day for me to fall in love with this section of Barcelona. The Gothic quarter is amalgamation of the best of the city's history, architecture, food, shops and tourist attractions. While staying in this district there was no need to spend a lot on transportation. We were able to walk to many of the attraction and popular tourist areas such as museums, churches, Port Veil, Plaza Catalunya, La Rambla Street and Portal del Angel Street. Even after exploring this area for a week, I feel like there is so much more I haven't seen here and I plan to return. I absolutely love this area!
A myriad of streets. Wander the streets of the Barri Gotic, the narrow lanes. Get lost and 'find' yourself again. Steeped in history, a surprise just around the corner
Better than much of the city. Some said this was not safe, etc. but not true. Very beautiful with many gems to be found. Some good shopping if you watch where the locals go
Genuine. I really enjoyed walking around in this area. If you are doing some shopping, this is were you can find unique items!

Really charming. Just a wonderful ambiance walking around the quarter. There are many shops, restaurants, and bars, and the architecture is very cool. If you like architecture, or friendly city experiences, go.

Lovely place. Absolutely loved the gothic quarter with all the little lanes, tapas and wine bars. Spent most of our time in the gothic quarter as opposed to La Rambla. Jaume and liceu stations are both near. Thoroughly enjoyed my stay in the gothic quarter, so much to see, shop, eat and drink! As with all of Barcelona the structure and architecture of buildings is beatiful.
Great History. really interesting area of the city to visit; great mix of landmarks, historical sites, shops and food;
Fascinating. The area dates back to Roman times and is fascinating just to walk through and imagine how folks lived back then. Lots of shops & soe restaurants. Beautiful archetecture.

So Much to See. Our Hotel, Mercer, was in the Gothic Quarter (Barri Gotic). We really loved walking the narrow streets and exploring the many great little shops that it had to offer. Lots of wonderful tapas such as, Le Bouchon and Lonja de Tapas also a fun little family restaurant La Carassa. There are many shops for gelato, chocolate and drinks. We also walked along the La Rambla. It was very busy and there is much to see, our favorite was the La Boqueria Mercat (food market) where we found delicious fresh fruits and chocolate to bring home (recommended by a friend from Madrid). Go hungry and leave full, you will not be disappointed.
Get Lost. This is a place you get lost in step into shops have a drink with some locals and have a few tapas. Make sure you wear comfy shoes it's definitely an old city.

Barcelona at its best. This is the stuff that makes Barcelona.. Its gothic buildings, its architectural culture.. All drawing students of architecture and design from all around the world. Inspiring them.Its just something to gaze upon over a stroll and admire.

Lots of Fun. So much to do. Lots of fun. Awesome restaurants and hotels. Had one evening where a couple of drunks (bums)were getting too close, but they were not paying attention to us, they were too interested in arguing with each other.
A feast for your eyes. Lovely architecture. Pleasing stores. Literally ate my way from one end to another. Loved it. Visited the church and afyerwards went to see the historic El Born.

Please allow as much time as you can. A day may seem a lot to walk the streets of Barri, but around every corner there is something different and unique. Well worth keeping 1 full day to explore this amazing area
FAB. The narrow streets. Beautiful restaurants and great bars. Check out the Penny Banger and Ramen. Avoid Las Ramblas.

Barcelona. What i love about European cities was that you can just walk and feast your eyes and just soaking the ambience. The same with the gothic quarter. Be prepared to look up and see the intriguing architecture from a different angle.

Let yourself get lost a bit.. This is a wonderful corner of Europe in general and Catalan in particular. Architectural gems abound, interesting cafes and shops are around many corners. Enjoy the small squares and spare a coin for the buskers!

Exceptionally interesting!. My husband and I had a walking tour that was just us in the Gothic area and it was exceptional! A hidden area in Barcelona that is a must when visiting. We discovered Roman ruins, the Jewish quarter and many charming plazas. I highly recommend taking time to see this part of Barcelona!
A must see part of Barcelona. Really what more can be said about this beautiful part of ancient Barcelona. No trip would be complete without at least a day visiting this area.
Just Fascinating. We visited this area in December 2014 and found it fascinating. Lots of little laneways and alleys to get lost in.

An area rich in history!. Spent a whole afternoon here in this part of Barcelona, exploring the streets, discovering small family businesses, and also almost getting mugged! Hahahaha, lovely area to be in! The best way to appreciate the areas history is to join a walking tour! The tour guides are super informative and experienced in their field! Just be careful as the Gothic Quarter is swarmed with pickpockets!

Let yourself loose and wander in the old part of town. We walked without route planned, just wandering a choosing the streets and alleys that seemed interesting. It is a great way to the old parts of ancient European cities.You can see there is economic life, with many interesting restaurants, workshops, etc, but not many people on the street. Maybe it was the time of day. It was pleasingly quiet without being deserted.If you enjoy photography there are some interesting subjects if you have a keen eye.

The Gothic Quarter - Then & Now. The “Barri Gòtic”? Despite the name, you should not expect to find it full of pasty-faced loons, all dressed in black and sporting enough metal to make a knackers-yard boss slaver. It refers to an architectural style in vogue between the XII and XV centuries. The area includes the Cathedral and surroundings that stretch down to the sea-front which, until 1990, was part of the commercial quays and port of Barcelona, the other side of Via Laietana (the wide road was built starting in 1908 and involved demolishing great numbers of buildings) encompassing the Santa Caterina Market over to the Arc de Triomph and, again, down to the sea-front after skirting the Parc de la Ciudadella which houses the zoo, a hot-house and the Catalan Parliament, and the Estació de França.Although you may think the Cathedral is the place to visit, OK, it's alright. THE church to visit is Santa Maria del Mar. In the early seventies I heard Ella Fitzgerald sing here and that was a very moving experience. The acoustics are fantastic. And, talking of singing, for the Christmas Midnight Mass (called la Misa del Gall - Cock's Mass - in Catalan) they sing a choral version of The Song of Sybil (Cant de la Sibil·la) a Gregorian Chant from the 10th Century which foretells the end of the world. That will really make your bring out the goose bumps. A moving experience in an outstanding setting, even for those, like myself, who are not believers.This was an area of Barcelona for the rich and noble; evidence of which still exists today. Leaving aside the obvious indications of the Cathedral, Palau de la Generalitat (seat of the Catalan executive and the Prime Minister's Offices), the Town Hall building across the Square of Sant Jaume from the Generalitat, and many other official buildings and museums that have been installed in the mansions of the nobility, the whole quarter is dotted with “palaus”. The lazy translation of “palau” would simply be “palace”; however, at least in my mind, the word “palace” conjurers up images of a splendid building housed in vast estates in the country. Whilst these edifices were certainly splendid in their day, they were (and are) far from isolated. In general the landed nobles and gentry lived next door to each other in the city and visited their domains infrequently. A better translation would be town-house or mansion.The Picasso Museum (Carrer de Moncada) occupies 5 of these mansions which can, almost, be described as “terraced” in the old British industrial town sense of the word. Many of these “palaus” are now museums, libraries and art galleries. One notable example of which I am especially enamoured in the Palau Savassona which now houses the Ateneu Barcelonès (The Barcelona Art & Cultural Association) which dates from 1860. Their private library is nothing short of spectacular, and the garden bar is a calm wooded oasis just 100 metres from the hurly-burly of The Rambles. Unfortunately, most of the building is not open to the public and you will need to find a local cicerone who is a member of the Association to visit.Very close to the Generalitat and City Hall, you will find the Plaça del Rei (King's Square) which houses the Palau Reial Major. It is said that the Kings of Castille received Christopher Columbus on the steps of this Palace on his return from his first voyage to the Americas. There are myriad other marvels to be discovered by walking the area with your eyes well open and ready to explore hidden corners.Perhaps my favourite square in Barcelona, Sant Felip Neri, is to be found here. During the day it is the playground of a local school, but after 5 pm it is a very pleasant place to have a coffee or whatever other poison may take your fancy at the terrace attached to the Hotel Neri, a “boutique” hotel which will delight even the most jaded of tastes. By the way, the rooftop terrace-bar/restaurant of the hotel is well worth a visit too.During the Spanish Civil War (1936 to 1939) the square of Sant Felip Neri was bombed by the Francoist air force at a time calculated to catch he biggest number of children possible in the “patio”. The walls of the church and school are still deeply pock-marked from the shrapnel.I first visited the quarter in the late Sixties and was, at the least, a weekly visitor up until the mid Seventies. For many reasons, although living a short metro-ride away, it was not until the early XXI century that I have rediscovered the pleasures and drawbacks of the area.When I first ventured into the area, “venture” being a very apt verb in this case, it was very different place from that which you will find today. Better? In many aspects, it probably is, but, for me, it has lost a lot of its attraction. I was going to say charm, but that is something I have certainly never known in connection with the Barri Gòtic.At that time, the neighbourhood was, broadly speaking, inhabited by two classes: on the one hand were the owners of small shops and the shop-assistants. Owners of bars and restaurants and the waiting and cooking staff, small craft workshops and the occasional micro-industry. Then there were the creatures of the night, myself included.The whole area, with very few exceptions, was dark and dingy, dirty and (detectably) dangerous. The streets were dispiriting, permanently shadowy, even at midday in July. This is what appealed to a twenty-year old clean-cut kid. The fauna that made up this twilight world were drabs, doxies and demi-mondes far past their best, gays, drag-queens and lesbians who found refuge here from a generally intolerant world outside and a penal system that could make their lives very unpleasant. You have to remember that the decadent, disreputable, disgusting, diabolical and detestable dictator, Franco, was still fully in the driving seat and dispensing death penalties right left and centre.Densely dotted with myriad dank dives dispensing drinks and their daily-bread to debauchees, dilettantes, drunks and other diverse depraved devils. Restaurants that were cheap, even by the standards of the Seventies in Barcelona. Casa José, right beside the church of Santa Maria del Pi, served two daily “cubiertos” (set meals) for 12 and 14 pessetes respectively (€ 0'072 and € 0'084). The latter included a small salad or fresh orange juice before the two plates, dessert and wine; coffee was extra.As you can well imagine, this was paradise.Then the eighties crept upon us. The new, democratically-elected mayors and city councils needed to be seen to be “doing things”. A previous “pimping” operation for the 1929 Great Universal Exhibition was, by this time, totally overwhelmed.The main thrust of the reforms was to “open things up to the light”. This meant the demolition of a large number of buildings to form squares and mini-parks. And, thus, stones which hadn't see a ray of sunshine for 300 or 400 years suddenly found out what had been attracting so many tourists to Catalonia since the sixties: the sun!The quarter started its “gentrification” much to the chagrin of people like myself who enjoyed the decadence of yore. All of a sudden the area was dotted with mini-workshops hand-making soaps and perfumes. Second-hand clothes stores specialising in twenties outfits complete with feather boas. Hand-carved thingamabobs rivalled baubles and hippy necklaces for the passing tourists' Dollar, Pound, Mark or Franc.The dominant language changed from being Catalan during the day and Castilian at night to the Spanish of Argentina, Bolivia, Peru, Chile, etc. In their turn, these started mixing with the languages of North Africa, Pakistan and India. Restaurants began catering for the visitor. Our "magdalenes" have become cupcakes (though they are exactly the same) and granny's cooking has been replaced by kebabs. One is regularly assaulted in the street by hawkers extolling the virtues of their particular restaurant without speaking a word of the language of the country. Something which pisses me off in the extreme, but them I'm just a cantankerous old sod nostalgic for the “good old days”.As an occasional visitor, you will, no doubt, wonder what I am complaining about. It is, after all, a vibrant place full of fun, small boutique bars and restaurants and places to queue up at: The Picasso museum, for example.All in all, I would thoroughly recommend a visit by taking a long slow walk around accompanied by a guide, if possible, a local or, if push comes to shove, just a good guide book.

christmas markets. Went to Cathederal and all around was Christmas Markets selling the usual christmas decorations, also fresh christmas trees, holly and mistle toe. Cathederal is marvellous inside and out.

Beautiful backstreets, alleys and shops. Have a wander round the backstreets of Barcelona and you will be amazed what you find. Quirky shops , beautiful food shops , a former nunnery serving really cheap coffee and food...passages that lead you here , there and everywhere. My advice would be to throw away the tourist maps and go and explore...you will be amazed what you find...

The best part of Barcelona. We didn't really discover the Gothic Quarter until we went on a walking tour with Discover Walks and then we were introduced to so many additional gems that we hadn't found when we were on our own. Great little alleys and buildings, all with fascinating history. If you'd like to explore on your own, I'd suggest head for Picasso Museum (even if you don't go in). There's (free, clean) bathrooms there and it's right in Gothic Quarter and you can then wander and explore.

Fascinating.. It's essential to get into the basic history of the area and then simply wander around to discover hidden sights (like the Roman forum), tiny shops, and excellent restaurants and bars. Just watching the people is a delight. I could have spent days in the area but, unfortunatey, was limited just to an afternoon.
the quiet old barcelona. its the old part of the city ,no busy , no beggars, clean.i went to LICEU to see an opera . an experience to do in wanderful theather

On an eBike Tour. Rolling around with Barcelona eBike Tours is the way to see so much of this ancient area of the city. Narrow streets, a diversity of architecture, and interesting things to see. You could walk it, but you would never see as much of the history as on a bike with a guide.
Really interesting. We loved walking around this area. The Cathedral is here and very worth visiting. Lots of intersting shops,bars and restaurants to visit in this area.
So much to see!. I will be back to Barcelona as I discovered that I could have spent 3 weeks straight in the Gothic Quarter alone. So much to see. Must go and plan for as much time as you can spend!

Wander around. This barrio is great for just taking a stroll and looking around. There are many great restaurants to choose from and many old buildings to see. Very unique! I really enjoyed this part of Barcelona. It may not be everyone's cup of tea but if you like the old city feel and sights and ambiance, then this is for you!
So full of atmosphere. A bustling area full of beautiful architecture and lots of lively people. And good places to eat, too. Oh, and museums.
a wonderful adventure. the streets--more like lanes--reveal a very interesting architectural area. well worth looking it up.

Do not miss the walking tour of Gothic Barcelona.. When we got over our jetlag from Los Angeles we embarked on a guided walking tour of the Gothic section of Barcelona. It was a rainy cold day and added a lot to the intrigue of the area.after seeing most of the city I still say that this was one of the best things that we did.we had a wonderful wonderful tour guide – I think they are all really very good from what I've heard –and really got a feel for historical Barcelona. Don't miss it

A Must See while in Barcelona. This area of Barcelona known as the Barri Gotic is a must visit area of Barcelona. Some of the oldest and most interesting and beautiful architecture and history is in this area. Take transit to the market and walk around there for a few hours.
A very easy place to be. For romantic walks, eating and chilling La Gotica is unbeatable, and as it's just off La Ramblas it's easy to reach other part of the city

Outstanding architecture!. An excellent place to walk around! The cathedral and the other gothic buildings are really amazing, while there are several options for food and drink. The medieval architecture of the Barri Gotic is outstanding!

Truly quaint!. Free musicians, lovely food, beautiful lighting, pebbled streets, gothic structures are a few things which make Barri Gotic area a must do while in Barcelona. I was there for 3 days and yet every night I was fascinated to go and walk around in the area!
Discover the city. Enjoy walking the beautiful narrow streets, holding hands with your partner, watching people passing by, stop by a cute bar for a drink... Enjoy Barcelona
Suggestive. I visited this barrio during the night, I think with the artificial lights is very nice. Here you can find some pubs where to drink something without pay a fortune.
Very historic. Get a walking tour and you'll get more details out of the historical sites which was very interesting

Incredibly old. Little Spanish narrow streets and wide streets, open courtyards now filled with modern restaurants. Lots of shops and so much history. Highly recommend a guided walking tour as there is so much to know - give a meaning to the old streets of the Gothic Quarter - you will see the oldest building in Europe but won't know it unless you're told by a guide. Every time you turn a corner the street laid out ahead runs for what seems miles. An absolute must when visiting Barcelona. This was the highlight of my weekend. We used Runner Bean Tours but there are many.
Real Barcelona!. We went when the Christmas market was on. Total mayhem! It was great! Check out the unique Christmas decorations and get to know the stories behind them!

Remarkable place to enjoy.. The narrow streets, crowded all day long, full of shops. restaurants for all tastes, very pleasant atmosphere. We visited at the end of November to the first days of December. All the streets where illuminated in variety of colors. Enjoyed it very much.
Wander and get lost. It's really all part of the fun to wander the streets, find fun bars to grab a glass of wine in and eventually find your way back to your hotel.
Touristy but nice. Classic pedestrian quarter with a lot of tourist souvenir shops, restaurants etc. Still nice to stroll around. Late at night can be a bit unpleasant.

Charming and very romantic. Much has been written about this area...It is definitely worth a visit. Start at Aviguda del Portal de L'Angel, then to the Church of Santa Anna, then into Placa Nova, a visit to the Cathedral is a must, Matyrs Statue, kiss your girl or guy (or just grab anyone on the street) under the Bridge -of-Sighs (Carrer del Bisbe Bridge), and visit the seat of government for 2000 years at Placa de Sant Jaume, and find the place called the Roman Temple of Augustus (four columns still standing which are as old as Barcelona itself, dating back to late in the first century B.C.). Don't forget to eat, drink and be merry!
weekend. Githc area cannot be better, nice narrow streets, shops, places to eat, old buildings, bars, very nice to walk and spend time

Wonderful area to stay in or visit. We spent four nights here recently and are very glad that we did. The small shops and restaurants are very welcoming and have some of the most exciting things we encountered during our stay in Barcelona. We felt safe in the area and found it easy to navigate - although a map can help with the twisting streets. The small shops that sell a range of clothes and shoes are particularly exciting to explore.
Play the game and.... get lost, if possible, in this marvellous area. Try to get away from the Rambla and enjoy the atmosphere of this unique borough.
Take a slow stroll. Take a slow gentle stroll through the various streets. Well worth the afternoon. Lots of shopping opportunity.

Gothic quarter. Really cool and interesting place to visit and hang out.
Lots of quirky shops, eateries and attractions.
The scenery/architecture is lovely and the church is a must, great attraction and full of interesting sites

Get lost in the tiny streets and just soak up the atmosphere!. Take a half day, or more if your want to take in some tapas and a bar or two (recommended!) and just wander around this fascinating area. Yes it can be confusing and busy but take your time, expect to get a little lost and just enjoy the mix of history, shops, cafes, restaurants and bars.There are roads so narrow you can stretch your arms and touch buildings on both sides, hidden squares and fascinating architecture all around. Seriously, don't miss it!
Favorite area in Barcelona. Wonderful area to wonder and shop. Visited old synnagogue. Loved the small narrow streets.Great restaurants. Will definitely stay in hotel in this area next visit.

the best part of the city. This part of the city is like it doesn`t belong to a meditteranian city. But, on the other hand, is so impessive and probably the best part to walk and dream of being in another time and place....

Spectacular.. I love walking through this amazing part of Barcelona. It's filled with history, beautiful architecture, and it's a great way to burn calories from the sangria. Do it during the day and at night. You won't be disappointed. Read about the history of the buildings and streets before walking through it. Another alternative is to do one of the many available tours.

Stunning historic area - far better than Ramblas. The narrow streets and half hidden shops, bars and cafes are a complete delight. The maze of streets may be confusing and even disorientating at times, but no trip to Barcelona is complete without spending a few hours in this most historic and enchanting quarter.

Walking the Gotic. this is a really great place to wander around in. Lots of old and beautiful buildings and a wonderful church which offers on Sundays at noon a dance which is a cultural event of Barcelona, its called the Sandana. Therir are lots of resturants & shopping too.

Gothic & Gastronomic!. We found plenty of amazing dining options in Gothic Quarter from simple tapas to full on seafood restaurants, sushi, Italian, bakeries & cafes galore! Just roaming around this area is fun.. lots of shops, pubs & tapas! don't forget to try a menu del dia!

Brings History Alive. Took a 4 hour walking tour with the company "Hi Barcelona". Our guide, Teresa, made sure that we saw as much as possible of the area and understood the significance of the history. Beautiful old buildings with winding streets, delightful for walking.

Very historical interesting neighborhood ... good for a stroll!. Very historical interesting neighborhood ... good for a stroll! It is really nice to walk around these ancient streets as I did back in 2005.They carry you back in time ... also there are decent eateries around this part of Barcelona.
Historical. Worth the time to stop and walk around the very narrow streets to see all the interesting shop stalls and eating places.
Historic. This is a lovely aged area of the city with a laid back feel, yet has a definite aura of family life.
Gothic Quarter. This is a must visit in Barcelona. Narrow, ancient streets. Numerous shops and restaurants. Visited the recently discovered synagogue before the expulsion.
Great place to explore. This is the old part of town where the streets are narrow and the buildings ancient. Lots of fun tiny shops, interesting cafes, and, of course, plenty of Tapas!

A must go. For this reasons you must go:
Decoration
Shopping
Lunch
Things that you have never seen in your whole life
If you want to feel apart from Barcelona, this place give u a special moment in your staying.
The architecture is mostly interesting. Unique character, many cafés , restaurants.

We stayed here. I would recommend staying in this area. It's the old town and it's beautiful. I loved it. The streets are narrow and you can get lost but don't worry or panic just head for las Ramblas and get toyr bearings again. We avoided quieter streets only because it's a major city and we're a bit paranoid where safety's concerned... There were several police wandering up and down las Ramblas but there was no trouble... Possibly because they're visible.I would recommend this area if you're coming to Barcelona and I would recommend you find a square (they're round every corner) find a bar to sit outside with a glass if wine n soak up the atmosphere whilst you people watch. There are loads of museums and art shops/galleries here. I loved it and I will be coming back soon.

Gothic Beauty....... The oldest quarter in Barcelona, we literally stay here, right in front of the Barcelona Cathedral and walked it every day for 5 days......Narrow beautiful streets full of music and surprises literally around every corner....We always travel together and never alone. Since Barcelona is the pick pocket capital of the world.Always carry your wallet in your front pocket and try not to use your cell phone in the open.Other than that, this place is amazing. I wish i had lots of time to see every corner of it. Maybe next time i will take a tour so i can learn more about it.....Just lovely!!!

Convenient location. The location of the Gothic Quarter is great because so much of what is interesting can be done just walking. It's an interesting stroll from the cathedral square to Las Ramblas with many interesting shops. There is also the Plaza Real which has great restaurants and a good place to hang out at night for a late dinner.

Interesting Architecture. Very nice area to just wonder and look at interesting forms of architecture. The streets wind around each other. Take the time to sit in one of the many cafes for a coffee and people watch.

A place you shall not miss. This area offers a lot indeed. Personally, I found the architecture mostly interesting: a number of valuable buildings, giving the area a charming and unique character.You will find also many cafes and restaurants, and shops. I think it is just what you need to enjoy your time in Barcelona, day and night.

Awesome in every way. Such a beautiful area full of great shops and places to eat. Just remember that siesta shuts a lot of businesses in this areas down in the afternoon and plan your visit accordingly.

To understand better the big Architectural changes after Franco's era and,Olimpic Games of 1996. To understand better the big Architectural changes after Franco's era and Olimpic Games of 1996 that happens in Barcelona,it's great to walk in this medieval area to see the talent of some people like the Great urbanist Architect ILDEFONSO that inspired many generations of Urbanists all over the world,with the profound changes made in Barcelona.How they open and integrate the access to the Port and to the Sea for instances. Also,it's very hepfull to understand the culture backgrounds that inspired MIRÓ, PICASSO, GAUDI,The American CALDER and many others ...Not necessary to tell that despite all that , it is a wonderfull well preserved Roman ruins and medieval streets,with variety of small shops and Tapas restaurants! Enjoy.
charming. this was my favorite place in Barcelona! many old small streets, lots of people. it´s the oldest part of Barcelona, but very well conserved!
Fascinating. Oh there is such history and beauty here. Lots of really fun unique shops...cathedrals, roman to Gothic architecture......endless adventures!

Travel.... ...back a few hundred years with the modern BCN next door. The atmosphere is just fantastic with nice tapas restaurants mixed with shops you won't see anywhere else. Don't stay on the tourist streets, get lost and be amazed!
Fantastic quarter of Barcelona. Narrow sreets , buildings hndreds years old , impressive church ( ont of the biggest I have ever visited ) and so many nice and specific shops !

Brilliant night out. An awesome place to visit. Quirky and vibrant with plenty of different bars and restaurants. This is not a place for the 'precious'...it can be a bit scary with very thin dark roads.I would not miss it for the world.....but would not want to go there at night on my own! Go in two's....I suggest that girls do not go there at night on their own

Favorite part of town. This is our favorite part of town, with medieval streets and monuments, built on the former Roman settlement from 2000 years ago. Plenty of tapas bars, churches and museums which give the area a special feel. Of course a lot of tourists, but there is a good reason everyone wants to be here ;-)

The old City and Hidden Secrets ..... The atmosphere , specially at night, its unbeatable .... You have lots of bars for TAPAS .... Should try to discover little secrets as Saint Anna Church ( The Templar Church of Barcelona ) , the Palau of Music , the church Gaudí visited everyday , the remanents of the walls of old city and the cathedral ... For me, its the best place to feel the old soul of the awesome city ....
Relaxing. We had many Relaxing walks through gothic quarter.. Definite to do especially if you are trying to get some relaxing on often hectic vacations

So much to see. Great architecture dating back to Roman times--check out the Museu d'Historia de la Ciutat. Ornate cathedral--don't miss the geese in the cloisters. Street musicians, sardana dancers, tiny open-front restaurants serving cured ham; the list of great things to see is exhaustive.

Mystical and fabulous for roaming. Absolute stunning and a must see if you appreciate gothic architecture.I spent an afternoon wandering around the maze like streets and walking off the main tourist routes, which I would highly recommend to take in the atmosphere. A great area to spend an afternoon taking artistic photographs too.The Barcelona cathedral is stunning.....check the opening times to see when it is free to enter to save some money!
excellent shops, cafes and a cool vibe. Everything that the vegetarian and vegans(and the meat eater) wanted in one area excellent food drinks and architecture
Nice set of small streets. The place is small street after small street, really easy to lose direction where you're going. Just few steps away from Rambla, so you should go and see it.
TAKE A STROLL. Shops , eating out AND museum Frederic Marés . A discovery . Do not forget to visit the nearby food market , The Boqueria Food Market .
interesting. Very different and interesting. A must see though. We sat outside at one of the many cafes people watching and looking at the Gotic apartment building
Lovely area. Great area for just walking around, especially with a hangover as there is a lot of shade, during the day. Great architecture and many restaurants and shops dotted around.

shopping. Lots of little shops and lovely eating places. Suddenly you can come out to a big open square where you can eat and people watch. Beautiful old building you will get neck ache from looking up.

variety of historical sites AND shopping. A huge array of shops and restaurants. Many sights to see and experience. Remnants of the old fort and cathedral are particularly interesting. lookup the hidden historical sites to visit including the underground one. I would rate the most historical sites in an area
Romantic. It was really lovely to wander through the narrow streets in this area. There were many places of interest to tourists and lots of photo opportunities.
One of my favorite places in spain. fun, romantic, unique, delicious sangria available and flamenco shows. A nice place to take a little walk around and a break from the bustle of las ramblas.
like a maze. LOVE this area. Right by the Rambla Street. There are lots of small and unique stores. One of my favourite places in Barcelona.

lovely gothic church. Theres a lovely gothic church to visit all the surrounding little streets are full of shops,a very busy market
Really worth a visit

Great place to wander. This place has so much to offer that I just wandered the narrow streets for hours each day. Whether it's the buildings, the museums, the numerous restaurants or shops, there's plenty to do here. You won't find the chain restaurants, but you will find cuisines ranging from pintxos to japanese. If you enjoy shopping for something a bit different to the norm, this is where you'll probably find it. Make this area a must on you places to visit in Barcelona.

A must visit neighborhood.. The old Gothic part of Barcelona is spectacular if you into history and architecture as I am..there are great tapas cafes and lots of nice shopping available...very trendy area to stay in as well.

The old section- don't miss it!. We didn't feel like tourists here. There is everything one could wish for in this most interesting area: interesting shops (unusual mask makers, shoe makers, open air markets, leather ware, & oh so much more) & not studded with world-wide chain stores like almost everywhere else, but If you do want those, a short walk will take you there.

Great neighbourhood. Whether it's shopping, tapas, or just enjoying the lovely Spanish architecture, the Gothic Quarter is a great area of Barcelona to wander. Take the small alleyways, they often open up to squares where you can enjoy a nice glass of wine & watch the people go by.
Awesome Part of Barcelona. Plan to walk a lot, be prepared to explore...lots of little ancient streets filled with restaurants, bars, shops and people!

old world feel. The Gothic Quarter is the place in Barcelona that gives you that old world feel. Narrow streets, lots of shops, museums and churches. The Picasso Museum is in the Gothic Quarter and well worth visiting, however it is not well marked, we walked past the lane to turn into twice. It is easy to spend a day roaming this part of Barcelona. In the evening, I would feel much less safe, as the streets are dark and there are sections that would make you a target for pickpockets.
Tons to see. Great shopping both for souvenirs as well as middle and high end stores. Beautiful buildings and sights around every corner. Great food shops and cafés. Loved this area.

My favourite part of Barcelona. I loved the narrow alleys, the small shops and cafes, the friendly locals. We did a few self guided walking tours (more of less anchored around the cathedral) to explore the roman walls, the buildings, etc. Great atmosphere, a great area for unstructured exploring.
Go Barri Gotic. Great area to wander for hours. My wife and I loved getting lost walking the streets here. The only neighborhood we enjoyed more was El Born.
Fun for wandering around. Great atmosphere--just wander up and down the streets and soak up the beauty of all the buildings! Be sure to stop in the cathedral--it's free and beautiful.
Beautiful Quarter. You could spend an entire day just wondering in the narrow streets of the Gothic Quarter, sitting in the coffee shops and watching the old buildings. Highly recommended!
Gothic Quarter. Loved the architecture in this part of the city. From the churches to the old synagogue, it was so worth the visit. The visit to the old Synagogue was especially impressive to us.

Magical maze of historical beauty!. I felt as if I were inside a fairy tale! Winding streets led us to beauty and unexpected sites everywhere we walked. We thoroughly enjoyed wandering through these ancient streets with no particular agenda but to see what we would find. Since Peter is an architect, we easily identified the various periods, from the Roman walls to the Medieval buildings, but a friend found the organized tour (that she thought would be cheesy) to be very informative and enjoyable. While some of the streets are clogged with tourists, others are almost empty or used primarily by locals, making it easy to avoid crowds if you wish. I highly recommend trekking through the Gothic Quarter just for its beauty, history or surprises, to shop (not my thing) or dine, to stay (we waited until the last minute to book otherwise we would have stayed in this area) or simply to get from one place to another.
Quaint and artistic. The narrow streets, the graffiti on the metal gates, the Picasso Museum -- it felt magical and surreal, peaceful and beautiful. I continue to relive the moments spent there.

Such a beautiful spot. Barcelona is fantastic! We stayed in a little flat in a tiny historic passetge. This location is amazing - to walk to the beach, to the catedral, to La Rambla etc etc; perfectly located. Barri Gotic is perfect (as long as you're not driving a car - vehicle access is fairly limited). If you want a slice of old Barna, Barri Gotic is for you. One thing to note: we were located off carrer de ferran. Amazing, until the weekend (and 20,000 tourists) hit. If you don't want to share space with the hoards, maybe choose earlier/later in the week.
Cracking area. A great area to wonder around and explore, a must see area in Barcelona, even in the rain we all enjoyed exploring
Very nice and authentic place !. Just walking around in the area and looking at the amazing buildings - a feast for the eyesight and the soul !!!
Any day, any hour. This is Barcelona old town. Day or night for a walk or shopping or eating...are you meeting friends and going for a drink?. It is our magic quarter, stroll, get lost, enjoy.
Great place to stroll. Just wandering around this quarter is well worth a couple of hours. Fascinating at every turn. Don't miss the roman columns tucked away near the Gothic Cathedral.

The best area. Beautiful area away from the horrible tourist Las Ramblas which could be any high street in the world. The Gothic Quarter has a charm about it that will leave you wandering around the many beautiful streets with a smile on your face & your camera on hand! The buildings are stunning and there are many lovely tapas restaurants and wine bars. Not to be missed!
Nice neighborghood. Strolling around this old quarter of Barcelona is really great. You can fine many small excellent bars and resaurants within is alleys worth of visiting.
I stayed here. I'd been to Barcelona before, always staying in newer parts of the city. Loved staying in the Gothic Quarter. Close to some amazing sites. Surrounded by history.
Confusing Streets. We loved this area and wouldn't stay anywhere else, but it took a couple of days to know our way around.
Must see!. Great place to visit for shopping, food and the like. While there, visit Xurreria, a churros shop that has been around for ~50 years.

Lovely area. It was really nice to walk around this quarter after dinner - loads of street musicians, people strolling... The architecture gives you many little surprises at each corner. It's a nice rest from the noise and crowds of the Ramblas.

exciting. Shops (spanish only), vibe - liked. Contrary to that, Pakistany/bangladesh shops avoid in a great radius! Those men are rude and pushy. Only one shop was good, close to franca train station (opposite to hashish Museum), young couple runs the shop with funny t-shirts, prices ok, name..? I think some outlet...

Okay walk. Got lost in the quarter on the way to the disastrous Picasso Museum. While the neighborhood is kind of interesting, with residential areas and small shop around the areas, it is interesting to observe how the locals interact in these areas. I like the conducive environment but I wouldn't call it a tourist attraction though. Recommended especially after a heavy lunch.
nice photo opportunity for free. this place is free for public and the buildings are too old. its nice to go around but i am not really impressed.

Interesting!. - It is just beautiful to go to the Gothic quarter and get "lost" in the small alleys there.- Either day or night (preferably night) you will enjoy it!- You have to be a little bit careful though but this applies to the whole of Barcelona as you have to be careful not to go to small and dark alleys with cameras and other valuables exposed as there were some incidents of people being attacked!
Perfect to end the day!. I've made a one afternoon waliking in the gothic quarter and find it amazing. In my next trip to Barcelona surely I'll stay here 2 days to enjoy it more and more!
The heart of Barcelona.. This is the soul of Barcelona.Cafes and restaurants are abundant.This is the perfect place to meet friends over a mug of beer (Estrella). :)Manuel
Interesting streets and history. Great area for a wander around, taking in the sights of the old buldings. A guided tour might be worthwhile.

Not what I pictured. We wandered around and had a nice lunch but the shopping was disappointing. I had hoped to do some Christmas shopping but saw no shops with Spanish made items other than high end.

Such a nice place to visit. You may be surprised to find from the list below that there isn't a great deal of things to do. Barcelona's Gothic Quarter is more about getting lost among the narrow streets and discovering a plaza you've never seen before.

Visit later in the day. If the weather is warm I recommend visiting later in the day or in the evening when it's cooler. Lots of lovely lanes to wander through with plenty of interesting shops and bars

Unique ! Loved it.. One of the most impressive areas in Barcelona and a MUST see.Take a tricycle taxi tour ( available beside the Cathedral) through the gothic area .You will see a lot, you don't get lost and it is fun. One hour approximately 25 Euros, and well worth it.

Put this tour on your to do list.. We did a walking tour in this area, by buying a Barcelona card, which then gives you a list of things to do, with discount. The guide was excellent, his knowledge amazing, and you would not see or find these places without their tour. During the tour he pointed out another attraction , below us were street's the Romans had made, once our walking tour was over we did this attraction too, a full day we'll spent, learning about Spanish history, fascinating.

Wonderful and Interesting. This was the location of our hotel, Rialto, and we truly enjoyed the area. It is busy yet relaxing and fun at the same time. We will stay in the area on our next visit to Barcelona.

Crowded tourist district. The area is a very pleasant area of narrow back streets and old buildings, mostly from the nineteenth century or earlier. We had booked into a hotel for a week on Ferran. This turns out to be one of the main tourist drags leading down to La Rambla. Apart from the inconvenience of the crowds, afternoon and evening, it meant that most of the shops and restaurants were geared to providing for this trade Consequently, you do not see the sort of place that the locals favour. Also you are always paying tourist prices, and at eating tourist quality food. There was no shortage of restaurants, but we found none that delivered a knock out meal you would want to return to. So is it worth a visit? Answer yes. Is it worth staying there? Hmmm.

Great atmosphere. This was the best bit of Bracelona. Loads of little streets, small Tapas bars and trendy wine bars intermingle in a friendly atmosphere. So much better for food than Las Ramblas area where you can be ripped off. As in all of Spain provision of toilets is a problem. Best et we found is to either stop for a drink and use the owners or use McDonalds

Living in BCN. I rented a villa for a month in BCN - Just got home Friday. The Gotic Quarter is the most inspiring place I've ever lived. A stunning, charming neighborhood full of history and intrigue. FOR 30 days, we did not repeat a restaurant! Borne is my favorite neighborhood.
Rich in history. Amazing walk down through the history books. Took a walking guide tour of the region, definitely worth every min of your time.

Wonderful. Amazing architecture all over. Look up and you will see more of it. Narrow streets, little plazas with terraces and friendly service everywhere. Just what you look for on a weekend out! Loads of restaurants and bars, in the evenings foreigners mix with locals. Great food, so a real treat. Find your way around and you will enjoy so much. We stayed away from La Rambla, instead enjoyed El Born area the most!
Let's get lost. Love this area. Love to 'get lost'. Just wander around the narrow streets. Decide on any corner where to go. Look at all the beautiful street art.

lovely old narrow streets. every time we go to barcelona, we wander these streets lovely atmosphere, nothing to dslike, great for wandering looking for tapas bars, who wants three course meals when you have so many quality tapas bars.
Amazing evening walks. Dear fellow travelers,You have to visit and walk through the streets of this Gothic quarters. Prague has better ones but this is worth the visit too.

Lovely streets and shops. Take some time to get lost in the maze of streets and shops in the gothic quarter - there are some unique places there including shops that just seem to sell scissors!Have a drink in one of the many squares - we liked the Placeta del Pi
Enjoyable. Very pleasant wandering around on a sunny autumn afternoon. Get yourself lost in the little alley ways and lanes and streets. Stop for lunch and one of the many cafes.
Cultural.. Very very busy....well being a tourist sight it would be. Clearly written Information in various languages.

atmospheric and quaint. The Barri Gotic is my favourite part of Barcelona. It is a delightful area with great cafes and buildings that are so interesting. The little narrow streets are great for finding gifts for those at home and for yourself.

History, Architecture and Tourism. all three combined to make this area really surreal. Everyone has heard of this place , its true what been written about it. There is so much to see and do in terms of walking, museums , churches , shops etc. You could easily spend a couple of days wondering around the gothic quarter.Only drawback is that when you sit in some of the squares for a drink you are pestered by beggars. The hawkers i don't mind to much but the beggars are a pain.

Place with great atmosphere. We spent in this area one evening and really enjoyed it. Beautiful multicultural place with historical building, shops and restaurants. Place which is full of life whole night.

Hotel Breakfast Alternatives Abound!. It's hard to review what is essentially just an area of street but basically it's highly recommended to just wonder for a while. Also, our top tip would be to avoid the hotels for breakfast and venture out into one of the plentiful cafes for a very reasonably priced coffee and breakfast combo. You can't really go wrong!

Great for aimless wandering. My wife and I wandered into this area with an inadequate map that didn't have all the narrow streets and totally lost track. It was just beautiful, and we didn't care that we were lost.

Unmissable Old Quarter. Winding narrow alleyways, dozens of little shops and bars, some beautiful old palaces and mansions full of character housing museums (such as Mammoths, Modern Art and Picasso), churches and lots of people!

Narrow streets and fun little shops. The Gothic quarter has it all-the medieval history and architecture, complex zig-zagging streets opening into squares, and cultural influence dating back centuries. Easy access from the Ramblas and the seafront. One of the most interesting areas of of Barcelona.

Keep on strollin'. We stayed in Barcelona for 5 days and every day we had some plans what to visit. One of those days was just Barri Gotic. Plan was to stroll without knowing where are we going and to turn where we feel like. Only gonna say that this was our best day in Barcelona.
Gothic District. The architexture is breath taking. Be prepared to walk a lot! Many shops and restaurants. Loved the buildings and the people.

Beautiful to just meander. I visited this area with a friend of mine, we only had one evening of time in Barcelona and we wanted to do something where we could just get lost aimlessly meandering around the streets. This place delivered, it's beautiful and quaint.
Really is how i pictured Barcelona. You should go here!

Great Example Of Gothic Architecture. This was actually our second visit to the Gothic Quarter and it was very close to our hotel on Las Ramblas. There are interesting, narrow winding streets with shops, cafes, etc. The centerpoint of the Barri Gotic is the beautiful Catedral de la Seu which represents one of the finest examples of Catalan Gothic architecture in the Region. There is no charge to enter the Cathedral and its sheer size and beauty closely rivals the Sagrada Familia.

Enjoyable to get lost. Of all the neighborhoods of Barcelona, I liked this the best. It´s a welter of little byways that one can get lost in, happily lost. The eateries are so much better than those found on La Rambla, and so are the shops.
Wander. touristy & usually crowded. They warn about pickpockets... Just be observant & careful.Loads of stores ( if that's your thing) between the sights.

Intimate Streets and Ancient Reminders. We spent some time wandering through the Gothic Quarter and enjoyed it, especially remnants of the the old Roman gate and aqueduct, an overpass of a narrow street reminiscent of Venice's Bridge of Sighs, and the area adjacent to the Cathedral.

Fantastic for shopping and eating. I love the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona. It's winding, narrow streets are full of life, shops, bars, cafes and restaurants to discover. Try going off the beaten track a bit and see what you find.
Beautiful!. Brilliant, lively atmosphere surrounded by some stunning buildings and architecture. Great places to eat around here too - went for our anniversary and it was very special!

Spend hours getting lost!. More shops and boutiques than you can shake a stick at. Very busy on Saturday/Sunday. Quaint, winding streets with plenty of bars and restaurants. Drinking fountains regularly provided for free refreshment. Look for interesting architecture above street level too - that's where most highlights can be found.

Another world. every step he takes in the Gothic neighborhood is a new world to discover !Everything is different , with a mix of mystery and the occult , the narrow streets with a thousand and one ways for choosing , old buildings , do not have words , is simply magnificent . I have no words

Another world. every step he takes in the Gothic neighborhood is a new world to discover !
Everything is different , with a mix of mystery and the occult , the narrow streets with a thousand and one ways for choosing , old buildings , do not have words , is simply magnificent . I have no words
Get your share of old city. It is a nice place to visit and also go to the street shops. A visit here will help you enjoy the old city and its buildings. Many a surprise tucked away!

Great experience. Very old, walking there is mind blowing, rich of sightseeing and landmarks. and the most important thing ... the food. its stacked with delicious restaurants and to-go snacks. in addition to mouth watering pastries and sweets shops

Loved ambling down the backstreets. Lovely walking the backstreets of the Gothic Quarter. No harassment from hawkers and simply so much to see so keep your eyes open and enjoy a relaxed stroll and maybe a beer or two!?

away from the touristy bit. wonderful little alleyways & narrow streets. Lots of graffiti but mostly on the metal shutters of shops, so not visible during shop opening hours. Great little Placas to sit/wander in. Wonderful Cathedral, including The Cathedral of the Sea.
Lost. I lost myself in this area and I loved it,the day ended to soon.Tiny alleys which seem to open up on old buildings,never to far from somewhere to just sit and drink or eat and people watch.

Really enjoyed. We all really enjoyed this extremely interesting area.Nice to just stroll through the whole area.we visited the old chocolate shop,Catheral ,and the beautiful square off the Ramblers,with cafes all around it.
Lively area. Lots of people, restaurants, shops and drinking in this area. Be mindful, and enjoy the unique pockets in this area.

Fun Maze. We didn't have much time in Barcelona (which was too bad) so we picked a few things to explore. After seeing a few sites, we wandered into the Gothic Quarters. We just wandered through heading down any street or alley that looked interesting. We never seemed to get lost and always found something interesting...a shop, awesome architecture, gelato. It is amazing how old this area is. Highly recommend getting "lost" in the Gothic Quarters.

My favorite place in Barcelona!. The best place to have a walk in this area, and should be visited at the day and the night, the neighborhood is awesome, the buildings, streets, and shops are fantastic, and you'll always find someone playing music in any of the surrounding streets :)

Beautiful, Interesting, and Great Shopping. The Gothic Quarter provides a great deal of history, many cultural experiences, great food and shopping. We found ourselves coming back to this section of the city even after sightseeing in other areas. The street performers certainly contributed to the atmosphere and were very talented!

I could live there!. The walk we had through the Gothic Quarter was by far my favourite part of the trip to Barcelona. I absolutely loved the narrow passages, beautiful buildings and many hidden treasures that you would not find on a regular map! A MUST-GO!!!

Interesting place to visit. We travelled here on a tour & loved the old town & its architecture. Our guide gave us a colourful insight about the area & there were plenty of shops to wander around in.
Well worth the visit.

Barri Gotic. The Gothic Quarter was wonderful. Walking around the narrow streets was lovely. We took a free walking tour & the guide was fantastic. If we didn't have him, we would have been a little lost. The tour was free but we tipped him at the end.
Great place for a wander. We stayed very close the this area so we seemed to walk through it each day. Lots of shops, restaurants and squares to take a well earned break.

Explore the Gothic Quarter!. We wandered thru the Gothic Quarter a number of times during our stay in Barcelona. One unique approach to our visit was by taking a Tapas Tour via the Barcelona Cooking School. Sam gave us a unique historical perspective while walking around before we dined at some of the 'locals' taverns. Make sure you see some of the Roman ruins and walls. There are some sections that have been excavated and are on display as if you are in a museum with viewing platforms. Great selection of small restaurants, boutiques and dessert/candy shops.

wandering. Great place to wander around the narrow streets. View the remains of the Roman city walls and visit the Cathedral. We took a Segway tour and I would recommend this to see the Gothic Quarter and the beaches. The Rambla is nearby and excellent shopping at El Corte Ingles

Great for shopping, nightlife, food, walking around. visit it , very intersting are with. Great monuments, shops, restaurants, barsOldtown area , near ramblas, although very turistic has some great places.Very nice for walking around

Spend some time and walk!. The Gothic Quarter in Barcelona is one of those areas that you walk through the first time just to get the lay of the land. You will find yourself coming back again and again. The shops and restaurants are great. One of the best features are the Roman and Medieval structures. Also, be sure to find the the little bridge that is a Medieval version of the Bridge of Sighs.
pleasant promenade. There is a place to walk around, stopping in front of the ancient shops, wandering on the old bars... having a tapa and a beer, a place to visit without watching the time!
Great!. Beautiful architecture and a great place to go for a walk. A lot of unique shops tucked into alleys.
Great walking are. this is our second visit to Barcelona and walking in the gotic area is the best part. lots of wonderful building to see and visit.

Best area in Barcelona!!. This is what I came to Barcelona to see! The old parts of the city, to get lost wandering it's back streets and alleys. This area is close to a lot if sights and the best, quaint little restaurants. The famous market is right in the center. So glad I stayed here!

This is the place!. My husband and I visited Barcelona for 5 days in October 2014. A friend recommended El Jardi Hotel in the Barri Gotic and this neighborhood is perfect for exploring Barcelona! First of all, there are many little streets where you can enjoy strolling up and down at a leisurely pace, stopping at many interesting shops along the way.Secondly, outdoor cafes and restaurants are everywhere and let you have a nice little snack on tapas in between your shopping.This neighborhood provides easy access to La Rambla and thusly to La Boqueria, both highlights for many visitors. I personally found the Rambla to be highly overrated but the Boqueria was lively, colorful, fun, and delicious!Metro stations are easy to find in the Barri Gotic. Our hotel was a 3 minute walk to the Liceu metro station and allowed us to visit the other Barcelona highlights, such as Casa Mila, Casa Batllo, and La Sagrada Familia, easily and inexpensively. The T-10 metro ticket gives you 10 rides for 10 euros.I would definitely stay in the Barri Gotic again. Not only was it picturesque, it was easy walking distance to all the places we wanted to see.

best place for night walking. nice area with still its own atmosphere, many small tapas, restaurants, bars and shops, much better for shopping than main streets with all their multinationals trade names..

Old stone. great history written in the marks in the stones Keep looking up and see the masonry and the fantastic gargoyles and hear the threnody of the strings played by many street entertainers as you walk through!

Our favorite part of our trip!. Wander the Gothic quarter at your leisure, you may get 'lost' but you'll find the narrow streets and shops worth the experience. Designer dresses, tile work, hats, restaurants - - while it may be geared toward tourists, hey, we're all tourists - so enjoy!

Loved it!. Gorgeous alley ways, lots of restaurants, cute boutique shops, beautiful buildings bursting with history and architecture. Overall great location, close to most amenities. But keep in mind that a hot spot like this does get quite busy, especially in the afternoons and evenings. Would still definitely stay here again!
WOW!!!. Definately worth a look. Off the main street. A lot of little independant shops down the small back streets. Some amaizing buildings to see. Really old architecture.
