Impressive architect. i liked the layout of the area. Wide streets and large street courts. Each building had different appealing rain storm spouts. Streets made of cobble stones that have lasted for years.
Best area of the city. Full of charm loads going on masses of restaurants , music etcetera etc. fabulous old buildings with narrow quaint streets and amazing shops.

A Barcelona MUST-Rick Steve's book!!!. Everywhere we read warned of petty theft- if you are smart and alert you will have no issues. Do not be concerned, just be aware. This area is phenomenal to say the least. We highly recommend Rick Steve's Barcelona book and take his walking tours vs the paid tours offered for 15.50 Euro each...well worth it! And if you are new to Rick's books, they are very useful for any place he has covered in Europe, by far our most favorite of all of the travel books.

Roam the streets and enjoy the experience. We were in Barcelona for 5 days and spent 2 just wondering the streets and taking in the sights. In the day time walk the side streets and look at the balconies with flowers (and clothes drying). Walk through the markets and explore the shops.

Great fun - but watch your wallet!. In both senses, watch your wallet. There are tapas places charging €10 for a prawn - and there are others after your money in a more direct and informal way! I've never seen so many rucksacks worn as "belly bags". A maze of little street with all manner of odd little shops and bars, great for an evening of wandering.

Charming narrow streets!. We walked around starting Carrer d'Avinyo and ended up at placa Sant Felip Neri where a lady was playing the violin sitting on the ledge of the fountain. We sat on the terrace of the Hotel Neri and had a glass of wine and enjoyed the great ambiance of this ancient Placa overlooking the church. This area is my favorite in the Bario Gotic!

Everything about Gothic is wonderful. From the cathedral to the old cobble stone streets with trendy shops, tapa bars and history wherever you turn there is so much to love. This was my favorite part of Barcelona!

Brilliant for an afternoon wander. All I can say is don't plan to end up anywhere just wander the streets. Go up as many streets as you can and explore the beautiful historical architecture which has been well preserved. It honestly is like a step back in time with so much interest and detail, look upwards and check out how detailed the gargoyles are! If you wander enough you'll probably end up on Las Ramblas or Placa de Catalunya, both are worth a see. We got the metro the Jaume I and went from there. There was also an antique market on at the time which was interesting. Enjoy and take plenty of photos!
Great Location. easy walk to La Rambla, short walk to the beach area. great restaurants too. Trip Advisor wants at least 50 characters, so I will add a few more words.
When you have free time. If you'll stay for a couple of days in Barcelona, and you have a free time to visit this place and enjoying the coffee shops in this area, you can do that
Just walking is an experience. Lots of things to do and places to go, but just walking through it is an experience. Very worth it. The cathedral Sta Maria was particularly great.
Hop on Hop off bus tour. Fantastic area off Las Ramblas, explore but you will get lost, don't worry its an adventure and every corner offers something different

A glimpse of the past. If you dream of wandering the streets of Barcelona and imagining how it would be like back in the day, this is the place to be. You could spend hours wandering the area, browsing through the shops and if you are hungry, there's no lack of cafes just to sit down and people watch.
Nice place to walk about. Nice place to walk about. Nooks and corners filled with people. Nice cafes and bars around. Beware of pickpockets.

A favourite place, area.. The Cathedral is stunning, go early morning to avoid crowds.Take a lift to the roof top, you will not be disappointed.Its situated in a lovely square, restaurants and cafes are very close.Its a five minute walk to to or from the center and surrounded by beautiful buildings, a sightseers dream.Its also well worth visiting at night when its illuminated, just sit in one of the local bars or cafe and take in the atmosphere.

A wonderful way to stroll Old Barcelona. The narrow streets, the old and very old buildings and the mix of shops, tapas bars and coffee shops makes the Quarter a great way to spend hours imagining what old Barcelona was like. Walk for as little or as much as you want or can, but don't mis it.
Recommended. The best part of Barcelona to visit!!! Fab tapas restaurants, cobble stone streets, and great bars!!
Barri Gotic. WoW!!! this was like travelling back in time. walking through the streets. looking at the buildings and church. very historic!
Unique place. I recommend this place .... It is just going back to the old times history is everywhere ... I just enjoyed walking around all the time restaurants cafes hotels stores
Great place for wandering around. Tons of cute shops, restaurants, etc. Great for window-shopping! My friend even got his ear pierced at Stademonia, great service there!

Imprescindible. If you want to know the sense and the beauty of the city, you must go here! There is no place in the world like this, makes you feel you are a part of this big city! Of course, what can I say, I live here! Even with all stress of the city, in the Gotic you will feel relaxed!

Spend a few hours wondering, getting lost and exploring.. A nice part of town. Easy to walk in circles for a few hours and have no idea. Small little streets in the old part of town. Plenty of charm and plenty of interesting little shops, restaurants and cafes to check out.

Lose Yourself. This is a great place to simply stroll and take in the ambience of Barcelona.
The narrow streets and allies are full of interesting sites, interesting shopping, and interesting people.
Just lose yourself on the streets. Every corner, every street brings a new discovery. Leave yourself half a day to just wander around. There is so much history, so much to learn.

So much to see!. You keep getting amazed by all the old buildings, narrow streets, cosy bars and restaurants and old churches as you walk around in this area. We went in here to find us a place to eat every evening when visiting Barcelona. Suddenly there's a huge church in a little square. We happened to pop in to a wedding with opened doors. In the evening there were three guys holding an opera-concert in the back of a church. This was just an amazing experience.
Well worth a ramble. Local color. Looked for a bad restaurant and could not find one. The narrow streets date from medieval times and the remnant of the roman wall was spectacular
Wonderful walking in this area. Loved exploring the narrow streets of this very quaint area. Really enjoyed just strolling and people watching.

Get lost and enjoy it. Just steps away from La Ramblas, this quarter is filled with many gems. Get a coffee, your guide/map (you will eventually get lost) and just walk. There are so many churches, cathedrals, bazaars and places to eat. Do not forget to see La Catedral de Barcelona (it's really hard to miss that one anyway).

Such History!. We loved the gothic quarter, with it's history and it's shopping! Just a warning though, if you intend to tour the cathedral make sure you are wearing shorts/skirt longer than your knees and that your shoulders are covered otherwise you won't be let in.

Touring - On our own. Today we opted to spend our time on our own. I had read Cathedral by the Sea, and wanted very much to see it when we got to Barcelona. Took a taxi and asked him to drop us off at the Church. Beautiful old Church with many Statues of various Saints, each with candles that you could light to honour them. We had wanted to go to mass, and had checked the times, but we somehow missed it. Once outside, we saw where there was a memorial for the many who had been killed in on of the Spanish wars. We then wandered some of the narrow streets and old buildings looking for the Museu d'Historia de la Ciutat. Anne, Karren and Damien wanted to go through it, but I have never liked going down into creepy basements with Roman ruins and hidden passages, and narrow shafts, etc. Karren told me to just go around to the right and she would find me after they finished touring the place. The building had been the Royal Palace built in 1370. he told me they had seen parts of the heating systems, mosaic floors, parts of the surrounding walls, water and drainage systems, and from the cellars you could enter a narrow shaft set vertically in the town wall, where you could view old Roman hidden passages that had been blocked up in the middle ages. They saw many other things of interest and it is said that Christopher Columbus was received by His Royal Majesties on his return from his first voyage to America. However, I found the courtyard where they had probably come out on the balcony to welcome him back, and sat at a table with an umbrella and had a beer. After about an hour, I heard Damien cry out 'Nan! we thought you might have got lost.' We then wandered around and found the Gothic Cathedral, another beautiful Church. They had a fenced in area that had a pond, and there were geese, at least 20. Each time the bells rang, the geese would start to gabble (if that's what geese do). Wandering a little more in the Gothic area, we asked someone how to get to la Ramblas, and we were almost there. We stopped for some wonderful coffee and Damien had a hot chocolate (made with real chocolate) and said he would never be able to drink the kind at home again. We walked up the Ramblas and found the Hard Rock Café, where Anne left us as she had to get back to the hotel to receive her temp Credit Card. Damien loved the Hard Rock, and we ate so much we just went back to the hotel also, as soon as we finished our supper.

Great tiny little hallway-sized streets to wander. One of the high points of our trip was wandering around these little streets, with small bars, restaurants, tapas or shops around every corner. We extended our stay too over a week (from 3 days), we couldn't get enough!
Great Location. Being in the "old city" of several other European cities this one felt the most authentic and was fun to adventure.

Stroll the Gothic Quarter. A must see easily accessible to and from Ramblas, the pedestrian thoroughfare. The cathedral, the placas, the streets, the shops...all to take in the feel of this older area of Barcelona.

Spent Days Going Back. This is really an amazing part of Barcelona. The streets are tiny and narrow and really around every corner you discover something new. Had some of the best tapas by just walking up to a place that looked good. Also, had some great Sangria pretty much every place we stopped. The shops are small and some are very touristy but there are others that do have some amazing pieces that really reflect the Barcelona vibe. I found a great jewelry store tucked in between some tourist shops that had beautiful and artistic pieces (Agudee). In addition, we discovered a great wine shop and cheese store that had some of the best jamon and cheese selections. Every day we found ourselves going back there and picking up a snack and some Spanish wine to take back to our hotel (Vila Viniteca). If you like to explore and shop, you will love visiting this area.

What a wonderful little area. We had no idea of the small little roads that wind through the area. Warning - we got totally lost and my GPS on the IPad stopped working for a while - but what a wonderful place to have that happen! We kept walking and enjoyed the area and finally hit a major road, which is the street of everything in Barcelona.

Pleasant walk. There are many different sites to see in the Gothic quarter including a Gothic Cathedral. The music hall was quite beautiful. We just spent a few hours walking around and enjoying the architecture and the area.
Brilliant. Fabulously beautiful part of Barcelona. A must wander/visit - just pick a restaurant, you probably wont be disappointed :)

A good look at older buildings and lifestyle. I had not been to this area since 1963 and found little or nothing had changed. The cathedral is beautiful, pleasant streets to walk though sometimes crowded. Some small nice cafes.
Walking tour. Well worth taking the walking tour, beautiful place and the guide (Colin) was a mind of information. No charge, you tip the guide at end of tour.
Wonder with joy. Loved the great small shops, food and sights. You can spend hours or a day getting lost on these old city streets.

Vibrant and exciting. Had drinks which were pretty pricey but the place was buzzing, we had sangria which knocked the old block off it was that strong so only had 2. The placa Reial was a truly happening place. We saw 30 minute Flamenco at Tarantos for 8 euros (book on line) then danced a fair few hours in Jamboree night club for 10 Euros until 4am. Top night
Getting lost in the barrió. Gothic Quarter, nice place to visit but... So dark and stuffy, but still interesting. You can easily get lost, bring a map!

The Gothic Heart of Barcelona. wonderful place for wandering around looking around, ancient churches, antic shops, handmade shops, cute loca bars and cafes. In few words, its a completely different part of the city with its real colorful life. High recommend
Gothic Quarter. Very nice area for eating, shopping, museums. We had a lovely time by just hopping off the HOHO and spending time in the area.

short break away. Amazing,great shops ,restaurants ,architecture, fantastic street artists,must visit this area if in Barcelona,very busy went we were there in September,we found food and drink to be reasonably priced
Interesting. Interesting part of the City. Very narrow streets, many alley ways to get lost down, a bit disorientating. Visit in the daylight, not sure that i would venture there at night-time.
Need a few days to explore. Loved restaurant 'Los Caracoles' - fantastic food and atmosphere. Shopping and architecture was also brilliant with a wonderful atmosphere.

Brilliant. We spent the afternoon trying to get lost in the gothic quarter stumbling from one tiny lane to another. It was very busy with tourists and locals and the shopping was very eclectic and eccentric.We also stopped for a tapas lunch in one of the side streets. Unfortunately I haven't a clue which one it was or even where it was but there were dozens of little bars all doing superb tapas and all doing a roaring trade. I have to say that this felt much more like authentic Barcelona than the nearby touristic crush of the Ramblas.

Visit at least twice. Visit the Barri Gotic during the day and again at night - a completely different atmosphere each time. Remember to always LOOK UP - some of the roof tops, eaves, facades, etc., are amazing.

A beautiful walk through a beautiful city. We were here just a few days ago and i can honestly say that me and my partner enjoyed this the most, although the buzz of La Rambla is great, this is just something else. Beautiful little streets leading off to different places, an array of great little boutiques and vintage shops. This is Barcelona at its best. If you want to experience some of the history then the cathedral is also based here and not far from saint Josephs market. Great place

Try and get lost. You just can't ... But do try. The most amazing little shops and bars and restaurants... Just keep going up and down and across. You'll find little piazzas great atmosphere, friendly, loved it

Fun to walk through the old alleys. We had a nice walk through the Gothic Quarter seeing a classic Gothic Church and the Barcelona Cathedral. Some of the Medieval effects were actually built in the late 19th century but none the less it is a must see in Barcelona.
Interesting Area. This quarter is full of little gems--old buildings (churches, etc.) and is quie close to the port and good restaurants and tapa bars.

Great to stroll around. Just go for a walk and enjoy the sites etc. Don't forget to stop off and have a long drink though. The whole area is just a maze of narrow street and all seem to have something worth seeing.
interesting area.. forget your map and just wander. the architecture is fascinating. we came across the old medieval wall of the original town.

Fascinating. We walked up and down the narrow streets, tons of people around during the day. Would not walk around there alone at night. Saw ancient roman aqueducts in a courtyard. Gorgeous architecture, gargoyles, etc.

Get comfortable shoes. there is a free tour available with student guide in different languages. You can sign on line or through your concierge. The tour is informative and fun. be ready to walk for 2 1/2 hr. and get a lot of interesting details about Barcelona and catalan determination.

Spend endless hours discovering little gems. Lose yourself in thenarrow Gothic ally ways on this area. Every corner and placa has something else to offer. Recommend finding a hotel in this area since it combines: food, entertainment, shopping, site seeing and bars. Stores vary from international brands to local hand made crafts

Nice walk. Great winding streets through the historic part of Barcelona. They have great small and quaint shops and many restaurants. Besides the Cathedral, the St. Mary of the Sea Cathedral (Iglesia de Santa Maria del Mar) is there. This was my favorite church in all of the places we visited in Spain.
great goths. Busy streets but interesting. A few good signposts but they need more. Remember your maps. Variety of priced shops

Old world charm, amazing architecture, shopping and dining. My wife and I spent five days in Barcelona. The city is beautiful with so many sights to see. We spent a couple of days wandering around Barri Gotic. The gothic architecture and the narrow, cobble stone streets near the cathedral are an absolute delight to experience. The locals were so friendly and helpful. We found many little cafes to take a break from walking all offering great espresso and pastries and the bars throughout the area had plenty of cold, sparkling (wine) Cava as a reward for walking around in the summer heat. My wife found beautiful designs in the boutiques that fill the streets of Barri Gotic. She bought several beautiful outfits at prices no boutique in Canada could compete with.

Pleasantly surprised. We spent the afternoon here today. Truthfully after reading some of the reviews, I almost did not want to come. It is true that the GPS was a bit spotty, but after we saw the few things we wanted, we turned the darn thing off and just wandered. We happened upon some wonderful galleries and lovely shops. If you love truly different jewelry & other surprises, find La Basilica Galeria. I bought the most beautiful handmade dress at Novedades Dorins. Many terrific restaurants as well. A great day!Worth the visit!

A Maze of Streets and Alleys. The Le Merce Festival was on and had lots happening, including dance competitions with at least 50 teams, bands, shows, etc. It was great to wander and get lost in this area. Lots of shops, restaurants, plazas, etc. Stayed at the BCN Catedral Hotel right in the centre. Wonderful location. WATCH OUT for the pick pockets. Wear the waist wallets in your pants to protect yourself.

Like a step back in time. It was so easy to spend time in this wonderfully interesting part of the city. The buildings are amazing and you walk round looking up almost the whole time. For us it was the windows and mixture of balconies - mainly made from iron work - all works of art in themselves. It is very easy to get lost but you soon come across a building on the tourist map and get back to where you want to be.
Lively. This is a great area to wander around and look and feel the atmosphere of the city. Excellent shops, boutiques & cafes.

Not that impressed. We walked around the winding nArrow streets and saw tourists and lots of uninspiring little shops and coffee shops. If you are short on time, I don't believe you will be missing much if you pass on this.

Alley upon alley... do you like to wander?. If you are a tourist in Barcelona, you are going to spend time in the Gothic Quarter. Come prepared to wander about endless small alleys to experience Barcelona in medieval days... not sure if the foot traffic was as dense then as it is now. Probably so.I walked a fair distance in 2 hours or so, at various times in search of the small cathedral, a pottery store, and a restaurant. And so got pleasantly lost from time to time (Google maps had mixed performance here... not so fine once you were actually moving from alley to alley) but caught myself and was able to get back on course easily enough.When you need a break, plenty of cafes for drinks and/or tapas to refresh yourself.
Interesting tour. Very interesting to see buildings so old and the Jewish quarter. I took a free walking tour from Runner Bean tours. They were great!!

Great to walk around. Good walk around the Gothic Quarter. Great architecture. Good souvenir stores.
Catch the idiot's tour guide.

Fun. A lot of restaurants and little bar. Very touristic and the prices are very affordable. It's fun in the afternoon and in the evening to hang there with friends, chat, drink and have some good pinches or tapas.
A neat area but too many tourists!. We decided not to 'walk' this area but took a driving your through it. Some good photo opportunities but we have enjoyed other European cities more than this area.

Fantastic City Walk. The best part about the Gothic Quarter was just wondering around and 'getting lost', there's so much interesting architecture around the area, including Placa Real and Barcelona Cathedral and there's no limit to restaurants and bars. There's an astounding amount small speciality shops on some of the side streets including perfumeries, speciality tea shops and hand crafted shops. A must do of any visit to Barcelona.
must do!. Hire a guide... too much to learn and see. Be ready for lots of people but you won't be disappointed. I recommend Forever Barcelona... Marta is great!
Explore away. I walked around here for days - still needed a map! - lots to explore, bars, tapas, churches, shops. Great.

Lots of History. Loved the Barcelona Cathedral and the really old architecture, the narrow streets. Hated the touristy cheap souvenir shops everywhere. Wished had gone into History of Barcelona museum.

A maze of amazement!. Getting lost in the Gothic area every day in Barcelona was a pleasure! After a very good tour, we thought we knew the way and didn´t! We loved getting lost and finding interesting nocks and crannys in the Gothic area! A mysteriously amazing place!!
Good to walk in. I did not find special things to do, I just walk through the small streets, it i just nice to walk around

Old World Charm. The architecture and buildings are a sight to behold. What we liked was narrow streets with many different stores as we got lost along the way. There are many churches along the way too.

She Said Yes. She had no clue what I was about to do. While planning our once a year major trip for January I decided to take it a bit further. I proposed to my junior high sweetheart in Catedral De Barcelona. While she was taking in the views I was fumbling around trying to get the ring out of my coin pocket as discreetly as possible. I finally did and got down on my knees and proposed. She said yes! Guess you can say we will never forget this beautiful historic church.
Get out for a walk!. Just wander the streets, that is the best thing you can do here! Be aware of pick pockets though (we were warned by locals).

shop and dine. Great place to stroll, so many shopping place and eating place, I recommend to eat in one of the food stalls of La bouqueria(so you can let me know if it's very good, we regret not waiting on the line) because the spanish restaurant along La rambla is definitely a tourist trap and not very good (we tried it). And don't worry about pickpockets unless your bag is so open or your wallet is sticking out your pocket while you are busy taking photos of "Marilyn Monroe" on one of the verandah somewhere I can't remember where in particular, just along La rambla.

Terrific, but easy to get lost. The architecture and history in this area are incredible. We spent hours wondering the narrow streets and lanes. Some intentionally, some because we were lost. We hired a private guide to show us around for a couple of hours which was a good decision, but it did not prevent us from getting lost (like rats in a maze) on several occasions. An essential part of any trip to Barcelona. Check out the interesting little shops in the neighbourhood.

Wear some comfy shoes. This is one of the best things to do in Barcelona. Just spend the day and/or night strolling around the narrow streets. You can find some really nice shops, bars and places to eat.
Friday night music. Everywhere we went, we found great musicians just set up and singing in the nooks and crannies of the gothic warren that is this part of the city. A great friday evening stroll.
Amazing. Perfect. The best neighborhood to walk around. Perfect for have some nice Spanish dinner. Also, its pretty ease to walk. Beautiful churches and business.
Nice to walk around.. Close to the city center. Nice music, cafe, shop, and of course the beautiful buildings. Easy to walk around.

A very cool place for a walking tour or just to get lost. Many reviewers recommend getting lost in the Barri Gotic. I can see why - the architecture is spectacular. There is something different and interesting to see around every corner. But my suggestion would be to take or follow a walking tour in the area to get some sense of the historical context: the walls, the Roman aqueducts, the Jewish quarter, etc. We followed a path from a Rick Steeve's tour book which helped to explain what you are seeing. I recommend it. Either way, it is a beautiful place to spend an afternoon.

Don't take a map - just get lost..... Wander the winding streets and get lost amongst the cafes, delis, shops, restaurants, churches and marvel at the history surrounding you. Don't follow a map - get lost and wander amongst the suprises you will find around every corner.

Ideal for photo lovers-could I be your model? ;D. This neighbourhood looks as if it was taken out from a middle-age scenery,while you can easily imagine scenes from "Goya's ghosts" taking place in there..Wonderful!!DO NOT MISS to take a picture below the balcony that connects two houses -no way you won't see it printed on any postcards!Wander around the smallest path you will see,and trust me,you will never ever regret it: the photos you will take there will escort you for a lifetime!
Drive through. Wanted to walk the site to appreciate it more. Frozen in time, and well maintained. Joyful to look a
Most beautiful quarter in BCN. Beautiful architecture, had to keep coming back, one of my favorits in Barcelona. Great night life, feels safe.
Put the map down!. Best advice I was given was to put the map down and go get lost in the Gothic Quarter. Spend a couple hours just walking around the streets, grab some food and a drink.

Bothic Quarter. Great place to walk around and shop. The church is beautiful, and there are lots of interesting places to eat. My friend and I ate at Las Carracoles (we booked reservations months in advance).
Very shady. I not a big fan of Barcelona. I did enjoy people watching and mimes. The tapas are more reasonable here. Its almost like a circus. Beware of pick picketers and beggars.
A great place to just get lost. Just put your map aside and get lost there. Every street has a unique medivel masterpiece even if it is a small building or a hanging bridge.
Nice place to lost. Good place to walk and look and then walk more. Every little street has something interesting to look at.
Nice for a walk. This quarter is nice for a short walk around the picturesque area. There are several churches in the area, plenty of shops and delicious cafes.

you never know what you'll see around the corner. I love the Gothic Quarter...never know what you'll see when you go into and out of one alleyway into another. Some good, some bad, but, all a good experience!

Wandering and then wandering some more. Fantastic place to wander around, not for the claustrophobic though. Tight streets with high buildings mean that you can escape from the heat of the sun, as very little sunshine gets to these streets. Lots of little crafty type shops selling interesting stuff to tempt you.
Try out some of the small bars and restaurants, little gems

Where old meets new.. Take time out from modern Barcelona and wander through the Gothic Quarter with its narrow streets; quirky shops and unusual pubs and restaurants. A reasonably detailed map is an advantage to gain the most from the area. Be sure to visit the main cathedral which is in stark contrast to the Gaudi Cathedral.

Walking tour recommended. I would recommend to book a walking tour for visiting the Gothic Quarter. It was very a very informative 2 hour walk with people from across the globe. We got information about the Barcelona Cathedral, the Jewish Quarter, Roman temple of Augustus, Placa de Rei and so much more!

Bustling interesting walking. Great area to walk through and take in the historical buildings of Barcelona. We did find it a bit busy and touristy to want to spend too much time in the area, but certainly lovely to walk through. You are greeted with the usual touristy shops selling junk (t shirts, nylon flamenco dresses etc) that line the lovely stone alleyways.
a must see. Definitely a must see! The architecture is fabulous. We enjoyed just wandering the street and discovering the joys of Barcelona. There is loads to see, cathedrals, restaurants, museums.

Enchanting. A wonderful day was spent walking through this area. It was like taking a step back in time ! It evokes thoughts of what life may have been like during a time that we cannot even imagine, but that shaped all that we know today. The most admiral thing about this area is the way it has been restored and preserved as such a valuable piece of heritage but yet an integral part of barcelona life today. Loved it loved it

Lovely place to get lost. Enjoyed wandering around browsing through shops and streets, felt safe and unencumbered. There were a few touts from bars/restaurants, but nothing too invasive and generally everywhere was very pleasant.

Barcelona's Jewish History and more. We did the Jewish Quarter part of the Gothic area tour with Dominic and it was an illuminating experience. Without a guide much of the history of the Jews in Spain and specifically Barcelona would be missed. Much of what was, although still is, has been changed and can easily be unrecognizable without such expertise. One stone with hebrew writing can transform an event back to life and we had many experiences such as that. We toured the small ancient synagogue which was amazing. Nice Judaica for purchase. We did tour the Gothic Cathedral of Barcelona which was amazing. The small narrow streets of the walled city was fascinating and there are many beautiful shops to explore. Most certainly the Gothic Quarter should be on top of your list as a place to visit.

quite cute... but there's controversy about the age of the buildings. it's just very cute and different from the rest of the city, seeing the musicians play it's quite a joy!! admiring the architecture is also great... and here is the big problem: I read in to many places that the all place has been rebuilt to turn it into a touristic attraction in 19th and 20th...nonetheless you can still see part of the roman wall... and the all place is just pretty awesome!!

The Best Place in all of Barcelona to Locate for a Trip. central location near many other areas such as El Born. Great restaurants, bars, tapas bars and shopping. Old world feel and charm, lots of culture and a maze of places to explore.
Barcelona Walks Tour. The guide was wonderful- tour of old central area lasts about 2 hours- price very reasonable. We learned a lot about the city from its onset thru today.
Super cool place!. If you like to wander, this is the area to do it! There are so many nooks and crannies to explore and you never know what you will find! Great place to take photos!

A Must. This section of Barcelona is a must - the architecture is fantastic and there are plenty of side streets for shops, restaurants and bars. Try and cover up though shoulders and knees are not appreciated in the cathedral...!!!
Top spot.. It was great just to wander about down the little nooks and crannies and just enjoy the experience(s).
Fabulous. We stayed here and there was so much atmosphere and so many intriguing shops and restaurants and bars. Beautiful architecture! Best part of the city

Go to the Gothic Quarter Day or Night!. I highly recommend spending time wandering the streets of the Gothic Quarter. History, good food, street performers, and stunning architecture await you. We felt safe walking there at all hours.
Be prepared to get lost. Wandering small streets full of interesting shops bars and boutiques. It really is an interesting part of Barcelona, worth exploring

Another of Barcelonas areas not to miss, unfortunately it was so hot we had to miss some things out.. nothing to dislike, so much to see , the buildings are amazing everywhere you look. Loved the quaint narrow streets
great place for photos. very nice place to walk around loads of little Tapas Bars also live music in street very near the Port
Gothic Quarter. Just a few strides from the hotel. What an amazing place and some very interesting architecture. Lots of lovely Tapas bars and beautiful Boutiques hidden away down the side streets.

Great location. A fabulous place to stay full of great architecture juxtaposed with plenty of modern day graffiti - a lot of it very good. A myriad of narrow streets to wander along and while the hours away, Packed with great tapas bars, shops, Roman ruins and churches. The streets open out into squares with cafes. I think we took a different route every time we headed out from our hotel, which was close to the underground, the hop on hop off buses and La Ramblas.The only problem was trying to find a shop I'd seen previously and just could not find it again!

Historic cathedral. Great place to sit and have coffee/lunch and watch the world go by. The Cathedral is worth a visit. In the ticket price you can go up in the lift to the roof top, views are amazing. You can walk past the lift entrance if you don't know where it is, walking in the cathedral to the left half way down is where the entrance is.

Transports you back in time. The gothic quarter in Barcelona is so different from La Rambla, its neighbor. It is so full of great architecture and history at every corner. Walking there is like going on a treasure hunt.

A Very Interesting Place. The Gothic Quarter is the area around the Barcelona Cathedral. It is filled with many narrow streets and many interesting shops and places to eat tapas. It is easy to get lost here, but it is fun to find your way back because it is so very interesting.

Half the Barca experience . . .. We stayed in an apartment right on the border between the Barri Gotic and modern Barcelona: Gaudi and the amazing modern architecture one way and the medieval city the other way. It's the tensed two halves of the Barcelona experience, and we found ourselves going an equal number of times in each direction. The modern Barcelona soars with light; the Gotic is full of narrow shadowed streets: I'd hate to miss either side.
Stepping back in time.... Gob smacked by beauty of the cathedrals and lanes - plenty to explore! This area is a maze of squares, cathedrals, restaurants & shopping. Boredom is not an option!

A nice walk. The narrow streets just off the Rambla makes you think you are in a complete different place. I liked taking a walk here. It is not far away from really nice Spanish bars where you can have a nice meal for a very good price. A must-see in town!
QUIRKY. Excellent during the day, we wandered off the beaten track into some "interesting" areas which were really good and enjoyable during the day but be I would be more careful at night.
Interesting. This was so much fun to see coming from the US. Easy to get lost in, but so small that eventually you will find your way out.
Great place to wonder..... It's so easy to get lost in time and place when wondering the streets of Barcelona. Thank goodness for friendly locals who are happy to assist you with directions.
stunning part of barca city and history. great location to find restaurants and wonderful quirky little shops. be warey of walking around here at night though as its quite dingy!
Wandering location. Great location for wandering/exploring the many side alleys/shops. Lots of sights along the way (Cathedrals, old walls, etc).

Essential part of Barcelona. I always find the oldest area of a city the most interesting. It highlights the city's history and gives an understanding of it's development. The Gothic Quarter is easy to find and navigate around. Lots to see here so it's well worth your time, just remember to wear comfortable walking shoes. Some good tapas bars here and pleasant stores.
Interesting. The Gothic Quarter was very interesting. Lots of restaurants. You can shop, dine, eat great gelato or just enjoy the architecture

Something Special. You can wander around for hours marveling at the beautiful old buildings & the inhabitants.
Lots of shops, cafes & restaurants & pensions to stay at.
Siesta time is quiet & evenings busy, till late.
The only problem is the distinct wiff of Ammonia!!

Beautiful and unique. Definitely worth a long stroll around this area to view the beautiful architecture and narrow streets, very different to the rest of the city. Have a wonder around and take it all in! Visit Sweet Dreams cake shop, just off plaza de sant juame for a delicious cake.

Spectacular. Beautiful both day and night. Cheaper than La Rambla is general. Stroll around the souvenier shops, pop into the churches and stumble across a gem or 2. At palaca reial they offer free walking tours 'tip based but optional' enjoy your time here and dont miss the beautiful Cathedral in the centre, not to be missed!
Beautiful buildings. The gothic quarter is filled with beautiful and historic buildings - including Barcelona's Cathedral, which is free to enter.

Gothic area, Barcelona. We were walking in La Rambla and cut through to the Gothic area. This is a wonderful area to get the feel of such old living quarters, shops, walkways and churches. The streets are extremely narrow certainly not made for cars. Well worth a visit. After walking through here you can take a side street into La Rambla where there are so many Restaurants and Souvenir shops etc. great atmosphere.
Great atmosphere. The Gothic Quarter is a bustling place. There are lots of places to eat and drink and soak up the atmosphere.

Guided walking tour (book via Tourist Info) adds much to seeing the area. We took the 2 hour walking tour, booked through Tourist Information. Guide met us, group of 14, at Tourist Information in Placa Sant Juame. Interesting insights & access to a number of areas one would not normally get into without paying or visiting various sites formally. We enjoyed it. Book ahead as can get busy (2 similar sized groups that morning so different order of sites so good access).

Best place to stop for a while in Barcelona. Three things: accommodation, food, transport. It has the best of all. Plus, Barceloneta beach is 30 min by foot, local stores with clothes at every corner and main city attractions are here.
Quaint. Beautiful narrow streets lots of little boutiques & great bars! We loved wandering & getting lost & finding a lovely bar or restaurant.
Amazing. We loved this area with its narrow streets, ancient buildings and all the fascinating shops. I wish we had spent longer there. Next time perhaps.

Stepping back in time. We walked in the Gothic Quarter during siesta and late at night. We loved the small streets and looking up at the buildings. Walking in Barcelona and just looking up, you always find something to see. You just hold to your bag while doing it :)
Loved waling here. Just off la ramblas and Place Real, old Barcelona at its best, very bohemian and make sure you look up
Free concerts in the plaza. This area is within the old Roman walls. Many of the roads are to small for autos so it is great for walking. There was a free concert of local Catalonian music one night.
Incredible. What a quaint and wonderful area!! Loved all the architecture and history here. Every time you turned a corner there was something else to oooohhhhhh and ahhhhhh about. Fabulous area.
One of the few nice things in the city. Really nice narrow streets that take you back in time. All in walking distance from the Barcelona cathedral. Many little shops as well.

Interesting to all.. A maze of quiet back streets filled with delightful architecture and a photographic opportunity round every corner. A pleasant area just off Las Ramblas full of small quirky shops, restaurants and bars.
Wander and get lost!. A great way to spend an afternoon or evening, walking through the winding streets and discovering bakeries, restaurants, food and design shops.

Beautiful. Wondering around the Gothic Quarter is the highlight of this beautiful city. Atmospheric doesn't come close. The architecture is awe inspiring and there's a surprise around every corner. Can't wait to return.

Best part of the city. My Favorite!. This to me is the best part of the city for sure. Love small streets to get lost in while roaming and taking in all of the sites and shops. It was even better then i was hoping for.

Something Interesting at Every Corner. Winding streets, historic churches & shady plazas. Dozens of little cafes to get a drink or dessert or even a full meal. One of the best ways to spend an afternoon/evening just walking around.

Gothic was AWESOME!. Loved walking about the gothic quarter. many of the buildings date from Medieval times, some from as far back as the Roman settlement of Barcelona. Just walking through this area sent chills up my back especially the Remains of the squared Roman Wall! This is a must for anyone who loves architecture and history.

Very Old Architecture and Wall. This area gives you an idea what Barcelona was like back in the 12th century. It also has some very modern art pieces around the church. Very abstract and ironic. They were setting up vendor stalls when we were there but we never saw them being used.

Wonderful Wandering. We had a free afternoon and evening post-cruise and rather than spend the time on Las Ramblas, we chose to wander around the Barri Gotic. It's a great place to stroll, explore the narrow streets, admire the architecture, explore the little shops, and to grab a snack and stroll some more. We (my fault) got lost a couple times, but that was fine because we that meant we could explore new streets. The Barri Gotic has some destinations, like the Picasso Museum and the Museum of Chocolate, but it was sufficient just to stroll and discover.
Great walking ground. fantastic for a walk around and for all the little shops and tapas bars. Well worth a visit, highlight for our trip to barcelona for us.

Great glimpses of Roman past in Barcelona. One thing I noticed is how good the city has preserved the historical bits that are worth restoring. In this area, these include a Roman fortress and walls, a fine cathedral, a classic building converted not the Gaudi Museum, and massive Roman pillars that are now entrenched besides modern apartment buildings. A walking tour here is recommended.

Great atmosphere. First of all: Take your time when you visit this part of Barcelona. Be sure to visit the area both in the day and at night and just feel the atmosphere. You will find a lot of nice places to sit and rest, a lot of small stores for shopping,restaurants and art. Feel the atmosphere, the old Buildings and the small narrow streets .  If one haven't been here, one haven't really been in Barcelona!

Stay in this part of town. We had an apartment here which was awesome, so central to everything with fantastic food and bars everywhere you turn. Its easy to get lost though so have a gps phone with you. Mind you that is half the fun of the place trying to find your way home.

Touristy unless you get individual tour. Las Ramblas area is very crowded and has typical tourist venues and souvenir shops. But if you can get a small tour that takes you into the side streets on both sides of the old city it makes the experience much more interesting and satisfying. We had a tour by a local and learned much more than just walking down the main street.

A must go. We kept Barri Gotic area for last, but were sorry that we did not have time to go again. Nice little shops in interesting little alleys and also enough places to eat and drink. Better than more modern places.

Get Lost!. From Neo-Classical design all the architecture is so outstanding and such sites to behold! We decided to do our own stroll through out the Gothic Quarter, and even got a little lost, but that was an adventure in itself! Come to Barcelona and get lost in all of its wonders!

Beautiful Barcelona!. I loved every bit of Barcelona but I believe The Gothic quarters was my favourites! I find the narrow streets and grand architechtures so loveable.. it gets me every time! I was busy being a paparazzi and my friend busy shopping! So both were having a good time =)

Not an historic site, more a tourist attaction. Nice but not spectacular. A lot of tourists and people offering services, food, whatever you can imagine in the streets so it is crowded. During the night good offers on tapas and bars. Not a must visit but if you have time it is a nice experience.

Amazing architecture. Walking through the Gothic Quarter is MUST! The architecture is very unique and absolutely gorgeous! Remember to take an extra battery for your camera! You will love the Gothic Quarter!
Loved it . We had a walking tour booked to be honest I thought nooooooo ! To my amazement I loved if, steeped in history our tour guide was brilliant I loved it !!

A paradise of architecture. This is the place to walk keeping your head high all the time, admiring the neo-classical buildings. Just watch that you don't stumble. And another thing: If you're planning after your walk to leave by the metro using the passeig de gracia station, note that only two of the four entrances lead to the metro. The other two are for a suburban train. Don't get mixed up because it will be trouble. I was unlucky enough to face that, together with heat and rain at the same time. I also missed seeing Casa Mila, because of constructions. This is called bad chance. But the area is a must see.
Incredible buildings. You must walk through this part of the city to appreciate the wonderful architecture, however you might get a crick in the neck because many points of interest are high up.

Place to be in Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter mover fails to delight on any day or night. Yes, one gets lost among the narrow, winding Medieval streets, but even getting lost has its rewards, as it leads to another delightful square or tiny tapas bar. There are many significant museums, cathedrals, galleries, and other historically interesting buildings as well.
We walked everywhere. We couldn't take in enough. I kept saying I could see myself living there. The people were friendly, the food was great, and the architecture was beautiful.
A must for lovers of architecture. The Barcelona Cathedral is well worth a visit, as are the streets around it which are narrow with lots of hidden architectural gems, tapas bars, pastry shops.

Highlight of my wife's trip. The various nooks and crannies of Barri Gotic enticed my wife so much that we returned 3 times during the 5 days we were there. Beautiful churches, the Picasso Museum, lovely local eateries, handicrafts. There is a little bit for everyone.We even did a Segway tour (all Segway tours originate here)

Convenient. This area is convenient to everything. It's where the history of Barcelona resides, the Old Roman walls are here and have bee excavated and many Ipof the shops are attached to them. The streets are windy and quaint. The historic Cathedral of Barcelona is here, the Picasso museum, the government buildings, and many quaint shops and restaurants are located here. It is a short walk to Ls Ramblas and to the beach at Barceloneta.

Unique atmosphere. The atmosphere is really unique and enchanting. Restaurants, art galleries, shops and rich history in every stone around.See my review about "Runner Bean Walking Tours" in this quarter.
Lovely walking tour. Booked with Viator prior to travelling. Great experience. Good English speaking guide. Lots to see and photograph. Great trip.
Walk and look. I could go forever in this part of Barcelona. Fantastic. Take your time when you visit this part. I liked everything.
Atmospheric. Visit the gothic quarter both in the day and at night for atmosphere. Musicians abound . The cathedral is well worth a visit.
Trendy but Dirty. There are great shops and sites to go to but there is a foul odor and litter in some allies. There are also really good chocolate and gelato stores around.

A perfect place. If you haven't been in Barri Gotic, you haven't been in Barcelona
A lot of nice places to sit, great stores to do a little bit shopping. great sites of ancient Barcelona
Beautiful streets and atmosphere. The Gothic Quarter is a can't miss of Barcelona. Quaint European streets with great restaurants, art and shops. Just an overall enjoyable experience.
very interesting place. we walk all day and find more and mor ebeautiful point and places. hope to came again. very safe to walk day and night.

Awesome. Like: atmosphere, old buildings, small streets.
Dislike: some queries to Picasso museum, some bad smell on the streets
Gothic Quarter. Loved the narrow street ways. Many little shops, restaurants and bars to duck in to. The architecture is amazing as well.

Medieval Experience. Cathederal Santa Eulalia is an outstanding 13th century work of art. There are many sites throughout the Gothic quarter to take in. Great little and inexpensive bakeries/coffee shops as well.

just a great place to walk. a fabulous walk....almost information overload with so much to see! There are so many restarats and bistros....the medieval wall around the cathedral. just a facinating introduction to Barcelona
GREAT AREA. If you travel to barcelona, you must visit the Gothic Quarter. The architecture of the building are marvelous. The area is fun and hip. Many restaurants and bars to choice from.

Walk around and stop by interesting places. You can enjoy historical atmosphere, architecture and landmarks walking around Barri Gotic. There is also many good cafeterias and pubs where you can drink cup of cafe son leche or glass of cava. You can also find the most interesting little boutiques in street of Barri Gotic.

My barrio Gotic. I lived for 7 years in the area and it definitely is the most beautiful part of Barcelona. all the small streets, history can be found on every corner.
night times in some small streets to be careful!!
A great area for shopping/eating. Interesting shops and little restaurants. Beautiful architecture! We enjoyed walking around the area taking in all the sights and sounds
Pretty interesting. I would say that this is one of my favorite places in Barcelona. Full of shops, restaurants and weird characters walking around this narrow streets.

Worth a stroll!. Walking around the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona is a must: narrow streets, amazing architecture, culture everywhere! You end up having a sore neck from looking up to gaze on all there is to admire. Small shops, artisan corners, tapas restaurants, musicians, singers.. all there!
Wonderful. This is a neighboorhood from the medivial times. Wonderfully preserved! Lots of restaurants and shops. Very nice to walk through.

Great architecture!. At first I was a bit skeptic of the gothic architecture but once I walked the streets of this city, I was in awe of the incredible detail and care put into the creation of each building.
Fantastic. But busy and hot, Picasso museum is great, and the two little coffee shops nearby. Allow time to wander.
Absolutely beautiful!. very beautiful walking in this old part of Barcelona...take your time, looking up the buildings. Beautiful buildings.... Easy to get lost through those streets.

don't stay here. it is really fascinating but expensive- the Barcelona public transport system is so convenient that we recommend staying somewhere real close to a subway stop close to Hospital Santa Creu et St Pau. That way you see where the locals live and its a short interesting walk down Avenida Gaudi to the Sagrada Familia Cathedral - quite an awesome sight to see the Sagrada all lit up at night while walking locally to dinner

Unique atmosphere.. Barri Gotic is a very interesting part of Barcelona. It's got a unique vibe. This is the place for you if you love to explore. When you need a break, sit down at a cafe or have tapas at a local restaurant - What a great way to spend your afternoon!
wander to your heart's content. I've spent years wandering through the barri and I'm always seeing something new. pick the streets less traveled, there is always a delight around each bend
Definitely worth weaving in and out of as you stroll Las Ramblas. cute shops and great photo ops. pay the money to go into the Basilica and check out the prayer stations and tombs.

Great Visit Through History. Barcelona has a wonderful Gothic Quarter. Great fun to explore and lose yourself in the winding lanes. Sights, shopping and dining are all much better than Las Ramblas, to which the Barri Gotic is adjacent.
Ambling along. It has a wonderful atmosphere. It's a nice place to walk around in and get lost. There's always something to see and look at.

Very Old and Quaint. Just beautiful with its little alleys, beautiful apartment buildings, etc. The 8 year old couldn't believe that cars, etc. still used the old narrow streets, but saw for himself. There are many talented people playing harps, Spanish guitar, etc. for spare change.

A wonderful maze!. What a great area, with it's winding streets, great shops and restaurants! Easy to get lost [which isn't a bad thing, you see more that way!] so give yourself lots of time! Everyone is very helpful, so if you do get off track, just ask someone how to get to Las Ramblas!

Explore it.. Very picturesque and atmospheric with many shops/cafes ,explore it and don't be afraid to get lost (you can't really) ,watch out for the hand made signs in every street designating the size of the pathway the family names in the building and stories that happened on the spot.From Montserrat Caballe's first recitals and Pikasso's first exhibition @4cats cafe everything has a story to tell.Enjoy.

Lovely part of Barcelona. Barri Gotic is a lovely part of Barcelona. Despite lots of tourists, you can still find many lovely local cafes, bars and tapas restaurants. If you cross the main road into El Born there is more to be found. Felt really safe, nice for kids as well. Loved it!
Fun day to walk.. A shopping area of course and so much more. it has such a great vibe to the area. Found a great cafe in the area for drinks and tapas.

You must go here. With the Cathedral as a back drop and all lit up at night, its a beautiful part of the city. The Placa Real is a lovely square to sit and watch the world go by, either with a nice meal or just a cocktail. All the tiny little streets off the main squares to explore and lots of little tapas bars to stop at. The Gothic quarter is a must!

still beautiful, but it seems given away to tourists too much. atmospheric part of the city, totally worth getting lost in it for a couple of hours (especially that you cannot really get losy there))). unfortunately, it looks like given up to tourists in most of its parts

Get lost in Barri Gotic. Just walk around between the narrow streets & alleys.
if you have the time, take a 2-3 hrs walking tour of Barri Gotic
(we took a free tour with Sandman, they depart twice a day at 11:00 & 14:00 from next to Jaume I Metro - next to Suizo Hotel)
Nice quarter. Nice to go exploring between tall buildings and discovering cosy restaurants around each corner. Could feel a bit unsafe during nightime.

Best area!. I loved the Gothic Quarter for its alleyways, lots of odd shops and churches tucked away, as well as discovering Roman columns! Also found the best little ice cream shop where I had a nutella and Ferrero ice cream!!

Beatifull. Its very nice to walk the narrow strets of barcelona.
The best time to do it is in the afternoon,
maybe you can also stop for some churros and hot chocolate somewhere.

Beware of thieves!. The area is very nice with lots of cool shops, restaurants and buildings. The joy was spoiled when my wife's purse was stolen.
Lots of my friends had the same experience in this area. So - BE CAREFUL!

Alot of history and beautiful architecture. The Gothic quarter in my opinion was the best part of Barcelona. Our hotel was in the Gothic quarter and I wouldn't have had it any other way. Go at night and try all the local tapas restaurants

Happy wandering. There is so much fun to be had just wandering around the Gothic Quarter. Architecture, food, shopping, people watching or having a coffee.
Make time for it.
so much to explore. my favourite part of Barcelona lots of narrow lanes plenty to explore and discover lots of good restaurants and 'tat' shops!

Architecturesque. Ok, I am no architect but this place exemplifies the city. I have been to Paris but neat and beautiful is this Catalan city and clean too. Beyond that, it's touristy with a few local brand shops but it's a nice place to chill out, walk around, have some tapas, try some Iberico ham, etc.

Gothic Quarter guiding.es tour... excellent!. My wife and I stayed in the Gothic Quarter last week and wanted to make the most of our short two days there by taking a guided tour. After our great experience at the Dali museum in Figueres with guiding.es we decided to use them for our tour of the Gothic Quarter as well. We were incredibly satisfied with our decision.To start with the tour consisted of the two of us and our guide, a 12 year resident of Barcelona who came to Spain from Bulgaria to study tourism. It was apparent that she was in love with the city and had dedicated herself to learning all there was to know about the city, the culture and history of Barcelona. Half of the tour took us to areas of the Gothic Quarter that the other massive group tours saw (places where we ran into groups of 25 or more -- groups so large that headsets were required to hear the guide). The other half of the tour was far more personal sharing century old specialty shops, taking us places to show us answers to questions we asked and showing us historic restaurants and businesses. The gothic quarter feels large but it isn't. It seems like it should be a place that can be self-explored. However, after doing that on our first day in Barcelona and then taking the guiding.es tour on the second day we realized exactly how dense the history of the small ancient city is. Only with a guide as passionate and knowledgable as ours were we able to truly understand the history of such an important part of Catalan history. I highly recommend the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona. I also feel that if you are going to visit it and want to truly understand the place you have to use guiding.es for your tour. They are excellent at what they do and we feel incredibly fortunate to have been able to spend a few hours with our guide.

just around the corner.. Just wander around as you want. Most of the time you will be lost but eventually you will find a landmark so you can find home. There are all kinds of architectural features to see, bulidings, small squares, narrow alley ways and shops of all kinds. It's all for free so you can't fail to enjoy. I f you cant find something good then it's just around the corner.
Very nice. We took a "free" guided tour (paid about 5 EURO per person directly to the guide at the end). It was very good

Great place to wander around. The Gothic quarter is beautiful and easy to get to. you can wander around for hours and find lots of amazing places from shops to cafes to museums. Admire the architecture and the history around you and when your done is a short walk to La Rambla.
Nice old streets. Lots of streets to walk in, interesting places around. You can easily lost there and find some nice restaurant or pub to rest and drink mojitos or local beer.

OK but very busy, watch for pickpockets. Was very busy here when we visited so a little disappointing. The streets between Sagrada Familia and La Ramblas were better as there were so few people walking them. A bit touristy for my liking.
Cool little place. I really enjoyed walking around here great little side streets and amazing places to eat and drink.We spent quite a few hours walking and exploring this area

Just walk around and explore old Barcelona .... This is old Barcelona, lovely to walk around and look at all the buildings and the streets. Find your way to the Cathedral or venture off to Ramblas or even Port Vell.

wonderful sightseeing. wondering around the streets of the Gothic area, popping in and out of the little shops. Walking tour is available, but it is fun to just wonder and get lost in the area.definately at least half a day of wondering, book a tour if you want information about the area

Great place to get lost..... Spend a leisurely few hours wandering around here and take in the lovely buildings, tapas bars and small local shops. It's a world away from Las Ramblas and you will not be disappointed.
Gothic Quarter. Interesting vibrant place. Well worth a visit. Lovely Tapas Bars, and other small boutique shops, plus the history of course.
great sights. Worth a visit to see the older parts of Barcelona. Lovely little shops and restaurants up the side streets.
Lovely place to wander. Was very crowded, with some schlocky touristy stuff, but a lovely place to walk and spend an afternoon.

The best part of Barcelona. And it's free if you wander around without a guide. It's quite safe and full of tourists even at 1 am. In some of the evenings there are guys playing the guitar in the squares.
Sometimes you get lost but the scenery it's to good to bother.
The only downside is that many times this narrow streets are quite smelly.

Original Barcelona. The old city and its magnificent Cathedral stand out. The streets are even narrower than the ones in the more modern parts of the city. There is usually some kind of entertainment going on in the square in front of the Cathedral. Heads up there is a 6E entrance fee which I didn't think was right to charge for a church.
Wander Around and Get Lost. Great area to just wander around and find incredible and interesting places that show you what BCN used to be like.

Tourist Frequented Area!. After finishing sight seeing at Las Ramblas we headed for the Gothic Quarter which adjoins it & also rivals it as among the top choices for the tourists in Barcelona.Its main attraction is that it is a mix of the old,having remnants of the Roman past; & the new!Being in the center of the city with many famous attractive places close by.There are lovely cafes,restaurants & bars here specially in Calle Ferran.The night life is also entertaining & lively.The shopping is also good both in the old shops & the new attractive shops that have come up recently. The Gothic Quarter being the cultural hub of Barcelona is a place worth visiting for any type of traveler.

Good for spending time just wandering. Lovely little streets where you come across loads of little cafes, shops and museums. We spend an afternoon just wandering and looking and discovering strange little places like the Mammoth Museum and the more expected Gothic Cathedral. Occasionally you come across a larger square where it's great to eat and drink - be aware that even if there is a fixed menu you often have to ask for it as they will only offer the al a carte menu which is more expensive and eating outside has a supplement of up to 10 euros per person.

Ambianced history. Too many people, but hey, you're one of them ;0) the monastry close to the basilica is a must see, you will have to wear appropriate clothing to get in - no tops and shorts. Otherwise it is calling for both the romantics and the history interested. Personally, I went for structure, architecture and history.
Hidden gems. The small twisting streets hide small shops and restaurants that worth exploring. Don't be afraid to go for a wander off the beaten path.

Nice area to walk around. I wasn't sure if I'd enjoy walking around this area. I was wrong! We had an evening walk around this area and wished we had more time exploring! The cathedral was magnificent, the letters 'Barcelona' was cute and even going through the small alleyways was quite enjoyable. The most important part we felt quite safe.

Never bored!. We spend three days in there and I wanted more!!! Many stores and culture all around you! Loved the cathedral and portal del Angel and oh we loved Placa Reial!! At the and of the trip we regretted that we did't stayed at a hotel there!
very nice quarter. I like to walk around the small streets in this quarter specially the part without shops and manly with artist delivering live music

A Real Treat. It was march when i attended with a group of other students and was blown away by the culture that was harvested in this quarter. I myself like to indulge in the darker sides of history simply because it has authenticity and a real story behind it. The gothic quarter definitely met those standards; it was amazing to see first hand the detail in all of the buildings and the craftsmanship was astonishing. The Gothic Quarter may just have been my favourite part of Barcelona.
Really cool. Did a free walking tour centered around the Gothic quarter and it was really cool! Sandemans New Europe offers the best tours I have ever taken

Interesting and historic area. I recommend doing the historic tour offered at the tourist information office. Provided a good historical background to the area. Learnt about Barcelona's medieval history and the influence of the roman emperor. Must do for any visitor!

Barri Gotic. Narrow streets full of interesting shops. Some areas you need to be wary in. Main square has loads of bars and restaurants to meet all wallets! Lively with street performers with high police presence but purely observing
Disappointingly touristy. Not the "upscale and historic" neighborhood we were expecting. Lots of tourist shops and bad food. Very disappointing.

Most unique area of Barcelona. Barri Gotic is on the left side of the La Rambla (as you go from the Placa de Catalunya square down towards the harbour). Barri Gotic was the centre of medieval Barcelona, a labyrinth of old streets interspersed with small squares, pavement cafes, shops and gothic churches. 14th Century Basilica Santa Maria Del Pi with its shrines, cloister and medieval stained glass is particularly worth a visit. Make sure that you allocate enough time to wander, explore, relax, listen to the buskers (some of them are really excellent musicians) and take in the atmosphere. Two practical points: a street map may help you find your way around – it is a bit of a maze; and as in many city centres popular with tourists (Paris, Rome, London, etc) take extra care to keep your bags, cameras etc safe. Overall, Barri Gotic is one of the most fascinating parts of this charismatic, bustling city.
Stunning. This area has beautiful architecture and impressive buildings. It was busy with tourists, but very pleasant to walk round and take in the sights.
So much to see. An amazing, simply amazing area, the beauty of the architecture is second to none, the area is fantastic

Old and "dirty" but still the best part of Barcelona. Ok. It's old, and dark, and "dirty" . It's small and cramped. For some, it might feel unsafe (although I never felt so). I love the Barri Gotic and everything about it. The small winding passagways, the suprising twists and turns. The little stores. The little garden squares. Just like Venice, everytime you start to think you know the place, you make a turn and find out that you're lost. To me, no trip to Barcelona would be complete without several hours of aimlessly wandering the Barri Gotic.

History is alive. We walked this quarter and the history was alive for us. Around every corner there was something we would stop and look at. The buildings were unique yet beautifully old aged by many years they took on personality's all of their own.
It just shops and more shops. It's just like everwhere else. Worth a look, but nothing really to write up about. Lot's of shops mostly.
nice walk. great just walking round and seeing historic buildings and pavements also different souvenirs etc go for a wander don't forget your camera

We had a guide. Barcelona is complex...surprisingly big....so I used a personal guide from Vayable.com which employs college aged people and other locals to walk with you and tell you their experiences. This worked great here and in Paris...not that expensive as each guide has their own advertisement and they do not get paid until after you are happy....about $15 to $20 per hour is what we spent...and got that back by finding the best happy hour and meal deals I am sure.There are scary stories of this section that will curl your hair....from saints to houses empty for centuries....the deep history of Barcelona lies nearby...we saw very small places where Picasso studied and a courtyard of a school where bullet holes remain in the surrounding walls...I can only say that my wife a history buff learned new facts...so walk these streets and eat lunch in this area and you really feel connected to the past.

One day do a tour...then go back everyday and get lost!. If you only have a day or two, do a guided tour (there are lots of free ones where you tip the guide whatever you like) but if you have the time (I had two weeks) go for a walk early every morning before the crowds build, explore every nook and lane you can and you will find something new and inspiring every time!I got one of the free McDonalds maps available at the information kiosks and marked every laneway i went down to ensure i got them all.....(im a super tight budget traveler)Bring your book so when you find that perfect quite beautiful spot you can perch for as long as you desire. A coffee + croissant is 2 euro at the many cafes set in stone courtyards. For the super budget traveler (like myself) make a cuppa at you accommodation to take with you, buy a croissant at a local bakers for 0.50 euro, and you'll be grinning from ear to ear as you listen to Barcelona come to life as it has for hundreds of years. Easily my favorite part of Barcelona.

Fascinating and beautiful. There is so much to see in the Gothic quarter. Almost round every corner you will find an architectural gem! You can return time after time and still see something different.Take a guided walking tour. They are excellent value and give you a real insight into the area. English language tours take place every day from the tourist office in Placa de Sant Jaume and start at 9:30.
Beautiful. The smaller streets and beautiful buildings are a must see, also the little cafes on the corners give you a sense of everyday life in the city.

lots of small alleys to get lost. spent lots and lots of hours in Barri Gotic. the place is immersed in history. lots of historical bulidings and plazas: santa maria del mar, plaza sant jaume, plaza del rei, cathedral de Barcelona, plaza sant felipe de neri, plaza del pi and many more.lots of tapas, resturants, cafes, shops. you could easily get lost here if you don't have a sense of direction. i was walking north only to find myself at the southern part of Barri Gotic. the tapas there stay open late upto midnight (wihich is unusual to most parts of Europe).

history, Gothic arcithecture, but less then expected. It was nice to walk in the quarter for some time, the buildings form a nice unique place to stroll in. But I don't really think that is is worth the hype, though there are a few hidden gems, that you won't find, unless you have a guided tour, such as roman ruins in the buildings, that you will never tell could contain any.
Historic and artistic my favorite part of Barcelona. Lots of history as well as a hip artistic feel. It really makes Barcelona one of the best cities in Europe.
A Must. Take a tour so you can fully appreciate the area. The Roman walls and aqueducts were very interesting and well the shelled out walls from the Spanish Civil war.

Very Gothic. Our Hotel was in the Ramblas ie the gothic area. There are these little streets with shops n restaurants n the buildings look like fr mid evil times. Lots of pick pockets n gets a bit lonely in the streets so choose yr restaurants at night wisely , otherwise it's really great!

Crowded. Not as beautiful as other European old towns so my expectations were a bit high. However despite that Barcelona's gothic quarter is a must see and if you've done some planning there are great eats around the area

Buildings from medieval times. The Gothic Quarter is a medieval place located in the heart of old BCN city. The tiny and narrow streets (looking like labyrinths) are full of tourists, shops, cafés and bars! Close by you can find Picasso Museum :-) Inside the Gothic Quarter there are few landmarks that you must see: The stunning Cathedral of the Holy Cross and Saint Eulalia (also know as Cathedral of BCN), Saint James's Square, Plaça Reial and the most famous bridge in Carrer del Bisbe. Since its a very busy area, the Gothic Quarter is one of two extremely popular pickpocketing hotspots in Barcelona, together with La Rambla.
Quaint. Lovely to just soak up atmosphere,narrow rd shops architecture, can have a guided tour around the area,quite historic
Nice area for walks. Very nice quarters to walk around in and experience the atmosphere. Lot's of shops and restaurants and exciting buildings.

Gothic Quarter. I never tire of the architecture found in the older areas. I especially love the Gothic style. We were able to tour the Cathedral and walked along the tight streets. It is interesting to be walking a narrow street and suddenly it open to a square.Since the temperature and humidity was very high that day, it was nice to be shaded by the buildings for most of the time. There are lots of small restaurant and boutiques in the area. Nice way the spend half a day.
A romantic hectic immersion of sights, cuisine, and shopping. We loved the narrrow winding streets with shops and restaurants and the wider boulevards with throngs and kiosks.

Old and quaint. This is a lovely place to walk during the day. The Picasso museum is housed here and is a fabulous place to visit if you like Spanish art and the styles of this era. There is some surprising art work as well. The Cathedral is very nice and good place to go if you’re feeling hot as it’s very cool inside. Loads of places to go shopping as well.
great place to get lost. We loved the atmosphere, small bars and restaurants of the place. No Barcelona trip would be complete without a visit here.

Most Romantic Time of Our Lives. My husband and I have traveled all over, but our first night in Barcelona (Gothic Quarter) was the most romantic night ever. The history and the romantic air was awesome! We stayed at the Hotel1898 and what a great hotel. It was clean and beautiful and right in the middle of the action. It had a great rooftop bar. We rented bikes and did a tour all over Barcelona on bicycles. Our visit could not have been more perfect.
Worth a stroll. A good place for a stroll. I know it is old and a vey popular area of the town, but do something with all the graffiti. It doesn't belong.
Lovely place to wonder. Spent many hours wondering (and getting lost) around the streets. Some lovely shops, restaurants and architecture.

Loveliest area in Barcelona. So picturesque and beautiful. These quarters are best viewed at night, when there are less people (tourists) around, but of course you should walk with someone and not alone.

We really enjoyed! Not to be missed!. We used Barcelona Dreaming as our tour guides of the Gothic Quarter. There was a lot of history to learn. This and the Basilica tour were our highlights of Barcelona.
Get lost.... ...in the narrow alley ways and you'll discover a new nook and cranny of the olds quarter, whether that's a sunny square or a monument.

Wander about, get lost, find a fabulous eatery and then never find it again - but find another!. What a place the old Cathedral at it's heart, narrow paths, the Picasso museum, buskers of the highest quality, beautiful shapes made by the buildings when you remember to look up! Be careful the temptation is to look up all the time - if you do you'll bump into things and people! Endless bars and cafes the odd restaurant lots of barcelona touristy bit shops, glorious old buildings, wonderful back alleys that open onto unexpected squares with coffee or drinks outside.Too many tourists and with reviews like this you can see why!

Cool area, different from the rest of Barcelona. We did not go through this part of the city in 2009. Walked through twice this time though. Neat, old-city feel, cool little bars tucked away, just interesting to see.

Lost in the Quarters. This is one of the places that I absolutely love in Barcelona
The narrow and shadowed streets and airy squares that are full of unique architecture that I admire.
It is easy getting lost in this maze, yet I enjoyed it, wandering about and walking aimlessly discovering nice little stores.
Lifetime Memory. Exploring the gothic quarter is fun. At times you can hear guitar on small squares overlooking the side of the cathedral. Definitely worth it.

Architecture stroll. Has got lots of history and takes in among others La Rambla. The whole area provides an insight into the Catalan past and provides lots of photo opportunities with many unusual sights and buildings,

Perfect to loose yourself. A great Barri to wander around aimlessly and discover something new on every corner. From small design stores to the best Churros available (Carrer de Banys Nous 8) to beautiful little squares with restaurants and playgrounds.
A great way to spend the day away from the big chain stores.

Perfect for Teenager Shopping. A very colorful and interesting. You will not be bored. You may be a little uncomfortable with some of the merchandise but if your children are into cosplay or animay this is where you want to pick something fun up. There are also stores for you but a working suburban parent may have to let their guard down. Have fun.

Pulls you back into the ancient history of the city. Fascinating to see remains of the old Roman walls and to remember the ancient history of this vibrant, modern city. Loved the cathedral, and few remaining reminders of the old Jewish quarter. Lovely eclectic shops.
nice area to walk around. The Gothic Quarter is a nice area to walk around - a lot of stores, restaurants, and narrow streets - good places to take pictures!

Lots of interesting streets to wander. We stayed in a condo in the Gothic Quarter for a week, so we wandered the streets here daily. Lots to see.
