The tour guides we had were friendly and knowledgable as they shared the different historical and architectural details during the tour.
Worth the walking. Worth the walking, lots to see in terms of architecture and different shops to peruse. Locals are quite friendly.

Gothic heaven. The buildings and architecture around here will leave you breathless!You feel as if time has stood still here and you are immediately captivated by the sheer enormity and intricate labour of love these buildings were upon construction!Great photo opp!

Gothic Barcelona. A must see and do. The streets around this part of Barcelona will amaze you each time you turn a corner. Not only are there great buildings to admire, but if you need a moment to take a break there are many small tapas bars to take a rest and soak up the atmosphere.

A Maze You'd Like To Get Lost In!. This is a bustling maze of narrow side streets and alleyways bursting with life, independent little shops and food places, and tiny bars that were literally a bar and some stools. My eyes didn't stop moving, there's so much people watching to be had. With it being busy just be careful of your belonging, only drawback is it's another place you can't relax. While we were just sitting outside the basilica of Santa Maria we had beggars with their hands out approaching us, and going around every else. Awkward. The older Cathedral is here, but you had to buy tickets to get in, plus there was a dress code so we couldn't get in anyway. There was a couple of old women beggars with hands outstretched on the steps too. Surprised to find the Picasso museum hidden away down a side street here with a huge queue. Not a huge fan of his work though. Definitely an area you should check out, especially for those who love people watching!

Historic!. Standing on the steps where Columbus came to request money to support his journey to "India" in 1492 was such a treat. That and many other facts of the area simply brings the history books to life!

nice place. Get lost in these narrow streets, buy souvenirs and enjoy tapas ! Amazing area with so many things to see and to do, dont miss it
Excellent adventure. My wife and I walked through the Gothic Quarter. We stopped at several churches that we beautiful. We had a great time and really enjoyed ourselves.

Great part of town. We loved the narrow streets and the variety of boutique shops, artisans and cafés. It is easy to get lost, but buy a goog map at bookstores or kiosks. Make a gothic walk at the area and just enjoy what you end up discovering!
Back. My family wanted to return and return and return here. For buildings, for lamps, for tapas, for shops, for restaurants, for small squares, for history, for ice-cream.

Mixed, but some hidden gems. On one level, the Barcelona Gothic Quarter is what you might expect - lovely, windy narrow streets, medieval stone work, layers of history in the building themselves. On the other hand, it was not quite as enjoyable as other medieval cities I have been in. It was more trendy in spots, and more graffitied in spots than I would like. Still, if you can find them, there are great bits, like a wonderful fiddle/marrionette show I stumbled into in a small courtyard, and very off-the-beaten-path attractions like the oldest synagoge in Spain. Worth a wander, but nothing that was really spectacular, either.

Maze. this area is a maze . Tip : to fully enjoy i would recommend using no maps and get lost... there are plenty of shops , cafes , restaurants . Very narrow streets and crowded ......but overall a very fun experience .

Great to walk around. Wow a freebie in Barcelona, just walking about and admiring the buildings and streets. If you go to Barcelona this is required and do some of it without a tour guide, just experience it.

A walk back in time. Suspend the here and now as you explore this area. Read up on this place and understand the history behind the tiny winding streets. Look for the portion of the village wall that still stands.

"amazing". If you are into beautiful old buildings and quaint little shops this is for you.

Loved it!. We stayed in the Gothic Quarter and truly loved it. Quaint alleyways and so much history! Would highly recommend a visit if you are not staying in this area.
Gothic Quarter. Great area to walk around with some really nice little old school Spanish restaurants/bars. Go in deep to make sure you get past the tourist spots.
Lots of things going on. It's a great place to go and lots of things to see and do. Lots of shops and restaurants about. The cathedral is great too.

A place to live.. A very interesting district from the Roman times. It has everything. It has culture, it has restaurants, it has shops and it has life. Nice if you have a guide. This area is literally a maze and our tourist map did not name the streets. We enjoyed it with a local guide who made the visit very enjoyable. Otherwise, we would have not known what we were seeing.

A Must See !!!!. Amazing area with so many things to see and to do!! There are many little shops, coffee shops, beautiful buildings and many more!We loves the environment and unique feeling in this place, which we didn't see in any other city in the world! Don't miss !!!
A hidden treasure. We loved everything about Barri Gotic, beautiful narrow streets, cafés, bars and restaurants, hustle and bustle, absolutely perfect

The Best of Europe!. If you want a historic quarter that has everything, then the Barri Gotic may very well be the most eclectic, entertaining, and well positioned in all of Europe. Squares and ambling streets are reminiscent of Rome and Venice. Ancient Cathedrals, the Picasso Museum, and tapas bars share side streets in a harmonically chaotic existence. Locals and tourists mix in a vibrant melange of bustle that is interrupted daily and nightly by parades, fireworks, impromptu street shows, concerts, and stage acting. The food scene in the Barri Gotic is eclectic, exquisite and hugely affordable (think tapas heaven).But if anything, it's perhaps the location of the Barri Gotic that sets is apart. Rome has Trastavere, Paris has Montmarte, but there's no beach, major shopping area, port, world class park, and zoo within a 10 minute wall. The Barri Gotic has all of them. Barcelona's city beaches, constructed after the '92 Olympics, rival anything Southern California has to offer, with chic restaurants, wide sandy beaches, and runners/bikers/rollerbladers/palm trees galore. Plaza Espanya and Las Ramblas are minutes in one directions and Park Cituadella and the Zoo minutes in the other, and the port runs just south of the Barri Gotic with countless options for seafood and Paella.The Barri Gotic is lively, loud, historic, local, touristy, and hip all at the same time. It's everything you could want a major world city to provide!

Perfect area to stay while in Barcelona!. I am obsessed with the Gothic Quarter. I loved staying here and would stay in this section again. Not only is Barcelona my favorite city ever visited, but it is gorgeous with tons of things to do.The Gothic Quarter is beautiful and perfect day or night. We stayed for 4 days, and I want to return again sometime soon. Not only are restaurants plentiful, but shops are fabulous and around every nook and corner. It's easy to get lost, but also easy to find your way back where you need to be.Every meal we had in this area was fantastic. I bought some fun items and loved navigating through the small winding streets. It's a very lively area. I always felt safe, and as long as you are aware of your surroundings - you are left alone to get lost in a beautiful area of the city.

Certainly worth a stroll from the Ramblas to Parc de la Ciutadella. Really had a nice stroll around the Gothic Quarter (Barri Gotic), we took our time walking around the small streets and hidden gems that it had to offer enjoying all that it had to offer. Stopping in at the Cathedral and the Mercat del Born all the time making our way across to the Parc de la Ciutadella. It was a great few hours relaxing and enjoying our surroundings and popping into the markets on our way.

Epitomizes why you visit Barcelona. From my perspective, there are two reasons to take a trip to Barcelona. For the younger crowd it's to partake in the party scene while also having access to beaches. For most other people, the Gothic Quarter represents the draw of Barcelona. The unique architecture of the quarter is well representative of how distinctive the city is to see, while also having some fabulous restaurants and cafes, and shopping boutiques to spend your money. You would almost have to put effort forth to find bad food here, and you don't feel as though you are paying an premium simply because of the location (Las Ramblas, on the other hand, seems to understand it can get away with over charging). Most people would probably get more of an an appreciation of the quarter if they were to visit it as part of a walking tour, which my girlfriend and I didn't do and I slightly regret. My girlfriend and I along with another couple had a great dinner at Bilbao Berria (http://bilbaoberria.es/) and then strolled the quarter and grabbed wine at various locations nearby as part of a "quiet" evening that ended at four in the morning or so. You can easily plan either a date night or group gathering in the quarter without worrying about it being a party scene. It's probably a better place to end a day than make a lunch destination.

My favorite part of Barcelona. This was almost my daily spot...loved walking around the area...the small streets that always lead to new areas you still didn't visit..street performers and nice little shops and cafes...it off la ramblas so just enjoy a walk there if you are tired of the crowded street

Great experience!. We love our stay in Barri Gotic quarter. We rented a charming apartment via www.airbnb and live by the Santa Maria del Pi cathedral, just right in the heart of the old Barcelona. This place full of light, action, great restaurants... We will be back soon!
1 location so many things to see. Love the patisserie's, art galleries and restaurants. Make sure to check out the cathedrals and museums too.
Amazing. Great to walk the old streets and take in the old buildings, churches, museums would definately recommend a day just walking around the small narrow streets, great atmosphere
Definite. We followed the route recommended by the Dorling Kindersley Barcelona guide around El Born.Started before noon.Really good tour. Check out Basilica of Santa Maria del Mar. Really beautiful.

Nice afternoon!. A nice way to see this different architecture. You can stroll through the streets and browse the shops. There are some one of a kind shops, and some chain stores too. I did not pay to get into the Cathedral.too much to look into another church
visit. building terrific to look at lots to do and lots to see lots of shopping.had to pay to go into church which was 7 euros
Wonderful. Great architecture , recommended to visit , you need to work along the very small and beautiful streets. Also to visit a cathedral and sit in the cozy cafe)
Lovely. We walked through the Barri Gotic and it was great :) A must if you're visiting Barcelona with a lot of cute little shops and restaurants along the way!
Worth walking around. Seriously a beautiful neighborhood. Great place to walk around, explore and get lost! Near el Raval which was even perfect for us.

Gorgeous!. Really gorgeous area with twisty, interesting side streets with shops, cafe's, restaurants and a gorgeous central square. Just keep an eye out of beggars approaching you (a firm no and they walk away) but that was the only mild downside. Explore the side streets for the better value restaurants for dinner!
A great place to get lost. Take a map or you could be wandering for a while. The narrow lanes are terrific to explore and there are plenty of places to discover.

Go Back In Time ... Sort Of. I just loved wandering around narrow medieval streets with no particular place to go. A surprise may await you around the next corner.Most of the streets are lined with modern shops and restaurants, but you can still close your eyes and imagine the way it used to be 300-400 years ago. I agree with other reviewers who recommended a guded tour, but also spend some time on your own if time permits. Guided tour takes about 2 hours, but you can easily spend a whole day just walking around.

Beautiful narrow streets. Just take your time and get lost in the streets of this beautiful section. It is totally safe and your cannot really get lost. It is beautiful and full of surprises. There are lots of great local shops and restaurants along the way.

Take Time to Wander. Everything that you read about this area is absolutely true...the tiny streets, the meandering alleyways, getting lost, etc. Don't panic! Just enjoy the experience but allow yourself enough time IF you need to get somewhere as you might get turned around and need extra time to get there. There are some really great shops and restaurants in this area.
Wonderful little shops. Lots of wonderful little shops in tiny narrow streets. Very unique styles, lots of hand craft things, leather, soaps, choclates,etc. etc.

Gothic Quarter. A good idea is to get a guided tour around the Gothic Quarter as the guide will tell you about the history of the area and also hidden little gems that you wouldn't have a clue about. Our tour was a 2 hour walk with the guide talking to you through headphones only cost about 15 euros each. Bargain!

Wonderful to wander. It was great to get off of the crowded commercial streets of Barcelona to wander through this old area with picturesque alley ways and wonderful restaurants. Would highly recommend just wandering - you cant get lost but you can discover many fantastic surprises.

The soul of Barcelona. Every city has a district that personifies the character and soul of the entire town, and for Barcelona, it's definitely the Gothic Quarter. Every building reminds you of the eccentric architecture that made the town famous and these streets were the stomping grounds of legends such as Picasso and Gaudi. This district exudes history and Old World charm that only Barcelona can portray. If you pass through Barcelona and don't visit these quarters, you've missed the character of the city.
Great Architecture. Great place to visit and hang out. Beautiful architecture and a lot places to eat and have a drink. Different from everything I had visit.
Nice, but nothing special. Yes, this is definitely the nicest part of the city, but its nothing special. Nice to wander around but not worth visiting to see
Very nice but getting a little too commercial. Could use a walking map to be sure to see the key places. The Cathedral is a no brainer, very special, must see inside. Free.Street activity is fun.

Gothic Quarter. The Gothic Quarter is the centre of the old town of Barcelona. We did walking tours, first with a guide and then on our own. There is so much to see, lovely narrow streets, Remains of the Roman Wall, buildings dating back to medieval times. Roman relics. So much to see, need a map.

Lost in time. My husband and I are on our second visit to Barcelona - in 2012, we stayed in the el Born neighborhood, but this time, we rented a VRBO in Barri Gotic, the oldest part of the city. Our building is many centuries old, and I'd always wanted to "see what was behind those doors."The Barri Gotic has buildings nearly 2 millenia old, and it is easy to imagine these apartments when there was no running water. The buildings are so close together, you could jump from balcony to balcony (without being Spiderman!) and since these aren't air conditioned, everyone's windows and doors are wide open all the time. As a result, when you stay here, you get to hear the murmur of conversations in hundreds of households; children laughing and play in the street, and (when there is a festival), firecrackers all around. As I look up from my computer at this instant, I can see hundreds of balconies draped with laundry from as many families, and I can smell the aromas of cooking meals and the laughter of families together. Oh, let me mention the graffiti: Graffiti in Barcelona is an art form, not only tolerated but encouraged. It is never painted over. If you have the idea that graffiti means a part of town is somehow unsafe, etc., you don't know Barcelona. Certainly it is nothing to be concerned about and if you pay attention you will see that much of the graffiti is very well done, and preserved with pride (some shops commission graffiti for their rolled-down shop doors; when the shops are open, you don't get to see this art form much). All my experiences in Barcelona, including Barri Gotic, have demonstrated it is safe; keep your purse closely at hand and your wallet deep in your pocket, because some pickpockets might take advantage of your attention being elsewhere. But harsh crime is almost unheard of.In the USA, we live in single family homes with lawns to tend to; rarely do we hear neighbors. (This is where we get it wrong.) Here, the city is dense with people going abut their lives, doing business, having families.... and it feels like the heartbeat of Gaia.Spend a day getting lost in the Barri Gotic and you will stumble across charming shops the size of a closet, tapas bars not much larger than a living room, and so much more.Fabulous! This week, I am privileged to call it home.

Arm yourself with a good map to enjoy this labyrinth.. The streets of the old quarter are a delight to wander around with so many treasures waiting to be discovered but it's easy to lose your way among the myriad tiny streets and lose your sense of direction so if you are trying to get somewhere specific a good clear map saves you time.

I loved this place. I have always loved the narrow streets and the Gothic style, so for me The Gothic Quarter was the best attraction In Barcelona. I enjoyed wandering in these streets, taking pictures. That afternoon i spent there is unforgettable and if i go back to Barcelona, i will search for a hotel in this area!

Wonderful walks in the lanes. We went for a guided Free Walk Tour by Runner Bean on the first evening there.It was a tour of the old city and it really gave us a wonderful perspective of the narrow lanes along with the stories behind them.After that, for the next 3-4 days we wandered around this area almost eveyday and really enjoyed doing some window shopping, stopping for a bite to eat and generally enjoying the maze of streets. Very pleasant even in the bright afternoons.
Charming area. Small streets, old buildings, I really enjoyed the feeling what I have got there. Just walk there, and enjoy every corner. Its a must see.
Nice Historical Center. The gothic center with its narrow streets has a very unique look and feel from other parts of the city. It's definitely a must to stroll through this area while in Barcelona.

Muy excellente barrio...so much to see/do...just start walking.. Barcelona is just a terrific city w/ lots to do...and if you had to spend all your time in this neighborhood that would be fine given the plethora of cafes, bars, restaurants, museums, architecture, outdoor music in summer. Can't go wrong.

Very worthwhile place to visit. A wonderful place to visit and to stay. Our hotel was in La Rambla which really comes alive in the evening although there is much to see and do during the day as well. The mime artists are amazing. There are so many restaurants in the squares just off La Rambla. The food is excellent and the prices are reasonable. Even the buskers that entertained us were talented. Just be aware that if you chose to eat at one of the restaurants on the main thoroughfare you will pay considerably more for everything. If in doubt, ask to see the menu before you are seated. A worthwhile place to see.

Cathedral in Gothic Quarter. It is well worth the 6 euros charged to go into this Cathedral. Be sure to go up in the elevator to the top of the church. Great views. Don't miss the cloister with the swans swimming around. Beautiful inside. Great square outside the church with local entertainment singing, dancing, playing instruments, especially on the weekends. Found a great little restaurant there also.Wonderful sangaria.

Nice. Certainly full of tourists, but very interesting with our guide. We went to the market and sampled food, which I recommend. The hawkers of junky toys on the Ramblas was extremely annoying so I am glad we only went there once.

My favorite part of Barcelona. This area is full of small winding streets, small shops selling things from cheap tourists trinkets to hand made jewellery. The architecture is amazing, every turn you see something new. Spend a day and prepare to be lost, this part of the city is a maze. Try to keep your bearings on where La Rambla is so that you can get out when your ready.

picture worthy. Stroll the narrow streets and explore the churches and tapas bars. Check out the Picasso Museum. Yes, the area is full of tourists, but also full of history and beautiful architecture.
Must visit if you're a history enthusiast. Beautiful old buildings, lots of history and a very nice place to walk around in Barcelona. i would recommend everyone to visit this old quarter of the city

Great place for shopping. This area is very famous for small shops. Lots of souvenirs and authentc "Made in Spain" only items can be found here. Although there are other shops and vendors that carry similar items but made cheaply and are imported elsewhere so beware. The small alleys and streets are like a maze and you can venture and get lost which we didn't mind since you can discover the hidden souvenir treasures of small shops.
Enchanting. Give yourself an afternoon to get lost amidst these meandering laneways and streets. Enjoy the boutique shops, cafes and bars that line them. What a delight!

Walking in the footsteps of medieval Barcelona. Lovely atmosphere in the original old part of the city. Visited once and kept going back just to soak up the sights, sounds and feel of the place. Great food at Venus deli cafe. On the way back to the hotel, around midnight Saturday night, there was a woman with a beautiful, trained voice singing opera in the street next to the old church. It was wonderful.

No other place to be. Seriously, do not stay anywhere else if you are going to Barcelona!!! More bars and restaurants than you could ask for, all servicing delicious food, cheap drinks and with awesome staff that are keen to talk to you and give you good service. I could have wandered in those narrow alleyways for days discovering bar after bar.....
Historic atmosphere. Good to stroll round and take in the atmosphere. Mirada of side streets and squares. Take a seat at a street cafe and take in some tapas and just people watch.
Every Turn reveals something to see. Like the title says we were taken by all of the interesting things we found as we strolled and explored the Barri. Had some of our best meals there as well
Enjoyed it completely. Take some time out of your trip enjoy the architecture around the Gothic Quarter, check some of the market shops near the Plaça de la Catedral de Barcelona. Wonderful
very cool. If you love architecture then this is a must see!! The winding streets, the narrow ways are very cool. I loved it!! In the mornings its very peaceful

Beautiful, but priced for tourists. This area is full of gorgeous buildings and plenty of history, but restaurants and cafés charge ridiculous prices because tourists are silly enough to pay them. We were also disappointed by the rubbish toys, souvenirs, knock-off designer goods and gimmicky crap being sold on the streets - it reminded us of Phuket's worse side. It also did not feel particularly safe. Visit by all means, but eat elsewhere and watch out for pickpockets.
Old buildings and many shops. It is very interesting walking there and discovering Gaudi`s first masterpiece: the cathedral. don`t lose a walking through it.

Do Not Miss if in Barcelona on a Sunday!. The Gothic Quarter itself is wondrous to walk anytime with winding streets, cafes and tapas. However, on a Sunday early afternoon, the square in front of the cathedral fills with locals dancing traditional dances to a full band. It is is fun, solemn and extremely moving. That's the wondrous thing about Barcelona - the pride of the Catalans. Should not be missed.
atmospheric. Lovely to walk round then sit with tapas and drinks outside a cafe watching the world go by. Cathedral is impressive
Fantastic!. Just wonderful to wonder around these narrow winding streets and find treasures from the past and present. Don't miss and bank on spending a fair amount of time getting lost there!
amazing history. A fascinating place to wander around. the old walls running through the area are amazing and just a street away is the 21st Century

Beautiful. Lovely part of Barcelona. Spend an afternoon and get lost there. Lots of places to eat and drink. Stunning architecture and a beautiful Cathedral. We walked out of a side door of the cathedral and into a little square where a man played such beautiful violin that I was reduced to tears. Amazing.

oldnes but cozines. you let yourself to get lost in the barri gothic ... it´s amazing what you can find-small stores, local stores, organic,/natural stores...and above all the feeling being "lost" in there is just amazing
Beautiful. Lovely area to stroll around nice bars cafés and boutique shops the buildings are beautiful you could wander around for hours admiring the area

A trip into another world. The narrow routes through the Gothic quarter, and historic locations found there, are best appreciated with a guide. Many unique shops and beautiful courtyards and squares make this a fascinating adventure.

Very interesting. We were walking by foot, all day,and its great if you have time, to go there, feel the spirit of the town, sit in some of the interesting restoraunts there. Barcelona is the place that you must feel, so if you dont have time to feel the town, you wont know the town :)

Great Alleys. We had a great time walking through the tiny alleys and looking up at the architecture. Though the walk through the neighborhood is great, after having tried many restaurants in the area, I would recommend eating elsewhere (most of the restaurants seem to serve microwaved tapas).

interesting and fun to explore. Cruising little alleyways, aware you are walking in an area that is thousands of years old. Lots of little shops, restaurants, bars, plazas around each corner. You never know what is around the next bend. Small and walkable area
Nice. I liked it very much, as my husband is interested in Gothic art, we visited this Quarter, including the Cathedral. Nice, a lot of sculptures and paintings...

Endless photo opportunities. This area is amazing, the architecture of the buildings are so interesting and fabulous. There are lots of side streets to explore which lead to more suprises of shops and markets with local produce, take an extra memory card for all the photo's and a larger pair of pants for all the tapa's !! The markets have delicious cheap tapa's and snacks at a great price.

Great for a Wander. Take a stroll, day or night, people watch, eat at a cafe, the atmosphere is superb. Some of the cafe's insist you eat as well as order drinks at certain times of the day, but there is plenty of choice.

Very Historic and Very Clean. I love the history of this area. Take one of the free walking tours - runnerbean or Discovery. I stayed in this are for 10 days and easily found my way around the city. Restaurants are good but overpriced. I enjoyed grocery shopping at carrefour (bring your own bags) on las ramblas and buying my own sangria, bear, cheese, serrano ham, eggs etc...

Nice place to take a stroll. Nice place to take a stroll and really emerge yourself in the the city, if you like walking this is a must because of the narrow streets and plazas walking around this area is a great day out.

This part of Barcelona is fantastic!. When you are walking around Barca I would advise you to keep looking up - otherwise you will miss the amazing and lovely old (and new!) buildingsThe Gothic quarter is just,lovely - narrow streets with only old buildings, and then suddenly you emerge into a hidden square and the sunlight lights up the area with warmth and lovely light. There are innumerable little cafes, bars and restaurants in this area. It is really quite large and will take you a while to see it all, but if you don't have time to do that, just a couple of hours will give you a real feel for the place.

A must see on any visit. There are lots of little pedestrian alleys, so it is very pleasant to walk around and see all the old buildings, Even on a hot day there is plenty of shade. Lots of the little squares have amazing modern sculptures in them. Plenty of cheap places to eat.

Love The Old Part of the City. Returning to Barcelona after 29 years (I lived there for 4 years), it was as if I never was gone....except there were more tourists. However, that was not a problem as it was not as crowded as was my last trip to Rome. Rented an apt on Argenteria (right off Via Laiteana), so was able to enjoy this area from the "comforts of home". Loved all the small streets with wonderful shops, tapas bars and atmosphere. Ran out of time to explore a lot of them although we were there for 12 days. Definitely a return trip in 2015.

Gargoyles & Narrow Streets. This part of the city is very old. Here you will find some very interesting gargoyles, shopping, several good eateries, churches, and the Picasso Museum. Shopping here is not of the high end variety. Here you will find mostly import shops and souvenir shops. The highlight for me in this area was the Picasso Museum, which has many of his early works.
Check it out. Fun area - the cathedral well worth it. the tapas bar on the corner also a great place to eat lunch or dinner(downstairs). Dessert tapas are yummy

must see. I could spend a hole day there, nice places, old bulidings and good little restaurants and bars. lot of shops for souveniers are there and of cours many museums, like the museum of modern art and picasso museum.
wonderful. Very very nice. Well mantained and with a lot of small roads very typical and inviting for a walk looking here and there.

Narrow streets with lots of charm. Our group wandered the Barri Gotic for several hours during our visit to Barcelona. The Jewish Synagogue, the old Cathedral, narrow streets and wonderful shops make this a must do while in Barcelona.

NICE PLACE. An excellent HOTEL with a charming host and great facilities. Very stylish, the rooms were beautifully furnished. The location though was very tricky to find, so I'd recommend a map or else you'll be assisted by 'local help'. Apart from that, its an excellent hotel I'd wholeheartedly recommend”

Beautiful part of the city.. If you like to wander around ancient winding streets and get lost in a new city, then this area is for you!The picturesque buildings and plazas provide an apt background for picture taking. There are many sites to see including La Boquería and Catedral de Barcelona, and are all close together, unlike most other attractions in Barcelona which are spread very far.

nice place to get lost. The Barri Gotic is a nice place to get lost, and escape the hustle and bustle of las ramblas.... there are some nice little pubs and restaurants and the best way to explore is really just to get lost...

Ancient and modern, sedate and quirky. We followed the Lonely Planet Best Walk: The Old City in a Day. We didn't enter all the churches since they all charged a fee but the exteriors were impressive and we loved the architecture of the alleyways. If you want something quirky, have a drink in the truly weird Boise de les Fades next to the waxwork museum off La Rambla.
Great area off the beaten track. Really enjoyed exploring this area and discovered a hidden gem in Placa George Orwell which contained a few awesome bars.

Like traveling back in time. I loved the winding lanes and unique shops. The cobbled streets look like they could tell a lot of stories. I enjoyed it most because I had no place to be and nothing to do. I could just wind around, lost at times, and just wonder about the history here.
Like a spider web. Very, very interesting area with narrow streets that spread out like a spider web. Lots of history and handsome old structures.

So much to see. My wife and I spent many hours just getting lost in the narrow lanes and streets. Popping into shops, bars and great eating places.
If you don't do the Gotic on your trip you have short changed yourself. Do a walking tour, we booked with Runner Beans and it was great. Highly recommended.
Narrow streets. It was good with some narrow streets and old architecture. However, unlike Madrid, there isn't a lot to do in the gothic area except for looking around.

Very touristy but worth it. Typical of what you will find in other old mediterranean cities. Little winding streets open to plazas. Small shops and artists everywhere. A twist though is that there are some very modern artworks in some of the ancient plazas, which makes it fun and surprising.

Lovely architecture. This part of town is really beautiful to just walk around in. Full of delicious tapas bars it's worth spending an afternoon walking around, enjoying the sights and secrets hidden round every corner and just seeing what you can find!
Great day out. Loved it all can get a bit to crowded look out for pick pockets. Lots of shops and things to see very old and well gothic

Charming Buildings. The Gothic quarter was a great surprise for us when visiting Barcelona. Wandering around is great fun and a fantastic way to discover restaurants and wine bars. Wile there are a number of groups of young guys selling drugs (note the red beer cans!), they seem harmless enough as it is a busy area with many tourists. The charm of the narrow streets and countless small bars and restaurants is definitely worth a visit. We stumbled on one bar with great live music (jazz) and and an incredible arabic / tapas restaurant neither of which we will forget!

Amazing twist and turns. This is one of the four quarters and a really amazing one. Find the Iron Gate off of La Ramblas as that is the original gate to Barcelona, there is not a gate just a marker and small muriel and enter. There are great hidden spots like court yards, Roman Columns, wonderful shops, and people. It is not a great place at night unless you know where you are going as it is easy to get lost.

Outstanding shopping!. Not only is this a remarkable area to see so many historical sites, but the shopping is a treat here also. I just wish we had had more time to spend and larger suitcases! This is an area you must visit while you are in Barcelona!
Wonderful Walk. We went on a Tapas tour with Barcelona Taste in the Gothic Quarter. This is such a beautiful part of old Barcelona. Take a few hours , stroll, enjoy gelato and tapas.

cosy little streets. nice little shops, small streets, amazing old buildings (architecture)
be carefull at night for robbers
Beautiful. This place is a must to visit! Get lost, walk through narrow streets. I took a tour to this place and liked it a lot.
Worth visiting. Picturesque, great contrast with other features of the city, such as the waterfront. Narrow streets, interesting shops and cafes.
walk & enjoy.... Its an area which is full of small shops and winding narrow streets, you never know when you will end up in a beautiful square! A stunning area to discover just walking around!

Great walking area. We enjoyed a walk through this area on 3 occasions. The restaurants are fantastic. We spent time on the hop on hop off bus so getting here was easy. The Cathedral is nice landmark.
Beautiful. We visited the Cathedral which is beautiful and then wandered around the quaint streets and squares. Absolutely delightful.

Noisy, busy and lots of fun. Some great restaurants and bars our particular favourites were Sukur (restaurant) I had the Hake with asparagus and it was fantastic. Also Cuevas del sorte, bar on carrier de gignas is a great bar with dancing downstairs and best Mojitos in town. Say hello to the lovely Sulin for us

must visit especially if you like to shop. I love the alleyways and architecture. Me and my girlfriend much preferred the shops there than on las ramblas. We spent about two hours there.
it has a good atmosphere. Would have been nice to have spent longer.

Well worth spending time walking around. Walk around with a guide book or go on a walking tour it is well worth spending time and effort. You can imagine going back in time in these streets and alleyways with many galleries and museums. Remember most government places are closed on Mondays but are free on Sundays.
Great place to walkabout. We went here as part of a tour but returned again. Good atmosphere and lovely old buildings. One of the maim must see areas In the City.
Wander the narrow streets to find little shops. I would recommend taking the Barri Gotic tour offered by the Tourist Office. It is excellent with very good guides at a reasonable cost.
Enjoyable stroll!. Take a stroll through this area to enjoy less clouds, better prices on souvenirs, foods and drink! We liked this area much better than Las Rambles!

Wonderful Place to visit!. Gothic Quarter is one of the areas that you should visit if you come to Barcelona! It is full of typical places and wonderful monuments to discover.
This is the central tourist boulevard in the city which is popular not only among the sightseers but also among the local citizens who like to flaunt her one before another. Enjoy it
A marvelous way to spend a day!. Wandering around the streets of the old city was a marvelous way to spend an afternoon and evening. Their seemed to be a surprise around every corner.
Gothic Quarter. Loved walking around in this area. It has the essence of history and modern feel mixed in a lovely balance
Beautiful. Nice stroll within the Gothic Quarter with its narrow and beautiful streets. Worth the stroll. Many small shops, some are even not expensive. The atmosphere calm and easy

Historic and car free. We stayed in an apartment on the Ramblas on the edge of Barri Gotic. Enjoyed the atmosphere of the old streets although we got lost a few times. Time your visit to consider when the stores are open. We went first on Sunday and a lot of the stores were closed, and on other days some were closed in the afternoon.
Take a free guided tour with TripAdvisor guide!. This is ideal to get to know the streets and bearings right. The TripAdvisor guide was excellent and we only had to tip her.
beware of pick pockets. Lots of shops and places to wine and dine. But be streetwise and always look around you and keep your bag in front of you at all times.

Great walking around this quarter. Brilliant, we enjoyed walking around and exploring this area. The history is amazing.
We visited this area after being at the Picasso Muesum.
It is well worth a visit.

Great Place to Visit. We spent the last evening of our Spain vacation touring this area. We loved the Gothic Quarter with its wide plaza, the beautiful cathedral and all the shops. After visiting the touristy shops, be sure to wander through the better quality shops for beautiful clothing. I found a sweater shop that had sweaters of several different colors that were made in Barcelona. I would have bought one of each color, but the shop only took cash.
Wow. The place is absolutely beautiful. Stayed at Hotel Montecarlo on the La Rambla so the Quarters were directly behind the hotel and very easy to get to. lots of fun shopping!

best part of town. While the Ramblas gets the publicity this area is much more interesting. We shopped here and took an evening tapas tour at 4 small tapas bars. One of the oldest, if not the oldest , part of Barcelona this area has numerous churches , shops and restaurants. Unlike the Ramblas it is much less touristy and more old town beauty. It is a relative small, very walkable area and is quite unforgettable. Reserve a day and an evening for this beautiful section of town

This is Barcelona. A pleasant walk through the narrow streets, with many shops, bars and restaurants and historic buildings. Just off La Rambla, and we felt we had seen the real Barcelona having trailed the alleyways and byways. A wonderful experience.
Absolutely fantastic. Just being there was so magical. Took a tour which was amazing and very personal and went to the best ever local market off Las Ramblas

Take a walking tour!. Interesting from an historic perspective. Along with the Basilica of the Sagrada Familia and the Park Guell, the Gothic Quarter is one of the major tourist attractions in Barcelona.But, for my money, the one site to stay and linger within the Gothic Quarter is the Picasso Museum. For art lovers, it's a MUST SEE!

Lovely area to walk, but disappointing as far as a historic quarter goes. I had been hearing for years about the fabled Barri Gotik of Barcelona as being a most fantastic area to visit. Oh of course it's lovely to walk in all those streets (and it must be nice to be in the shade in the summer), but at the end of the day, except for a few historic buildings (mostly churches, most with an entrance fee), it's rather disappointing as far as history goes.Don't expect much. The cathedral is fantastic (and free in the mornings, but mobbed), the old roman aquaduct and gate is impressive and there's some nice churches... Oh and if you can find it, there's also the ruins of a Roman temple inside a modern atrium... But other than that, at the end of the day, the fabled Barri Gotik is just a labyrinth of streets full of restaurants, cafes, souvenir shops and Desigual shops.Plaça Reial is a nice square, but I would avoid eating there and the Rambla, near it, only holds interest for the many pickpockets who are waiting for the unsuspecting tourists.Don't get me wrong, it's a very nice area to stroll if you're visiting Barcelona, and it certainly qualifies as something to see.It's just not what they're trying to sell you in tourist guides.

Gorgeous medieval maze. A simply lovely medival maze of little streets, shops, and cafes you can get lost in for a couple of hours. If you want to go into the main church on the square, DO observe the dress code - they turn people away for wearing shorts or short skirts!

Super cool. Like a spider web of alleys and tiny backstreets, every turn brings new and interesting things to see and do - it is just so much fun to get lost and explore the Gothic Quarter, you can spend an entire day there very easily.

Great place to get lost. Forget about the map, go with time and walk and walk around the countless narrow streets, taking in the sights: squares, chapels, museums, gorgeous Gothic architecture, great markets. Cannot miss it if you are in Barcelona.

Narrow streets and beautiful squares. That's the beauty of old Barcelona. This is the area that makes this city unique. Prepare to get lost, and then find yourself in a beautiful square with amazing architecture.

Like a maze. Loved the Barri Gotic. Went on a guided walking tour around the neighbourhood and learnt all about the history of the area and why things are the way they are. Charming little streets which can get slightly confusing at times. The narrow streets and old houses of the Barri Gotic have made for some of my favourite photos of our time in Barcelona. At least have a walk around it!
Good to Walk. nice shops and restaurants, very nice architecture and churches located throughout. Good for a nice stroll.

just wander. Wander through the narrow streets and just imagine the days gone by. There are so many cute shops and interesting people and if you are lucky enough to be there when the school lets out - you will have the treat of seeing all the cute little kids going home chattering with their parents.

Stroll down the past. What a wonderful place to wander - lanes and alleyways full of interesting and quirky shops. Architecture truly Gothic, some amazing gargoyles. Around each corner is something different to look at and admire. Also a great place for tapas and lunch, cheaper than you would find in the more touristy La Ramblas.
A must see. Lots of interesting nooks and crannies to explore with bars and restaurants and interesting buildings at every turn

Walking around the past. This is a lovely area of the city, with narrow lanes and small squares packed with interesting shops and cafes. It can become a little crowded at times, and you're likely to get lost. But just relax and wander around. Part of the pleasure comes from just going with the flow and realising these quaint, small and occasionally confusing streets have been here for hundreds of years.

If you are bored here then it's your own fault. We stayed at a nice hotel in the gothic quarter. Get a couple of blocks off a Las Ramblas and you can find some fabulous restaurants and stores. We spent hours wandering around. The architecture is second to none.

narrow pedestrian streets to wander. A fun way to spend an afternoon- great tapas bars, quirky shops, old Roman relics. Spend an afternoon wandering these streets. It's a great way to feel the Barcelona vibe.

You will get lost; it's inevitable. This section of town is what makes Barcelona the unique destination it is. Here is the medieval and romanesque juxtaposed with the modern and art nouveau. You likely will not encounter the same street twice and really no maps can help you. The Rambla south of Catalunya, should be avoided in my opinion but it makes for an orientation. You may also see the Miro sidewalk mural on the Rambla by a square near the big market (closer probably to Theater Liceu). There is a great place for churros at Carrer dels Banys Nous, 8. It's a tiny place where you can get these great chocolate churros that are also chocolate covered. For one Euro, 40 cents you get about 5 in a paper cone.

Wonderful and eclectic.... It's a historic patchwork quilt of tight maze alleys and surprising plazas. Shops are diverse and while tourist-y mainly, they are fun to look at when you get tired of just gawking and walking, looking at the structures and balconies, Roman relic buildings and baroque bits. A wonderful area.

Stunning architecture and a beautiful stroll. Make sure to visit the Gothic Market, located on the grounds outside of the cathedral. The Gothic quarter is home to some fabulous restaurants, incredible artisan shops, and absolutely stunning architecture. A must-visit!
Flavor of Old. Loved the cobblstone streets and the feeling of being in Barcelona from days gone by. Lots of shops and restaurants to chose from.

A most pleasing ramble. You can lose yourself here, in the Barri Gothic, or old Gothic Quarter of the city, as the tiny lanes twist and turn, meandering past cafes, boutiques and artisan dens. It's a slice of Catalan life in all its quaintness, sans slickness. And it's been spruced up quite a bit prior to the Expo they had in Spain in the 1990s, and is safe. Cats love it too!

Amazing!. I am a lover of Gothic art and architecture, and walking in this barrio was an amazing experience for me! I stopped and stared at the buildings several times, and I've taken so many great picture because the light in this place is amazing, so remember to bring your camera with you! It's a walk to remember, getting lost in this place feels great!
Wonderful. Love the twisty turns of the narrow streets and the variety of boutique shops, artisans and cafés.It is easy to get lost, but enjoy what you end up discovering!

An opportunity for a good wander with hidden gems. Without a specific destination we enjoyed a good wander around the gothic quarter, lots of quaint little designer shops, and plazas. Even found a authentic coffee shop that did fantastic cakes and the like, including chocolate covered churros, which were simply devine!
walk around and get lost. quintessential old town Barcelona. Plenty of interesting buildings, stick close to the catedral, shops, bars and restaurants.
Cool area to walk through. I enjoyed this area including going to the Cathedral Barcelona. I had lunch in this area too. Lots of restaurants and good people watching.
Interesting but not spectacular. Take a tour of the old Gothic Quarter. It's not nearly as spectacular as the old cities in other towns but it is interesting to give you a feel of the old city.
Beautiful area, great architecture. The centerpiece of this area -- the cathedral -- is simply gorgeous. Don't miss it. We did not go inside although I am sure it is stunningly beautiful.

Perfect place to get lost in. This is one of the nicest neighbourhoods in Barcelona. Getting lost through its streets and getting to know small squares, churches and amazing shops can be really amazing.
Fabulous!. Real old world Spain, the buildings are awe inspiring, some rather bohemian types wandering around, which added to the atmosphere-a must visit if you are in Barcelona
Quaint part of the city. Loved walking through this part of the city. Plenty of bars and resaurants. Be sure to take a map as you can easily end up lost in the small winding alleys.
Great location to everything and our hotel was here. We stayed in the gothic quarter. Our hotel H10 Raco Del Pi is located in it. Perfect location to enjoy Barcelona.
Charming. Love the medieval maze of streets along with the dotting a rustic bars and cafes. Could walk around this neighborhood for days!
Lovely area to wander around. We spent a few hours happily wandering around this area. It's architecture is delightful with lots to see and places to eat and drink. Don't miss it!
Beauitful area to get lost in. A beautiful area to get lost in. So many beautiful buildings, church and squares! I would not recommend it however when there is a political riot!
shopping mecca. This area has a great variety of shops in varying price ranges. Fun place to walk around, window shop and/or stop for a drink.
loved it. very cool and pretty with lots to see and do. loved the neighborhood very safe and cool things to see.

Just wander...... Spend a whole day just wandering the web of streets and alleys of the Barri Gotic, remembering all the time that this used to be a Roman village, something new and interesting pops up round every corner. Take you time and drink cafe solo, eat churros, then a light tapas lunch.

Loved this area!! Unique history and architecture!. Very old area of Old Town Barcelona. We spent five days walking up and down small alleys and into building, churches, tapa bars, stores, and just sitting watching the people. This area goes further back than the Romans. Roman ruins are still viewable in the area. Spend plenty of time exploring and reading information of this areas history.

Surprise around every corner. We were lucky enough to do a free (donation accepted at end of tour) walking tour of Barcelona's gothic quarter early on our first day in Barcelona which was a fantastic introduction to the city. Getting a first hand look at the medieval city as well as remnants of the ancient Roman city was truly fascinating. It's a 1.5 hr walk so put on some comfortable shoes and be ready for a fascinating historical perspective on Barcelona. Most central hotels close to placa Cataluña will have information on walking tours around the gothic quarter. Don't miss a visit to La Boqueria market and look for the artisan shops and cafés that have plaques installed on the pavement in front of the front door. This is recognition by the city of Barcelona that the store has been carrying out the same use for a very long time, in some cases over 100 years
Authentic. Just wonder around in the narrow Streets, get a bit lost, experiment to have something to drink and eat in one of the numerous small cafes

A Must See In BCN. Stunning little streets to explore and some great little shops to visit. There is a really amazing ice cream shop down here too if you want to see and some great restaurants in the square in the middle. I would say this is close to the main and happening area!

Nice historic place. The feeling you get, walking on the alleys of Barcelona is incredible. You start walking and exactly when you think is nothing to see or you are lost, that when you find the gigantic churches and etc..Very nice place to go and walk around. Love it

Lovely but tiring. If you want to really enjoy a family walk around this area I would recommend that you give yourself goals (either plan to end in a café or give yourself 'spotters goals' like number of different styles of balconies / tiled floors, largest door knocker etc etc) so that you don't become overwhelmed or overtired with the wandering and looking.Its fun for grown ups, but a bit baffling for children - and you need to hold on to them as well as your bag / purse when it gets crowded!

Vibrant city combines tasteful antiquity with hip experimental modernity.. This quarter is the medieval heart of the city,somewhat confusingly named. Strolling between the protective walls to discover the tremendous royal palaces,to admire the cathedral,dominating everything and to see the impressive rival,the parish church of St. Maria del Mar,can easily imagine ourselves to be in a gigantic and living open-air museum,with narrow-alleys which wind like ravines through historic residential areas,only intruded on by impressive palaces in the wider streets and squares. Life pulsates in this picturesque because young occupants have moved within its venerable walls. Now famous galleries and elegant businesses and hip junk shops mingle with traditional and ultra-cool bars all benefit from the charm of the historical buildings,vibrantly combining tasteful antiquity with experimental modernity.

Wander around and get lost. Yiu may be a little intimidated here at night to just wander around but it is really the best way to see this area. There are many bars and restaurants tucked away that you won't find if you stay on the beaten track. Just be street smart and you will be fine, during the day, a great place to find a seat and a beer and watch the world go by.

Charming area. Charming area of Barcelona; fun to walk through the maze of tiny streets and alleys to see where you will end up. There are lots of shops, restaurants, bars, etc. You can end up in some areas that may take you out of your comfort zone, but overall it is a nice place for some leisurely strolling and refreshments.
Beautiful quarter. A wonderful place to get lost in Barcelona and explore the bars, restaurants and architecture. We loved it!
Lovely, buildings are so nice. Sunday morning local people dancing and tourists joining in. The area is so clean and nice to wander around and you must go into the Cathedral.
How cool is this place?. We had WAY too much fun running around the Gothic Quarter. Epic architecture, and really good people, not too touristy.

A real medieval exploration!. We used the Rick Steves self-guided walking tour through the Gothic Quarter and had a blast! Plenty of awesome places to stop along the way for tapas, Cava and delicious Damm Lemon beer. Take his self-guided tour or book a guided one for a great half-day of lost-in-time exploration before or after a visit to the Picasso museum. Be sure to stop by the El Xampanyet Champagne bar for delicious tapas and sparkly refreshments. Check hours for both Picasso and for El Xampanet.

Great place to make camp. Stayed here for a week and a half. Great place to make camp. Very easy to get anywhere in the city, plus walking the alleys of the Gothic quarter always turn up little gems of cafes and bars. Food is great in most places, especially off the Rambla and in the Mercado..

Forget the map, getting lost is the aim of the game here!. The gothic quarter is a maze of tiny little streets, built way before Barcelona was divided up in to regimented blocks. Tall buildings line narrow roads, with fantastic architecture, every twist and turn takes you further in to this fabulous fairytale part of the city. There are tiny bars and restaurants a plenty, we struggled to find bad food and drink anywhere around here. You'll find a bar or restaurant here that you will fall in love with, the only problem being when you go back to find it again another day, you'll get lost and end up finding somewhere else just as amazing.

Little streets with a big history. Lots to see and do while just strolling through the streets taking in the atmosphere. Plenty of shops to explore, bars to relax in, cafes to eat in and churches to marvel at.

Lovely to meander. We really enjoyed just walking around here. The church is beautiful, even though one does contemplate how much good work the gold would pay for. There was street entertainment (but not 'in your face' and the area felt very comfortable clean and a pleasant place to be.
great for a walk. nice to see this old center, great for a walk, a lot of bars and restauarants to have a drink or get a snack
busy. loved the bustle , lots of little alleys and then squares to sit at. loved the whole feel of the place. felt safe all the time
WONDEFUL. A very interesting and quirky area full of good tapas bars and restaurants plus the amazing cathedral. A bonus is on Sunday at 1100 there are people dancing a traditional dance
Gothic. What an amazing area . Great spot for lots of photos, and a good spot to people watch if you score a nice table and chairs in the sun with a few drinks its a great spot to relax.
Romantic!. Great place to go for a walk, shopping in small local stores, sightseeing and great for a night out, dinner and bar!
Must visit. This is really beautiful. We walked down the narrow streets in this area and we loved it. The narrow streets will take you to the sea and that is also a must see-thing.

Do get lost here! Walk, eat, drink and discover. This area in Barcelona easily became our favourite place to go. Include the connecting Ciutat Vella (Old City). The maze of small streets that fill with tourists at day, comes alive at night. Walk around, have a drink, continue, shop a little, find a place to eat (many good restaurants). A place to really enjoy a city trip, relax in a big city.Don't worry, it is hard to get lost as it is not that big. But for sure, you can go there 7 days and do 7 different routes. On our next trip to Barcelona, I'm sure we'll get lost here ... again!

Typical European Old Town. just walk and walk, and eat and shop. Lovely place to just wander and take lots of photos . Make sure you get off the main street of Farren and Ramblas to really experience it.
Old European city. The old streets and interesting churches were more than we hoped for. Lots of good places to eat and interesting street entertainers.
Beautiful. Beautiful area, a must-see. Nice to just wander around, discover the little boutiques, beautiful historic buildings, eat tapas & chocolate with churros.

Great vibe. We stayed here in an apartment . Lucky for us! Centre of everything. A short walk one way to the harbour and a short walk in the other direction to the shopping in Las Ramblas. Santa maria del mar is an amazing church which entices you in to sit and contemplate. Great Tapas restaraunts every where and little shops. Definitely stay in this area.

Very nice atmosphere at night. In this area you find many restaurants. However, you don't even have to go for a restaurant in order to enjoy the area. Just walking around in the night is amazing, as you will see a lot of activity in a very nice environment.
Historical, sunny and alivr. Full of museums, historicsl sites, restaurants, bars, interesting shops. Jewish city inside. Ancient city walls. Cathedral and a lot of churches.narrow streets also.

Get lost in time. Have a stroll around and take in the beautiful buildings and old churches. I would suggest you set aside at least a morning to stroll around to take it all in. Many touristy places to eat, but I would recommend you go off the beaten track and find a gem the locals go to.

Old Barcelona at its best. We loved this part of Barcelona and enjoyed exploring the old narrow streets lined with lovely little shops that were different from the 'tacky' tourist ones.We also enjoyed eating in the squares surrounded by old buildings full of character and loved watching the world go by.

Loved it. . Walking and exploring this area is really a great way to spend some time. The old winding streets lead you around the next corner and you don't know what will be there. You can get lost but that's the adventure. There are lots of shops to explore. I found myself heading back there whenever I had time. And one other comment. This is a very very clean city.

Beautiful part of the city. The gothic quarter is a beautiful part of the city with lots of character to it. the streets are very narrow and have a lot of variety to them. The architecture of this area is what makes this area so special and is worth a look

Loved staying in this area of the city. We stayed at Hotel Colon before our cruise and were very happy with the location and ability to walk and experience the Gothic Quarter. Plan on devoting some time to explore the streets and alleys of this area to find shops, restaurants and historic buildings to admire!

Must visit. But you have to make a plan, as with number of small streets and turns you can lost your way and simply miss some details. It would take a lot of time to walk each and every street of Barri Gotic, but even if you have just few hours to stroll around, you will get a sense of the rich history Barcelona has.
Intriguing dark, narrow streets. We found a great little bakery with wonderful chocolate-dipped churros. Lots of interesting little shops.

Worth time and a little prep.. This is an interesting and important part of older Barcelona. It retains a lot of character and is obviously still a focus of several aspects of city life. We ate in several good cafés, enjoyed the Cathedral and the Picasso gallery. We discovered two of the best tapas restaurants/bars we have encountered anywhere. Although the area responds well to the flaneur approach there are several bits you could easily miss and later regret it. Spend half a bottle of local wine on a comfy chair with a better guide book. Or scan down the Tripadvisor listings.

Fun to to get lost in the winding streets. My wife and I did a walking tour through this very old section of Barcelona. Well worth it as otherwise you would pass by a building or structure and not know the historical significance.

Great Place to Wander into the Medieval Time.. There are so many places to visit in Barcelona. Even with our four nights stay in this city, we seemed to rush from place-to-place and still could not visit all the places we want to see. However the Barri Gotic with its proximity with the other sites of the must-visit, we happened to pass it several times. Walking through it allowed us to find different new interest we missed before. The different light angle in different time of the day also created varieties of photo opportunity. The Barri Gotic is a must and do spend the appropriate time to appreciate it.

Great neighborhood to wander through. This was a step back in time. There are lots a sights like the main cathedral and plenty of shops and restaurants. We simply wandered for hours and just soaked it in. It's easy to get lost but just as easy to get back to something familiar. We went during the day and night and always felt safe.

The best part of the city. The last old part of the city, narrow old streets, old way of life and still really inhabitted. At the borders of this city part you can visit old cathedral (for me better than Sagrada familia) and Plaza real - really historis places. And - a lot of people everywhere

wear comfortable shoes. It was thoroughly enjoyable to wander through the streets of the Barri Gotic, though very easy to also lose all sense of direction, or find the shop you had passed previously. Plenty of photo ops, small places to grab a bite to eat, and lose yourself in the past.

Great area off Las Ramblas. As you stroll down the busy Las Ramblas you coma across the Gothic Quarter and what a contrast. Stroll along the narrow streets and take in some very old and interesting gothic architecture

Fun Place to Walk Through!. I really enjoyed walking through the gothic quarter while I was there. There's lots of fun shops and interesting architecture. I walked through at night, which was a beautiful way to first see it. The next day, a Sunday, I went to the cathedral (definitely peek in if you're nearby - as long as you're dressed appropriately!) and watched some of the locals perform a traditional dance in front. I got a great feel for the local culture there!

Nice old neighbourhood. One of the most beautiful part of the town.Just let your footsteps to lead you on the narrow labyrinthine cobbled streets and admire the architecture of the beautiful old buildings.Some landmarks that you'll find here are:La Mercè basilica,Carrer del Bisbe,Cathedral of Santa Eulàlia,Plaça Reial,Church of Santa Maria del Pi.You will also find a lot of nice little restaurants,bars and cafes.

Just Walk & Lost A While. Beautiful architecture, narrow streets, lots of people like wandering in an unknown place for a little while, don't worry you'll not really lost at the end of the road you'll see the La Rambla signage .. There you go-- prepare to see the famous La Boqueria Market infront of Sex Museum with Marilyn Monroe dancin' in her famous moves at the balcony of Third Floor...

Barri Gothic. I loved this area. The streets are small and wind in every direction and it is easy to get lost (especially at night) but the buildings are amazing, the shopping and little bars are very cool.
excellent!. just wantder thru the streets and observe, excellent architecture, history, restaurants and all. Make sure to watch Sardana dances in front of cathedral on Sunday at noon.

Well worth a wander. Lovely to randomly stroll around and get a feel for the city. We really enjoyed the atmosphere of the area. More than enough cafes and terraces to give your feet arest and soak in the area.

Get lost in the past but watch your wallet. This is an absolutely exquisite part of Barcelona but, seriously, leave your passport and valuables in the hotel safe. Muggers and picklocks are on the lookout for unwary tourists. Keep your wits about you, travel in a group and listen to your instincts. We met several people who had been robbed in this district.

Beautiful place to wander!. I stayed in Barcelona for a few days after my cruise at a hotel near the Gothic quarter, and spent my time primarily there, wandering the alleyways. Check out the Picasso Museum and pig out on tapas! The area is also home to a FANTASTIC upscale restaurant with exquisite food that is not to be missed is you are a foodie like me, Montiel. Don't miss wandering this area when visiting Barcelona!

There is a romantic appeal to this old and vibrant part of the city. I loved the variety of shops, cafes, and crowds of people. It was a lively experience as we wandered through the streets and shopped for our family and friends.

Romantic place off the beaten path in Barcelona. My husband and I had a romantic photo session with Joan of Filma-T Productions in the Gothic Quarter of Barcelona where he showed us all of the historical sites of this area while photographing us. This is an incredibly romantic place in Barcelona. It is definitely worth a visit with the one you love.
lovely walking around. my daugther (14) where there both in the day and in the evening. lots of nice shops and place to eat. something nobody should miss if in Barcelona
Like going back in time. Have you ever seen the video game assassins creed???? If so this area is like that! Another must see in Barcelona. Fantastic architect Loved it

Our Favourite Area of the City. Spent 5 days in Barcelona in an apartment in the Raval close to Las Ramblas which was nice as it had been 5 years or more since we had been to the city and hadn't seen much of it then. When we go back, and we will be will be searching for an apartment in the Gothic quarter. Beautiful streetts packed with history, great food an drink.A lovely atmosphere too, roll on our next trip

Really nice historical area. I did a walking tour around this area and it's steeped in history and is just a really nice area to walk around and admire to architecture, lots of little shops and cafes to check out as well.

Beautiful, great food.. Were stayed in the Gothic Quarter and loved how close we were to everything. Great shopping and food nearby. Every street was fun to explore and it was fun to just drop into different places for tapas and beer. Loved every moment.
A mystery tour. Lots of lovely windy streets, each hiding quant restaurants, shops and bars. Lovely place to amble round and get lost

If you've seen one ancient quarter, then you've seen the Gothic!. Great to walk around and capture a sense of old Barcelona. If you've seen numerous historical districts(we have) then this one doesn't present anything different. Plenty of cute little boutiques, cafés, etc. If you have a limited time in Barcelona there are other attractions that are much more worthwhile.

got lost and ended up here. What a fun night. left our hotel heading to the Rambla and got sidetracked on diagonal streets. ended up in one of the exciting neighborhoods we have ever been in. so much fun. places to eat everywhere, people, shops, excitement. don't miss this incredible walk through an amazing neighborhood
Loved it. Lots to see and do, just wander along and go with the flow. Lots of history with fountains and churches and statues. Lots of good shopping and food. Seemed safe to me.
near to my heart. an historic part of town AWAY from the mainstream &&&& luxury shops ..... where real people walk, eat, shop & enjoy 💃
The oldest district. Barri Gotic is the oldest part of Bareclona - everything else was taken down and rebuilt. Go to the civic museum to see how it happend.

Lose yourself in history. Great place to get lost for a while. Daytime there are shops & little boutique, craft shops down all the narrow alleys. Lots of cafés as well. turn a corner and see history and the real Barcelona everywhere you look. NIghts are as good as plenty of bars and outdoor cafés in the old squares

Great Area to Visit. Wonderful area to visit in Barcelona.Great little restaurants.Alleyways give wonderful sense of
old spanish architecture. Fun area for whole
family
Fav Part of the city. Amzing place! So many brilliant shops restaurants bars and people. Make sure you spend some time getting lost here.

Medieval mystery streets. Go get lost in the labyrinth of medieval streets in Gotic. Loads of atmosphere at night. Just watch your stuff. It's true what they say, Barcelona is a pick pocket's paradise.

Another world. We never got organized enough to follow an official walking tour, so we missed some key spots, but we went through once in the day and once at night and enjoyed it very much. I especially liked stumbling across the Sombreria. The area is perfectly preserved and quite wonderful.

Wonderful Area to Spend Time Getting to know Barcelona. The Barri Gotic (Gothic Quarter) is a fantastic area to spend the day or if you have less time the afternoon walking around to absorb the culture, history and ambiance of Barcelona. The area is charming and is filled with old world architecture including the old style gas lamps, alley ways, building facads, etc., and you can imagine what life must have been during the height of its period. The first time I experienced this area was back in 1975 and have been back four more times. Many shops and cafes have popped up in the Quarter but the architecture and charm still remain. The area is vibrant and all ages will enjoy their time spent here.The area is very busy most times of the day so watch your pockets and purses.
A nice and touristic place. Take care when you visit this place, many pickpockets in this crowdy borough. The streets are narrow and very typical. A lot of restaurant at affordable prices.

Very Old. I loved the small streets, obviously built before there were cars because the occasional car can barely get through. But so noisy at night. The people out at night may not realize how loud their voices are echoing off the 5 or 6 story buildings surrounding the squares. I stayed in an airbnb room in someone's flat, and the building was ancient, but quite functional and clean.

Really impressive. The Gothic quarter has several of the attractions I enjoyed most in Barcelona including the Picasso museum and the Basilica de Santa Maria del Mar. It's also great just to wander around there, really interesting history and visually really impressive.

Fun, Intriguing Area of Barcelona. My wife and I spent an afternoon walking the narrow winding streets of Barri Gotic. What a treat. Then shops,are fantastic and varied and we had a great lunch there as well. Wonderful way to spend an afternoon or morning.

The heart and soul of Barcelona. You could not experience a trip to Barcelona without spending a lot of time in the Gothic Quarter. The many placas, churches, the bocqueria and other attractions made this the highlight of our trip. We were not particularly impressed with the Rambla itself and only spent one trip down it and then skirted over to some of the side streets where you see the life of the locals. The Rambla is a street divided by traffic going down the middle. We did not see anything very interesting on this street other than restaurants and other typical shops. I guess everyone has to see for themself.
much better than La Rambla. Really enjoyed walking around here...much more so than La Rambla. Feels like you experience the town more as La Rambla is just for tourists. Nice vibe early evening.

The Life of Barcelona. El Barri Gòtic is an excellent neighborhood, having lived here for 4 months. It is one of the oldest parts of Barcelona, and represents a convergence of ancient and modern culture. Lots of bars, restaurants, close to La Rambla, and great architecture all around!

WONDERFUL historical area!. I love this area of Barcelona with all of its varied history and gothic architecture. Get lost in the narrow streets or take an informative walking tour. Always busy, I like early morning the best.

Nice for walking. This section of town has narrow streets filled with shops and tapas bars and other restaurants. The buildings are old and quite ornate. You could easily spend a whole day enjoying the atmosphere of the area. If you come to Barcelona you should see the Gothic Quarter.
Absolutely splendid . The winding alleys, the little restaurants, the colossal architecture, the street performers, a treat for the soul. i kept strolling around for over 3 hours !!

Great sites and shopping, but count your change!. Beautiful narrow streets full of bars, restaurants and shops. Sadly on 3 separate occasions (during a 3 day stay) we had clerks/vendors give incorrect change during purchase transactions (this is not by accident).There seems to be a trend among the less scrupulous vendors to provide a small bill(s) and a handful of random euro coins when one tries to use a 20 or a 50 euro bill to purchase a low cost (<5-10euro) item. Count your change, explain your vendors "error" and if they persist in not responding a loud call for "policia" will swiftly bring them around and get you your correct change.
Brilliant!. Enjoyed what little we saw of the area...will be back again in the future as we didn't have much time (or energy) to explore in its entirety!

Jewish walk through the Gothic Quarter. Learning about the Jewish history of the area was really compelling. The guide at the former synagogue gave a fantastic overview of what life was like before the expulsion of the Jews. A must see at a reasonable cost.

The heart of Barcelona. One of the main charms of the city is this ancient area, full of winding narrow streets, unexpected squares, small artisan shops and galleries, and open air cafes and restaurants. We had several walks through the area and enjoyed its quietness and picturesque nature. Make sure you take the time to enjoy this part of the city.

Beautiful part of Barcelona. Barri Gótic is a beautiful historical part of Barcelona. It is located in center not far from La Rambla. YOu can find here the gothical cathedral which you should visit as well.

Interesting maze of streets and shops. Great place to spend AT LEAST one afternoon. We actually spent two afternoons there; the first afternoon we checked out the place with a free walking tour with Runner Bean (it was excellent!! Gorka was our guide and he was so knowledgeable and interesting to listen to) and another day on our own just wandering the streets. And there was still so much we didn't cover :)

Take a walking tour. Without a guide one misses a lot of the story behind the different buildings eg. - the facade of the main cathedral was added much later! Lots of interesting history and buildings and shops.
Something for everyone who visits...... The historic sights, the restaurants, museums and shops. All located in a wonderful walking area of Barcelona.

Interesting History. If you enjoy learning about history, take the time and get a tour guide to show you around and point out interesting locations. Its worth the time and expense to explore this portion of the city.

Great place for a stroll....during the day. These narrow alleyways and lanes are beautiful, so many winding streets and little shops to let yourself get lost in but they can turn quite nasty at night. We finished up dinner one night and decided to go for a walk to look for a bar but on every corner there were groups of lads selling drugs, drink and I'm sure other stuff as well if you asked. The streets are so narrow and can be quite dark and I found it a little intimidating.
old Barca is nice. I would reccommend the Seu/Cathedra in that area - then you have to remember that you need to be properly dressed, entrance is for free.
Some fantastic tapas bars. Get your self lost within the gothic quarter. Try as many local tapas bars as you can . So welcoming Catalonian families....just be aware of the pick pockets
Heart of Barcelona. Take a two or three hour walk through this area. Good shopping and good places to eat until late at night.
Authentic Barcelona. Great location to stay and absorb the 'real' Barcelona. Definitely need a detailed map unless you have time to spare to find your way around the tiny streets.
History at its best. Must see part of old Barcelona city. Keep looking up, as the sights in general, plus the amazing architecture is nothing short of stunning.

Very Good if Done in a Guided Walking Tour. This area really has a unique atmosphere with lots of historic nooks and crannies to learn about. However, unless you already possess a good knowledge of the city's history, seeing it as part of a guided walking tour will really help you get the most out of this attraction.We booked a free walking tour with Runner Bean (They have a review page on this site) and I think it really made a difference in how we saw the area and how the different aspects were interpreted to us by a knowledgeable guide.I can't imagine that this quarter would be half so interesting if you tried to do it on your own.

A charming little piece of history in the centre of town.
