same as others. this place has many shops and cafes.. quarter is same like other old cities quarters. but this is a symbol of barcelona so need to visit.

Needed more time. There is so much to see. I took a tour with Alex Steindorf via Toursbylocal. We had 3 hours and it wasn't near enough time. There were so many small places, churches, and museums to visit. The tour was great for orientation and history and finding some small niches that we wouldn't have ever found. A definite must when in Barcelona.

DARK AND HISTORIC. Again the area was one of huge interest and the tiny shops selling everything imaginable were brilliant, the terraces, Catalonia flags flying, galleries, tea rooms, washing hanging out, just need a sneak preview as to what the flats/rooms are like. One of the few other places I would like to live (once I win the lottery)
Fun place to zig zag.. Get lost in the Gothic Quarter and explore unique shops and restaurants. Great place to take a break from walking, grab a snack and watch the people go by.

Nice to visit.. Recommend a guided tour to learn the interesting history, followed by browsing some of the old shops, or lunch/dinner in one of the many nearby restaurants. Not too far to walk from here to Port Vell.

Cozy atmosphere. A great place to wander around. Perhaps it would have been best to get a guide and learn a bit about its historical background yet it was still nice to walk on our own and admire the area. Occasionally there were groups with guides and you could get away with some eavesdropping. . Plenty of small charming shops. Lovely narrow streets, the architecture can't go by unnoticed..
beautiful Cathedral. well worth a visit, locals dance to music from a brass band in the square in front of it on a Sunday morning.

My absolute favourite. This area of Barcelona is my personal favourite. The streets are narrow yet full of history. Spend at least half a day walking through the streets, stumbling upon quaint boutique stores and treat yourself to some nice wine n tapas in one of the local cafes in the bylanes. Cant do Barcelona without at least a few hours in Barri Gothic.
Really old buildings. Lots of really old buildings and nice architecture. Easy to reach by metro or bus. Shopping street nearby.

Untouched medieval town. Beautiful, complete amazing old city. Not harmed by wars or stupid mayor who nwish to destroy and build anew. Great Medieval city with surprising narrow alleys and romantic corners.

Gothic Quarter. Get a guide and see it all. We learned so much from our guide, that we would of never seen or known on our own. The history of the area sets you off to discover the rest of Barcelona with a better understanding.

Not what you'd expect. Filled with street merchants, urchins, drug dealers and prostitutes (in broad daylight!) this is not exactly a family friendly part of the city, although at the same time very touristy. Nothing Gothic to be seen here as most of it looks like it was built around the beginning of the 20th century - it is only the fact that it's very dodgy and poorly maintained that it passes for old and authentic. But it's not.

great. a little bit of ancient history - old Roman walls and mideval church. Wonderful small shops tucked into old buildings selling everything. went during Christmas season and it was fun and festive.

Wander around and step back in time. Great old area of Barcelona - walk around and explore old and new with some cool shops. You can spend an hour or better still a morning taking in the sights and sounds - Must do !!
Great place to wander. Great to just wander and get lost, there is something beautiful around every corner. Lots of bars and restaurants for rests and tapas.
Wonderful architecture. I could have walked around here for many more days than I found myself amongst fascinating architecture & also unusual streets lined with magnificent buildings.

I recommend to see. The best part of Barcelona. Alongside are many attractions combined with beautiful typical restaurants, shops and boutiques, local markets, theaters and attractions and of course the most popular La Rambla.

Narrow streets, great bars.. Like a different Barcelona the Gothic quarter is all narrow streets and atmosphere. There are great little craft shops, brilliant restaurants and around every corner some new piece of street sculpture. Don't visit Barcelona without seeing this part of it.
Fantastic. beautiful small shops here and there on the qaint narrow streets. felt very safe and clean. surprised a the amount of dogs people were walking but added to the freindly family feel

Walk back through history. We enjoyed the Spanish architecture, but under the city of Barcelona are the ruins of a Roman city that are you can walk through. I think it was at the Barcelona Museum, but just ask around -- cant miss it.

Lose Yourself Without Getting Lost.. There is something for everyone in this part of the city - shops, bars, restaurants, cafes, squares and interesting monuments. The area has real character and is a refreshing antidote to the more touristy Ramblas nearby.The better shops and bars are to be found in the section towards the Plaza Catalunya and the lower part towards the seafront feels a bit more down market. The street layout is not complicated and it is unlikely that you would get lost or confused. The whole barrio feels safe but after dark it would be wise to avoid some of the narrower streets where there are few people.It's a great place to wander around or to sit and watch the world go by, it costs nothing and it merits repeat visits.

nice. the church around this area is nice to see. we only did a walking tour to this area but i think if u are around it is worth the walk. i think the michelango museum is in this area as well. this area was once the beginning of the city
Very Unique Neighborhood. Enjoyed walking around. Like no other neighborhood in the world. Old buildings, narrow streets, great shopping and Tapas.
Gothic Quarter. Fascinating area to spend a few hours wandering. Great little restaurants and bars, lots of independent shops plus the history and architecture.

not to miss!. Completely surprised by this unique district. Didn't expect that we can found this type of tiny cute streets in a European city! the Gothic architecture of some buildings is breath-taking! worth the visit!!

Great place. A real gem neighbourhood. So many places to see, so many restaurants to try out. It is full of people night and day. Narrow, romantic streets with beautiful lanterns. Felt really safe, too. Really good.

A maze of streets. You can spend hours juts wondering around the tiny back streets with weard and wonderful shops. You come across little square with lovely cafes. Be aware of muggers in ceratin areas, if you stay to the busy parts you should be fine

Interesting and charming. A really nice to have a walk around and to explore. There are number off nice bars, tapas joint and little squares to sit down and watch the world go by with a coffee and some cut hamWhen you visit Barcelona, this area is a must, little shops, church' and art galleries.
Walking tour. Took a free walking tour which was really good - geography, history, culture and politics in one! Barri Gotic is full of charm and hidden delights, well worth exploring.

Nice small streets. It's hard to explain Barri Gotc in a view words. You're in Barcelona so it's inevitable that you'll end up in Barri Gottic at some point. Nice to stroll the small streets, when not so full of people.
Charming. A lovely and very interesting part of the city. Worth a wander around, with quite a few nice bars and restaurants to stop at.

You can take a lot photos here. Lovely place to stroll around.
Try some fresh cut ham in the small shops, they put it in the bamboo cone.
A must in down town.

Great place to get lost. A really nice place to spend some time and get lost wandering around. You can quickly forget that you are in a major city. There are many restaurants and shops and some sights too, but just spending time meandering is time well spent here.

Lost in History. If you want to spend a few hours in history you must go in Barri Gotic.Old buildings, narrow streets, majestic churches,cafes and small shops,a lot of people and happiness, this is Barcelona!
Amazing. Make sure you allow time to wander round the Gothic Quarter. There are some walking tours available (with Guide).

history. The gothic quarter is well kept historical part of the town.,the narrow streets,squares with wells,little shops,elderly ladies chatting away,little balconies with flowers etc.There is a lot to see and a lot to take picture.
so much so interesting!. full of interesting sites, wonderful architecture, and cool history. fabulous cathedral and other medieval structures. great tapas place right on cathedral square!
nice small streets. narrow old streets and buildings.nice restaurant , ice cream parlours, cute shops.special atmosphere.do not arrive too early.
travelbar.com. fascinating. The tour guide was so knowledgeable.This was a highlight in Barcelona! We leanrt so much about the city and its history and the history of Spain as well.
Nice place to walk around. Lots of small shops and alleys and easy to get lost in. Go in the daytime when its more safe and enjoy the architecture of some of the buildings in the area.
Gothic quarter. Loved it! Loads of little alleys to wonder around! Lots of great shops, bars and restaurants! Fantastic architecture, spent a whole day and still didn't see it all!

Don't miss it. Love this area. Bit of a maze but who cares if you get lost. You're on holiday. Never had a problem in Barcelona re crime. Just don't draw attention to yourself and keep to areas that are recommended and don't wonder off the recommended areas. Gothic area is amazing.

So much fun. Unusual shops and Cathedrals. First: I wouldn't go here for clubbing. Since the clubs in Barcelona open so late... and some of the alleys reek of urine during the day. The daytime and evening are perfectly safe. We spent hours here, and discovered the most amazing outdoor market. A store that sold large clown heads (I want one!), churches, great food...

Gothic Quarter is amazing!. It depends of course which country you are coming from. Some people have this type of old centres in their own place, so they may not be impressed. But for me, it was fantastic, to stroll along the cobbled narrow streets. Many interesting restaurants. In the night you feel a little scared in the little dark streets, but still the feeling is great. Of course if you are in Barcelona, this is a must visit. There are also the cathedral, and some museums. Loads to discover

Very interesting!. The walk into history was very interesting, especially the cathedral of Barcelona! All the shops and restaurants and weaving in and out among all the buildings made for a great couple of hours!
Favourite part of Barcelona!. Such a gorgeous part of Barcelona, I loved walking through all the side streets, especially Pl. St Jaume and the surrounding areas. Must see!
Best naborhood in BCN!. The tiniest streets, best athmosphere and a lot to see. I chose to move here. Dont miss Barrio Gotico while in Barcelona!

Great History Place to visit in Old Barcelona. Take a walk thru the old town and see the cathedral, shops and restaurants hidden between buildings, the narrow streets and seeing artists stores, stopping and having a glass of fine wine, let yourself unwind and think of the history.
Beautiful. Beautiful old streets with a lot of shops and cafes. If you are asked to see a Flamenco dance, accept!
Must see!. This is a must see in Barcelona! Excellent old streets and alleyways! Lots to see and a lot different to the rest of Barcelona! Explore, don't use a map, enjoy!
Lost in Barcelona. Top tip for Barcelona, just walk and walk and get lost in all the little avenues and you will find all the great spots like the Gothic Quarter

Beautiful part of town..... The streets the buildings..... so old, if they could talk..... a nice part of town to walk through unrushed. The churches are interesting, the buildings are a treat to look at. A nice area to spend a few hours.

A mesmerizing walk. We explored the Gothic quarter on a late afternoon and saw a lot of queer Gothic structures. Visited the Church of Santa Maria, Placa Sant Juame and a couple of other landmarks. All these buildings were unique and the pleasant weather added to the Christmas season made it a very nice experience. A lot of squares has Christmas market on, all so colourful and bright
Loved it. Very beautiful quarter, worth visiting! We spend few hour there, enjoyed every minute! However, the weather should be nice

A wonderful precinct for pedestrians. Ramble down from Plaza Catalunya to the Museum Maritim, a stroll of 1.5km and divert into the lanes of the Gothic Quarter surrounding the Cathedral, for a wonderful experience. There are a huge number of shops, market on different days; any amount of restaurants and attractions. Visit the Four Cats, so beloved of the artistic circle in old Barcelona and still an amazing place!; eat icecream and buy curios; visit the Cathedral and all the pother places of interest.The Gothic Quarter is fantastic; exactly what every big city needs for soul!

Go and lose yourself, literally, in the alleys.. Nice old buildings, narrow alleyways, great shops and food. You'll hit the occasional church. Stop in to shops with delicious food displays and give it a try, you won't be disappointed...at least I wasn't.
Beers in the gothic quarter. loved bar 13 - its tiny but quality. right in the heart of the quarter. plaza reill isnt worth seeing if you know about madrid, too pricey and lacks atmosphere

bring time, good shoes and your wallet. love love love....meander, stop, sit, listen, enjoy....it's so much fun to discover what's around the bend. and don't worry, it's not that big to get lost, eventually you'll hit La Rambla...just follow the streams of people

Gothic Quarter One of my favorites. This is one of my favorites in Europe. The Gothic Quarter in Barcelona Spain is a lively area of this great city. I was lucky to find a vacation rentals apartment right in this area which I enjoyed very much.
Quaint streets--something on every corner. Loved wandering the narrow alleyways and history of the area. It's a great way to spend an afternoon getting lost here!
Cute little streets. Really beautiful small streets which make fantastic photos as well as really transport you into the heart of Barcelona.

Cool. This place is very chic and is the kind of area where you can walk around for hours and just soak up the Catalan atmosphere. Make sure you don't spend all your time here though, because there is lots more to see and do!

Atmospheric and pictoresque. Beautiful place, one of the most inspiring areas of Barcelona. You can and you really want to get lost in the narrow alleys of this historic quarter. The final touch is the sound of a classic guitar that echoes in every alley. This area is in fact also populated by many guitarists playing their notes at every street corner. Some of tem are real talents too. Really nice experience.

Lovely Stroll(s). We stayed very near the Gothic Quarter and loved strolling through the back cobble-stoned streets. We found ourselves going back to wander through most days of our week long trip to Barcelona.

I love this area. Beautiful part of Barcelona city, and you can get great tours around the area. I went with my family on a tour with a group called "Orange Donut Tours". Absolutely wonderful tour guide, with a great knowledge of the area. Beautiful place.

Atmospheric, historic. My first impression of this area coming from an inner city background, was that it was not a place I should be after dark. How wrong I was! The area is comprised of narrow alleys (streets), with Gothic walls on either side, and broken up by inviting boutiques and wonderful restaurants. Every so often these streets open up to charming squares that often house magnificent churches. Absolutely charming!
Barcelona's Gothic quarter. Stone's throw from our hotel so we could stroll there at night for restaurants and shopping. Daytime for history

Wonderful small streets to get lost in. The shops and old buildings are worth a long stroll thru this quarter. If you can, take a RunnerBean walking tour of the Old City. There are wonderful places to eat and shop hidden in all corners of the quarter.
Glad i had the chance to Visit. I really enjoyed this Area and was very lucky to have a walk around after using the hop on hop off Bus

Don't spend your $$ on La Rambla, go further into the Gothic district. If you turn off La Rambla anywhere, and walk in a block or so, you can save a considerable amount of money on food and drinks. There's everything from Falafels to Paella, popsicles, liquor stores and all kinds of shopping. The architecture is amazing, and there was so much to see. We loved the inner courtyards all over, where we could stop for a glass of wine and feel like we'd stepped back in time. There were several very affordable liquor stores / grocery stores where we grabbed snacks and wine to take back to the hotel with us. This area was my favorite in Barcelona.
Lovely. Pondered the morning round the Gothic Quarter looking at all the different buildings. It was nice to go back in time and see some of the history.

A Great Place to Stay. Brilliant place - funky tapas bars and restaurants, great hotels and apartments and excellent shopping. A must visit or great place to locate yourself in Barcelona.I had been warned about La Ramblers as it has a bad history of pic pockets etc so we stayed here - much more chic area of town and the food was cheap and excellent (not to mention the wine). Close to the Zoo, Parliament, The Port, Gardens and plenty to do. All walkable - even if you have kids!
Enjoyable way to spend some time. I just liked walking all over. Wonderful shops, and and great little places to get churros, and a "cafe con leche".

Easy to Get Lost. This is a nice place to just wander around looking at the sites. Stopping in the little cafes and shops. Skip the map, it doesn't cover all the alleyways. Just wing it, get lost, find cool stuff, and find your way out by pure luck.

A fabulous mix of old and new. We spent about a whole day, spread over two days, walking around the Barrio Gotic and El Born, looking at the eclectic mix of old and new buildings and shops. It is an amazing place, managing to link the past and the present quite seamlessly. We were never pestered or threatened and never felt unsafe, despite the narrowness and enclosed feel of some of the lanes/roads.

Very interesting!. I liked very much the atmosphere ,the monuments ,the little shops and the fairs !I The architecture is incredible beautiful and some of the large shops housed in ancient builds are good examples of a modern shop established in old building but without killing the beauty and the soul of it !!!

Why you can't go back again. 10 years ago, we spent a week in Barcelona in an apartment in the Gothic Area. All over the neighborhood there were fantastic street performers. We even had our own violinist under our window. I'm wondering after our last visit if they were having a festival at the time. On this recent visit, there were huge crowds everywhere. The little shops had been replaced by international chains. And not a single street performance. The worst is that I attempted to find the old apartment area on a Friday evening. I finally found the right street, and it was roped off for an auto rally. This further condensed the crowds, plus the noisy smelly cars running the home stretch. The most worst is that at the end, in front of the cathedral, they had a huge loud speaker announcing the results in stentorian tones. Fortunately, this ended after 5 minutes, and my friends had kept me from running away. I found the apartment. My true goal was to find the lovely wine bar across the street in the basement of a 14th century convent. I found it. It's a ticky-tacky clothing and junk store. Disappointment!!!There are many good things about Barcelona (concerts, museums), but it's dropped off my list of favorite places.

Pedestrian Paradise. Lively shops, bars, restaurants scattered over large area of narrow winding safe streets. Pedestrian traffic very heavy at all hours or so it seemed to us. Every inch of the area is charming. Convenient directional signs for pedestrians.
Beautiful quarter. This is a beautiful quarter where you can walk and get lost in its beautiful little streets, full of cafés, restaurants and small traditional shops.
Great neighborhood to stay in!. We rented an apartment in the Barri Gotic Quarter and it was a fabulous area to stay in. So central my husband, 5 kids and I could walk to everything.

Perfect. I'm in love with this street. You can see many small shops with anything you can imagine. You might find a woman singing like in the Opera too in the center of the street. Really nice atmosphere. I also find some christmas market selling cheese, honey, herbal soap and anything. and also art market selling painting,

Gorgeous place and so much history. This is my favourite area of Barcelona. We last visited 18 years ago, and I loved the cathedral just as much this time around, the wonder cafes with chocolat con Churros, and the beautiful architecture everywhere you look
Stunning. We happened across the neighbourhood by chance as it was a short walk from our apartment. This is a must see area.
Lovely small streets with boutique shops and histroy. Nice to stroll into the area off the Las Ramblas bustle. Lovely small streets and history around the Cathedral.

Fascinating pedestrian maze. Barcelona has so many pedestrian-only streets in this neighborhood - this makes is so pleasant to visit (should be done elsewhere). You need a map because it's easy to get lost. These pedestrian areas have hundreds of little boutiques (very few chain stores) with all kinds of interesting things. This neighborhood is also chock-full of historical interest, from Rome to the present: too long to list here.

verry goog. my hotel was located in the gothic quarter so it was easy for me to visit all the quarter of this area. il liked the cathedrale of catalunya and the historic musium. i also liked the architecture of the constructions.

Get Lost in the Gothic Quarter. Get lost in the Gothic Quarter by simply wandering around. Take turns down alleys and narrow streets, stopping to enjoy a beer or wine or food.One of the most fun places to explore in Barcelona.
The place to chose Hotel. soo nice small littel old middelage streets with fine small shops. And many many nice Things to do, and all in walking distance within few minuts.

Forget the world and find yourself getting lost in this beautiful gem. This is by far one of the best places in Barcelona. The building, architecture, cafes, restaurants, gelato, plus all the shopping! This covers a wide area, and best to take your time to stroll around and do some light shopping, sit down with sangria or coffee and watch the world go by. Because there's so much going on here, it may take you an entire day or perhaps two days if you'd like to do some shopping without having to rush. A must go in Barcelona.

always something happening. we really liked walking throug the Gothic Quarter, cause every time we went there something was happening. and at any time you go there, you can see many people enjoying themselves in tapas bar... really nice experience
Lovely area to visit and wander the streets. Great atmosphere in this old area and nice winding streets to wander around. Lots of lovely bars and restaurants and impressive cathedral.

nynjtrvlr. If you love to walk and take in the feeling of the local atmosphere, architecture and culture, this is the place to stay in Barcelona! My friend and I rented an apartment in Barri Gotic and would most definitely stay there again! The old streets are a labyrinth of sites and local businesses and the people are friendly. I love this kind of vacation and did the same thing in Prague which was also wonderful. There is so much to see in Barcelona and so many wonderful shops, restaurants, cafes and placas (squares or plazas) to see. We would wander and get lost for hours and then find our way back to our apartment again. We were there for 8 days and want to go back to stay and explore more.
Go Explore!. Just a really cool area with excellent restaurants, shops and history. I could have spent the entire day here. Lose yourself and enjoy!

Great, Amazing, site seeing place. Being interested in the period, I loved seeing the architecture and the history of the Gothic Quarter. If you are interested in this you will be amazed by the architecture and how advance the architects were in this period, to be able to pull of the architecture
good for walking. Lovely walking through and taking loads and loads of pictures. The architecture was amazing to look at

Center of everything going on. Almost everything is within a 15 min walk from here and if it is not, the mass transit, bus stops, and taxis are all around again in easy walking distance. Great location with lots of shops, food, drinks, and after hour spots.

ONe can never tire of this warren of alleys, shops and culture. This was a treat to keep turning down streets to find more and more interesting places that kept our attention for hours. We were lucky to stay close by and walk to and from the harbor in warm winter nights.

Real authentic medieval city walk. You just need to spend ample time enjoying the maze of the narrowest streets, little shops and cafés with the best pastries and coffee. Very enjoyable dive into Middle Ages!

If you love exploring medieval alleyways, you'll love this. I love exploring the higgledy-piggledy maze of alleyways you sometimes find in old European cities. York, Rome, Lyons all have nice examples of these. However, Barcelona is the daddy of them all, the Gothic Quarter is HUUUGE, just look at a map ! If you like exploring this kind of area, you'll love this. Even better, you can pop onto La Ramblas which borders the western side of the Gothic Quarter, and dive into the the Boqueria market for the best food in the city.
Lovely old town for a ramble. Unique shops, antiques, clothes and gifts shower this old quarter. Gorgeous cafés litter the corridors of cobbled streets.

atmospheric, narrow lanes. So much to see and do here; museums, little shops, cafes...really atmospheric, narrow lanes. We felt very safe in the daytime but have heard that it can be a mugger's area after dark. We saw nothing to that effect though.

Ideal to get lost. Even though I've lived all my life in Barcelona I love to get lost in the Barri Gotic; don't even bother trying to find your way to a building you've been told it's interesting, your feet will guide you there, believe me. Although it might be a little scary the best moment to visit it is by night, when the dim streetlights fill the streets with moving shadows and the old doors crackle making you feel as though you were in an Edgar Allan Poe story. Totally worth a shot!
Very cool, medevil streets, cool shops. Narrow streets, cool shops and lots of local color. You get the feel of our old this city is. Will spend more time here on our next visit.
Nice walking tour. Really Good to take guided walking tour of this area. SO much history and passion and really amazing things to be discover while this walking tour.
Our visit to the gothic quarter. A must see when visiting Barcelona,spent a couple of hours looking at the lovely architecture,well worth a visit
Gorgeous. Give yourself time to wander around here. It is truly wonderful! You feel as bough you've stepped back in time, and ere are plenty of good eats to be had!
A neighbourhood not to be missed. Plenty of small shops, restaurants, and bars in a polished gothic atmosphere. Tiny pedestrian paved streets, antique markets and specialized shops.

Fun to wander. Go during the day. Lots of small, windy streets with shops and some cool architecture. At night, though, most shops are shut with graffiti-covered metal doors - not particularly pleasant or interesting to look at. Small enough that you won't get lost.
Beautiful place..... A wondrous place rich in culture and history...you really cannot afford to miss this area. There is plenty to see and do as well,as to eat....

Simply breathtaking!. If you are in Barcelona, you gotta visit the gothic quarter! Plan at least 3 to 4 hours in day time, go to the Cathedral, and just let yourself get lost in narrow gorgeous streets around it. Regardless which direction you take or which street you walk through, you will love what you see! For maximum enjoyment, stop at a little cafe in one of those narrow streets and sit down and enjoy a cup of tea or coffee.Worth to see: Cathedral, Basilica de santa maria del mar, and the area around Picasso's museum.To go there, get out at "Jaume I" metro station and walk to the Cathedral.If you have more time, walk towards the Palau de la Música Catalana, its gorgeous!

Great for food and shopping. Great little place to find some hidden shops and restaurants.The streets all run into each other and run along to the rambles .Great for finding hidden gems amongst the narrow streets .We stayed by the zoo and travelled along these streets everyday to get to the rambles ,take your time to get use to the directions ,you can easy get lost but this is half the fun .
Fascinating. Beautiful part of the city with lots to see and admire, including the cathedral, art galleries and market stalls.

Walker's paradise. It's amazing how the atmosphere changes as you move from las ramblas to these network of lanes. The hustle and bustle of las ramblas changes into a sense of calm as you walk through the historic paths and buildings. Cool shops and flea markets too. Just watch out for pickpockets
Walk in the old city. Stay in a hotel near here and walk though it every day. It takes several visit to learn it. Do some shoping and hit some of the restarounts and chocalate shops.

Good place to get lost in the atmosphere and bars of Barcelona. A great place to wander, day or night. Fabulous individual shops and great bars - especially Asensor and Rubi bar for late night drinks. Well worth a visit to this district if you want to see the real Barcelona.
History all around. The area is full of ancient buildings - a true photo paradise. Lots of good eating places at better prices than the Ramblas area.

real "old world". This was a fantastic experience. One can wonder through the past by walking these unique streets. These places are hundreds of years old. The history is unique and inspiring. The past glory days of this city is clear here.

Terrific area to visit. This is an area of great interest, lovely little streets, charming shops and plenty of eating places, cafes, restaurants and carry out places.Easy to get to from Las Ramblas, safe as well and hassle from no one

My most favorite. I really loved this area. The first thing we went to was las ramblas and I was a little disappointed. I wanted the cute alley ways and neat buildings. That is what I found here. We found it by accident. We made a left off las ramblas and just walked. It was awesome. We found ourselves just walking into new areas and loving it. So neat! You will love walking around here. This was my favorite thing to do in Barcelona. Fun!
Stroll through.... You will not be disappointed. Charming stores, lively music and crowd, a real treat when in Barcelona.

From Rome to the Middle Ages. Barri Gotic has many places to explore, many alleys with shops and museums. You can spend a day here just roaming around. Our favorite area was near the Cathedral where an open air market was going on for Christmas but make sure you do your shopping before 8:30 PM because everybody goes home then. We also walked around and saw many early Roman ruins including some in an open air market just down the street from the Cathedral. Definitely a place to explore.

Loved it.. I loved this place. It had a really gothic feel (hence it's name) but nevertheless was fantastic experience to walk around and just look at the old buildings or watch people walk past when in a cafe.

Get lost in the Gothic quarter. Built in the 1100's (?), the narrow streets are jam packed with cafes and tapas bars, and wine cellars. If you get tired of the crowds on La Rambla or at the Catalunya plaza, wander through the smaller side 'streets' (I don't think a car could fit thru them). Somewhat reminescent of the 'streets' fo Mikonos Greece, it's easy to get lost in here. My recommendation - don't rush, just wander until you get tired and/or find your way out.

Great to visit. The Gothic Quarter "is" old Barcelona. There is so much to see and worth spending a day to see. We were there at Christmas and the Christmas market added to this quaint section of Barcelona.

Intermix of old and older. great old buildings, cathedrals, churches and buildings. Many are no charge to explore. Knowing the history (read up on details), this is amazing in what is still standing and the state of details present. Plan a day or more to take in the entire area - just off Las Ramblas in case you want to squeeze in both areas in a quick tour... Worth the walk.
So interesting at every turn. It was all food, as long as you are up to walking through such an interesting area. Each lane is unique and offers something different.

Plan on spending a lot of time here. Get off La Rambla as fast as you can. Junk shops and people trying to drag you into mediocre or worse restaurants. The further north / west you go, the better it gets. Though it presents like a maze, kind of like Venice, it is manageable. Go to the old Cathedral (600 years to build). Cross Laitanea (sp?) and then walk towards the water in El Born. Nice boutiques and restaurants and watering holes. A family could spend days in the Gothic Quarter. South of La Rambla, while it has cleaned up in recent years, is still sketchy, street walkers, etc., not family oriented. Ladies, watch your purses in the Gothic Quarter, men watch your wallets. Safe but notorious for pickpockets. Don't ever consider using an ATM in this area which is not within a bank, i.e.., no ATMs which face the sidewalks.

You like the sceenery of the middle age?. Pass through the streets and get the sound of Barcelona. There are a lot of little things to see and also nice churches arround. Restaurants and bars for relaxing at many little places.

Barcelona is absolutely wonderful!!!. We rented an apartment (we brought our Chihuahua with us) in this old section of Barcelona and find it all an amazingly delightful experience. Everyone in Barcelona has been so friendly that even tho it is a big city, I feel like I am in a small village. The apt. is two levels and some of the interior stone walls brought to make this part of the building date to the Middle Ages! (It was renovated 10 years ago by the owner, a fairly young woman who is an architect.) It is on one of the very windy narrow teensy little streets a car can hardly fit down and right across from a sweet little restaurant whose manager has been a wonderful help. When my sister-in-law came to visit and broke her ankle, the manager carried her in his arms all the way down the street to our apartment when he saw us getting out of a large cab that wouldn't fit down at the end of the street. My husband and I bought each other rings hand-crafted by two jewelsmiths who had just opened a tiny shoppe kitty-corner across from our apartment. They had to be resized and when we went back to get them, Roberto invited us to the "neighborhood Christmas Dinner" "because you are our neighbors now"! I couldn't believe it. There were about a dozen others who were all artists...one world-famous artist who later invited us to his studio 3 doors down, several jewelsmiths, a woman journalist who covers the art scene here, two women art school students who work in the jewelers' studio and thrown in, the guy who runs the Segway Tours biz around the corner. We had such a grand time and I was in heaven as Friday here is "duck day" and I got another leg of duck! The Barri Gotic is the best place to stay if you don't mind the occasional street sound (someone singing at 2am when the bars close, people gleefully laughing occasionally). We walk to everything including our favorite Café de l'Opera on La Rambla where we have our nightly espresso and Napoleon (milles-feuilles in France, mille-ojas in Spanish), an exquisite phyllo-layered pastry filled with a divine custard between all the layers. I was in Barcelona 52 years ago (hitchhiking down from Grenoble, France where I studied) and all I did was slurp down cheap brandy and play chess with one of Spain's most famous retired bullfighters! This time, I am getting to know the real Barcelona! What a joy!

Enjoyed wandering around. We mainly wandered around the streets aimlessly as we made our way to other attractions in the city. Its definitely worth visiting this quarter though, but I liked the Ramblas better.

Elegant and historic. Lots of fine buildings, some very old, spacious squares jostle with quaint lanes, masses of shops and plenty of eateries specialising in local cuisine, and don't miss the medieval cathedral among the most delightful I have seen.

You will never see all of it.. We were fortunate that our hotel backed onto the Gothic Quarter. It made our trip. It's such a brilliant place to stroll through at any time of day. There are 5* hotels! superb restaurants, quality shops and picturesque streets and squares.
Wonderful.
Gorgeous midnight stroll. Dimly lit and worth a stroll in the night, maybe stop in a bar for a drink, nice in the daytime too but better in the evening!
Go there. Tapas bars to die for, everything about this place from the churches to the roman architecture is superb

Get Lost in Barcelona. This area has heaps of narrow streets apparently heading nowhere but opening onto plazas filled with atmosphere and onto the bustling main streets that border it There were enough churches, markets, museums, shops, cafés and restaurants with an authentic Catalonian feel to keep us interested most of the day. All in all a great way to get the feel for Barcelona.

Lots of little interesting outlets, but......... Really interesting area of the city. Lots of different gift and fashion shops as well as the touristy bazars. Loved the atmosphere until I was mugged. Beware its not just pick pockets you need to look out for. They attacked me for a gold necklace. Fortunately 2 British tourists gave chase and they got away without anything but you need to be aware and maybe leave your jewellery at home. Despite this experience we went on to have a fabulous holiday and will return to Barcelona
Stroll. Walk around at the small streets,have a carahillio cafe in a small cafe,eat a boqatillo with jamon serano do some shoping walk some more BUT be very careful from pickpockets that hug around

Fascinating. We stumbled into the Gothic quarter after walking La Rambla, absolutely enraptured by the little cobbled walkways with stunning buildings and gargoyles! Spent 8 hours walKing around here and lived every minute. Be prepared to go camera crazy and don't forget to bring spare batteries and SD cards!

Must see Barcelona. This is a must see during your stay in Barcelona. Cool cafes and tapas bars, boutique shopping, great old architecture and winding streets and overall good vibe. For me personally this beats all the overpriced attractions in Barcelona.

Must go!. Must go see area of Barca, funky and young, yet appeals to everyone! Great, old, wonderful buildings. Great bars, restaurants and shops. I prefer staying around this area as apposed to the ramblas. We had a lovely glass of red wine, a beer and a light bite of croquettes with a lovely sauce and spring onion decoration - very tasty, it was like potato bravas with a twist. This cost 5 euro for drinks and 6euro for food, it came with a selection of bread too. Very nice atmosphere, candle lights, chesterfields and other old quirky features. Ballakano was the name of this bar/ restaurant.There's a great outlet store that sells a lot of Deisel clothing and footwear - both mens and womens.

Forget the map and just explore!. Beautiful part of Barcelona with lots of small streets and laneways, shops, restaurants and cafes. Best to leave the map behind and just explore, you are never far from transport links if you get tired!

Spend days here!. This is a great part of Barcelona to spend a few days. It is old, but also young and interesting. You can easily spend your whole Barcelona travel budget here in the many shops and restaurants. Watch for pick pockets (I had one try me, but he was unsuccessful), but I always felt safe enough to return.

What's Not To Like. We made it a point to stay in the Gothic Quarter to savor Barcelona's best both day and night. We walked to the Ramblas, Plaça de Sant Jaume, Placa de Catalunya, Picasso Museum, etc. Just roaming all of the alleys with their nonstop activities, and stopping here and there to eat or window-shop was time well spent.

Just spend a day wandering!. Plan to spend a day wandering these darling streets. You can eat and shop your way to heaven in this neighborhood! I think paying the fee to visit the inside of the Barcelona Cathedral is worthwhile, as it was lovely. In the summer, there's a flea market in front of the Cathedral and in the winter, a Christmas market, so it's a very lively neighborhood. The streets are charming and graced with beautiful architecture.

A delightful area. The trafficless streets are a welcome change from the traffic everywhere in the world, though one must admit that Barcelona has better traffic conditions compared to any big city that I have been in. Lots of shops and little restaurants and dont miss the cathedral. This is a delightful building too. There was a market in front of the cathedral selling christmas decorations.

Wonderful part of this city!!!. This area is a must see! So many shops, restaurants and old buildings. Although I read a lot about pick pockets in this area, I felt very safe. Just use common sense and be alert. You will love this area!!!

stunning. We wandered up las rambles and just happened upon the cathedral _ wow! The whole scene was beautifully enhanced by the Christmas market and superb seasonal lighting, probably the best time of year to visit
Gorgeous old streets to wander. Good place to wander at night. Gorgeous Xmas lights, cobblestone streets with narrow limitless alleys. Romantic stroll.

It is maze!. My friends living in Barcelona took me this area.They said it is maze, If I went there I am sure I was lost.It is complicated zone and interesting.In this area, if you find anything nice, I recommend to buy immediately, otherwise you cannot come back the same place.Anyway, it is one face of Barcelona, wandering in the maze is interesting experience.

Barric Gotic. It is nice to walk around and see the old time, especially the Cathedral, which is a must to visit it. But be careful of any stranger who may come forward to you with a business card and pretend to invite you to some drinking place in La Ramblas. They are distracting your attention so that can snatch your wallet from your pocket.

Hearing the stones. Your experience in Barcelona will not be completed until you get completely lost in the narrow streets of Gotico. Sit in a terrace, grab a beer and just hear the stones whispering their history to you. Barcelona at its best!

Gothic Quarter - Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter is steeped in history. The buildings display some spectacular architecture. The atmosphere was very chilled and very Spanish. There are restaurants and bars scattered about throughout the quarter and you can wander the streets looking at the shops, sampling cheese, chocolate and meats at the market stalls. If you visit Barcelona this is a must for your itinerary.

Could spend days just wandering here. The Gothic Quarter reminds of of Venice in that it is a great area to just get lost. The narrow streets just invite you to explore each one. So many restaurants, bakeries, shops…Just wish we had had more than a day and a half!
Interesting and crowded. Some great history and architecture but the small streets get quite crowded. Is is nice to stumble on some new "square" or cool building.

Gothic Area, Barcelona. i adore this part of Barcelona - these narrow streets, w/o traffic, you can go and go, drink coffee and make shopping. there are a couple of interesting places for shopping there Carrer Bocceria where you can find a great store with "ballet slippers" - a huge variety of these shoes of different colours and textures. the second place is a shop of vintage clothing, which is just after couple of doors after the shoes shop.
Barri Gothic. It can open its beauty rather late, after wondering in the streets some time. Just look up and enjoy wonderful windows and decorations. Street Bisbe is astonishing!
Beautiful. A great place to visit. Very beautiful and lively. We love visiting here. A great experience. Fab places to eat and drink. Lots to see.

Barcelona at its best. We had our B&B here and it was worth every penny being in this part of Barcelona as the atmosphere, architecture and just the general buzz of the place made the holiday. We could have stopped outside this part of the city in some Holiday Inn but being here made us feel we were somewhere on holiday experiencing the culture. You can spend a good couple of days here without any trouble. This was Barcelona for me.
Gothic Quarter. You can easily spend a day just wandering around, enjoying the sights and partaking in a drink or two. A beautiful area!

Gothic Quarter Barcelona. Loved this area! Had tons of shops, interesting old buildings and it was just fun to wander around all day! Had a great time in this city. Would recommend it to anyone for a great vacation. I little cool at Thanksgiving but tolerable if you do not mind bundling a bit.

Endless streets to explore. Although some areas were quite busy with tourists, it still felt fun to wander through the narrow streets and dive down interesting looking alleys. Found it particularly fascinating walking through some of the more residential streets and seeing these beautiful old buildings rising up on either side. It felt like we could have been there for days more and still found something new to look at every day.

A trip back in time. Take a long trip back in time, get lost in between the wonderful old buildings. The streets are narrow and clean with small stores and paintings on the walls. Old squares with sculptures and people feeding birds. Do you need more to relax ?

Cool neighborhood!. Very medieval and interesting part of town. And like everything else in the fabulous city of Barcelona, very easy to walk to from anywhere. It was wonderful to just stroll around and get lost, gazing at the beautiful buildings :-)
loved this. This is one of the most architecture wonders of this city the Gothic quarter is full of fabulous building complete with gargoyles. Also don't miss the shopping and great food in the area
walk in time. This old section of town contains new shops, museums and a step back in time. It is also the scene of battle during the civil war.
Old Barcelona. You really need to spend an afternoon wandering around the area... Old Roman walls, narrow cobbled streets that wind around old buildings, great little shops, etc.

So atmospheric. Barcelona's old quarter is fascinating to stroll around in. Have your camera handy! There are many walking tours that go through the Barri Gotic and they're well worth going on because there are so many hundreds of years of history to learn about. So many stories these old street tell...

Lovely place to get lost. This is the place to just wander and not worry about a specific destination because you will come across so many beautiful places and little shops and random vendors. Dedicate 2-3 hours to just explore this magical part of Barcelona.

Fabulous little shops. We just loved exploring Barcelona's Barri Gotic. So many fabulous little shops, and so much character. Although I periodically referred to our map, we had more fun just meandering around all of the small streets. Yes, parts of it are rather touristy, but there are loads of non-touristy shops, cafes, etc. We enjoyed putting our Spanish to the test with some of the non-English speaking shop owners, who appreciated our attempts at speaking their language. We thoroughly enjoyed browsing the area and highly recommend spending some time there.

Strolling. ....when we decided to go to visit Las Ramblas,the concierge at the hotel gave us a print out of what to look out for to stay safe......this put a damper on the visit,but like any big city anywhere in the world..you just have to be ''aware'' of your surroundings.....What a pleasant surprise....the place was buzzing...plenty of shops cafe's and bars....and SAFE......It was just a great place to explore,and worth going into the old market,and all the little side streets.....talking with one of the locals,he said the Ramblas did have a bad reputation for ''pick pockets'' , but the city had gone to great lengths to protect its ''visitors''.....well worth a visit.

Back to the middle ages. The most iconic quarter of Barcelona, filled wih tourists during summer, but really worth it to get lost inside. The little streets where cars can't get really brings you back to the middle ages. I love every inch of it.
Lovely. This is a great place to just wander around - don't use a map - if you hit Las Ramblas turn back and plough down another tiny road

Walking around. I was there for an afternoon with my wife. It's a good neighborhood for walking around and see some nice buildings. There's plenty of stores around, shopping and eating. We had a nice time, you won't miss a whole lot if you can't make it though.

Nice area. My wife and I stayed in Hotel MonteCarlo in this area (at the top end of La Rambla). There is so much to see here. The Liceu Opera House, the Cathedral, Palau Guell, Placa Reial, Palau Musica Catalania, the Christopher Columbus monument and Port Vell at the other end of La Rambla.

Great neighbourhood. There is so much to see and do in the Gothic Quarter. For a start it is where the amazing Picasso Museum is and that in itself is worth a visit to the neighbourhood. Apart from that it is just a great place to wonder around without your tourist map and explore the small streets and find a cosy place to have a coffee and some cake or lunch/dinner. There is a great atmosphere and there are lots of little hotels. Next time we are in Barcelona we will most likely stay in a hotel in the Gothic Quarter of the equally attractive Raval neighbourhood.

Graffiti spoiler. Barcelona's architecture is fantastic and the Gothic area is a warren of streets lined with bars, restaurants and shops amid the visual splendour. However, for me, the graffiti, no matter how 'artistic' they may deign it to be, totally spoils the City and drags it down into the distasteful mindset of suburban squallor.

Good for spend time in evening and see real Barcelona. I liked the shops, restaurants, small streets and you now pretty active area. so we came back from Cathedral and just took the street to BARRI GOTHIC and could go around and finished in LA Ramblas street, we didn't feel time goes and it was nice. You can find typical things in the area, souvenir shops, pubs etc.

wandering and finding. The old city of Barcelona is a great place to just walk around and discover shops and restaurants and sights. Narrow streets and small alleyways hide little places that you'll never find unless you walk by and look in the window. Found a guitar maker, with an interesting sign stating his shop was not a zoo, or a tourist attraction. Found a new men's shirt shop making cool stylish shirts in spain. Lots of locals making and selling stuff in the heart of BCN.

Classic old world charm. Barcelona is a beautiful city. The Gothic quarter is a great place to walk through and experience old world charm. The HOHO off buses have a stop here. It is good to do some research so you know what you are seeing. Great little cafes and bakeries. Don't do the tourist rush. Take an hour just to stroll through the area.
Lovely area to visit and stay in. We stayed in the Barri Gotic and were amazed at the history and how much there is to see. WE are already planning our next trip.

amazing history. Went for a guided walking tour through barri gotic and must say, its best to go on a guided tour rather than just walk around because it is so easy to miss things and details that have a great history behind it, which a good tour guide will help point out and even tell you the stories behind it! Although the lanes are tiny and very easy to get lost in, you can walk around and find something beautiful, i specially loved the murals and paintings on buildings!

spend some time here! You'll love it. Our host lived in this area, and honestly, I'm pretty glad! We walked everywhere. I think we took the tube/underground a couple of times. but Everything you can want or need is around here. :) Nightlife, food, shopping, markets, everything.
like a fairytale. you must go for a walk there it is like you go back in past,also you can buy souvenirs there,(there are many shops).

Must Tour of Barcelona. This was our second time doing this tour, my wife and I did one during our first visit in 2011. This time we did a second tour with our family (first timers) and despite the second time, I learned some new things.Number one, bring your walking shoes because you do lots of walking and moving. Be prepared for whatever the weather may bring so please check the forecast prior. Time: typically starts at 9 AM, you can buy tickets at any local tourist office or even your hotel lobby. Loved our tour guide during both tours, extremely knowledgeable people with a great attitude. Highly recommend and feel this is a must have since Barcelona has so much history to share. I feel that if you are a first-time visitor to Barcelona, please make time for this tour.

Strollers delight !. Narrow, historic streets lined with shops, cafes, and artisans. While crowded morning, noon and night its the heart of Barcelona. Consider taking a walking tour and if wandering on your own don't be afraid to get a little lost.

Nobody tells you this but you HAVE to see this part of Barcelona!. We didn't feel the impressive history of Barcelona until we visited this area of town. It's so beautiful and there are Roman walls and ancient buildings and we almost missed it! Make sure you have the chocolate and churros and then explore the ruins and churches on a sugar high. 2 adults and 2 kids and we kept coming back to this part of town because it was the heart of Barcelona plus the food was better in this part of town!!
Prepare to walk. This place is so deep - with history, hidden alleys, and great places to eat. Got lost several times but somehow manage to get back where I needed to be.

a warren of artisan shops.. an area full of character with lots of small specialist shops-especially clothes and shoes ,bars ,coffee shops. reminded me of Venice. Some of the buildings are run down and the shutters on the shops are full of graffiti,but it didnt feel threatening and is obviously on the up. Some nice plazas and grand buildings and just head in the general direction you want to go and a maze of alleys will get you there eventually.

Take it slow. Just wonderful for walking around aimlessly. Street art is really nice. Shops are cute but kinda the same all over the place. Restaurants, cafés and bars all over the place. Make sure not to only visit the ones on the bigger streets, lots of tiny places waiting to be discoverd. Keep an eye out for thieves, keep bags in front and over your pocket to discourage them!

Feels like Old Europe. This is the oldest part of the city. We agreed that we didn't feel like we were in Europe until we went to this part of town. Great food, shopping and old winding narrow streets. You can cover this part in an hour or two if you're in a hurry and longer if you grab a good meal. If there are cruise ships in the ports, this area will most certainly be crowded.

Good Food and shopping. This is a very fun district in Barcelona. It is full of wonderful restaurants and tapa's diners. There are a lot of outdoor cafes for people watching and great shops, very enjoyable area.
Maze. Yes it is a maze within a city. But it is great just to walk inside it and take notion of the old barcelona. It has in it some of the great things to see around here.

Great ´Time-Machine´ to old Spain !. They had fantastic GOOD Ice-Cream in B. and walking about, in the warm night (september) it was a fantasic feeling. All the small shops were worth many hours to look into.

a treat round every corner. Give yourself time to meander through all the tiny streets and squares. Usually in touristy places gifts and crafts can be tacky but not here there was so much I wanted to buy and lots of cafes bars etc. You'll want to go back but don't get lost it's quite a maze1

Beautiful Place to roam around.. We had nice romantic time there roaming around in streets and various shops. There were many different kind of things to see like the store selling Red-Indian accessories, Candle shops, Food and Sangrilla shops, Shops selling souvenirs.

Ignore Las Ramblas and go here. The original part of Barcelona which is just off Las Ramblas. Lots of narrow streets full of interesting shops, bars, churches and other gems. A must visit area and if you want a guided tour try the Travelbound walking tours which start just inside the area and last around 2 1/2 hours - highly recommended.

Important in time. The Gothic Quarter offers many streets and buildings to explore. The architecture and history is very interesting and provides a base for understanding the transistion within Barcelona.

kept coming back. within our four day visit we kept wandering back to this area, each time finding something different and unique to see. worth wondering around without a map and just getting lost - best adventure and finds

Lovely place to just wander. We wandered the streets in the Gothic Quarter and found the whole area a wonderful place to have experienced. Lots of little restaurants everywhere as well as interesting little shops to explore.

Charm, with Buzz. It is much changed from the area of small workshops which were here 50 years ago- probably safer now. The deep, narrow fronted, premises are now restaurants, bars and shops, many selling tourist tat, but this is far better than being closed up. Lots of history, old buildings, museums, narrow streets, few cars, buzz and lots of charm. Never felt unsafe

Lost in Gothic Bliss. Completely free. A good wander through the Gothic Quarter. The deeper you go, the more you see. Little pharmacy shops, grocery stores. . .everything on a small scale. So intimate and historical. Winding alleys with street lamps hanging from the high walls. The sound of cathedral bells. . . You half expect to see someone from another century round the corner.

So much to see and do - don't miss!. The cathedral, the Sardana dance, the flea market, the ruins of the Roman temple, Placa St. Filip Neri, the wall and the Roman guard towers, the Jewish quarter and the entrance to the synagogue, the Roman necropolis, the Santa Anna church, the restaurants and shops...this huge list of worthwhile sights, all within easy walking distance. Get off of Las Ramblas and walk through the side streets and alleys of Barri Gotic!

The best place to visit in Barcelona.. Take a walk up La Rambla or maybe a walk down La Rambla or both but do not leave Barcelona without spending some time in the Barric Gotic. This is the authentic, beating heart of Barcelona and where your memories will be shaped. Narrow street, passages. bars, restaurants and safety away from the thieves that prey on tourists up and down La Rambla. Not to say that you are immune from opportunist thieves here but with a little care you should enjoy the buzz of the Barri Gotic. Not to be missed and a million miles more pleasurable than the hidden perils of La Rambla ( no matter how sharp you think you are the criminals that have overrun Barcelona have the sophisticated ability to rob you by stealth) The city is marvellous for tourists and has too much too offer for tourists to be but off but special care is needed.

Perfect Stroll. This area is also close to the Rambula but it is very quaint and typical of the older parts of Barcelona. Look carefully into each tapas bar and choose the ones that look smaller and are filled with locals. Narrow streets,historic buildings and lots of small shops. Good deals on shoes and modern clothing designed in Barcelona and other parts of Spain. A good half day at least.

Preserving History in a Bustling City. A quiet part of bustling Barcelona, with interesting shops and cafes, even a traditional Irish pub, Paddy's Rest. The church of Santa Maria del Mar is certainly worth visiting, as a contrast to Gaudi's Sagrada Familia.

Little streets back in time. Well worth walking through There are a variety of lovely shops and coffee houses to stop and have a quick drink in When you are walking please make sure to look up and enjoy the great buildings

Great little streets, secrets and gems at every turn. You kind of cannot miss these streets if walking around and about off the beaten track of the La Rambla, so you should find this quarter quite easily, it's loverly, quaint and full of little cafes, tapas bars and shops for the tourist, ice cream, coffee and pastry galore.

Sunday afternoon stroll through Gothic Quarter. We started out on the promenade facing the Christopher Columbus statue. Cross over and bear to your right heading upwards and you will come to the Gothic Quarter. Walk along tiny narrow cobbled streets and see the many quaint old churches, buildings with ornate patios, leafy squares and restaurants and eventually you will see the cathedral you will walk. The afternoon that we visited there was a small orchestra playing music on the steps of the cathedral. Unfortunately they were just packing up when we arrived around 3pm.There are many people dressed as ghosts and fairies who are anxious to be photographed with you for a fee of course, so beware if you don't wish to be pestered.

Amazing and beautiful. The Gothic quarter is a collection of lovely little streets, filled with shops, restaurants and cafes, which all fit in place. There are lovely Gothic buildings to visit and enjoy. I could have stayed all day there. It really is beautiful and an absolute must to stop off at and visit.

Barcelona as it used to be. You can feel the charm and essence of history in this part of Barcelona. You may be surprised by very nice buildings, narrow streets, restaurants, cafes and patisseries all around the neighborhood. Stroll around these streets on your way in and out of La Rambla.

A lovely mystery. Toured around this area with our walking guide Luke (from the Free Walking Tour) and it is very impressive with all the history that the place has seen! Lots of little restaurants and shops. Definitely a unique place not to be missed!
An array of small backstreets - fantastic!. An fantastic maze of backstreets with shops, cafes and artists displaying their wares. Great experience. Don't miss it.

Legs hurt. What a fascinating area. It has so much character and so much diversity in the small shops that are hidden down every passageway. The only downside as to a lot of places in Barcelona are the pickpockets. However if you use common sense you should have no problems. I really did find it amazing.
Lovely. worth a visit, lovely building in quiet streets.Wonderful inside,no queues a chance to relax and put life into perspective.

Great base to explore from. My teenage daughter and I stayed in this area and it was perfect for the metro and lots of easily accessible attractions, bars and restaurants are on your doorstep. Highly recommended!
Tapas, Tapas, Tapas.. Walking distance from La Rambla, excellent places for dinner and tapas (pinchos). Interesting stroll along many little alleys.
Great character, great people watching. Walking here after the shops are closed takes you back in time. When the shops are open, its a bustling destination with throngs of people nightly.
Nice area for tapas. Try a few places for tapas. They have specials just make sure to go early some places close early around 6

Do the Walk. Since I love Barcelona I think there aren't any negatives. Strolling through Barri Gotic makes you feel a part of the long history of Barcelona. Lots of little surprises on the buildings and narrow streets. Felt comfortable and safe.
Walk the area. This is in the downtown core and very worth an explore. Wander the streets and stop for food and wine

We stayed in the Gothic Quarter.. And we are glad we did. There is no end of street life here, from the Boqueria market to the florists shops on La Rambla, to the hundreds of restaurants and stores and museums and historical buildings. This part of town is like being a rich kid on Christmas; each turn you take puts you in a new place that just opens up yet another delight. Eixample, to the north, is full of urbane and cosmopolitan life, Barri Gotic has charm. Stay here. Wander around. You won't want to leave.
Mysterious and fun to experience.. You never know what you will see or experience in terms of shopping, eating, or just people watching.

Gothic Quarter. Actually stayed in this area, very busy , many places to eat of every type, many bars, Very narrow cobbled streets with many sightseeing area's including the Cathedral, NB open for FREE after 5pm. Adjacent to La Rambla and easy to get around the city centre.

We loved this area.. We rented an apartment in the Gothic Quarter for 8 days through VRBO. Loved this area....the narrow streets, great restaurants, easy access to the waterfront, Las Ramblas, and the other attractions in the Old District.

Histroy at its exquisite best !!. This is a definite must do in Barcelona. We got off from the hop off hop on bus to just see the Gothic cathederal, not knowing that the overall area by itself is worth a investigation. Usually some of the tourists miss this part due to the outer lanes but if you go to the Gothic Cathederal then this part of the city and its magic draws you in. The cathedral is in a big open space and then like a octupus arms a lot of small lanes join into this open space. Take any one and start walking. Each street is unique, shops are exquisite, from clothes , souvenirs, eateries, herbal stuff or fresh fruits everything is there. Each of these streets joins a big open space which could have anything from a police station in a historic building, church or even theater. The alleys are just so filled with history that you can feel the ghosts of old travellers moving with you. Buildings and architecture is enough on its own. If a group of friends is going there with you then more the fun. Also we had the pleasure of seeing a dance performance and a individual musician on a flute, you may get lucky and see something even better. Every city retains its core heart over the ages which gives out its true flavor, this would be for me the Integral part of Barcelona.Unfortunately this happened on last day of our visit from 3.00 pm onwards, Could have easily spent another whole evening discovering this one ......................... look forward to another oppurtunity

Busy but well worth it. Be careful with your pockets and don't get lost but be sure to investigate all the various parts of this location, some brilliant architecture and good cafe bars to relax away an afternoon

VERY INTERESTING. There is lots to see and do in Barcelona - but this is one area i wished we had taken the time to fully learn about. i suspect on our next visit we would allow to join a tour or prepare more.Not to be missed or just walked through.

UNIQUE PLACE TO TAKE A STROLL. My wife and I visited Barcelona recently while on vacation and we had the opportunity to walk all over this city. This area of Barcelona is unique and you feel like you are going back in history as you explore the many alleys, odd/hidden streets, and interesting buildings. If you are in Barcelona, you have to visit this area. Check out Rick Steve's Barcelona book as it will help you find many of the hard-to-find gems in this community.

So much history!. Make sure you book a guided tour with the Barcelona Tourism office, so that you can learn all the history of the Barcelona Gothic Quarter, otherwise it is just another part of Barcelona, or another cathedral.

Lonely planet leads the way. I used Lonely Planet for Barcelona. While it was a bit light on the basics, the walking tour or the Gothic Quarter was genius. No surpirse that the prices (sadly) need updating. I particularly enjoyed the Roman Temple that I would never have found on my own. Saddened by the evidence of the civil war.

Remember to Look Down!. An astonishing area of cobbled streets and narrow alleyways. The temptation is to wander around looking up and the slither of blue sky that can be seen between the fabulous buildings. Remember to look down too. The walls are amazing. Try and get onto a guided tour such as Runner Bean Walking Tours. It gives such an insight into the history of this area. Be brave and just wander.

simply beautiful. gorgeous twisty streets of the most beautiful architecture. Worth getting lost for the morning in the cool alleyways and decadent squares. Do not skip this area if you want to feel utterly transported to a gothic fairytale world.

Very Spanish.. You'll get lost for sure as did we but that's the fun & adventurous thing about it. It's a labyrinth of narrow winding streets filled with quaint, unique shops, cafes & boutiques. You must look upwards when walking around. The sights, the smells is all Spain. Loved it.

Wandering the Gothic Quarter. This was one of those experiences in which you are aware of those who have walked the streets before you. Wandering rather than a planned route leads to surprise encounters. Despite all the warnings about pick pockets etc, it felt quite safe. Lots of beggars. The cathedral was astounding, we went back for a mass. Market outside in the square was interesting. Great cafe on corner. Busy with queues for toilets. Completely confused as what is street versus footpath as the streets are so narrow. Don't forget to look up when walking. Beautiful decorations on building roofs. Catedral spire acts as great reference point.

Grafitti encrusted smelly alleyways? I don't get it.. My wife and I had a day to spare before flying home & decided to visit the Gothic area of Barcelona.Walked Las Rambles (touristy but ok). Cathedral area is nice. When we visited there was an orchestra & traditional Catalonian dancing going on. Nice ambience.Wandered back through the 'gothic' streets. Closed, grafitti covered shops & urine smelling alleyways. Not gothic, just shabby.Might have missed the best parts as we were on a timeline but not impressed. Sorry.magnificence all the way

beautiful area. The Gothic Quarter is a beautiful area of Barcelona situated behind Las Ramblas. There is plenty to explore and can easily spend a full day finding its treasures. If you are there for longer than a day this area is well worth exploring to the full.

Nice shopping. Nice local shops, though there are already lots of big company retail stores which are the same all over the world. Impossible smell all over the city, I think because of a drainage problem(?). Is it always like that? If so, I would´t like to live there...

A great place to take a walk. At first glance this place appears very regular, but as you walk through the streets, the buildings and narrow walk ways take you back in time. Its a great way to spend your morning. The Cathedral and walkways around it are enchanting, there is also a great market in the street across the cathedral that has amazing fruits, cheese and a lot of other stuff that I didnt have time to check.
quaint and lovely. loved the food hall that we stumbled upon in a back street that had all sorts to eat so you could eat tapas to chinese to japanese and have a bit of all ,

Great walking tour in Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter is a great place for strolling and people watching. The streets are narrow and winding with lots of places for tapas and wine. Don't miss the beautiful Cathedral of Barcelona located in the Gothic Quarter. I felt very safe walking in this area during a beautiful sunny afternoon. The Picasso Museum is close by and another great attraction if time permits.

Love the close quarters. I love cleanliness of most of the narrow streets and alleys throughout the quarters. I has a great feel to it and love the Placa Reial, the area around the Gothic Cathedral and Las Rambla

Enjoyable afternoon. The gothic quarter and its architecture are different than the rest of Barcelona. It was lovely to enjoy it all walking through the streets. There are also great spots to grab a quick meal or drink to complete your afternoon or evening.

Wonderful to Explore and Discover. My wife and I left the HOHO bus at the Eglesia de Santa Maria del Mar stop. We visited this beautiful cathedral, then wended our way through the narrow medieval streets of the Gothic Quarter all the way to Plaza Catalunya. Along the way we came upon surprising little plazas, some large, some small, and all with tables and chairs set up for diners. We ate lunch inside at Taller Tapas, taking a break from the heat and from our sightseeing. The lunch was tasty and reasonably priced, a nice break in our day. We then headed to the Cathedral of Barcelona, the ancient church, and the large plaza outside. While in Barcelona, we were staying in the El Raval section, just across La Rambla from the Gothic Quarter. We enjoyed our first exploration so much that we made two more ventures into this section. One was to go to dinner at Babia, not far from the main cathedral. That was a wonderful nighttime adventure walking the ancient streets trying to find our way. With help from a shopkeeper we found our restaurant, had a great meal and then headed back to our hotel. On the way back we turned a corner to find a wonderful gelato shop. There were many others on the streets as we headed to our hotel around 10:30pm. On our last day we walked through the impressive Plaza Reial and made our way through the streets to the water. I would recommend spending time in this old section of the city because it is unique in Barcelona and a treat to explore. It is filled with plazas, shops, and dining venues, and the people we encountered were genuinely hospitable.

Loved the walk in the night. At first I was a bit sceptical on wasting time here. But once we were there it just felt nice walking through the narrow street. Passed some museums which were old looking and the cathedral. Recommend going during the dark and we went on Halloween so it was nice to see people dressed up spookily
Go early. The gothic quarter is a wonderful place to walk around and explore, but becomes quite crowded later in the day. Go early (from 8AM - 10AM) and you'll practically have it to yourself.

The real Barcelona. We stayed on the edge of the gothic quarter so walked through it every day at least once - there was always something new to see and the maze of narrow alleyways was never threatening, even at night. Many people had warned us about pickpockets, to the point of almost making us paranoid, but we saw no street crime or dodgy characters.

Historic Barcelona.. Just strolling around this area brings the history of Barcelona to life. The range of buildings is amazing with changing trends in architecture around every corner. Narrow streets lead into pleasant squares with trees, cafés and bars of every type.No problems with traffic as much of the area is pedestrianised so you can wander at your leisure and soak in the frescoes and gargoyles high up on many of the buildings.Lots of interesting little shops are hidden away between larger, grander buildings. All in all a fascinating part of Barcelona which should not be missed!
Gotic. Excellent buildings with narrow street to explore however difficult to find way around as maps do not have small streets names on.
not a night time haunt. Really interesting old architecture but I don't think I'd feel safe on a night time as very dark and dingy.

Amazing!. The Gothic Quarter was definitely our favorite place in Barcelona! If you are visiting Barcelona do not miss spending time wandering up and down the narrow streets, visiting the multitude of tapas bars and just taking in the scenery. If at all possible, I would recommend choosing a hotel that is located within the Gothic Quarter.

Great neighborhood to get lost in. Tiny streets and great shops. This was a great area to wander around in and just get lost. We also stumbled upon a great wine and food market just below the Gothic cathedral. Tons of food and drinks at very reasonable prices.
Traditional. Our hotel was opposite the cathedral and the walks round the Barri Gothic were easy from our base. A few little tapas bars, although we couldn't ind them till the last night.

blueboy melbourne. Walking around this area was fascinating. Walking through narrow laneways that suddenly open into large squares. We just walked and discovered. It did take a while to track down the Picasso Museum but we discovered many other features in the process such as the Roman wall.
fun area. walking around this area with all the small squares and outside restaurants is very delightful. Love the ped-only streets with small interesting shops

Packed with history but doesn't feel like a museum.. We had a great time just wandering through the narrow streets, every corner brings a new church or tapas bar, and it's reasonably well lit at night. Top tip: remember to keep looking up, fabulous frescoes line many of the alleyways above head height, there are intricate lamp posts to admire and statues and gargoyles look down on you from bridges and churches.
A little gem round every corner. Narrow streets teeming with shops bars and cafés Tons of atmosphere but watch out for bag snatchers.

Great day of wandering!. Take a day to wander through this. The Cathedral and the Santa Maria del Mar are the highlights, but the maze of streets with the architecture and shops is great to get lost in. Book tickets for the Picasso museum online beforehand as the queues are long!

Great Part of Barcelona to Explore. This area is great to explore, Little alley ways that open up into squares, a rich selection of shops and restaurants with the odd Cathedral and museum thrown in. It is definitely worth setting aside a few hours to wander around this area. We did it in two stage - An explore mid morning with a brunch stop. Then on another day, a look around in the evening.It felt very safe both during the day and in the evening. Loads of people around and it is brightly lit. Shops appear to stay open late.Note : There are public toilets in the tourist information centre.
Nice narrow streets. We enjoyed the narrow streets with small bars and the wonderful old buildings. We visited it several times during our stay as it was near our hotel.
Great!. A great way to spent an afternoon or evening just wandering the tiny cobbled streets. Lots of interesting shops, bars and cafes.
