Lovely pleasant village. You must visit here to get the feel of the gothic village. Small alleyways full of beautiful buildings, shops, cafes and restaurants. Not over priced either as compared to la ramblas. A safe local feel to the place.

SHOES!!!. What a fab array or little alleys to explore! You will everything you need here, from souvenirs to clothes, shoes (beautiful shoes....) and bars and restaurants. But it is interspersed with lots of old buildings so don't forget to look up! And we went during an annual festival so the parades and nightlife were amazing!
Fun and safe neighborhood. We totally enjoyed all that the Gothic Quarter has to offer: the churches, restaurants, bars, shops. We stayed out late into the night and always felt safe.

Worth the visit. Take the camera. The old city is located to the left of La Rambla if you are heading toward the Sea. Lots of winding alleyways filled with shops and lots of bars and restaurants to stop and relax at. Found a great restaurant with Entrée, Main, Dessert, Bread and 2 glasses of wine for 10 euro, The choice of entre also included a great paella which was a decent size.There are lots of shoe shops worth checking out selling Spanish and Italian made shoes at a fraction of the price we pay in Australia (even with the poor exchange rate).Street performers (instrumental and singers) find the perfect places to use to gain the best acoustic advantages in the area and are certainly worth listening to.I am not a history buff but certainly enjoyed my visit to the gothic quarter. There are numerous photo opportunities in this area.

AWESOME VIBE - DON'T MISS THIS!. Amazing medieval buildings - architecture and mysterious narrow alley ways - we have spend hours just wandering through this vibey area. Amazing restaurants - excellent tapas restaurants oozing charms and atmosphere.
Great area to walk around. Great architecture, shops, places to eat. A unique area in middle of city. Nice place to wander around for an afternoon. Safe. Nice art shops

Not to be missed. The Gothic Quarter is a breath from Las Ramblas. The pace and the environment changes all of the sudden giving way to a feeling of what must have been like to live in centuries past complete with the architecture, and the living.
lesson in history. If you are interested in architecture and history this is a great place to visit., much to see and area is pretty safe and easy to get around on your own.
Nice place. Good for shopping and eating. We had a hotel in the area we had a lot of fun on the terraces with good food, drinks and service.

Great experience.. The Gothic quarter of Barcelona was a great experience. We walked the many streets, saw the Cathedral and old Jewish section. Had a great paella with noodles rather then rice. It was fun neighborhood to walk around or grab a gelato in.

Fantastic. The gothic quater is unmissable is you like history. There are lots of small narrow alley ways, with tell imposing buildings running alongside. There are some brilliant independent shops, and always a bar or restaurant around the corner when you need to relax

Step back in time. Just spend time wandering the gothic quarter getting lost and you will stumble across the most amazing alleyways and little shops. Found a little clock place with so many different types of clocks and mechanisms on them. Also had an amazing hot chocolate and churro a in a quaint little cafe off the beaten track. You could spend days wandering there.
The old Barcelona. Incredible, full of tiny and narrow streets with a lot of nightlife, bars, discos, restaurants. Full of tourists though, but a great place to feel the city's mood.

loved wandering. really enjoyed the little streets. had some good coffee, good wine and really good paella from numerous places. can be really different street by street, some are more populated, some are more deserted. always keep your eyes open and make good choices.

Worth Seeing!. We explored this area through a 2-hour Las Ramblas and Gothic Quarter tour. The Gothic Quarter has so much interesting architecture as well as a lot of history and interesting tid-bits about Barcelona. It was amazing how this area is situated between the modern parts of Barcelona. It makes one feel as if they have transported back in time especially with the street performers who were playing music in the alleys! There are many shops, restaurants, and pubs in this area. Definitely recommend visiting!
Day in Gothic Quarter. Beautiful buildings. Lots to see and do. Great. Gothic Cathedral absolutely beautiful. Plenty of restaurants to suit all tastes.

Great. We took a Gothic walking tour and enjoyed learning about the history of the quarter. In the evening, we went for dinner to one of the numerous restaurants. The quarter is really bustling and fun. Although this is the center for tourist activities, the restaurants are great. We were in Barcelona and I only regret that we did not go down to the quarter for dinner more often.

Lost and loving it!!. The thing i enjoyed most about this part of Barcelona was all the walkways that you could explore. You might get lost but its worth it because you never know what you might discover around the corner.

A wonderful example of old Barcelona. Beautiful streets and alleyways with a variety of stores, restaurants and architecture. Disappointed we didn't find this til our last evening, don't waste your time on Las Ramblas, apart from the weird street performers.
Amusing. Each street is different and hide a misterious environment. It is medieval, gothic and well conserved.

Goregous to walk around at night. The gothic quarter is lovely to walk around at night. There are so many little walkways to get lost in and take in the architecture, also lots of little bars hidden away to discover. Fab!
fun little alleys. this is what you want an old city to feel like. We found that the tapas tour with Barcelona Cooking was a great way to explore this area.

Fantastic. We loved this area, our hotel was close by and we spent many hours walking the cobbled stoned lanes, it's like a maze.
There are coffee shops, tapas bars, wine bars, pubs, fresh produce markets, boutiques, leather shops and the list goes on.
Many interesting historic buildings, churches in this area.
We loved it!
It was a good experience. We had walking tour for Gothic Quarter. There were fantastic roads and buildings and you can feel the historical places
Wonderful atmosphere. It is great to explore the web of narrow streets and beautiful squares. Some stunning architecture to be seen.

An absolute must see when visiting Barcelona. Lots of bespoke shops situated in narrow Gothic streets with ornate frontages and wonderful street lights. Anything and everything seems to be on sale here and it's so pretty.
disappointment. We were expecting what everyone else probably does when you think "Gothic Quarter" - gargoyles! Needless to say, there were none, just a big church like building....womp womp.

Back to the middle ages...... The oldest quarter of the city, with a lot of sights. Wonderful Santa Eulalia Cathedral, Santa Maria del Mar Basilica, beautiful old houses, narrow streets, arches, balconys, and a unique atmosphere.
Cute little shops, tapas, restaurants, cafes on the little places. Street musicians. Very good to walk through.
Great area. Really liked the El Born area. Lots of shops to mooch in, bars to sup in and a wide choice of cuisines to eat.

A little time capsule.. Well worth staying in this quarter,quaint streets and fantastic restaurants mean if you didn't want to stray too far you could spend a whole week just exploring, the guided tour of this area is well worth doing, go with the flow,Barcelona has something for everyone. We were there in January and we didn't feel bored for a second and being out of season, meant that Las Ramblas and the Sigada Famillia were not so busy.
Love it!. You could wander here for days, love the narrow streets and eclectic shops/restaurants the area has to offer. You really do need to experience it as the "old" part of Barcelona!

Our favorite part of our Barcelona trip. Wandering the streets of the Barri Gotic and La Ribera was the most memorable part of our visit. We put the guidebook away and turned down streets and alleys as we came to them. Every time we turned a corner, there was a new architectural wonder- from ancient Gothic buildings to quaint squares and parks, and newer buildings from many eras - their architecure and facades amazed and delighted us. We found streets that were specifically devoted to certain trades - some of them for tourists - but not all. This was the real Barcelona - away from the "tourista" version of Barcelona on Las Ramblas. We were away from the crowds, and able to take our time to enjoy the buildings, the people, and the ambiance.

A must do its just Beautiful. Highly recommend going to here or staying here as there are lots of lovely hotels located here with bars, shops and many tapas bars and restaurants locted ibn this part of Barcelons
My fav part of Barcelona!!. I could walk the streets here all day! Just when you think you have seen it all, another surprise comes along. Enjoy a drink, shop, and people watch

Gothic Quarter. Our Segway Tour guide said just wander around the Gothic Quarter and get lost - and we did. Spent ages browsing the lovely colourful boutiques lining every lane, stopped for a cold beer or churros con chocolate when we got tired - just allow some free time to amble and soak up the atmosphere.
Loved it...... Windy pathways, interesting shops, good food places and a wealth of history surrounds you in this area. Pleasant, easy and a nice place to get in and around.
A must visit. Barcelona has done an excellent job here maintaining the historical aspect of this quarter along with the many unique shops
Old and interesting. A little like me! Take a walk around the quarter and soak up the history, avoid the peddlars though and make sure you have your hand on your wallet. St George rides again.

Time to get lost!. Tiny winding streets packed with interesting medieval architecture and boutique shops, all clashing wonderfully with layers of sprayed grafitti? Yes please! Get lost in this maze of antiques, perfumiers, and treasure troves of jewellery...I wandered away with jasmine oil, silk scarves, bronze lapel pins, and fresh fig caramels. Heaven! The shops were a little hit and miss as to when they were open, but the architecture is interesting in itself, and the area is close enough to more tourist attractions to pop back another time if needed!

Nice. We lived there in a 200 years old building. And every time we walked through the Quarter, we found something new, something striking. And excellent dining possibilities. But you never know when the small shops there are open. I wonder - how do they make their living :-)
Public market. Is only there till the middle of Oct but is a great way to sample the local food fare. We're warned frequently by tour guides about pick pockets but had no such experience

So many hidden gems. I love Barcelona and a wonder around the Barri Gotic will transport you away from the hustle and bustle of La Ramblas, down the small historic side streets with gothic architecture. If you know where you're going, its beautiful and off the beaten track.

best routes. Try your chance in the narrow streets connected to Carrer de ferran, Carrer Avinyo, Via Laietana.
Visit Born district at night time and grab a glass of Sangria next to Santa Maria Del Mar.
Nice to ramble. It's a bit hit and miss as to which shops will be open. Service is also marginal. Not sure if that's the case generally or just for tourists.
shop shop shop. This section of Barcelona is great for shopping. Especially if you enjoy just kicking back and shopping at all the small one off shops

Wander at will. Loved the Gothic Quarter - winding streets, an amazing Cathedral, lots of history and culture, shops, cafes, restaurants and Tapas bars - everything you could need in Barcelona is there.

Incredible place. Once you get away from Las Ramblas, and into the Gothic Quarter you soon realise the charm and character of the old Barcelona. The narrow streets and charming squares take on a new persona after dark with the dimly lit streets lighting creating a perfect atmosphere to stroll and take in a bar or two. Miss this and you will miss out.

Great atmosphere. we just loved casually walking though the Gothic sector of this city we loved the atmosphere and the vibrancy of this precinct this is a must do if staying in Barcelona and we spent a few days doing this.
Amazing. Amazing atmosphere, good to walk around without following the map. Lots of places to eat. Don't miss this quartier.
Not that exciting. Everyone says this is a must but we found it average. Yes their are some pretty little streets but give me a small French town like Quimper every time.
Just wander around!. Lovely area, lots to wander around and see. Felt quite safe at night too. We found it hard to negotiate using a map, just walk about to get your bearings.

Great for a days strolling around. Small gems and great restaurants are hidden in little alleys with spectacular architecture. Dont be in a rush, you are on holiday afterall and enjoy what this great city has to offer.
shops!. Loved walking around the Barri Gotic, lovely individual and unusual shops. Enjoyed the gotic cathedral and the market, lots of little outdoor cafes and restaurants within this area
beautiful, well worth the visit. A must see, beautiful architecture. Spend some time appreciate the time the artists spent working on the buildings.

Great market food and the tallest palm tree i've ever seen. Didn't really get to see much of the churches but enjoyed the area for the market and views. Admittedly we weren't really looking for the attractions, we just happened to stumble upon them. The area was very tranquil and did't carry the same hustle and bustle as others in Barcelona
Unique and beautifull. What a place, real history, fantastic Atmosphere. A labyrinth of narrow gothic streets. A must see place!!!
Venice without canals. Classic old narrow streets wiht alleyways. easy to get lsot, but not for long. Excellent shops/restaurants.
Great for a stroll. Away from the bustling Rambla there is a fascinating network of lanes and squares to explore. Plenty of cafes, bars and places to sit and watch people.
Not to be missed. This quarter of Barcelona is one of the most interesting from an architecture viewpoint as well as the numerous shops, restaurants and cafes.

A mixture of style and history (Jewish and Christian). I liked the narrow streets that suddenly opens towards large open squares decorated by Gaudi street lamps, and sometimes occupied with food markets or noise demonstrations.

A maze of narrow streets with hidden gems. It is easy to get lost so have a good street map to hand. Despite graffiti on most doors the streets were litter and dog mess free - not many cities manage that. Every street reveals its own secrets with great places to discover

Fun wandering our way around and through great Gothic structures. Took a free walking tour around the Gothic Quarter and saw some wonderful historic structures with some quiet plazas away from the crowds and noise. Our Travel Bound guide lead a walk and provided interesting commentary. Made for a wonderful afternoon in an old part of Barcelona.

Nice place to walk around. This is a great place to walk around and explore the little shops. It's a very quaint area and a nice way to spend an hour or two. Make sure to go to the Cathedral, it's free to visit between 8 and 12:45 and between 5:15 and 7:30 Monday through Saturday and between 8 and 1:45 and 5;15 and 7:30 on Sundays.
Heart of barcelona. No way to discover this place but to walk, a lot of walking. See, feel, taste and admire gothic quarter.
Lovely area. A great shopping area, plus great historic sites to see, abundant places to eat, beautiful city squares, a must!

Lovely. We really enjoyed walking through the streets of the Gothic Quarter as soon as we arrived to Barcelona. The history is fascinating. Suggest booking a tour through the Barcelona Turisme Office. The guides are really knowledgeable, and even watched out for pickpockets for us a few times. The tours are short, but you are able to really get your footing. We have beautiful pictures from this area in Barcelona. Definitely a must-do.

Excellent sightseeing. The heart of the area is Plaza Catalunya with its hustle and bustle, fountains, tourist buses, transportation hub, shops, department stores and restaurants. Located at the north end of Las Ramblas, the must see street of the entire area. Las Ramblas runs about 1 miles north-south from Plkaza Catalunya to the port of Barcelona at the south. Filled with HP, street performers, and all sorts of interesting sights. Not to be missed.

Gothic quarter unique place. Gotta at least walk around the quarter for an afternoon. Everywhere you turn is a piece of history. All the little side streets and plazas are full of shops and cafes. It's very crowded and I kept a watchful eye on my belongings. Much to see and do here!

Definitely take a stroll through here. This neighborhood is awesome. I wish I could live here. SO many awesome things to see (great architecture) and cute little restaurants and shops every where you turn. Definitely my favorite part of barcelona!
Cute Place. Beautiful architecture all around topped off with narrow streets filled with shopping! Definitely stop by here on your trip to Barcelona!

Atmospheric area. I can imagine the Barri Gotic area with its narrow alleys and tall old buidings being a bit intimidating for someone used to a more open modern environment - it just takes a little getting used to - once you have, you'll enjoy it. It's what you come on holiday for - to see the city and how it lives.

Fantastic!. Barri Gothic is the most fantastic sight I managed to visit in Barcelona!I was lucky to leave in a guesthouse situated right on a small street of this district. One may spend all day long walking up and down the wonderful streets of the district - and they are still safe!, watch and listen to street musicians from all over the world, get a good opportunity of shopping - almost all brands are represented here, have a nice dinner - lots of restaurants and open-air cafes.My beloved place was the square in front of the Cathedral - I used to spend my nights here, listening to musician bands on Saturdays and watching Catalonian dances, break-dancers and singers on all other days.The Cathedral itself is a gem inside of the district. And many museums and galleries add fantastic impressions as well.That was the best experience we got there and definitely will go again when back to Barcelona!
explore the alleyways. wonder around and nosh on ice cream whilst you do! look for marcos gelatiria off the municipality square
a must walk. it was my 4th time to Barcelona and after doing this walk i got a different sense of the city and it's long history.read before you go there or do a guided tour.

The Charming Center of old Barcelona. Obviously with the Cathedral and several other highlighted places to see here, the Barri Gotic is a must-see part of any trip to Barcelona. But a friend, Jim Utz, recommended the area by saying, "You can get lost there...in a good way." And he was right. You'll never stay lost for long, and the warren of tiny streets features one surprise after another. Good places to eat, to shop, to relax, and then of course there is Cathedral Square -- I had the great good luck to come upon it just as the sardana was being danced -- this slow, circular dance (a bit Zorba-the-greek-ish) is something tourists love to see, and for some, to participate in, but it's a dance of, by and for the Catalan people. It has a social aspect as it brings them together, and a political one, as it unites them in deeper ways. Yes, there are more than a fair share of tourist shops, but it remains one of my favorite parts of a great city! Oh, and don't be afraid to get a bit lost...it's the best way to get to know a new city.

Walk and see Barcelona at the best. The Barri Gotic is a place to walk and walk and walk just to see and appreciate the architecture, the people, the restaurants. Don't miss large streets. Barcelona is a very "handicapped friendly". I think that the Barri Gotic is the "sense" of Barcelona.
Interesting. Didn't see the whole thing, but there's a wide range of businesses on the streets. Definitely worth a look if you're in the city.
Astounding!. We were lucky to book a hotel in Barri Gotic! That's an area where you can feel the glorious past of the city.

Barri Gotic worth some time to ramble. The Barri Gotic area is the oldest part of the city and has a lot of gothic architecture, including the cathedral ,which is definitely worth a look, and then many narrow streets opening out into small squares and spaces with cafes, bars, restaurants etc which are great for evening meals. We enjoyed our meal in Tarantara, a choice of tapas, all very freshly prepared, we shared risotto with various salads, a dish of roasted small peppers, a plate of whitebait, and a bottle of wine for about 50 euros for two. great service, pleasant and quiet on a Sunday night. Eat in the restaurant if you want to avoid the additional charge for eating outside in the square.

Gothic quarters. The architecture and pride in maintaining the historical sites of Gothic quarters were amazing and impressive. The fact the you could find random stones from hundreds of years ago, makes you want to look into every wall and step to feel close to history. Styles were simple and beautiful.

Do a walking tour. We did a morning walking tour of the Gothic Quarter in english starting at 9.30am from the Tourist Office on Placa St Jaume. It was an excellent introduction to this beautiful area of Barcelona. The tour guide was entertaining and knowledgeable and provided historical, political and social commentary on the buildings in the area and Catalonia generally. The area is remarkable in its diverse architecture and its place in Catalan history. The tour was money well spent and provided a framework for further exploration.
Getting lost has never been so much fun. Lots of narrow streets and alleyways, each with their own surprises. Hidden bars, clubs, museums and shops all waiting to be found.
A trip back in time. The Gothic Quarter is a surprising find in the middle of Barcelona. Remarkable well kept and very charming. Don't forget to come back in the evening to enjoy the mystery...
Classic. Another one of Barcelona's gems to share with travelers. Don't miss this opportunity to see why visitors rave about it.

A Mesmerizing Experience. Wondering through the streets of the gothic quarter was one of my favorite experiences in Barcelona. Visit the Picasso Museum, stroll along the cobblestone streets peaking inside the many shops or sit and enjoy tapas at a local bar. We stumbled upon the remnants of the festivities of La Merce and watched the dance of the Catalonia. Plenty of historic churches, but ladies, carry a sweater or scarf as shoulders must be covered when entering any of the cathedrals.

Great to Stroll Along. The Gothic Quarter has lots to offer. It is very different at night, so visit both during the day and later. Be a bit careful late evenings as the narrow streets can be a bit unsettling if you go off the tourist trail. If eating-out as with any honey trap, food is that bit more expensive.

Eclectic and different. We stayed at the K K Picasso hotel just at the end of the Gothic Quarter, this neighborhood is full of character and interesting shops. very affordable and with a younger crowd, if you are looking for a quiet refined place this may not be for you. Very Bohemian and fun.Gerat for shopping, you will find plenty of stores with hand made items and unique gifts.

My Favorite Barcelona Area. Even with maps and directions, navigating the Barri Gotic is best done with a guide. Although we loved what mystery was found behind every corner and narrow alley, we would never have found the Roman Columns without latching on to a tour group and following them. Although in another language, it still got us to hidden places. Most we did manage to find on our own. We did the Taste of Barcelona Tapas tour which also was great for a guided tour, making our way back to some of the same places to eat the next day. Do not miss the stunning Catedral de Barcelona in the center square of the Gothis quarter. It is free and not to be missed. Your shoulders and knees need to be covered but it is amazing inside and the side cathedral houses the 13 geese. The Gotic quarter is alive and easy to reach. This is where to find great food, not on Las Ramblas. There are many museums and sights to behold. We wandered upon a great square at night on the way to the metro station and had no idea what it was but realized a hotel was surrounding the square. We had no problems, but be aware of your belongings at all time.
Great walking and shopping.. So many lovely shops and interesting spots take your time and just wander. Don't miss the dancing in front of the Cathedral on Saturday evenings and Sunday mornings.
wonderful place to spend your afternoon. Lots of small shops and things to see. We had tea break at Caelum which was awesome. Do try their hot chocolate if you are a choc lover :)

The center of the action. Our hotel/apartment was just off the Placa Sant Jaume and we were steps away from the festivities of La Merce. There were Sardana (the dance of Catalonia) competitions, the castelleros building human pyramids and towers, parades with 'the giants' meandering through the old streets. It was wonderful. Lots of restaurants and shops and museums tucked in amongst the beautiful stonework.

Must visit!. The gothic quarter is lovely! Theres lots of little shops which sell good nick nacks to take home with you, like tapas bowls etc. It's all made of stone and looks really pretty, we didnt spend long there, but 2 hours was enough to go inside the barri gotic and have a little nosy around! there was some buskers as well which were nice

Place where Barcelona was born. The beginnings of Barcelona were at "Ciudad Vella", it is a must visit the Gothic Quarter, the Born and " La Rambla", you can spend the whole day getting around and visiting Santa María del mar Church, La Mercé church, Barcelona's cathedral, la Boquería market and walk, la Rambla all these places nearby, full of places to eat, shop or eat "tapas" . Can Culleretes is inside the Gothic Quarter and one of the oldest Spanish restaurants that is still serving and has gone from generation to generation.

My kind of Place. With so much art and local querky shops you can spend many hours here and still not see much of it. So many possibilities. Comes alive at night, so many tapas bars, you will be spoilt for choice.
A great place to spend an afternoon. There were a tonne of shops to look in and lots of old buildings to take photos of. A nice charming place to spend a half a day.

Be careful where you walk here at night. There are parts of this neighborhood which are definitely not safe at night. Be particularly aware of what is going on around you, and when it begins to look sketchy, re-think the direction you're heading and turn back. Last night we were having trouble finding a guidebook restaurant, and the first place we stopped to ask directions we waited while a man ahead of us told the hotel clerk that he'd just been robbed. Then we stopped to ask a shopkeeper directions, and after he told us where to head, he added, "Don't go in that direction! It's dangerous there!" Looking around us, he was right. Most areas are fine, but watch where you are. And just because there's a restaurant in a guidebook, it doesn't mean that walking to get there is safe. Also, you can't take a cab into this neighborhood because the streets are pedestrian only. Daytime here seems great, highly recommended.

Don't miss it!. This is a great area of Barcelona, walk through it during the day and then again during the night, it is an amazing maze of little strees and small squares dotted with countless restaurants and bars. Truly an uforgettable experience.
Great area. Great area to just walk around and take in all the sights, people,shops, vendors, buildings, music playing in some of the courtyards.

Simply beautiful. My favorite place in Barcelona! the Gothic Cathedral was mesmerizing, the atmosphere itself was relaxing. I recommend staying around the Quarter for a while, there is so many things to do there, If i recalled (went there in May 2013) there is also a Piccaso museum there.

Get lost in this beautiful part of town.. When you enter the area, it feels a big spooky. There are al ot of narrow streets and all buildings are dark grey. But soon you will find out that it is a very lively neighborhood with a lot of hidden beautiful buildings and squares. The perfect area to get lost and discover something new in each corner.The area has become much more touristic than before and prices have definitely gone up, but it is still a beautiful place to walk through. At night, it may be not as safe as before. Therefore, I would recommend to do the tour during the day.

Barcelona's Gothic Quarter. We walked through this area of Barcelona and really enjoyed it. All of the Gothic Quarter is just a few steps off Las Ramblas.From the cathedral with it's gargoyles for roof drains to the narrow little streets, this is really entrancing and cozy. The little streets have really neat shops to browse through. Anything from nice leather shops, funky clothing and shoes to full head masks that sit on your shoulders, there are amazing sights around each corner. There are also examples of modern art that we stumbled upon. Really a great afternoon exploring Barcelona.

Amazing!. I've been visiting this quarter two times. In a day time you can see details of each building and squares, get the rest under the wall of some gothic cathedral and buy something in amazing independent fashion shops or find nice stuff for your home interior. Late in the evening walking around the quarter down the small streets gives you a sense of a quest! Authentic restaurants and bars gonna welcome you by the magic lights...
Walk the streets and feel the history.. Stayed in an apt through friendly rentals right on a small street. Art galleries and chocolate. Make sure you take a couple walking tours.

Nice to wander around. We walked in and out of the streets of Barri Gotic - the achitecture was beautiful - lots of churches to visit. It was also nice to see/listen to street performers and there wasn't a lack of good places to eat the "menu del dia".
Amazing Survived part. amazing part that survived in span. A must see with a tour guide to appreciate how old is barcelona.
Medieval. The place is so charming, full of shops and restaurants..just avoid it at night where lots of young people gangs fill the place

Great place to wander. Loved the food market and the cafes and the other suprises hidden in the maze of streets. Warning you may never be able to find your way back to the fascinating shops and cafes hidden in these tiny streets.

Just get lost in this great part of town. Just walking around is fantastic and you always find something new, interesting and unexpected. The shopping is good and the sightseeing is just as good. Do not miss the cathedral and it's library.

A beautiful early morning stroll. Hit this early before the crowds engulf it. It is easy to picture what life might have been like walking down these narrow streets hundreds of years ago. The sanctuary of the cathedral was beautiful. We skipped the Picasso museum since the Seattle Art Museum just had an exhibit from the same place. The lines were daunting but the space itself looks unique and beautiful so we may have regrets we didn't see it.

A great walking tour you can do by yourself.. And great way to spend 1-2 hours. Visit the cathedral, see the walls of medevil times, and visit the shops. If you want to spend a whole day, venture to the market and walk up and down ramble street. Have fun!

Lovely traditional area, real Barcelona!. The Gothic Quarter is one of the loveliest and most traditional areas of Barcelona. There are numerous small alleys and lanes that go around lot of shops, eateries and other lovely buildings. The area is even more beautiful at night ans it is full of people havinga a good time. Best area to hang out with friends, though I was there with my better half.

Lots to see and do. The gothic quarter in Barcelona is excellent -- there is a lot to see and do. We experienced it through a free walking tour, which I would highly suggest. The tour guides are fun and knowledgeable. The gothic quarters has lots of shops and history; showing everything from the Roman history of the city, to the dictatorship that ruled the area. I would definitely recommend seeing this if you only have 1 day in the city.
Strool and get carried away in the past!. It is nice to walk around the narrow alleys and see many curiosity shpos or old biuldings. The Cathedral is a must and try to stay a bit to see the vitraux!
Just get lost in it. Such a beautiful area full of hidden gems, wander around and get lost and you find shops, restaurants, bars and churches. Especially lovely at night
Scenic, Fun Area to Shop and Eat. Narrow streets, little shops, it's a nice place to walk and catch the sights. It was pretty busy in the evening but the daytime is good.

Best place to stay in!. We rented an apartmanet for a week so I would definitely recommend to stay at this qtr. as the hotels are also very good there. it is lively and full of visitirs all day and night, the atmosphere is amazing! safe at night and fun to be
Barcelona's Heart. All kinds of twisty little streets, interesting shops, people watching, lovely architecture. Small squares tucked in here and there.
Take a leisurely stroll. The Barri Gotic is a wonderful neighborhood for strolling and sightseeing. We took the self-guided Rick Steves tour and enjoyed it thoroughly.

Rented a room with a view. We rented a room using air BnB in the Gothic Quarter in an old building that had lots of charm and a lovely balcony overlooking a busy side street. It was so much fun to live like a local for a few days. There were lots of places to shop and eat within walking distance and we quickly discovered that if you went on the small side streets the food prices were much better than on the large thoroughfares. My friend is vegan and she discovered several places that catered to her needs and was pleased with the options offered. I went on the FREE BArri Gotic tours and enjoyed both of them. I took two tours since I really wanted to see and learn lots. The host of the rental apartment was in charge of one of the tours and he showed us places to eat and the several Gaudi properties. The free tours can be found on line or by asking at the hotel/airbnb hosts, etc. It was great to wander all the little side streets, get lost and get found again, have a delicious pastry....do try their melted chocolate hot chocolate...lots of little cafes offer it and it is amazing! We felt safe even late at night. One last thing...we used restaurant bathrooms and were a little disapointed in the fact that way too many were missing towels or soap or tp. so bring some sanitizer and some tp when u travel through spain.

Book a guided tour. Search the web for "free" (small donation) guided walking tours of the Gothic Quarter - there are so many stories behind the streets and old buildings that you will miss just walking around by yourselves.
A good place to explore and enjoy. Spent a few hours here exploring the small, winding roads basking on the architecture, food, specialty shops and just enjoying this part of Barcelona.

Characterful Old Quarter. This was the old medieval city before the expansion project of acentury ago. Lots of narrow streets the widest only room for onevehicle each way. This really gave you a feel for what an old citycentre was like almost all built of stone. At night it was very well lit and you felt safe, police noticeable at all times. Would take some time to find get round some of the tourist sights including city walls. Gateway by the cathedral was very impressive..Many interesting looking bars, restaurants and shops.

Barcelona a big disappointment.. Where to start? 1.First night wallet stolen by "Brazilian" giving us directions (which were totally wrong). 2. Dinner on Las Ramblas - sign - "Special Dinner with tapas and paella" - awful, awful! Medium beer comes in about a 2L stein for about 15 E. 3. Tour bus, which we caught late in the day, guaranteed the tickets were also good the next day. They were not. 4. After 4 days of awful food we finally found a hole in the wall in the Gothic area that was great. 5. Our 1 bedroom apartment in the Gothic area came complete with the apartment renter and her two children. Our bed was more or less a mattress on the floor - but they were great people. 6. The Gaudi cathedral costs 15 E and most other sights are similarly priced. All in all - it was one big tourist trap.

Full of character. This was an area we kept coming back to. A great place for a slow wander with loads of interesting bars and restaurants. Narrow winding streets with something different round every turn. At night it really comes alive.

Not to be missed. This area of Barcelona is full of little streets with shops and cafés. A large square which as restaurants all around it. When we visited there was a large stage in the middle with bands playing. The Cathedral is another wonderful sight. There is no charge but remember to take something to cover your shoulders.
Lots to see. Perfect for a Sunday morning wander, beautiful buildings, charming coffee bars to people watch. Lovely atmosphere.

Great if you like people watching and meandering. This is a half day wander around winding streets and not following any map, its a voyage of discovery and not to be planned, each corner takes you to something new and exciting, worth a few glasses of wine along the way to soak up the atmosphere..

misterious. this quarter is very good for waling, you go by very stretch streets with 5-6 floor old buildings and many stores where you can buy souvenirs, there is a lot of "paquis" in the area trying to sell anything to you.

Loved staying here. We enjoyed staying the quarter. There were bakeries and green grocers steps away from our apartment. We awoke each day to the aroma of bread baking. We took a walking tour and enjoyed learning some of the history of the area. Lots of public transportation made seeing the rest of the city easy.

So much to see. We wondered there this area for a week it was wonderful The small tapes bars. The Fabulous shop , the churches So much to see the old part of Barcelona the history there is amazing Don't miss this great area

Stunning architecture galore. The Barri Gotic is one of the best known features of Barcelona and for good reason, the architecture is absolutely stunning. I spent a fair bit of time just wandering the streets enjoying the sights, if you're a fan of interesting and unusual buildings like me you'll be in your element here.

Good mooching. great area just to wander around. Easy to stumble on little bars and cafes and interesting shops selling sweets, cakes, clothes, gifts, art and tourist shops. There are some gems of shops selling some really original products. No road seemed to have a theme, it is all jumbled in together. Don't forget to look up- interesting buildings and views to absorb.
a step back in time. An interesting well preserved area from an earlier era. The narrow streets, squares, specialist shops, cafe's and architecture make for a fascinating one to two hours exploring .
Lively. A nice area to spend an evening. Great, authentic restaurants and bars. Just remember to keep your valuables close as the streets get pretty busy.

Get lost in this fascinating area!. The Barri Gotic - the gothic area of Barcelona is a fascinating maze of narrow streets that wind & twist, & ensure that getting lost is a certainty that can lead to an unexpected square or hidden gem of a hotel, restaurant, bar, shop or ancient Roman wall - or one of the many stone churches. Great tapas bars, coffee roasting shops or delicious sweets & coffee shops mingle with gypsies (watch your bags), buskers, locals & fellow tourists. A fascinating cultural, architectural, historic & culinary mix.

Fantastic - great little bars/restaurants in wonderful old buildings.. Had a wonderful time eating & drinking and meeting all the local people. My husband and I were hailed as "Mamma & Pappa" and treated to great food.

nice stroll in town. The Barri Gotic was a few blocks from where our hotel was. So we decided to take a stroll that way, there are many interesting buildings to see and also places to eat and shop. there were a couple of sites to see shows there too. We like it and felt safe enough to go back another day at night, we enjoed it both times. a must see.

Gothic quarter. Loved looking around the Gothic quarter, all little side streets and shops which then opens up to reveal the Gothic Cathedral which is a sight to behold, free entrance before one o clock. Well worth a look.
Must see. Especially the courtyard by the cathedral. It gives you an impression of the medieval atmosphere. The white guese are a long tradtiion, from Roman times
Best restaurants in this area. We found cake/coffee shop in this area - "Sweet dreams" - amazing cakes and milkshakes. Owner really nice too - told us about his wife being a culinary artist

Great ambiance. It doesn't matter whether you are a seasoned tourist in the European old world or a first comer, you will love the ambiance, the people, the dense architecture, the charm and of course the food. I have seen large and small cities in France and Italy, and even Madrid in Spain, but still enjoyed very much the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona, couldn't help taking pictures of architectural landmarks, or just quaint shops and crowded plaza. Besides La Rambla and the tourist sites dedicated to Gaudi, Picasso and Joan Miro, the Gothic Quarter is a must see destination if you are in Barcelona the first time. Barcelona couldn't be Barcelona without it. We were there in September when the weather was still absolutely pleasant, having a small meal at a restaurant in open air and soaking in the atmosphere was one of the highlight of the trip. Enjoy!

Perhaps the highlight of our visit. Getting lost in the Barri Gotic was one of many highlights of our short break to Barcelona. We were a little scared of other reviews that warned of thieves, pickpockets etc to the point of carrying a bum-bag! But just keep your wits about you like you would in any city and it will be fine.Actually, I felt safer in Barcelona than I did walking the dog in rural Wiltshire when we got home! Enjoy the sights, sounds, people and amazing architecture.

Amazing place to wander, get lost and find.... This is my favorite neighborhood in Barcelona. It is right off La Ramblas and such fun to just wander around in. Just walk and who knows what cool site, shop, eatery you will find around the next random corner.

Going down. Some 10 years ago, and even more so earlier, this was a beautiful neighborhood. But the city should be careful: every menu now seems in 4 languages, service and quality are going down, prices up. It has become really too touristy! Petty thiefs know this too, crime is back in these hoods at night, so be careful. I stick to El Born these days when visiting, just a safer bet, also touristy but not in rip off overdrive.

I loved it. Lovely area, especially at night.. I loved it and went 2 times in my 4 days in Barcelona just recently. I met very nice people, had wonderful food and wine and caught a show at Las Tarantos as well. I always travel solo and no problem what so ever. Made friends with a lovely Hostess at a restaurant and we had some wine afterwards and met some lovely and very young ladies from Luxemburg on the Metro and we went Disco dancing. Not bad for a lady that just turned 70 while I was in Spain and Italy.
Lovely area. So much is so close. The streets/alleys are really confusing though. Just a few blocks off Las Ramblas.

Barcelona Downtown.. Finally, I managed to go in the Downtown. This is a lovely, small and special place in Barcelona. There are a lot of small cafes and shops, plus a lot of old and interesting buildings. Love it!!!

Wonderful architecture. Such gorgeous architecture and so much is well preserved and in use today. We had fun just wandering through the lanes and streets lined with shops, cafes, churches and govt buildings.

Centries of Intrigue. Centuries of Intrigue surround you on every step in this area of Barcelona. Now a definite tourist mecca, one can imagine first hand the lives of those who lived there first. Numerous shops today where shops have existed for eons. Today they sell jewelry, artwork, and memorabilia. Earlier times would have them selling staple goods for daily life. Narrow streets on which you can get lost, but you will find your way out in a minute or so.

really old world. The streets are narrow and crooked. We were in a small group that visited the old Synagogue. My husband got separated and we never saw him again until we returned to the ship. The sights are really interesting. Lots of old buildings, castles. We saw where Queen Isabel waited for Columbus. The is definitely one of the sites you shouldn't miss in Barcelona.

Gothic Quarter. Absolutely loved the area and all the beautiful old buildings. A photographers paradise. Easy to get around on foot through here and we accidently came across in a side street a very beautiful old cathedral with a court yard pond. Well worth exploring this area.
Incredible. Well worth the visit. We took a walking tour of the area and it was fascinating. Lots of history and character.

Unforgettable. First, just wander around and take in the sights. The stores, bars, restaurants and people from everywhere are amazing. Then go back with your guide book and learn about everything you just saw, some of it dating back to the reign of the Emperor Augustus!

Maze of Streets and Alleys. Stayed in this part of Barcelona and every day of our weeks holiday we found another narrow street or alley to wander down and explore. Look up and see the amazing buildings all round, stop at the many and varied little tapas restaurants or cafes and enjoy all the squares that suddenly appear round the corner. Great area to walk round.

Nice to visit, but I wouldn't stay here. We booked an apartment that was in the heart of the Gothic area in Barcelona. They were right it being central however this area is way too noisy at night to get a restful sleep. They just don't stop partying!! It's great to visit, but take my advice and don't book a hotel or apartment.
Lost in a laneway. The Gothic Quarter is a maze of laneways, if you have time, then get lost and discover it for yourself, when something interests you stop and look, enter and taste.

Great Fun. We were lucky to be here during Merce a four day festival and lots going on any way, but we loved the old city it's cathedral and buildings lots to see lots of cafes bars and places to sit and people watch!

A charming way of losing yourself. No google maps can help you here. Its winding and interlocked alleys makes sure that you lose yourself in its charm. And, in the process, you really start to feel like a holiday. There is no way you can excape this place as a tourist

Nice walks and sights. I loved getting lost in little streets and taking in the feeling of times long gone. There are more and less busy streets, you can stop at cafes (touristy area, hence more pricey) but you never know what you will see- little squares and interesting architecture.

Vibrant and beautiful. If you visit Barcelona pop here for a truly magical feel,stepping out of the hustle of the city into this calm beautiful area! A piazza lined with bars and restaurants! Perfect for taking in the ambience on a warm evening and people watching!

So much to see. We didn't get started on our Barri Gotic tour early enough in the day. The Barcelona Cathedral closes to visitors at 7:30 pm; the Synagogue also closes to visitors. We walked the Barri Gotic using Rick Steves' pocket guide to Barcelona, and it's walking tour. Saw lots of interesting sites, but once it got dark, thought it best not to be the lone tourists in the dark alleys of the medieval city. Definitely make a stop at the 4 Cats, where Picasso and other artists hung out, and Picasso hung his first work at age 19.
Crowded, vivid and lively. Beautiful old area. Lots of squares with restaurants and bars. Narrow old and sheltered streets. We felt always safe, unlike the situayion 20 yrs ago.
Gothic Quarter. Walk as much as you can and avoid the tourist streets like the Rambla .......... Boring ......... Tourists only and restaurants extremely high priced ......
Beautiful architecture. A great place to explore, lots of interesting buildings plus restaurants and bars for the sight-seeing weary to take a rest! Well worth a visit.

Strolling heaven. Loved just walking around the Gothic Quarter. Lots of little alleyways with incredible architecture, quirky shops and beautiful little tapas bars. You could spend hours there and only touch on some of the amazing places there. Go, enjoy, you will not be disappointed.

LOVED THIS. I loved the Barri Gotic...the architecture is outstanding. You should take a guided tour though...it's worth it. There is a lot of history here and it would be easy to miss out on the meaning of a lot of the buildings.

Beautiful Old Neo Gothic (I know oxymoron) Buildings. If you like architecture like I do, then Barcelona is for you. The Old Quarter is an excellent area to visit with it's narrow streets and Neo Gothic architecture. A wonderful way to spend a few hours just looking at older beautiful buildings.
Yawn. We took the walk as laid out in the Lonely Planet guide...boring. Really wasn't very exciting at all.
Incredible Atmosphere and Style. My absolute favourite part of the city, full of soul, life, music, incredible art and shops and cafes to enjoy the atmosphere all day.
A MUST see!. Everything within a walking distance. Better, arrange a guided tour for getting all the extra info you need to understand city's going through time.

Fascinating.. Loved it, immensely entertaining. Can't wait to go back.
Planning on May next year. Learn some Spanish!

Absolutely stunning. Barcelona's Gothic Quarter was beautiful. Around every corner was a new surprise and the back alleys were bursting with culture. I could've spent the whole day here just wandering and exploring. Shops, cafés, churches, and gorgeous architecture--what more could you ask for? Can't wait to return.

One of our favourite areas in Barcelona. Just love the Barri Gotic - all around the cathedral is beautiful - lots of bars/cafes/restaurants and loads of lovely little snickets with unique shops. Absolutely recommend it. While we were there it was a fiesta time - absolutely packed, lots of atmosphere and live entertainment including a stage in front of the cathedral.

A vibrant, cool area.. It's always buzzing here! With some of the best food and bars, it's really worth wandering around these streets. Carrer Ample has a few excellent restaurants i.e. Gilda's - definitely worth a try! There are also some great shops in this area. Every night we stumbled across a new gem.
A Must Do. Gothic Quarter is fabulous not only for amazing historical buildings but also for shopping, cafes etc. Dont miss whilst in Barcelona. Very easy strolling around

Gorgeous Church. My husband and I were on our honeymoon and stayed in hotel colon which is across the street from the Gothic Quarter. We had a balcony view of the church. Gorgeous exterior. When we went to visit, entrance is free, HOWEVER..be sure to dress appropriately. I was not aloud in because I was wearing shorts, so we went back to the hotel to change. I put on a maxi skirt and a tank top and when we tried again I STILL was not aloud in because I guess the guard could see my bra straps? So i bought a scarf to cover and I was able to get in. Inside is beautiful. I recommend seeing it. Just make sure you are covered, ladies..
Loved it!. Great area of Barcelona with lots of history. Fun just getting lost! Stayed in the area with a group of friends and were able to walk everywhere for the most part, great area!

Wonderful for wandering and eating and drinking!. We stayed a block from the Santa Maria Del Mar gothic church. Loved everything about the area. Unique shops and pedestrian friendly streets and wonderful food and drink. Very lovely to spend a few days wandering around. Be sure to stop into the all the unique shops... even grocery stores have interesting items to look at!

Wonderful area to explore and eat. Loved the old world feel of the area and how well used both streets and alley's were. Some alley's sometimes seemed deserted and thus we did not venture down every nook and cranny, but in general it is lovely area to explore.

Gorgeous Architecture Everywhere!. You'll be amazed by the massive structures that have their own individual character in each and every facet. On a bus tour, you don't have time to stop and take the pictures, but we went back on foot and took our time strolling through here. Just absolutely amazing!
Good and quiet. A change from the good Barcelona Tapas, the food here is more towards the French. I liked the menus and wine list presented on wine bottles.
Just wander the streets. spend a couple just wandering the streets taking in all the sights as there seems to be something around every corner

So. Fantastic area to wander around. Such a relief from La Rambla yet just across the street!
It's quiet with lovely (and very old) buildings and squares.
It's very charming and has a lovely "local" feel despite the tourists wandering around.
Great way to spend a few hours getting a feel for the old Barcelona.
Great strolling. This is a wonderful place to poke around in some very interesting shops - artisans galore and many things are unique.
A nice place to wander. We strolled through the Gothic quarter - great atmosphere and lots of restaurants/cafes to choose from.
Beautiful area. Followed Rick Steves walk...wonderful church...the del bisbe bridge over the street is a sight to see!
Idealistic! . When walking here you'll get an idea why the people use scooters! It is very nice, good atmosphere and nice shops and restaurants in every street/alley. A must see!
No words, it was just great. it'shard to describe, you need to get there. we also were lucky to be there during some local festival, and it was great time
brilliant!. spend a week getting lost in here and El Born and discover all the wonderful surprises that await; Roman ruins, weird little shops, little squares of Fascist history...

Magical quarter. A magical quarter, full of galleries, boutiques and coffee shops.
You enjoy just from walking down the streets.
Don't forget to across the road and visit Born quarter too

Lovely to walk around day or night. Great atmosphere to walk around at night - bars and beautiful buildings, no cars in some areas
Lovely by day, quaint shops and museum

Loose yourself in it. Just walk the narrow streets and you will find interesting shops, great restaurants in small little squares. Could start at Las Ramblas ( Metro station) or on Via Laitenea. Bets way is to start on one of those 2 streets and walk toward the other using only the small streets and alleys.

Wow!. Buildings are among the oldest and historically richest in the Barri Gotic, the streets are like little labyrinths and many open to small squares. The many different cultural influences are evident within each quarter, take the walking tour you will have a chance to see and learn so much more than the scooter or bike tours. (or take the bike tour for highlights and revisit the places that most interest you).
Great sites and food!!. Great place to do some walking, enjoy delicious tapas, and spend a little money. Be sure to find a restaurant outside on a cool evening.
Shopping. I like the sombre feeling wandering through the narrow streets.Many little but interesting shops and restaurants.

Go to Plaça Sant Felip Neri. When wandering the gothic quarter youhave to visit this sqaure. It is tucked away and is the site of bomb damage from the civil war. I recommend reading up on it's history and appreciating the tranquil calm of it in the midde of the city.
Wonderful amenity. Signs pointing to cafe all over, but only actually found one, near the entrance. So, poor signage, but otherwise well worth a visit.

Truly Gothic - go back in time. Wandering the streets takes in back in time - the architecture and narrow streets lead to churches and plazas around every corner. wonderful area to simple explore & enjoy. Lots of shops, restaurants & cafes.

Favorite area. This old quarter was our favorite. Just lose yourself walking the cobblestone streets and taking in the sights. There are also nice restaurants throughout the Barri Gotic. We had a phenomenal lunch at the Cafe d' Academia and would highly recommend it.

Fascinating. Full of character, full of quirky shops and great bars. I spent ages just wandering about. Several museums, I loved the Gothic Cathedral, it is awesome and was probably the best thing I went to on my visit.

a lot to see. From the jewish neighborhood to the remains of the roman wall, the Barri Gòtic is full of things to see. If you visit with some sort of guide you'll get to understand some of the history of the places you visit, which will make your visit even more interesting. The cathedrals are also really impressive: just go inside, sit and enjoy!

Town maze. Don't worry about getting lost! Just have a nice stroll in this old part of town. Discover the nice little shops in small alleyways. Go antique hunting in the jewish quarter. Or just find yourself a nice table on one of the many little squares and just relax...

So atmospheric.... We loved the Barri Gotic - its winding streets are so authentic and lovely to explore on foot. It holds so many wonderful secrets for the tourits to explore and discover - lovely little restaurants; stunning shops selling authentic Spanish souvenirs (loved the ceramicware); of course the beautiful buildings; buzzing bars; and of course - the wonderful people! - all of whom were so courteous and helpful! On the downside - we definitely think more could be done to keep it clean... more municipal bins would be great!

A walk to remember. I spent 4-5 hours just walking through the Gothic quarter, getting lost in the narrow ancient alleys and rediscovering my self in the process. A relic from the foundation days of the City by the Romans. it is humbling to think how much has transpired in this area over the last 1000 years or so. You have impromptu performances by musicians, loads of cafes and eateries all around, quite charming really. All in all, you can lose and rediscover your self in this ancient part of Barcelona like very few places on earth.

Fascinating historical walk. We wandered around with our guide - enjoyed the history and looking at the very significant buildings we had learned so much about. A real rabbit warren of old narrow streets and alleyways.All good fun

Very Interesting. This is a great part of the city to see. The architecture alone is so impressive. We took one of the hop-on / hop-off bus tours in Barcelona that stops in this area. Well worth getting off the bus to explore.

Cheaper to eat here. Avoid having a drink on Las Ramblas unless you can see the prices. Three drinks cost us 44 Euros. Lots of great places, and much cheaper, to eat in the Gothic quarter. "Carrer Ample" has some great bars and restaurants and "Carrer Boqueria" live acoustic after midnight, both just off La Rambla. Do the free walking tour in Carrer Boqueria Travel Bar. The history of Barcelona is amazing and you will appreciate the city more having done the tour..

Atmospheric. Lots to explore mand an overwhelming selection of places to eat, drink and be merry. Sunday lunchtime (12.30 to 13.00) just by the Cathedral for the chance to join in the local folk dances.
A must visit. Containing the Cathedral, the Gaudi Museum, the Roman wall and many other wonderful buildings, shops bars and restaurants in tiny, narrow pedestrian (mostly) lanes.
dark and intriguing. wonder around - take a coffee - take some tapas - get tix for a flamenco show in baroque palace - fabulous

griddy, mystical, ancient and.... in all of it's challenging hectic buzzing and thriving way, gothico is wonderfully fulfilling for any true travelers heart and soul. it touches you deep inside and leaves you always wanting to come back. it is an enchanted place where you can taste the history past up close and personal. it is a place to visit if you want to wander on ancient paths that might have been your own in an bygone era. find that wonder inside and delve in.....it is so worth it.....

Awesome area!. Quaint little town with narrow cobblestone streets lined with shops and restaurants. You can enjoy the unique architecture of the buildings and easily spend a day walking the streets and doing a little shopping.

Lovely old section, perfect for wandering. This area is the oldest part of the city, where you can see Roman walls, the old Jewish quarter, and wander down narrow streets and alleys. There are lots of bars, little plazas, shops and cafes. It's a nice place to walk around and see what you discover. You can go during the day if you want to shop, but it's also a destination for young people in the evenings.

Good place to get lost.. You will only appreciate this if you have lots of time in your stay in Barca to wander, get lost and wander again. Check out the history of 'The Gothic' before you wander and it will make more sense. It's the vibe don't you know!
A beautiful area to take a stroll. Stunning architecture and lots of cool sights to take in. A fun afternoon activity. Bring your camera.

Get lost in the tiny streets..... wonderful. We spent hours wondering around, great shops, fabulous bars with great tapas and a lovely atmosphere at night. We did not see any crime or any problems and we stayed out late, just use your common sense no valuables on show etc and you should be fine.
great atmosphere. it s a great place to hang out with friends, have a try of everything in the tapas bars and have a nice sangria. enjoyable nights.

Great for wandering around. My friend and I loved walking around in the Gothic Quarters and La Rambla. We stayed in the area so it wasn't too hard to get there. I love the Exotic feel Spain has with the tropical weather, Port and Beaches along with amazing food. There are so many places to eat and it looked like getting around on a bicycle was convenient as well!
Pittoresc. During our stay we loved to walk to and fro in this quarter. The admosphere was lovely. Lovely unexpected squares with bars and small restaurants.
"The" place to walk around both daytime and evening. Bring good shoes. Try to walk a little bit outside the typical "tourist traps" and find a local restaurant.
Beautiful Gothic quarter. Lovely area of the city to walk around. Safe and very interesting. Plenty of shops and restauarants.

Enjoy getting lost. These narrow lanes are absolutely gorgeous and really are like stepping back in time. Spent the afternoon just wandering from lane to lane and finding gorgeous shops along the way. There is a real heart and soul to this place.

Best district in Barcelona !. This is definatly the best area to wander and eat, nice buildings and feels like it's not so touristy. I would have liked to have stayed here as the resturants looked small, rustic and authentic .
Great to get lost in. Got totally lost here and absolutely loved just having to take a break in the odd bar/cafe to regain our bearings! Lots of lovely quirky shops and restaurants.
very nice. I was recommended to visit the traveler bar. from there (I think every day but you better check it out) at 11 am and 13 pm you can take a free tour of the gothic quarter

Leave your map behind. It's like a big maze for adults. I've spent hours wandering the jumble if lanes and alleyways on my 2 trips to Barcelona. Without a map you can just walk and look at the marvelous old buildings, 'discover' plaças hidden away from the main tourist thoroughfares, share a coffee with locals in keyhole shop front cafés, marvel at artisans creating unique bags, shoes, jewelry in their workshops. Far more fun than shuffling along with the crowds on La Rambla ... And you can't get lost. Eventually you'll come across a larger road or pedestrian route.

travel back in time. to get lost and wander around --- this is what barrio gotico is about..the fascinating gothic architectures offer more than what meets the eye..and the little nooks and green corners give a breather on this fascinating maze of long ago..nice view of the basilica tower is from the balcony of the archive building..free entry..
The best of Barcelona. The best of Barcelona cn be found in the Barri Gothic Quarters, get lost in the streets, filled with beautiful buildings, churches, tapas bars, shops and culture

Historic and quaint. Roman ruins are to be found interspersed around this old part of Barcelona. The Gothic buildings are majestic and dramatic. So much history within its narrow and cosmopolitan streets.

Amazing. Worth visiting.. For those who loves history, it's a must. There are walking tours starting from the information centre at the Cathedral square (the white building with Picasso's drawings on the wall), almost every day, at 9.30.

Historic Barri Gotic. During our maiden Barcelona visited, we selected our stay in a hotel on Carrer Ferran rght in the heart of Barri Gotic area or old historic part of the city which was also within close proximity to Las Ramblas ( the famous tree lined walking street) and many of Barcelona's attractions such as Barcelona Cathedral, Placa St. Jaume, Plaza Reial, Picasso Museum, Santa Maria Cathedral, etc.No visit to Barcelona would be complete without exploring the narrow streets of Barri Gotic and it's distinctive architecture, enjoying the variety of food and drinks in offer at the many restaurants lined up along the street and in the lovely plazas and catching up on some foot tapping Flamenco music and if possible a dance show.

Must visit while in Barcelona. This is one of the oldest parts in the city , the gothic district has much to offer, quorky little cobble streets, hidden cafes and plenty of unique arquitecture of the time. Preferably to go there in the morning or durin the say, because it is much safer and there are not so many weird people walking the streets . It is also very charming at night but there are many drunk people .
Live in the past. Tranform in time to relive the past with very old buildings, very narrow lanes, cobble stones pavements. It gets really crowded at 5-6pm when weather gets better.It's very relaxing.

Enjoy going back in time. Just walk around and enjoy the medieval feel of the Gothic Quarter. Nothing is more fun than not having a map and discovering unexpected feelings. Plenty to see and also beautiful at night.

Beautiful Gothic area of Barcelona. A nice contrast to Gaudi and modernist architecture in Barcelona. Wonderful area to explore (be prepared to walk a lot) with a plethora of cafes, restaurants, and little shops. Can be crowded.
Stark Contrast. The narrow streets and alleys of the Gothic Quarter are in stark contrast to the open boulevards of the remainder of Barca. Ancient Churches with incredible Catholic iconography.

A must see. If you visit Barcelona i would highly recommend that you take the time to walk through this area. Bring a camera. In addition to the old buildings there are great resturants and cafes that aren't expensive.
Easy Trip To The Past. Location to our Hotel was close and easy to walk to and fro. The Gothic Quarter was a visit to the past amongst modern day Barcelona.
Lot´s to do. Beutiful area with interesting architecture, shoping, nice restaurants/bars and cafés. I never get tired of it and always finds new places and alleys.

Amazing. Great sights for the mind and soul!beautiful and exciting walks!weather alone or along friends,the gothic quarter is definitely a must see for the experienced and advised but also for amateurs!

A place to explore. A wealth of history and charm make the Barri Gotic a must-do whem visiting Barcelona. Narrow shady streets hide intriguing shops and cafes and the underground Roman City remains should not be missed. Some of the smaller dark alleyways are best avoided at night for safety reasons but during the daytime we felt no less safe than anywhere else.
AMAZING. To be done at night and during day time for a different atmosphere. It is magical and overwhelming. Lots of nice shops and tapas bars!

Great Evening Entertainment. There are many great restaurants all within a very close area that is very lively and fun in the evening. We traveled with children. The area is charming and we tried several restaurants that were very good.

Stepping back in time. Barcelona is wanderer's dream. Leaving La Ramblas you really get the feel of this historic city and nowhere better to explore than the Gothic area with surprises at every turn. We loved sitting in the many outdoor cafes and tapas bars for coffee or beer to soak up the spirit of the history. Absence of vehicles is the charm as you stroll the cobblestone streets window shopping and exploring this great area.
Great area to wander around. A great area to lose yourself...and you will! No need to plan simply go for a walk and soak up the atmosphere

Put away your map and wander around. This is a great area to just wander around. It is just off Las Ramblas and filled with tiny streets, squares and, of course, lots of restaurants and the magnificent Santa Maria del Mar gothic church. Most maps won't give details of the tiny lanes (which are pedestrian) so if you get lost, just keep on walking until you get to a street and take a taxi back to your hotel.

Beautiful nighttime stroll. Compact old town district, easy to get to by public transportation and full of lively bars and restaurants. Felt very old world and yet cosmopolitan. Great place for a couple to wander around without an agenda, lots to do and see.

Nice area, quaint streets. This area was to us the central part of Barcelona. It had really nice streets and was definitely pleasing to the eye (especially with the street art!). It's somewhere you'll need a lot of memory for your camera as every building and lane is picturesque.
Only place not napping. This is the only place that is not doing siesta. Very exciting walk around all the nooks and alleys. Must go to the bakery that everything is made by nuns. Very good!

Great neighborhood but it smells. If you like old architecture, you will feel like in Disney here. You can for sure take a picture of every building. It can be crowded depending on where you go and the old sewer sometimes gives you a nasty smell but this is a must see area. The Barcelona cathedral, main plaza, la Rambla and great restaurants are located here. You can for sure spend a whole day here.
Barcelona Cathedral. Wonderful old Cathedral with a lot of interesting history.make sure you take the elevator to the roof for a view of the surrounding area.
Walk slowly and enjoy. Get up early head for the cathedral then the market de Santa Caterina for elevenses. Go on to the park or Arc de Triomf. Keep looking up, some of the buildings are amazing

Contrast to the modern city - do not miss. It is worht taking som e hours to spend here in the gothic quarter. It is narrow streets and like a labyrinth. You can feel the history in the walls, and there are plenty of good restaurants and shops for all wishes. Do not miss if you come to Barcelona!

Go for a guided tour. We had a guided tour of the quarter and it added so much more than the mere beauty of the buildings. The city has an amazing history that you will miss by just have a stroll to enjoy the vistas.
Love it. I think that this is the best part of Barcelona - lots of small bars, pubs, tapas bars and plenty to see. You can feel the history in this area.

An enjoyable maze. We enjoyed wandering (and getting lost a few times) in Barri Gotic. If you use Google Maps to get to a specific destination, they will get you close but won't get you there. The other paper maps we had didn't have much detail re; sidestreets, but wandering around was part of the adventure.

treasure of the city. I had my friend, Luis, took me to this amazing place & it felt just like coming back to the past! the history that written on the buildings, places, or monuments in Gothic Quarter part of Bcn could easily trace back.It's a pity that it happened on my 3rd visit to Bcn. Definitely recommend for any walking/cycling tour with guide/local people on this area &around if you ever wanna visit this place.

My facorite !! must see !!. You could spend hours together and still would come back!! Absolutely amazing. The Gothic structures are mesmerizing.....to me, you get a real feel of Barcelona in here. It is also conveniently situated and you can get here from various metro stations ( Jamue I is very convenient). A must see place. Be aware of pickpocketing.

Awesome (an italian girl lost in the old city). I found this place simply amazing and I'm writing this review in my orrible english just to make every tourist know that he/she can't miss the old city (or the Gothic District, as you please).I think it's magical. Maybe it's because it reminds me my own city (Catania, but it's veeery far from this beauty), but all the small streets, with ther "dangerous" charm (i guess they're not really confortable during nightime) and peculiar shops; and after a lot of incredibly narrow and intricate streets, you found out a square, more than one to be honest, like Plaza Real (really elegant: remind me of Rome and a waiter told me i'm beautiful...thank you!) or Plaza del Rei, where i wanted to go to the historical museum, but it was closed, so insted i had tapas in the square, where you can meet a very interesting waiter who speaks one million languages and made us pay a very lower price (thank you!).Of course you have to visit the cattedral, and remember to wear somenthing "covering" or they won't let you in. The most fascinating thing was about the ducks who "defend" the church and make a lot of funny noise.What else? Have very very fun and if you find some mistake please tell me, i'm a languages student and i like travelling and learning.Love everyone

Get lost between the streets. We came here looking for a particular cafe for lunch but ended up lost as most street names are not on the map due to how many different streets are in the area. However you will find many to choose from once you get lost in the side little streets. It is an area to go and explore and don't worry about a map as thats part of the fun.
Cleaner. I went there 15 years ago and remembered it as a bit dirty/shady quarter. It seemed much nicer -tough much more touristy- as many buildings (including the cathedral) got cleaned up.

Busy. touristy. Hidden Gems.. These "artsy" quarters always strike me as a little pretentious, but! we stumbled across a hidden gem among the museums and the cafes that made this one of the highlights of our visit. A three-piece band playing original music on what I can only describe as giant metallic bowls. It was very weird and completely wonderful and definitely a lovely way to while away the afternoon.Good luck seeing an actual spaniard around here, though.

Have to See. Just a short walk from Plaza de Catalunia, this is worth the trip. I am so impressed with how the Spaniards value and preserve these ancient buildings. Take time to step inside the church, with it's open courtyard. It's all beautiful.
Get Lost. Gotic is Barcelona, this is one of the funnest places in Barcelona. Take the day hit the shops, bar hop, Tapas hop and get lost in the winding streets.

Interesting area. The area has narrow little streets, many car-free, and tons of outdoor cafes. We walked thru around 10pm and there were still thousands outside gathered at cafes to eat/drink. Hard to find a taxi unless you walk several blocks to a main street.
Old school. The historic town centre -lots of little streets amazing stores and hotels. I really just enjoyed the feel of finding little gems, be it retail, caves or boutique hotels.
wonderful. I liked everythink, I recomand a visit ! I loved the arhitecture and the street singers ! A very pleasent place !

Ace. I loved this areaWould suggest a guided tour early tours Many are free - you give a donation depending on how much you enjoyed We used and would highly recommend runner bean tours.After your guide do your own thing , every twist and turn fab , could spends days getting lot in this great place.

A medieval quater in a modern city. Barri Gotic, is in the heart of Barcelona. Small picturesque, back streets, Barcelona's Cathedreal, impressive, Minifstry of Culteure, a beautiful medieval building with his museum.Best of all Placa Real, a beautiful square with Palm trees, old buildings and a lot of restaurants and Cafe.

Wild and Historic. Had one night in between flights to do Barcelona, so we chose this part of the City..Lots of hotels, old buildings, and is basically central to the city, but also close to the coast.Lots of bars, restaurants, and music venues to be had within walking distance. This was referred to us as the best nightlife spot, and we quickly saw why!Be alert to venturing out on the 'Rambla' near the quarter when going out after hours.
Great for walking. It's great to walk through the old centre of Barcelona. Full of great gothic architecture, with narrow street and nice squares where you can even hide from too much tourists.

Spend fun time getting lost here. Each street is a treasure and fun to walk around enjoying the local color. Just wander around the streets and the shops and you will get a great sense of current and past history.
magical. Located at the city centre, gothic quarter is easy t find and won't disappoint you! in the area there are many tapas bars and caffes and it has an awesome medieval architectural style.

Atmospheric. Loved the wall tile cartoons, loved the various shop and restaurants, but most of all loved the two guys playing hang drums (Google is you friend) and a guitar. It felt like a perfect summer evening. Oh, and my lovely partner tried on clothes and bought a new bag, so it was pretty stellar, really. The only thing I could have done without was the stench of urine in a couple of the alleyways. Didn't come across this even in the back streets of Marrakech!
Perfect Atmosphere. You need lots of SD cards/films to take photos. Details are everywhere.! A huge art region with small and cute cafes.
Gothic Wonder. Enjoy this part of town which is very different but fun.Easy to walk to and around this part of town and not far from Las Ramblas.
Nice area with good bars. It was really good to spend the evening having a few beers and the area was vibrant and cosmopolitan.

Lots of graffiti.
