Stayed in Gothic Quarter of Barcelona - well worth a visit but lots of graffiti on shutters and doors of shops and many of the little old shops were closed, unsure if this was because it was August or because they had closed for good. Probably didn't spend enough time just strolling around due to period of time we had in Barcelona, stumbled across some lovely bars where you can just sit drinking coffee and people watching.
Simply amazing. The historical buildings, architecture and Barcelona Cathedral were amazing. Walking around exploring, see the small shops and maze of old small lanes was just indescribable.

one of the highlights of barca. very nice boutiques selling famous spanish embriodered cloths,nice experience,also museo picasso is a must see...,baggers playing music in the streets giving a romantic atmosphere while walking in the narrow streets...

Absolutely amazing place. While you get lost in the gothic style alleys you find some nice takeaways or some tapa bars which are warm and make your stay there memorable. If you come accross to the cathedral even better or Placa Real

Feel th history in the heart of Barcelona. Not to far from La Rambla, and not so crowded like on La Rambla you will find the Gothic Quarter of Barcelona, with lot of historical buildings, churches and nice squares. Walk around, enjoy the atmosphere and listen to the local people singing and performing old historical music ! In any cas take also some free time to sit and have a drink or tapas in one of the restaurants with nice outdoor seating !
Roman. This is a nice area. You can see parts of Roman walls and the area is very old. There are a lot od shops and some good restaurants.
Old World Character. Loved the old world charm of this area of the city. Spent our days strolling hand in hand with my husband and got lost in the romance of Barcelona!

Cant Go Wrong. Walking around this area you will come across many of the Ancient Roman influences and artifacts where you can walk into a room and come across Roman Pillars still remaining. Of course you cant go past the Cathedral and also the Kings Palace with gargoyles along the wall. Truly worth taking a walk and admiring what this area has to offer and then walking down to the Ramlas to enjoy the vibe and entertainment and great restaurants.

Favorite Part of Barcelona. I spent a lot of time wandering around el Barri Gotic, just taking in the architecture, wandering into churches small and large, and listening to the music that comes from the life in the squares. It's a completely different vibe from the rest of the city in its old-world feeling and it is unapologetic about it, as it should be. My favorite part of traveling is getting to wander around without expectations and coming across hidden gems or just seeing the community members go about their day. This is a great neighborhood for such wandering!

Old World meets New World. We ventured into the Barri Gotic area of Barcelona on our second day. Right from the start I loved it. We passed the Condom shop and the Happy Pills shop with some wonderment. Then we came to the wonderful market called Santa Caterina with the Gaudi designed roof. Barcelona Cathedral was nearby and it was most interesting with the story of Eulalia and the presence of the geese in the cloister. Then into the labyrinth of narrow streets and alleys. We enjoyed photographing the martyrs and then onward to Carrer del Bisby with the much photographed bridge above and the gargoyles keeping watch from above. Very interesting historic part of Barcelona.

Rent an apartment in this area. Rented an apartment for a week with my girlfriend on Carrer de Ferran. Felt like the real European experience. The neighbourhoods of Barri Gotic and Ciutat Vella are full of narrow streets with lots of shops, restaurants, bakeries and ice creams shops.
Gothic Quarter. Fun to just wander this very walkable quarter. Interesting squares and churches, fine old buildings, great shops, street music, good restaurants...
A Great Walk. Get a map and wind your way around this area. Lots of shops and places to stop for a coffee. The shop keepers are very friendly and willing to work around language barriers.
Barcelona's Gothic Quarter. This is definitely a "Don't Miss" while in Barcelona. Take time to stroll the narrow streets that take you back in time. Wonderful!

Get lost in the alleys. If la Rambla seems too busy and touristy, try the alleys in the Gothic Quarter - they are located right next to Ramblas anyway. Lots of small, inexpensive pubs (not all of them), and shops varying from your run-of-the-mill souvenir shops to lovely little boutiques. The atmosphere is amazing, and the small streets are probably safer at night than la Rambla.

Take a bit of History home with you.. We stayed in this area, which was only steps to the night life of Barcelona, and living in a bit of History. From the Roman Wall about 2000 years , Churches, shopping, and much,much more.

Amazing neighborhood. when you enter this neigborhood, you are entering to an ancient story because of gotic buildings, close streets and a old atmosphere where you can find good restaurants. museums, and plenty people of all the world

Nice place to amble. It's for adults really. Kids will get bored as you wander around taking in the gothic architecture or get sucked into the many shops/cafes.On the downside, it's very busy and there is an issue with petty crime. Early mornings are pleasant, if you want it to yourself.
Great place to stay if visiting Barcelona. Stayed in the Gothic Quarter and loved walking around the area - so much to see - best to get a two day pass on bus for getting around and seeing the city.
tremdous frun to wander around - great food, shopping and sites to see. Cant really go wrong on the food front here - and the Cathedral is worth a trip around. Lots of art galleries to go to as well

Great vibe, energy and a bit of everything (do in early evening). Churches, shops, restaurants, etc.. We loved the vibe of Barcelona, and the energy of the city. Lots going on, lots to see and experience just walking around the Gothic Quarter and nearby Las Rambos. Great from about 6 p.m. onwards.
Very beautiful. Really beautiful place. Narrow streets and exquisite architecture. Very romantic ;) There are also many places of interest, pastry shops and nice bars.
Not funny at all. Nothing interesting to do, we just took some pictures and continued our trip.There is a nice restaurant nearby.

Interesting Tour. We had a lovely time winding our way down the Gothic Quarter of Barcelona - very much worth getting a guide as you tend to miss certain attractions, especially the Roman columns which are hidden away off the beaten track.Really interesting walk and got to see and experience alot - also a perfect location for the evening to come and have a proper drink.

Leave a few hours to stroll around the alleyways of gothic Barcelona. We stayed just around the corner from the church Santa Maria del Mar and spent 3 very enjoyable days strolling the streets of the gothic area.We bought food from the Santa Caterina markets. Visited the Barcelona cathedral. Walked to the Barconaleta. Las Ramblas was an easy walk from here. Picasso museum was in the area but didn't venture inside.
great!. Beautiful place to walk and have fun. good light, you feel safe there. Its very traditional and you will find nice restaurants. Barcelona is all amazing... the best city in world.
off the beaten track. Excellent quieter areas with interesting places to eat and drink and much cheaper..Also out of the sun

Lose yourself in narrow streets. If you have ever travelled to historic mediteranean ports with castellations and narrow streets full with character then be amazed by an area as large as all those others added together. Unlike the rest of Barcelona, the grid pattern does not exists as naroe alleys criss cross and intersect and many differing angles. the buildings are to tall as to obscure your view of the position of the sun and I found myslf using a compas in order to work our our direction of travel. The many shops, boutiques, cafes, and hidden churches make this a wonderfull place to stroll through at any time of day. At night time most are very well lit but I would always be prepared and caryy a small flashlight.

Picturesque but not a museum. We found a restaurant that is located in this area. To get there we had to leave the main streets and walk down side streets and alleys. If you like to look at old buildings and like small streets this is for you. We were there in the evening so I can't comment on daytime activities in the area but in the evening there are restaurants and bars. There is a lot of foot traffic. A good place to walk and if you go there you don't have much choice: the streets aren't designed for cars.
stunning architecture.. The whole atmosphere was amazing, incredible buildings,so much to see also plenty of places to eat and drink.

Interesting place to have a walk and take pics. Again to many people, but I guess that's the spirit of Barcelona. Very interesting and pretty area to see and of course to take pictures. You should go to the smallest streets and corners there, so you will definitely see something interesting :)
Stepping back in time!. Fantastic maze of narrow streets with quirky bars, restaurants and shops! We loved wandering and discovering bars where locals drank and ate!

It's a walk in history. If you're a historian, you will love this place. For those who are not historians, you will still be in awe of the rich history that the Gothic Quarters has to offer. It's a must see for Barcelona.
Interesting to walk. Interesting to walk through this district, especially to see Picasso museum and chocolate museum in its neighbourhood.
Added charm. Won't say much, it's so charming around the Gothic Quarters, it used to be part of a castle.....loads of places to eat (tapas) off the beaten track....cheaper too....
Plenty to see. We spent hours walking around this tight little area of Barcelona and also found our favourite restuaurant there, sadly not featured on TripAdvisor.

A great afternoon trip. You should walk around this place as much as you like and as many times as you like. I feel like everytime I went through I saw something different. Wouldn't recommend walking there after nightfall seeing that some of the allies are secluded and have poor lighting.

GREAT to Tour. We rented a flat through vrbo.com in the gothic quarter. Great to tour and see the parts of the old original Roman Wall in the Gothic quarter. Recommend you take a tour from a guide through this quarter.

great sightseeing. you can just walk around here and be amazed by the old buildings and great restaurants. There's the cathedral, picasso museum nearby and really interesting buildings and museums. It's a romantic and atmospheric place to look around
Historical Beauty. Very beautiful old and historical architecture as well as cute and hip resturants, bars and boutiques. Cant forget the Tapas and sangria too
Stunning. Beautiful architecture, quaint lanes, never sure what was round corner! Near La Rambla and easy to access and explore

Mix of old & new. We walked this street one hot afternoon. The architecture was very interesting if you were able to find a place to stop. The street was very crowded and many of the stores are newer chain stores.There are a few unique stores and gelato store fronts. If you get off the main drag and wonder down the side streets and alleys ways it is much more enjoyable. I used Rick Steves' book as a guide to some special sights. I would also recommend you stop in to see the Church of Barcelona if you have time.

Definately walk through this area. When we first arrived in Barcelona we didn't think it had as much character as some of the other cities in Spain we had visited. Then we found the Gothic Quarter. Lots of charm. Great place to walk around, shop, or sit at an outdoor cafe. Please be advised that the Gothic Church will not allow women in with shorts or sleeveless shirts. My husband waltzed right in with his short. My shorts were as modest as his and they wouldn't let me in. We hadn't enountered this at any other church in Spain. When we went to Italy, it was common everywhere and I carried a shawl to wrap around me. should have brought it with me, I guess.
Must see. Fantastic atmosphere, boutique shops, cafes etc, ancient buildings, narrow streets, great for history, photography or just strolling - very romantic.
excellent. its a must see, it has to be done when you go there, its brilliant, but hire a bike, a lot of walking is involved.

A must if you are into Gargoyles. Great place just to wander around and enjoy the atmosphere. So many great little cafe's and tappas bars to visit and waste the day away people watching and enjoying the sangria.

One of my favourites. Getting lost through the streets of the Gothic Quarter is one of my fav things to do in Barcelona. It has bars, shops, cathedrals to see. One of my favourite restaurants is also here. A basque tapas bar that is always crazy busy but so good, you would want to have all your meals here.

A must see - like going back in time to mid-evil. walking in the streets of this quarter was a real like walking in a time machine... really worth taking the time. downloading an audio guide or even joining a local tour guide... so you dont miss all the great stops inside the quarter which can so easily be missed by just walking on theses small alleys...

Sad in parts. Having just visited Gerona we found this area disappointing. Yes, there is a pleasant atmosphere, but some streets are filled with closed-down businesses. If you want to see an unspoiled Gothic Quarter I suggest you make a visit to Gerona, preferably for more than one day.
You will really need a lot of time there!. Barri Gotic is not so big but you will need a lot of time walking there as its main charm is in small details which is a real pleasure to watch.

Day or night, worth the visit. Just walk around Barcelona and eventually you will find yourself in the Gothic Quarter of Barcelona. Day or night it is worth the visit, just keep wondering and wondering though all the streets, small boutiques, restaurants etc....

wonderful. We had a great wander through this gothic quarter, it is a must see for anyone visiting Barcelona. Very near to Las Ramlas and very charming full of sweeping gothic architecture. Great shops, bars and cafes here and great for a sit down after lots of walking and wandering. Enjoy, chill and take it easy. And bring your camera!

Fantastic History. The Gothic Quarter of Barcelona is a must do. We did a walking tour with Orange Donut - check them on Tripadvisor. As well as the amazing buildings, you will find lots of great shops and places to eat.
a must see. You must see this area to get a real feel for Barcelona. You can find parts of the old city wall, great shops, excellent restaurants!
Get lost in the avenues of great shops, bars, cafes & culture. A must visit to walk around. Lots to see, eat, drink soak up the atmosphere. All amongst great arcitexture & friendly people.

Getting lost here it's an incredible experience. Put your map away. Getting lost here it's an incredible experience. Take a look at the architecture sites, at the buildings, at the bars. We found and awesome bar hidden behind Barcelona’s cathedral.

LOVE IT. Stayed in the Gothic Quarter and loved it. Great restaurants, shops and atmosphere. The little old streets and buildings are divine to stroll around, never knowing what shop, cafe or old church you will find next.

What a delight is old Barcelona. The old centre of Barcelona is one of the most delightful places to visit, for the narrow pedestrian streets, the enormous number of shops, restaurants and bars, super food, outstanding value for money, and the history of the place. The Barri Gotic extends from the Ramblas to the Via Leitana and contains the main Cathedral, but one must also include the Ribera (Born) district to the NE of the Via Leitana, for the Church of Sta Maria del Mar and the Picasso Museum. Either before or after your visit, read the trilogy by Carlos Ruiz Zafon (Spain's most popular author), comprising Shadow of the Wind, The Angel's Game, and Prisoner of Heaven, plus Ildefonso Falcone's Cathedral of the Sea. These stories will bring so much of what you see to life, as they are set in this part of Barcelona. There is not space to do justice to Barcelona as a city to visit, but it is certainly the best city I have ever visited.

Beautiful Quarter. You can feel Barcelona history in this beautiful place in the heart of the city. There are a lot of small tapas' restaurants for a break after a long walk between the old buildings.

Best place to stay in Barcelona. We stayed in a hotel in this area rather than near Las Ramblas and city centre. The gamble certainly paid off. The streets had so much character, then some opening up into little plazas with bars and live Spanish music in the background. Each street is like a mini adventure, walking down the next road which takes your fancy.

Have to have a wander here!. Yes it's very touristy and yes there are lots of little low end stores, and 'gypsies' selling things every 30 feet..but it's got to be the heart of Barcelona. The Cathedral of Barcelona is well worth visiting and the area is full of shops and restaurants..and a Food Market that is amazing. Definitely a place to spend a day wandering around.
Could get lost for hours.. We loved it here.Lot's of hidden alleys to explore with tapas bars for refreshments. Also nice and cool when the weather is at its hottest.

Look out for the Little Things. Take notice of the street art on the stop signs and shops (especially during the night) or places that are hidden in small alleys, like the placa where the dictator franco used to execute his opponents, you can actually see the gun shots in the wall, or the shrine of saint eulalia which is a small statue on top of a wall in also another small alley way.

got off the bus tour to walk around~great sights to see!. Artwork,shops,cafe's just breath taking~There is so much to see.
I recommend the Red/Green/blue Bus Tour,you can get on & off as much as you like to see the city in one day~Definitely worth it!

Nice Architecture. The area is good for a stroll and the cathedral in the Gothic Quarter is free to enter. It is easily walking distance from the main street (Passeig de Gracia) and the beach is on the other side. It is worth checking out.

Its definitely must to take a stroll here, has lots of fantastic places to eat.. My husband and I, loved the time we spent in Barri Gothic.We didn't go by our map, we got lost, walked extra meters, sat on the stairs of old buildings and just gazed at the old houses, ate amazing food at small but very old places like 'Santa Clara'. I had the best hot chocolate ever, and a great great Tiramisu.Thoroughly enjoyed the time we spent there.

I wish I would've stayed there! Superb!. This area is amazing!make sure to visit the many shops, bars and restaurants in this viby area.A regret I have is not staying in the Gothic quarter. It was one of my favourite areas in Barcelona.

Enjoyed as part of Viatours full day tour of Barcelona. A walking tour was part of our full day Skip The Line tour of Barcelona through Viatours. We booked it online before we left and it was outstanding.
OK. The Gothic Quarter was nice but nothing to write home about. We didn't see anything spectacular about it.
Get lost in the warren. Just great to walk around, stop for a coffee, get a fan, stop at a museum, get a beer, some tapas, spend the rest of your life...

Gorgeous to visit, not to stay in. We found this neighborhood a lovely place to visit in the afternoon with the close buildings providing ample shade on the warm summer days. Visiting the Picasso museum is a must while you are in the area. However, I can't imagine staying here as it feels like quite a tourist-trap as far as hotel offerings go.
U cant go to barcelona without walking. To the old barri gotic.there are small alleys and different bars at every corner..make sure you sit and enjoy a few tapas /cocktails...
Very Cool:). The Gothic Quarter was really neat because of all the older buildings and there was a fantastic pastry shop there. Also, the gelato shop and museums there were really good.

Prepare to wander and wonder. It is amazing how quickly the maze of shops restaurants transports your to "old world" Europe when you are only steps away from the more modern and touristy Ramblas sidewalk fare. We definitely needed another day or two to explore....

Interesting area to get lost in.... I visited it long back so I do not remember it clearly, but I guess it was full of quiet interesting structures, a church and buildings, I stayed close by, so would often cross it to go to various destinations.

Just passed through. I wish we could have spent more time in this area but we just simply ran out of time. This was a really fantastic area of the city and if you are looking for someplace to just walk and look around this is it! A huge variety of buildings, architecture, restaurants, shops...it has it all in a very unique, Barcelona style.
Great restaurants, charming streets!. One of the best areas in Barcelona for restaurants and exploring. We ate here almost every night at charming, reasonable locations.

The Best Burrow in Barcelona. My friends and I stayed in Barri Gotic this summer, and it totally made my second visit to Barcelona an incredible experience. This are is ALWAYS buzzing. Which isn't always a good thing if you're in Barcelona to sleep. But it's great if you feel like stepping out for a stroll at midnight. The area is full of young and beautifully dressed people of all ages. Great shopping! But make sure to venture off Las Ramblas to experience authentic, wallet-friendly Spanish dining.

A trip back in history!. A labyrinth of narrow cobblestone streets, bars, restaurants and shops around every corner, quaint little squares in the shade, and vestiges of medieval and even Roman architecture, the Gothic Quarter is a great part of town to kill off a few hours. There are a few [very old] churches in the area (we visited the Barcelona Cathedral and Santa Maria del Mar (where a marriage ceremony was actually under way).Mercat de Santa Caterina is another local market in this area, and a great alternative to La Boqueria. It’s newer, cleaner, not as crowded, and offers the same experience, if not better. Browse through and check out the Jamón displays (from Serrano to Ibérico) where extremely high-end product can get as expensive as $100/lb.For more detail - and some cool pics - check out my full trip report: http://disdatdudder.blogspot.com/2013/08/barcelona-2013-part-2.html

Fun for everyone. We loved walking around the small alleys and coming out onto various small squares. There were tons of cafes, bars, restaurants, and shops. The architecture was beautiful. We felt safe, even though we had been warned about pickpockets. We also were surprised by how huge it was- it felt like going through an architectural labyrinth. A definite place to visit in Barcelona. You get a real feel for the city.
Very atmospheric!. Very atmospheric place, Its beautiful and also spotless!Lovely to just walk around and soak up the atmosphere and enjoy the views.

Great area to stroll around. Lovely little streets, lots to see, great architecture and quite easy to find your way, you always know which way is the sea so you head that way if you start to feel claustrophobic.A must see place to spend a couple of hours whilst in Barcelona.

Interesting. Interesting area. You can see where Gaudi was at work everywhere. Worth a visit. A work of caution. Be sure and wear a money belt or keep your wallet in your front pocket and your purse with your hand on it. Pickpockets were rampant when we were there.

Must see place. The Barri Gotic is amazing. We got lost because it's really narrow, but in every corner there are all this amazing pieces of Gothic architecture, and actually getting lost is part of visiting this place, and when you least expect it you get to places like Santa Maria del Mar Cathedral, that are really great, and there are a lot of shops and restaurants. However, on a Sunday, everything is closed
So many great places to get lost around. I've walked there so many times and I keep going back! Great little streets, so nice to get lost in but easy to find your way back.
Beautiful neighbourhood. Great for night walks and nice food restaurants but you have to be very careful. We actually witnessed a purse robbery twice.

tiny streets. tiny crooked streets, little shops with whatever you can imagine, vivid atmosphere. Just walk down the city to the seaside without any map, you cannot get lost and as a bonus you´ll see the real beauty of it

So so atmospheric!. By day or by night worth exploring (wonderful hidden courtyard for drinks if you can find it!). By night guitarists sit and play past midnight under wonderful gothic architecture, perfect. Roman towers which guard the entrance are amazing. Catalan folk dancing in square on Sundays mornings.
Touristic. Used to be a nice area. Now very touristic. Some nice tapas bars but skip the restaurants at Placa Real. They are expensiove and food not recommended

Very touristy with little quality shopping.. If you know where to go you can find a few quality shops. If you want to see some historical sites within or by the Gothic area then go for that if you have extra time. I would not recommend it as a highlight of your trip.
Particularly fun on Sundays. After church services on Sunday afternoons, locals get together to join in traditional dances. This is not a tourist attraction, but a local activity. Fun to watch

Talk About Getting Lost. One of the hardest things in Barcelona was to find my way out of the Gothic Quarter. So easy to get lost in that labyrinth. So do yourself a favor lose your map and walk the narrow streets because it always leads you to a new discovery. El Barrio Gotico is a challenge on its own right.
Wonderful!. Every where you go you see different foods. You have your choice of whatever you want. Don't eat too much so you can sample all the food. The buildings were fantastic!

Fantastic to waste time here. You can spend hours and hours in this quarter. Getting lost, discovering nice shops, good food, wonderful ancient architecture and enjoying your time in Barcelona. This is the place to be.
Beautiful. In my opinion this is the nicest area of Barcelona and is full of nice places to eat and little shops

Gothic. An amazing variety of buildings ranging from roman times to date. Very amusing street preformers typical spanish restaurants. And close to the cathedral. Not to br confused with the sagrada familia church

Lovely vue of gothic buildings. Gothic quarter is just so interesting as there is much to watch ! Lovely spanish people despite the massive presence of tourist !
I would surely come back to this place ! surely to taste local food and just blend in with warm friendly spanish people!
Architectural Wonders!. Don't miss this great section of Barcelona. Consider taking the walking tour listed in Rick Steve's Barcelona guide.

Full of character and charm. Lovely place to walk around and look, shop, or just soak up,the atmosphere. The area is a lovely mix of shops, cafes, winding alleyways that come out into little squares with great little places to eat. Some good hunting will get you off the beaten track and you will find the more authentic handmade items. Well worth the effort. Make sure you go and see the remains of the city walls from the roman times.
Find what you didn't expect.... ...anything from luxury Dead Sea cosmetics to cheap bric-a-brac, garments of all kinds, in short: anything. AND chocolate shops!!!

Great boutiques. Wonder around this area and duck in and out of the lovely shops...little side alleys, wonderful artisans and true Spanish flavor! This is the Barcelona that everyone hopes to experience...we loved it!
Nice walk around the Barri Gotic. Lovely to walk around. Lots of nice little cafes and shops. Quite a few alley ways to wander around with musicians and entertainers dotted about.

Get lost, enjoy what you find along the way!. The narrow streets of the Gothic Quarter are a lovely place to get lost and discover the wonderful places hidden within. Just take a walk around, check out the great shops, restaurants and monuments. You'll love the experience!
a-MAZE-ing. It was so cool to walk around this area whether at 12pm or 12am. A lot of cool shops/cafes/bars around here!!! Architecture so interesting

a must see for tourists. There is a lot to see and to enjoy in the Gothic Quarter - old and new, from Romans to Picasso and back again! It is small yet full of discoveries to make! We visited this quarter time and again, enjoying the restaurants and cathedral, the Roman walls and modern stores.

3 days wasnt enough. Fantastic place to explore full if unusual shops, many many restaurants and around every corner quirky little bars. We had heard there is a problem with pickpockets here and we saw the tourist police around but no one bothered us at all. Best G&T ever (like a fish bowl) in the Place Real just off the ramblas. Cant wait to go back and explore some more.
Historic Stroll. Colin the guide from Travel Bound was excellent he really earned his tip. a great way to spend 2,5 hours off the beaten track getting some history in nthis great city.
Atmospheric. Great to walk down the small alleyways and see where you end up! Some interesting and unusual shops and decent little tapas bars. beware the pick pockets though!

Must see area of town. This section of town consists of a warren of aincent, small streets featuring numeruos cafes and shops. It is kind of bounded by the Cathedral of Barcelona on one end and Santa Maria del Mar Church on the other. it is without a doubt an interesting area to check out.

Never pay for tour in Gothic quarter. You can tour the Gothic quarter for free. Dead easy. Start walking in the avenida portal d'angel from plaza de Catalunya towards sea side. Keep on walking straight on (in the shade) until you encounter the old cathedral at your left hand side together with a large tourist office at the corner up front. Can not mis. Follow the other tourists. Can't miss. Beware of beggars and pickpockets.You will find then here rather then on the Ramblas. Beware of all too obscure side alleys.So have your back covered. you will see little Policia Urbana or Mossos de esquadras here with guard dogs. Walk with at least 2 people bags up front your body. The old cathedral is far more beautifull then the Sagrada Familia. Do not pay 60-90 euros for ill guided tours.... Buy a book on the Gothic quarter :-)
A wonderful discover around every corner. Architecture, history, culture, landscapes, people, smells, sounds, it boggles the senses. We really, really enjoyed it all.
The Old World. Well traveled, old section of Barcelona should be walked by all who go to Barcelona. Reminds of days gone by.

Beautiful. Beautiful cathedral however mass is going on most of the day so you can't really look around properly. The gardens at the back are lovely and there are lots of things to discover around the gothic quarter... just explore.

one of the musts. you must go there , it is a very old and speacial place
it is nice to walk and sit in cafes
get lost in streets..
doing some traditional shoppings

nice part of the city. Really nice to walk around in this district.
Many resturants and mini boutics.
But sometimes it isnt so easy to find the right way to go

Rabbit-warren of streets, interesting little shops. Many shops close for lunch for a couple of hours. Great place for wandering around and window-shopping, dozens of tiny winding lanes and occasional plazas, but it's always possible to find your way back to La Rambla or the other main roads. Not sure I'd want to wander around there alone, especially at night, but it's a good mixture of quaint old 'local' shops and shiny tourist-oriented boutiques.
gothic quarter experience. full of nice bars/pubs, shops, restaurants... a nice labyrinth to walk through while surrounded by nice old buildings

Beautiful streets with unique details. Cool and nice place to have visit, a lot of narrow and beautiful streets that offers both shopping, food and nice drinks. These are the kind of street you don't want to miss if you are in Barcelona as it really gives you a flavor of how unique and lovely the town has always been. All these wonderful details like, doors, windows, lamp posts and etc. have all beautiful details of fine crafting from the old days.
Do not miss this. Interesting shops, eateries and all kinds of stuff going on...narrow streets lined with historical buildings, etc. Go there for a drink and tapas if nothing else.
must see!. Very nice place for shopping, dining and simply strolling around! Don't forget to look closer to the buildings and monuments, you'll discover hidden treasures!

Very interesting and historic area. Visiting the Gothic area for the first time can be a little overwhelming and confusing. This is a beautiful neighborhood full of narrow streets, shops, restaurants and lots of people. It is also full of history, and the best way to discover it is with a guide, especially for your first time. There is a daily public tour in English at 9:30, which takes you around in a group for about 2 hours. These tours can be booked at the Tourist Information office right by the Palau Generalitat. We hired a private guide, who was very knowledgeable, friendly and spoke excellent English. Gina Calvet, email gcalvetf@uoc.edu. She is a certified guide in Barcelona and can do any of the tours. We really enjoyed our time with her, and she was extremely reasonable. We highly recommend her.
Brilliant area!. The Gothic area of Barcelona is a fantastic area to find restaurants and bars. Try to get as far away from Las Ramblas as possible!

Architecture!. Absolutely stunning! I took so many pictures, there was a very good verity of architecture. So many alleyways to go down, the building are close and tall, but also big openings with grand cathedrals were never far away!

Stunningly beautiful and intricate. Barcelona is my favorite city in the entire world (yet!) and while the whole city packs a punch of culture, art, music, food, and people, I loved the Gothic Quarter. The narrow streets, small shops, intimate bars, and the rustic buildings provide for a really wonderful evening. At night it becomes an intoxicating blend of street musicians, strings of lights, and couples walking hand-in-hand. It was a highlight of my trip to Barcelona!

interesting. antiquari bar on placa rei great. historical museum and roman walls etc brilliant to see. many many interesting shops. dont miss temple of augustus - ask for directions if necessary as it is round the back of cathedral de la seu.

Crowded but worth a look. You can't come to Barcelona without experiencing this. The first time I came with a private guide which gave me a chance to see all of the important and historical features. The next time i came on my own and just wandered. Walked in circles. Enjoyed it all.

Edgy but Fun-ish. I am kind of on the fence about this area. We stayed here and we were able to walk to a lot of cool places like Las Ramblas, Placa Catalunya, etc. But there was a extra-toursity vibe and there were hoards of people in the streets. It was sort of like the Bourbon Street area, but without the buoyant energy. That said, we had a great time. We must fun and quirky people and there was a lot of English speaking in the air. At night, it was superloud which was a little exciting, but a little irritating too....

best part of barcelona to stay in. lots of activity, shops and cafes are everywhere. the farmers markets and la rambla are are walking distance. the tourist bus lines stop frequently, and the lines intersect in this area, so it is easy to change lines without having to waste time going through an entire loop. had a "fish pedicure and foot massage " there. warning though, not all shops or places to eat accept credit cards. check before you eat. i did not and was forced to leave a picture id until i transacted an exchange of cash for euros. i only had a 100.00 bill/banks close by 4pm. the exchange gave me 60.00 for my hundred and since i left my license with the cafe i had to use a strangers id card from israel to perform the transaction. the cafe wanted my passport, but i kept mine locked in the hotel as recommended. this took a lot of time and frustration, so ask prior to eating. also alot of places that do accept credit cards require the chip and not the magnetic strip, so keep at least 100 euros in your pocket for events like this.

Lots to discover- get an archi guide!. Barcelona's Gothic quarter vividly reflects the city's rich history. A long stroll down the narrow streets would be definitely enjoyable, yet you can get a lot more out of it if you'll pick the right guide. We decided to go beyond the lonely planet and got a tour guide to lead us through this neighborhood's wonders. The guide was a professional architect, who takes tourists along an urban tour of the old city, discussing it's past and it's relationship with the present, talking about the assimilation of the pagan elements into early christian churches architecture and the environmental choices of the current city planners, just to name a few topics.. We walked around the city with him for 8 hours and just couldn't get enough. You should try it, as it really elevated our understanding of the city's urban development and it was incredibly interesting!

Interesting. Spent hours wandering the small streets and interesting shops, cafes and restaurants. Can get congested. Many artisans visible and musicians in the placas. Watch for Saturday evening show outside Barcelona Cathedral - truly amazing!
beautiful area. I could have spent days just wandering around this area of Barcelona! It's well worth it for the amazing architecture and feel of the streets and alley ways!
nice walks. be prepared to walk a lot and get lost in the alleys, streets and squares as you explore. Stop and have some tapas and sangria in various cafes as you go!
So interesting !. Definetly a must to visit! We loved our tour with Jordan from the company HI. This is Barcelona! Don't miss it! Great day ! Fabulous sights and history, brings you back in time!

Very European. Loved strolling through all the narrow streets and discovering all kinds of shops and restaurants. Even found a small church, St. Anna's, with a choir rehearsal going on and a guitar recital later in the evening...non-touristy and a great find.
A must. Nothing too original to say here, if you go to Barna, you have to get lost through the tiny streets of the Barri Gotic to really live the city
So interesting. Wonderful buildings and atmosphere. Ancient streets and little bars and shops tucked away. Definitely worth a visit.

An easy walk around. Barcelona is a great city and this part of the city is easy to walk around and see all the sights.
Lots of eateries al fresco around the place.

love it. Forget the over touristy Las Ramblas, this is where to be. With amazingly pretty and ancient little streets, tucked away eateries and bars, fascinating little shops and more art than you can cover in a day it has everything - including easy access to the magnificent park and if, like me, you don't mind using your feet, is pretty much walkable anywhere within 30 minutes - Sagrada Famila, port, Picasso Museum. Perfect.

Real old world part of town. There are loads to see and do here get down the side streets to find some real jems and bargain shops. Gifts are uniquie but be warned you may not find the shop again or it may be closed when you eventually come back. If its a bargain get it there and then it saves tears
nice!!. Great architecture, unique style, brilliant atmosphere. Bars, restaurants, shops everything you need. A great place to go for a walk.
search and find. we had a great time wondering around this area just off the ramblas without really knowing whereabouts we were heading.Loads of interesting shops and restaurants around every corner
Old dirty streets. Meander around, it is interesting until you look too closely. Be careful, people throw garbage off their balconies on to the street. The streets are tiny and like a maze.

Like stepping back in time. I have lots of friends who travel just so they can experience something different from the techno-modern world they live in and I am one of those people too. When I was planning this trip, I was told that the Gothic Quarter was similar to Paris before Hausmann so of course, I had to make my way there.If I had to point to a single 'must see' thing, I probably couldn't do that - it is experiencing the area as a whole that makes it special. Of course, visiting a place as opposed to a single destination requires taking some time, so do take the time to wander down the many cobblestone streets. You will find quiet by-ways, busy squares and lots of locals going about the business of their day. We found a great tapas bar, a beautiful cathedral, some incredible architecture and street performers to enjoy. We were wending our way through one of the passages when the high, clear sound of an opera aria drifted around us; we followed the notes to their source, a woman whose talent would be hard to match even on the most venerable of performing stages. It was simply magical.

Stunning small streets with squares a-plenty!. This is off the main street (La Rambla) and is a pleasant move from the hustle and bustle. There are some fantastic bars, cafes and restaurants and also lots of independent clothes shops. you can easily lose your sense of direction as the streets are very small and thin, but it doesn't matter as you tend to come out onto a square at some point with some lovely little tapas restaurants/cafes/bars. Take the time to look up - some of the apartments have lovely plants hanging from the balconies, and the whole area has a very romantic and almost mystic feel.
The heart of Barcelona!. Great architecture, great atmosphere, great style, great bars, great music, great churches & buildings, great narrow streets...And it's not too warm in summer!
a trip to the past. spend a couple of hour wandering the area. if you can, take a walk in tour (there are a couple of "free'ones that are worthwile)
Fun!. Great street cafes, street performers, fun stores. Enjoy some tapas and Sangria on a hit summer day.
beautiful architecture. I loved the tiny small alley ways, the architecture, windows, the doors, the steps, the street performers. It's a beautiful neighbourhood!

Not the old Barri Gotic, but what the heck.. Depends a bit on the season you go here. In any case, this used to be very Spanish, but I think you'll find that's no longer the case. Long gone are the days of Eduardo Mendoza's sleazy Spanishness. If you go in the winter months you might still get a whiff of the old days. But nowadays you'd better brace yourself for a bit of North African globalization. Like all urban areas, as the other reviewers remark, there are plenty of places to drink here. If you want more of the Barcelona lifestyle, though, maybe you'd better head for the Eixample area. BTW, keep an eye on your handbag.

History and shopping. When in Barcelona gothic quarter is a must see for shopping,very nice small ethnic and local restaurants,historical sites and a very pleasant walk,The only downside is that it is not a place to spend time late evening when shops close as it is not very safe but day time is perfect

Just lose yourself in these narrow streets!. Lovely! nice small shops - could spend all afternoon just strolling there! must stop and have a quick bite to eat, some tapas! but choose your bars carefully!
Outstanding walk. You must plug in some time to walk this area. This is the old Barcelona with parts dating back to Roman times. A different world from La Ramblas.
Eating. Restraurants in particular were fantastic especially some more obsecure places. Historical significance

A great place to lose yourself. After a brief walk from our hotel with a walking map to find Gottica, it was great to put the map away and just wander the old streets and especially the side streets. Such a variety of shops and buildings and bars and people and.... Every trip to Gottica is unique as we find new places to explore. We can't wait to explore again.
Fun shopping. Fun shoping with several small shops with odd brands. Great contrast to the Garcia aea above Plaza Catalunya.
Gothic Quarter. Excellent area to wander round, plenty to see and do, no shortage of places to eat or drink. Highly recommend a visit
Spend some time wondering the streets. Always nice walking along old streets and seeing history. Especially nice was to visit the Call (Jewish Quarter) and the Oldest Synagogue in Europe.
Gothic city. Lots of narrow winding streets to wander through and enjoy restaurants and bars. Quiter than the Ramblas and cooler.

A maze of atmospheric back alleys. We spent several days exploring the Quarter and always found new sights around new corners: a reals sense of the city's historic roots and the current cultural atmosphere. Great.

the best of Gothic. I was a few times by buisnes trip but every time I went back to Barri Gotici.It was alwas at April so weather was the best for walking and between old walls you feel safe. Also there is a musician with violin so experience is complete. Also there are interesting shops, small garden inside of walls.

Have to see it. Best preserved gothic quarter of any city. We went to the Picasso museum in the Gothic quarter and looked around the streets. Beautiful architecture and some great little shops and restaurants. Definitely worth a look.

Gothic Quater. The streets are narrow and safe. I walked the area at night by myself and still felt safe. The historical buildings of the area are plentiful. There are even Roman ruins that can be visited. This area is a must see in Barcelona.
Worth a visit. Some of Barcelona's oldest and most beautiful streets can be seen here. Lots of interesting little shops to see.
Loved it!!. I love the history in the Gothic Quarter from the Cathedral to the old roads. You can't find more shopping or food in one place.

Go for the Tripadvisor self- guided tour!. A beautiful part of the city that can be hard to navigate through. Make sure you follow a map or use a self-guided tour. Many beautiful buildings. We did not go inside any of them, but I am sure that it´s nice inside of them, too.
An Adventure. You cannot miss this saction of the city, the best eating and shopping area with an old world flare. It was nice to stroll as long as you could without auto traffic
Wish I spent more time here. You can get completely lost in these streets - and that's not a bad thing! It's a shoppers paradise and its great to get that old world feel with the narrow streets.

Fascinating historical part of Old town Barcelona. We liked our tour with Runner Bean which was a great introduction to the history and culture of the original walled city. The maze of alleys with Churches, Palaces and historical squares was very interesting. There were shops and cafes and places to wander which made it a fun place to be in.

very average old town, but lovely independent shops. Few interesting old buildings and architecture, but very overrated in my opinion. you must take a map as small narrow streets look the same and there is no indication of where to go to see things. there are some great small shops with individually designed jewellery and clothing, but you need to wander around and seek them out - but they are well worth it, really reasonably priced too.

Great for exploring. Lots of interesting streets, buildings and shops, with surprises often around the corner. Lots of interesting courtyards and hidden gardens. Shopping was especially good with lots of small artisan producers.

very traditional and busy. spoiled for restaurants, very busy and full of atmosphere, seeped in history, not to expensive, be careful as in the evening the streets are narrow, don't wander on your own

Nice way to lose half a day!. Stumbled into this area before I knew where we were and took it at face value. Lots of tourists with cameras (including me) and it was a nice place to amble around discovering what might be round the next corner. As lovely as it is, I find Oxford (England) somewhat more interesting but the quaint shops and museums kept me entertained for a while.Would I come to this part again? Yes, I suspect there is lots more to be seen around this area and I imagine the buildings at night would make for super photographs.

A bit like the West Village. The most interesting shops and cafes can be found in this area. I would even recommend staying in this area for great walking, people watching and overall fun. Very safe at all hours.

Must see. The perfect place to walk around and explore or to just sit in one of the many pavement cafes and watch the world go by. We took time to walk around La Boqueria with stunning displays of fruit and iced drinks of all colours. We bought a tray of fresh pineapple that was the best I have ever tasted.
Love It. Going back the second time to visit the area quaint little shops and lots of little eateries prefer this area to the Ramblers.
Something around every corner. Forget Ramblas, get lost in the streets around here and find the most delightfully hidden shops, cafés and architecture.

Pleasure to walk around. Barri Gotic is an old part of Barcelona - small streets are just a pleasure to wonder around and explore. There are some fine churches that can not be missed, and many small bars offer great tapas and choices of food. Walk around, take your time, breeze Barcelona! Enjoy Gothic Quarter and everything in it!

stroll on the night with someone. don't plane to go alone at night as it turn to filled up with drug dealers selling beer or soft drinks as a cover as in the ramblas and other parts of the city
its wonderful and safe to go alone but still those people will never let alone (they will never force you but the are annoying)

Loved this area.. Just absolutely loved this area. We were in Barcelona for three days, and ended in this area at some time in the day, every day.Very quaint with lots of interesting shops, corners, churches and interesting little spots to visit. Just keep walking and enjoy.

Loose your self in the architecture. So wandering this part of town was totally fun. Lots to just look at and get lost in. Go find Quatro Gats!! Do the free walking tour and you will get so much history and interesting views of this neighborhood. Its filled with small shops and over priced items, but if you just want to look at things this is the place to go.
delightful. Similar to the born area, winding cobbled streets, great boutiques and tea shops etc, just lovely to stroll through on a bike or on foot at any time of the day or evening. Atmospheric.

A comfortable downtown. In Barcelona I stayed in this place, is great that you have everything near, the church, Starbucks, Las Ramblas to walk and shop, everything to eat and is very near of Plaza Catalunya, where you have the mall El Corte Ingles, Mcdonalds, the tourist buses, Hard Rock and also the buses that go and come from the airport.
Nice area to stroll and get lost. It's a beautiful area with old world charm, plenty of cafes and shops, museums and beautiful architecture.

best place in barcelona. my husband and i loved it here, it is very old fashioned with lovely little shops down every street and bars and cafes dotted around, will have to go back again next year as we didnt quite do all of it

Brilliant!. This area is probably the busiest area to visit. Stroll down the Ramblas from Placa Catalunya to the monument. Passing sections of stalls, flower market and restaurants. Lots of outside eateries offering meal deals which are really good value. The tree shaded walkway is delightful and cool. There are lots of side attractions to look for. Churches worth popping into. The Cathedral is off to the left. Ladies must cover their shoulders so if you don't have a shawl you can buy one from the 'ladies' outside for 2 euros.
Interesting place. This is a very interesting place to explore. Lots of shops, and great food, and the whole area is great to just stroll and see what turns up.
A GREAT PLACE TO GET LOST. Wandering the twisted narrow streets is a fascinating look at the past. You can't help but imagine what life must have been like many hundreds of years ago.
Check out in the day and night. This place was great to walk around - totally different vibe in the day vs. at night. I suggest you walk around at those two different times.

Very lovely place. The Gothic quarter is a must see in Barcelona as it gives us a glimpse of how the various religions and monarchs took over this beautiful city over the passage of time. The alleys are very interconnected and it is easy to loose oneself while exploring alone. The best way to explore would be to participate in the free walking tours and be enriched with the wonderful history that awaits in this lovely quarter.

Fun!. The gothic quarter is a fun place to explore. Narrow streets, unique shops selling everything from prosciutto to handbags. Cute tapas bars and churches. It is very clean, picturesque, and quaint with its cobblestone streets and archways.

mmm....ok. The Gothic Quater is over rated according to me. The only thing you can see here is the old roman church which is beautiful , not the most beautiful though. Apart from that you would not find much here.

My favorite neighborhood in Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter is my favorite neighborhood in Barcelona, with its small and narrow streets full of beautiful architecture and exhaling history. You shall not be afraid to adventure yourself and get lost on the small streets it is worthy! You will find yourself going back in time and admiring all the great buildings and alleys.

Good for a look around. July visit meant it is very hot! So obviously it was not ideal to walk around the Gothic quarters but its very nice to walk around and extremely close to La Rambla so you can walk all the way up to La Rambla. The Church is very beautiful too

Great place to wander. This is a very nice section of the city. Lots of good areas to explore on foot. Plan to get lost for a few hours and just wander. Keep in mind some sections are quite touristy, but there are still plenty of areas that are more secluded and nice to enjoy. I would recommend heading here for an afternoon of casual sightseeing and cafe hopping; don't get too caught up in trying to see this or that and just let yourself relax.

Great example of a medieval city. If your interest is in the Sefardic history, then for sure connect with a guide as much is hidden. Our guide Dominique from Urban Cultours was incredible. She points out things there is no way we'd have seen if on our own. She is an architect and historian so you are getting a true professional. Enjoy!

Stroll the Gothic. You can't visit BCN without visiting the Gothic Quarter...probably several times. Take your time and wander down the less crowded streets and fine jewels...whether it be shops, cafes or museums.

a special experience. To receive full value of the experience wandering this area read upon it first and identify what you would like to see. Otherwise you may wander in circles in the narrow streets of this traffic free zone.Lots of cafes around in which to sit, drink, eat and soak in the atmosphere of a past time.
Nice shops, nice area, nice ambiance. We stayed in the gothic quarter (H10 del raco del pi - see separate review) and really enjoyed it the shopping and cafés/bars, as well as the Cathedral.
Get lost...... just wander around the little pedestrian streets and there are pleasant surprises at every turn. Beautiful buildings, interesting shops, cafes. Love it.

Wonderful wandering. I remembered this from 20 years ago as my favorite part of Barcelona. I try to find the small narrow streets and just get lost in them. I was here a couple of times on this trip. Shops are closed on Sunday. And the shops close around 8pm or so, so you might not feel as safe wandering around at night.

Place frozen in time - Not to be missed. After La Sagrada Familia, this is second on my list of "must visit" places in Barcelona. Its incredible to find a place that is so "ancient" in the middle of a modern city. Dont miss "El Call", the ancient jewish quarter which is in the middle. If you want to take a break while walking around, there are plenty of small cafe's and bars sprinkled around the place.
Picturesque zone. simply wandering the Barri Gotic's labyrinthine passages and uncovering their secrets... there's no need for maps.. many vintage little shops..surprises
Don't miss it!. Just go walk around and explore all the alleys and find little hidden treasures. There is soo much to see and do, it is hard to pinpoint just one thing.

Must do in Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter is an expansive network of alleys and plazas that are in the center of the old city in Barcelona. Nothing beats walking down winding alleyways to then come across a small plaza with outdoor cafes and/or markets. There are plenty of people and we felt safe walking through the quarter. The crown jewel is the Plaza Real where you can grab amazing tapas to eat while people watching. An absolute must do in this city.
Fun to walk around. This place was wonderful to walk around and window shop. Many of the stores observe siesta so shops will close around 1 PM but reopen around 4.
Gothic revival and historic wonder!. Amazing historical significance, bars and restaurants, and so many interesting anecdotes to hear from the right tour guide.

Back in time. I found the Gothic Quarter stunning and I felt as if I was going back in time. Every corner you turn there is a beautiful section, street or store. It is endless and so architecturally and visually stimulating. A must see!!!

Great place to get lost. I think Barcelona is one of the most beautiful cities in Europe (along with Paris), and a lot of that is because of the Barri Gotic. You can wander for block after block, finding a surprise around every corner. You can follow several different walking tours to make sure you hit the highlights, but definitely plan to spend a little time wandering, too.
Just wander around. We enjoyed an afternoon just wandering around the area looking at the shops and the old buildings. Got some great photos of gargoyles and little streets.
Wear your walking shoes. We walked all over Barcelona but especially loved the Gothic Quarter. Cobblestone streets so make sure you are comfortable walking. Go to the Picasso Museum.

This was the highlight. Staying in and walking this area was the highlight of our stay. There is charm, visual interest, stores, museums, everything of interest. I highly recommend you spending some open hours wandering the streets, both day and night.
Great location. Close to beach, in the middle of shopping, but far enough or close enough (depending which way you see it), to La Ramba, which is a busy tourist street.

LOVELY AREA. Walking down Las Ramblas just turn right and in a few minutes you will find yourself enjoying the old city of Barcelona.The Portaferrissa street is also full of shops to look around. The Cathedral is very close too. When you get in Barri Gotic one's for sure: don't schedule, just stroll careless.

Quaint and modern at the same time. A lovely square to walk around and people watch. Neat little tapas places. The best part was watching the art students produce sketches of the cathedral in their little sketch books

Great place to get lost. Got lost in this area a few times but did so with great pleasure as there were many interesting shops and public venues found and worth the visit. Very atmospheric.Interesting to note is that on Sundays the local community meet at the courtyard of the Cathedral and the municipal principal house to take part in traditional activities like the Sardana etc
great. lots of shops and as well amazingly looking architecture. love the small streets that you can walk into just to have a peek and get lost in the beauty of the buildings...
If you like Gothic, this is very good to walk thru. The craftsmanship and preservations of the Gothic buildings in this area are great, truly a history, or architectural buff would enjoy.

Full of Character. you HAVE to spend time here! It's full-on, it's Barcelona, it's fun and full of history and character. Be mindful of your bags and your personal space, but don't get paranoid about it. Enjoy

wow. Visited Barcelona earlier this year and fell in love with the city. Amazing people, amazing places, amazing food..... I cant rave enough about it. We stuck to the gothic quarter - there are so many cool bars and restaurants which are so much cheaper than Las Ramblas - I cant speak highly enough of this city. Just amazing.
Fun place to go. Oozes with culture. Lots of restaurants, churches, markets and other happening places. Go early and avoid the crowds

Neat stores. We rented an apartment just off of Place George Orwell for 10 days so we spent a lot of time in the old town. Southwest of our place is a bit sketchy but the rest of Barri Gottic is great. Fun to get lost in. On one of our journeys we happened across a circus store, El Ingenio, just off Ferran where the owner make those giant costumes with the mask heads. He took us into his workshop and gave us a free intro to mask making in Catalan(we understood the main points with the help of gestures). Bought the girls some high quality circus toys, flower stick and Diablo yo yo which they won't put down.
Goes on for ever. Great to just wander around, a different experience round each corner, from shops to history, spend a day just walking.

Wonderful pedestrian area for wandering. Full of history and architecture, free of cars, totally confusing to wander around in, in a delightful way (make sure you bring a paper map; GPS may or may not be able to get a signal lock in a medieval era stone lane, 30 feet deep and only 5 feet wide!)
My Favorite. We experienced 6 days in Barcelona and the Gothic Quarters was my favorite. We enjoyed strolling In between the narrow streets and discovering new things around each corner.

Really neat area. The church in this area was built starting in about 1248. It was just neat to look at all the amazing craftsmanship and think of all the hands and hours that were spent putting this all together. From every stone in the walls to every carved figure. Going on the rooftop here ended up being my very favorite adventure in Barcelona. It was super windy but I stayed up there taking pix for a good while.

A labarynth of hidden gems. Nice to see small retailers showing their unique wares and crafts long since replaced by technology still flourishing. No visit to Barcelona would be complete without visiting the gothic quarter. Take time to look into the shops to see craftsmen still producing their unique goods.

Put the map away and get lost!. Bounded by la rambles, the sea, el born and plaza catalunya, this is a safe place to put that map away and just wander, soak up the atmosphere, and enjoy a nibble or two at the many eateries in the area. Cultural highlights include the cathedral (inc the rooftop terrace) and the roman ruins from the early AD centuries.
just go for a walk and some tapas. take your time, stop more than ones on the way, do not be afraid to get lost as the Barri is very safe.
Nice. Lovely area to just stroll around in, quite shady which suited my 'burn-easily' husband, lovely old buildings, bit like Venice with vehicles.

Great area to stroll. We were told to watch our bags and pockets due to pickpockets. It pays to be careful, for sure, but we had a great experience. Fun to walk around the area and we enjoyed some fabulous tapas along the way.
Great shopping off the beaten path. Our guide walked us thru this section of the city with great enthusiasm and explanation. A guide helps you understand what how why and for us was a must.

So much to see too little time!. Lots and lots to see but not enough time to see it all! Spent a day in the Gothic quarter and felt I could spend 2 or 3 days and still not see it all really beautiful buildings.

Gothic Quarter was amazing -- incredible atmosphere and many photo ops. We visited the Old Cathedral in the Gothic Quarter (which itself is a must see) and from there, began to wander the streets through the Gothic Quarter. Incredible atmosphere and many photo ops.In one particularly beautiful side street, a man playing classical Spanish guitar -- one of those travel moments you never forget. It just takes you to an entirely different place and time.In the Summer, it stays light out until 10pm there. If you were there after dark, very late at night, I can see where it might be a little scary getting lost in some of the alleyways. If that is a concern, my suggestion would be to confine your visit to the late afternoon, early evening. It is not far from La Rambla, however, so you are never too far away from the crowds.

Living history. Gothic area was fun to explore and discover all the hidden boutiques, eateries and history. We went on one of the free walking tours and weren't disappointed. It is a large area and easy to get lost in. Look for the street signs on the sides of the buildings 8 to 10 feet up then refer to your map. Most businesses have multi lingual staff, so its easy to communicate and get what you need.

Do a self-tour!. We had a walking route from the pages of a guide book. With that alone you might still take wrong turns due to small streets and plazas. We had a hand-held GPS with us and mapped the route. It is a must do if you want to take a step back in time! We stopped and had some sangria in one of the courtyards.

very nice. it was a nice enjoyfull afteernoon. those little streets of barri gothiv were all ending in a different square with caffes and shops. nice neighborhood to visit, to walk through the streets and enjoy an other sense of barcelona city. romantic atmosphere :)
Relaxing. Good for a relaxing afternoon of sight seeing. Most often there will be groups of people dancing or giving a show. Shops around there are pretty expensive so I would stick to the shows.
The past. Every city has its past period described by its places. This quarter is a brief description of the old Barcelona. A mixture of old and new makes the walk pleasant
its a maze. This place is great to wander about, loads of lovely shops and bars in narrow streets. Quite a bit quieter than the Ramblas but has a charm of its own.

Gothic Barcelona. This was an amazing area to meander through - loaded with tourists and cafes, interesting shops selling delicacies and leather goods. The small plaza's tucked behind the main streets house interesting modern sculptures - it's a wonderful place to browse through and there are lots of photo opportunities as well. My camera ran hot.

INCREDIBLE!. the one place we kept coming back to and discovering more and more little streets we'd never seen before. So many unique cafes, restaurants, shops, tapas bars and gorgeous architecture. could spend days here!

like a warren. Great to wander arround the warren of narrow streets that have many interesting shops, bars and resraurants,realy interesting architecture of buildings with ornate balconies and street lamps.When we were there we came across an art market and local farmers market in one of the small squares.We spent an hour outside the cathedral listening to the street performers and people watching.It is easy to lose your bearing in the narrow alley ways but if you ask a shopkeeper for directions you soon find your way back again,realy nice to wander around.
Great architecture. If you enjoy walking and looking at countless examples of fine architecture, topping for a tapas or two, and continuing, youe will enjoy this area.

stunning side streets. I actually stayed in the heart of the gothic quarter and i was stunned by even the sidestreets. The place is so charming, I would get a walking tour as there are so many interesting things to know about the gothic quarter that you wouldn't otherwise know.
Great place. One of the best places in Barcelona as it contains a lot of old buildings , Cathedral, and places to eat a good food there.
Best value. Eat around this area for a cheaper but good meals. The area has many windy streets and surprises ! lots of little shops and part of the old wall.

We enjoyed it enough that we went back the next day. My husband and I enjoyed two afternoons here. The churches are beautiful and there are endless little shops. It is much quieter than the bigger ramblas and an area we much more enjoyed. The tapas restaurants in this area seem much less "touristy" and the streets are picturesque and quiet. We visited the synagogue which is definitely worth a visit.

easily get lost. If you havent wandered in these allies then you missed out on the essence of Barcelona! Lovely shops, filled with history. its such a pity there is not much guides to this Cartier (there is an English one that starts at 8AM or something :S, but i havent tried it)

Great place to let lost wandering for a day. Shopping with my wife we saw tons of bars and clothing and jewelry stores and quaint quiet streets. Most tourists wont wander these streets and it will be their loss. Be adventurous and spand and hour during the day wondering. it feels quite safe.
Quaint!. A lovely area to stroll around and take in all the different quaint streets etc. Lots of lovely restaurants especially in front of the Cathedral there.
Walking the Gothic Quarter. Great time walking the backstreets and alleys of the Gothic Quarter, even though at one point we got lost and had to look at a map to realize where we were.
Very interesting. It's a gem that seems to go on and on. Well worth a visit, wish I'd taken one of the walking tours around the area
Nice place to walk around. The Gothic Quarter is a small ancient area in the old town of Barcelone. Narrow alleys with little boutiques and small Tapas bars. You should not miss it!

worth looking at. Didn't spend long enough wandering around here. The real old city. Too many boutique type shops for my liking, but not the girls in our party. Fascinating looking around though. And yes the shops were shut on a Sunday when my wife went back with her credit card...
Narrow streets and something new on each turn. It is crowded smelly dark and full of pickpockets so be careful. The quarter is worth seeing and full of great shops and cafes.
Beautiful and Historic. Windy roads, get lost in the history and culture of barcelona. Explore and find restaurants and ancient relics.

A must see in Barcelona.. Of course, everyone knows you should visit the gothic quarter while in Barcelona, but I have an extra tip for you: Visit the place, walk all around the various streets, from top to bottom--- do this both by day and night. You'll get different feels throughout the day, depending on the crowd at the time, the sun's direction and the goings-on. Also, spend some time stopping by the enclaves or placas you see along the way, they either have offices, shops or restaurants that are quite interesting. These places get exciting towards the evening. The architecture here is magnificent. Take a lot of photos. You'll regret not doing so later. Go into the beautiful buildings, most of it is free. Talk to the locals and just explore.

Shops galore, good restaurants too. We did a Gourmet Walking Tour of this and adjacent areas on a Saturday morning. I was impressed by all the interesting looking independent shops. Thought: I'll come back tomorrow and explore in depth. But they are all closed on Sunday and we were leaving Monday morning. What a bummer. A week later, we were in Nice and everything stays open on Sundays.Oh well, be sure to avoid that when you go.
Charming and fascinating. The Barri Gotic is well worth spending a day in. Museums, churches, quaint squares, performers (primarily excellent singers) all contribute to a meaningful travel experience
Worth visiting. loads of fun going around the old town, very interesting? lots of little boutique restaurants and bars

no enough time for all of it. is one of the greatest places I´ve been, there are so many stores, bars, restaurants and other things that time seems to shrink, from upbeat scene to very traditional, from guitar traditional makers to tattoo parlors. is the perfect place to go for a full day, get lost, have lunch and take thousand of pictures.

So old but so wonderful!. Enjoyed strolling the narrow streets and visiting the shops and sites! Would suggest you read "The Shadow Of The Wind" by Carlos Ruiz Zaton prior to your visit as much of it is set in and around Barcelona.

One of the best places in Barcelona. I loved just walking there, going back in time and see those beautiful colorful, different streets..You can also find some really special things, not just the tipical souvenirs..Definetly go there, if you are tired of the crowd and want to feel the true mood of the city.

Do the free walking tour as an introduction to this area. We wanted to find out as much as possible about the Gothic Quarter so decided to take the Barcelona free walking tour. It left from the beginning of Las Ramblas near the Hard Rock Cafe. The walk turned out to be extremely interesting. Besides the cobblestone streets, cafes, and shops, there is much history here. You wouldn't know about any of it without the tour. We went by some graves from Roman times, and the story behind that was awesome. Holes were left in the tombs so relatives could put food inside! We also saw a courtyard that had been refurbished except for one building which still had damage from the Spanish Civil War. The battered building stands in commemoration of that event. Later we went back to walk some of the area again. The tour took a little over 2 hrs, and we loved it. Definitely recommend.
Awesome place. very nice place affordable clean noce breakfast value fr money good very good moreover its in heart of city so very approachable
Very cool area.. An area of the city that dates to before the Moors. Beautiful old building and churches. Walk, take a million pictures, see history not seen by everyone.
Good. We went around with a tour. Barcelona is so much about art and architecture, so these places are worth a visit
Cobbled streets, beautiful architecture. Like a magical mystery tour, lots of lovely little shops, museums & restaurants. One of the highlights of our trip

The essence of local culture. I have been to these quarters on every trip to Barcelona. The winding streets, with elaborate details are an experience on themselves. Keep the camera handy amd try to visit early morning or evening for your best photo shots. Well worth to stop for a drink in the street.

We took some really nice pictures here. Yes spend the afternoon going around the old city so beautiful and safe (cameras everywhere). We took some really nice pictures here and had some sangria at a nice restaurant outside the church with the interchanging street entertainers.

Old Town. we enjoyed wondering arround the old town some lovley buildings and you must visit one of the food markets they were great.In the back streets you will find lovely squares with some great little restraunts , cheaper than in the main streets.

Ancient Rome meets 15th century Spain. The essential walking tour in Barcelona. Take one of the free guided tours and get immersed in the history of barcia and catalunya. Plenty of good tapas bars and coffee shops to keep you fuelled up and santa caterina markets nearby for those picnic essentials.

Beautiful buildings. We spent an afternoon wandering around the streets and squares and looking in all the little shop windows. Lovely cafes too with reasonable prices for tapas. Could have taken a photograph of nearly every building they were so picturesque.
El Born. Fab bars and shops an atmosphere. Go there 10.30pm or after for great nite out!! And on the day for shopping and tapas

A MUST SEE. You can't go to Barcelona and not hit the Gothic Quarter at a point or another. It is right near Las Ramblas, and it is a very well known area. Barri Gotic has a lot of history, narrow cobblestone streets, small coffee shops, restaurants and tons of boutiques - some of them hold amazing little treasures. Just take a stroll and you can fully take in the spirit of Barcelona. Loved it and would highly recommend!

Maze of charming narrow streets. A part of Barcelona that really should not be missed, likely to appeal to all ages. Very easy to get lost. Great restaurants and shops; my teenage daughter was disappointed that we visited this area just before leaving for the airport, as she would have loved to spend many hours shopping in the boutiques. Can get a bit seedy at night time.
barcelona gothic area. the plazas are nice and have tapas bars everywhere the history speaks for itselfthe architecture and churches are awesome

Barcelona must-do. (Lots of walking). It's almost other-worldly. This amazing labyrinth of corridors and narrow streets. Stop by the striking Barcelona Cathedral (Cathedral of the Holy Cross) and Museu d'Història de la Ciutat de Barcelona.

Quaint and mildly entertaining. I suggest finding a tour to join to get the stories and history of the area. Lots of twisted alleyways pretty much clean for the most part. No worries at 11 - 2 pm, other than what direction am I going.However, sadly, graffiti abounds.

Not to be missed, it is what make Barcelona so charming. Visit the city history museum to truly understand where you are walking in space and time, stroll Las Ramblas to the sea and soak in just what it is that makes the city special
GPS Saved Me At Night. I got lost here after a few glasses of wine, it's a bit of a maze, so the GPS on my phone got me back to the hotel.

Must see in Barcelona. The Barri Gotic is an area of Barcelona that is not to be missed. Its a wonderful area to check out restaurants, local shops and of course people watch. Every little little turn of a street or corner offered something amazing to see.
Worth a visit. Architecture and building very nice and preserved very well. Worth a trip to see Barcelona because some of the buildings have been restored or maintained very well.

Nice for evening entertainment. I visited the Gothic Quarter every night, there is always lots to see and plenty of restaurants to choose from. Some nice restaurants in Placa Reial and Santa Maria del Mar is nearby. Its great to have a wander around all the shops.

Cozy, dirty and beautiful.. The way it should be!. Barri gotic is full of narrow alleys and streets with a lot of restaurants, tapas bars, shops and everything in between.Walking around here gives you a wide choice in everything food related, from cheaper tapas to more up scale fancy dining places to high end shopping to cheap fake bling bling.Grab a fresh youghurt icecream while cruising the streets, do a little bit of shopping, let that camery go wild and when your tummy is screaming for food - make sure you make it happy by trying out a few of the many tapas bars and restaurants.If you visit Barcelona, the Gothic Quarter is a must visit!
