Beautiful. The architecture of the area of the city if stunningly beautiful. There also many little quirky and unusual shops in the back streets. Not to be missed!
Charming area. Interesting art galleries and boutique shops. Great local eats with lots of interesting street performers

Quaint twisty laneways.. We loved exploring the boutiques along the cobbled pathways. Around each corner was another delight, glowing shops filled with treasures. Loved the brightly coloured leather shoes.
Tappers. Make sure you price up your tappers, before eating it cost us for 12 small plates, for 4 people 86 euros, we did find some lovely restaurants after that which were better value
Wonerful wander. Check out the back streets away from the tourist run and there are some wonderful local art galleries

THE place to stay in Barcelona. We LOVED staying in the Gothic Quarter! Lots to see, lots of people-watching, lots of shopping (of all kinds), and easy walking to just about anywhere in Barcelona. GREAT location!

Walking tour. We did a 90minute free walking tour which we basically stumbled into when we got out of the train. Loved the special bits of information that you wouldn't know about if you just ambled along on your own. We went back when the tour was finished to the Historical museum and visited the roman ruins underneath the building. Absolutely outstanding ruins and so professionally organised, as in walkways, lighting etc.

Take a leisurely stroll. Take a leisurely stroll through the Gothic quarter. It is beautiful and full of little hidden treasures. I loved the Cathedral with its central gardens and geese, it was very surreal!

So much to see and do here..... The Barri Gotic has so much to offer and eating, walking, shopping and visiting the sites inside the Barri Gothic was satisfying. I wish we had more time to venture but had to move on to other parts of Barcelona.

Amazing architecture, hidden gems. We loved all the hidden surprises in this area. We came across a great restaurant, an archeological dig of some roman ruins, cute little shops, beautiful old buildings, an antiques flea 'market'. Liked it more than la ramblas!

Marvelous!. This place is really unique! It oozes history throught everything in it! It's also where the city started in the ancient times. The architecture is fantastic and there are plenty of bar, shops and all kinds of attractions nearby! That's the place to be if you are in the beautiful Barcelona.

Lose urself.. You have to lose urself in the gotic quarter, you can spend hours and hours , going round and round in this labyrinth, shop, window shop, eat paella, have an ice cream or just walk, most of the time, you will see something new everyday.

Lovely area. Pick of the nieghbourhoods in Barcelona. We did a Walking Tapas Tour and was introduced to the area by a guide - after that tour we were able to navigate the tangle of street with comfort and ease.
A great place to get lost in (in a good way). An intricate web of alleys and narrow streets with interesting architectural details. Lots of little shops to peruse.

great quarter. Watch the beautiful old buildings, most in roman style, and enjoy the peace of this part of Barcelona. Lots of restaurants, small shops, places where you can have a drink..enjoy it step by step

Barrio Gotico. An area close to the Cathedral that has very small street or alley ways with very old buildings. Some street are narrow and cute and shows how people lived in the middle ages. It is easy to get lost specially when it gets dark.

Great place to wander. There are so many interesting alleys and detours. Take a stroll, stop for some cava and tapas, people watch and walk some more. We are here for a week, and have ended up there every other day and have found something new every time.

Best place for restaurants. Try any tapas bars - all good. Keep an eye in your bags. Must visit the market, try the noodle bar at the entrance to the market, fresh, hot, reasonably priced, tasty. Check out coffee and creeps at the Artista cafe

Old city, art and food. You could say that the Gothic quartier is the actual Old Barcelona city. The offer is huge in terms of gastronomy, art (lot of museums including Picasso's at Montcada's streets), architecture and nightclubbing if you move a bit to the Born quartier.

Don't miss it: may be the most distinctive neighborhood in Barcelona. Gothic could be expected in a church, not in a whole neighborhood. So, don´t miss it, it´s completely unusual. In adition, it´s a very lively place, with cool atmosphere

Stunning apart from the Graffiti. We had a hotel in the center of the Gothic Quarter, you can find the best and most diverse crowd of people here and the architecture all around the Gothic Quarter is absolutely stunning although there is graffiti on almost every famous attraction or street which ruins some of the architecture.

Amazing place to wander and get lost for an afternoon.. I love this area. I would have loved to spend an entire afternoon just wandering the streets and alleys of the Gothic Quarter. The little hidden plazas, shops, and cafes are unique and enjoyable. I wandered for a couple of hours, and never saw the same street twice.
Loved it!. Amazing architecture! Saw the Temple of Agustus ruins from 1 A.D. and the Cathedral Basilica which was beautiful. Lots of great photo opportunities. A must see in Barcelona!
A beautiful centre. There is nothing more perfect than pedestrianised zones when on holiday - especially in such historic centres.

Interesting. A great few hours wandering around and so luck y to come across a perormance of traditional dance and music outside the Cathedral. Just lose yourself in the streets and enjoy the experience

Fascinating and full of hidden gems. We did a guided walking tour of Barri Gotic starting at (and paid-for at) the tourist office on Placa Sant Jaume. Cost was 30E each but discounted to 21E as we had had a bus-turistic ticket earlier in the week. There are lots of amazing hidden gems that we would never have found alone and more interesting because of the guide's info (which was in very clear English). Note - many of the locations such as Temple d'August can be visited at no cost and are listed in guidebooks however some we would never have known to go and look at such the entrance ways and courtyards of several public-access buildings including the Palau de Lloctinent. We went back to look at several of the buildings and streets again afterwards at our leisure. Note - much of the walking was in shaded places so was very pleasant on a hot day at the end of May.
Gothic Quarter. Ate at a few places in here. Saw the big church. Lovely little lanes full of shops selling all kinds of things. Great way to spend an evening just walking around.

Very Cool. The Gothic quarter is very cool. However you really shouldn't be alone in the quarter at night. The reason is because there are many narrow streets and you could get lost easily. Always travel with a crowd through the gothic quarter at night. It is very historic.

Get lost in this beauty!. We spent a lot of time in the Gothic Quarter. It is a very beautiful part of the city. It is actually my favorite part. You must take a few walks through this area during your trip!
Gothic quarter. This is a must to visit, also the cathedral - medieval quarter bursting of history. All very walkable.

Lovely to wander around. We took some time to ramble around this district and it was lovely, different shops, squares that open onto churches, a market square where music was being played every time we passed. Unexpected Archaeological museum dating from Roman times. Lots of choice of places to eat and drink.

an amazing maze. amazinf maze of small and enchanting streets with some great shops and eateries tucked away ...the gargoyles look down uppon u giving an eerie feelinf when u wallk down the street at night ....

Amazing. We rather over-used the word 'amazing' on this holiday but the place really was like that. The Gothic Quarter is a maze of little streets (many pedestrianised) and lovely open squares with an astonishing number of stunningly beautiful old buildings packed in.

Good atmosphere and interesting shopping. I love the winding alleyways of the Gothic Quarter and the little shops and placas. Have never been robbed in Barcelona but wary given that everyone, including residents, warn you about it. Love the Catedral there. There are always a lot of people and a great atmosphere here and interesting shopping and eateries.
Great to walk about. So many to see but need a good pair of walking shoes if you want to last long. Cafes and restaurant is everywhere.

Great area to visit. Great area to visit- lots of sites nearby. Don't miss the Roman ruins located in this area and the Picasso museum- both of which are tricky to find actually. Visit the Santa Catalina market- the tapas bar/Restuarant is inerdibley delicious!
Teaming with life!. By day or night, it is teaming with life. This is the area to stay in -- full of shops, cafes, and tapa bars. Perfect for evening strolls through antiquity.

Charged with history in a enchanting Quarter. You can walk a lot and see this incredible buildings that makes you think that maybe in this modern times we lack of imagination in our daily life to realize how they did this kind of greatest constructions
Fun area to explore. I loved the architecture and buildings with faces and gargoyles and narrow streets to explore. It is near the cathedral and can be combined together in one visit.
Beautiful Streets & Alleyways. After stopping in the gothic quarter for 5 days, I fell in love! So many streets and alleyways, with plenty to see and do! Something different around every corner!

Lovely - pretty typical. yes we enjoyed this, but it was not amazing or particularly different from other old quarters. It is charming and has lovely nooks and crannies, cute photographic opportunities, and is a pleasant way to spend some time. Good shopping too. The best was the Travellers Restaurant which provides free walking tours daily. Just go and ask. Nice terrace for lunch too.

Daytime Location. Walking around the gothic quarter is very cool to see the architecture. I would suggest spending an afternoon and walking up and down the side streets. Do not go at night, most of the shops are closed, and the area becomes barren and dark. Stick to daytime activities around this neighborhood

A great place to wander and explore. We loved meandering in the streets and seeing all the activity. We visited Picasso's museum, cool shops and saw ruins of the old Roman empire There are great little tapas places and restaurants in the area. It's worth the time to explore and get "lost" here.

Discover this wonderful part of the city and its history. I loved the Gothic Quarter for its tiny streets and 'secret places' such as nice shops, restaurants or bars. The only negative point in my opinion is the fact that this area is always packed with tourists. But, well, it's normal, you are in Barcelona!
Gothic. It is really very nice to spend an afternoon wandering round the old streets of the gothic quarter. Check out the 4 cats Restaurant where Picasso used to go.

browse the lanes !. You can get lost in all the old quarter and find wonderful squares with people relaxing eating and drinking with music playing. Step back in time great way to see the Gothic Quarter on foot
SOME FABULOUS ICE CREAM PLACE. Although a tourist trap, the Gothic quarter gave us the most fabulous meal in a tiny quiet square. Best food of the trip. Sorry can't remember the name!

Quaint and crowded.. The (very) narrow streets have lots of people walking through them. They seem to eb and flow as interesting sites make for awed stops along the way. Lots of old architecture and photo ops.
Quick stop. It would make it interesting to stop by this church since its free and very different from the other churches in Barcelona, you get the same feeling as churches in Prague
Beautiful. Love the narrow streets and architecture.Love the square.Altogether lovely.A bit spooky if the streets are empty

Great Area of Town. If you enjoy little shops and lots of restaurants this is a great area of town. A good idea ...get off the tourist lanes and find a little restaurant that has the menu in nothing but Catalan..you will be pleasantly surprised..and you wallet will than you

Walking Tour from Rick Steve's book. We did the walking tour for this area in Rick Steve's book. It actually took us all day because there were so many fascinating places to stop along the way. We watched the dancers at the Cathedral, then were lucky enough to come upon some kind of competition between castellers in a different square. You can do this walk quickly and get a general feel, but I recommend doing it on a day when you can be flexible. Lots of shops, museums and history. A charming, historic, and very safe feeling area.

A single day in Barcelona. This is a fantastic area to walk around. There's so much to discover down each tiny alley. We got the feeling that for everything we saw we were missing 20 others. There's so many quaint places to grab a drink or a meal that this area is a must see if you go to Barcelona.

Easy to get lost!. So easy to get lost in the winding streets of the Gothic Quarter. We stumbled upon Good Friday mass at the Gothic Cathedral and enjoyed window shopping through the shops and boutiques and checking out the menus of the restaurants.
Include in your City tour. A must see and experience especially if you like centuries of history. Many streets and alleys filled with hidden secrets.
Free walking tour!. I did the Sandemans free walking tour in Barcelona in this area and it really has an fascinating history! Recommended!

A stroll through history. It is hard to believe that all these old ruins are a few steps away from the Ramblas and the most commercial part of Barcelona. Bring your cameras and get ready to step into history. The government has provided information about each of the monuments, which makes it the most enjoyable since there is no need to try to figure out what everything is. Start from the Cathedral and follow the signs

I just so love it here. narrow cobbled streets that feel safe, smart, quirky and full of surprises. Easy to get lost but thanks to the sea and Ramblas, easy enough to find your way out if you ever get bored.
Nice buildings. Nice streets and buildings in this quarter, if you got time go and look at it, make sure you plan it beforehand not to miss anything.

Charming with a tad bit crazy. My traveling buddy and I headed to Barri Gotic as our destination twice during our trip. We went on our first night to get dinner, which we ended up in one of the more touristy restaurants next to the Cathedral (might've been the jetlag). We walked home through the winding alleys and charming streets. We also went for our final night and ate at Sensi (recommended for Asian-fusion tapas!). After Sensi, we decided to check out the bar-hopping scene and wandered through more alleyways - it somewhat got sketchy and the crowd was going crazy (this was closer to Las Ramblas).I was recommended to visit this part of the city with the disclaimer that it was so charming and quaint, but after seeing the crowd on a Friday night (we're only talking about midnight), I would advise going during the day.

Walking tour of the Gothic Quarter. Use a good guide book when you tour this area of Barcelona . Having a tour guide with you is more enjoyable. Don,t forget to visit the oldest synagogue in Europe while you are in the Quarter

Brief walk-thru. We got off the Hop-on Hop-off bus to walk through the Gothic quarter. The cathedral was even more awesome than pictures I've seen. And discovering the geese off the side patio was fun! The narrow streets and interesting shops kept us busy for quite some time. And then we discovered that we could walk right out to Las Ramblas and find our way back to our hotel.
Put this on your bucket list!. Great music, great history, great wine, great food! Not much more to say. Just a fun place to visit and stay for a couple of days.
Enchanting. Loved the gothic quarter. Intend to go back and investigate further. Book a walking tour to learn more and then just wander and get lost and discover nice squares with friendly bars

A Must experience. When visiting Barcelona, walking the Gothic are is a must..so much to see, visit and listen to. The four days we were ther, it changed, Sunday was an outdoor Mass and Parade for Corpus Christi, a day later an outdoor flea market and this was all in the plaza in front of the cathedral. The streets are filled with much and and singers. For an hour we sat and listened to two opera singers. The walk allows you to have a gelato nod it and watch people. It is easy to get confused in the labyrinth of streets, but you always come out to a Main Street . Don't miss this part of the city.

fun people watching and shopping. The old city of Barcelona is divided by a major road and Barri Gotic did not appeal to me as much as the other side of the road, El Raval, but this is really splitting hairs! Be sure to see the Roman ruins in Barri Gotic, close to the cathedral. To really get a grip on Barcelona, I recommend you read the book Barcelona, by Robert Hughes. Fantastic and fun insights. "Robert Hughes's magisterial paean to Barcelona: history, travel guide and labour of love from the well-known art critic."

Wonderful to explore. This is an excellent place to explore, and around every corner there seemed something new to discover. This was really entertaining. With the shops, I found that you could barter/haggle over prices if you thought they were too expensive, so don't be afraid to do this. One thing we wanted dropped from 12 euros down to 7 euros just by saying that we thought it was too expensive.
Wandering the lanes and streets. Always found a different route to go, buildings wonderful, not too crowded in June.Restaurants to try, churches to visit, nor too many people touting for business.

Excellent neighborhood to walk around.. You can spend hours and days just walking around the gothic quarter with all its hidden gems, narrow streets, eclectic shops, cafes and restaurants. A true Barcelona experience.

Pretty but too much tat. This was a lovely view of the city as it was, except the horrid tat shops selling vile mass-produced vulgar tee shirts and lurid junk. If you concentrate on looking up at the buildings its great but watch your bag and try not to bump into drunken Brits on a spree....

Not so safe but so pretty!. We stayed in a hostel in the Barri Gotic. Perfect location but a little dangerous, lots of pickpocket like everywhere in Barcelona. Lots of shops, good restaurants and museum! Have fun :)
long streets and great design. Must visit the "Gothic Barrio" well preserved and charming, lot of bars, restaurants and shops close by, great vibe from the city
Great place to get lost. This is an awesome area of town to just aimlessly wander about. The narrow streets, shops and restaurants make it interesting, but the architecture takes the stage.

Gothic indeed. Love this district. Loved the lanes that are almost like a maze, yet quite organised. You can't really get lost there. Enjoyed the stores that sells all sorts of things. The restaurants and bars too.

nice, but.... It's a great area of the city. Quite, clean and full of shops and restaurants. I liked to meet some boutique or artisans. It seems some time that the Barrio is loosing its gothic character to turn into a touristic similar-gothic zone.
But it's nice to be lost in all the little streets around the main alleys.
Great for Photography. Great Gothic Architecture for photos in small narrow streets, lots of character, ambience. People about at all hours. Safe and close to public transportation.

My favorite area of Barcelona!. There is so much history here it is incredible! I will say that it is intimidating when you first get there and see all the little streets. You can very easily get lost. We took a walking tour and that is the best way to see some of the very interesting sights and to get your bearings. There is plenty to eat as well as shopping also. The Gothic Cathedral is just beautiful. Go to the ancient Roman temple of Augustus and you'll see 4 Roman columns in this 2000 year old building. People are not really opening their shops and stores until about 9 or 10. Some will also close for siesta from around 1:30 - 4:30. Most shops in the Quarter will close around 8. The restaurants will be open much later and until early hours of the morning. I highly recommend a walking tour and Orange Donut Tours is the one we took. Very small group, no annoying headsets and she was very knowledgeable about the history and myths of the Quarter. She keeps the groups to under 10 people so it is very easy to ask questions.

A good place to walk and enjoy different sights. A very interesting area to walk around and enjoy gothic sights. There is an old church with a very definite gothic feel to it that verges on creepy but it is definitely worth a visit since you don't get to see that very often. If you have time, make an effort to go.
Lovely Barcelona area. Shops, bars, cosy squares, terraces, it's a really lovely area of Barcelona. A bit touristy on the bigger squares, but the night life is excellent here.
Lovely visit. Really enjoyed my visit. Was particularly impressed that my two teenage nieces had free entry! Really worth a visit!

A must see when in Barcelona!. The history, architecture and splendor is at full bloom in this quiet and colorful part of the city. Great restaurants, shoe shops and coffee shops are around every corner! The only negative is that, like you, everybody else will want to visit this too. With that said, avoid during peak hours.

very interesting area. we took a free walking tour with Hanna, the guide from Travel Bar : While walking around for two hours , she shared with us (some 15 - 20 persons , unknown to each other) - her love and knowlege of this particular quarter of Barcelona .

Gothic Quarter Review. We did the Gothic Quarter walking tour and had a lovely time! They take you to parts of the quarter that you would not be able to find yourself just by strolling around....and the Roman history is fascinating. Overall a morning well spent.

Culture overload. Loved walking the narrow cobbled stoned streets of Barri Gotic. It was the injection of culture we desperately needed.The cafes, restaurants, shops were all unique.Loved just sitting, people watching while sipping a coffee.We strolled for hours during the day as we were told the evenings can be a fraught with pick pockets. We felt safe and kept our hands on our bags and camera at all times.
Funky and a must visit.. Its old, unique, narrow streets, great shops in tight little corners, beautiful squares with cafes. Be careful at night if its late.Great place to go for tapas.
Center of Fun. This is the heart of the city, old streets, outdoor cafes, shops, history. Your visit will not be complete without a day and evening spent in this part of Barcelona.
so romantic. it is much better than rambla and all other places in barcelona, romantic and small...just walk around take your time and relax
The heart of BCN. It is loud, it is noicy but it is the heart of BCN with great tapas restaurants and small narrow streets and alleys.

Nice old town. Very nice old town and cathedral
we liked the generalitat of Catalunya and the old City hall
worth a 1 hour walk

Pleasant to walk around. Didn't really notice I was in the gothic quarter as much of the city is designed in the same way - tall buildings with meandering roads. Having said that, I do think we spent a longer than usual time wandering around feeling lost.
Very Interesting. We liked the Gothic very much and food was good. We also did a lot of shopping and people were very friendly. We would go back to this area again.
most interesting area of barcelona. historic buildings==performers-flamenco--little side streets --tapas and sangria bars and shopping.Also interesting markets.

narrown little streets. This part of Barcelona is medieval and has narrow streets opening into lovely squares. Be aware of the danger from pick pockets due the narrowness. The Palau du musica and the cathedral are well worth the trek. There are lots of lovely restaurants here.
lived up to its name. authentic jewelry, many various booths from ancient to new stuff. the people are pretty punk , full neck tattoo is no biggie
Amazing place. A great place to explore.....walk the streets, grab a coffee, enjoy lunch. Just off Las Ramblas, something different around every corner... Spend the afternoon and get lost in here..

Pleasant area to walk around. Barcelona is quite a pretty city that is full of things to see. This is just one of such areas. I particularly enjoyed the "Concierto de Aranjuez" music excerpts from local street musicians in this area. Be aware of pickpockets though. A young lady with protruding belly (with a possible young female accomplice nearby) attempted to open the zipper of my bag while I was walking on a quiet, spacious area in broad day light within 5-10 minutes after I started walking to start my day. She walked very close to me despite of all the space that was available to us. I felt my bag was touched and I walked a lot faster and looked at her straight in the eyes, trying to indicate that I was aware of what was going on. She started getting farther away from me after that. Something similar happened to me again near the MNAC museum in the Montjuic area.

A very busy area. You need to be aware of yourself when you are in this part of town off the Ramblas. It is very crowded with tourists and locals. Plan your route ahead as walking around with a map is not ideal. The varied architecture is interesting and picturesque. Many museums, churches and attractions are in the area.
just stroll and look. old buildings built to join onto ancient ones with different architectural styles, narrow streets between and the wonderful garden in the Cathedral

Allow yourself to get lost!. It is a maze of beautiful squares, fabulous buildings, street performers and places to eat and drink. I am a solo female traveller and didn't feel uneasy wandering around - obviously you keep your wits about you, as it is pretty busy. It is very easy to get lost, and you might find yourself in the same square three times but arriving three different ways! Just enjoy the walk and sooner or later you will find a way out, you can't be in a hurry here.
love the maze of streets. It is a lovely area of Barcelona. Maze of streets with shops and cafes. Lovely old buildings, churches. Can easily spend a day walking around.

Eat your way through this area. We rented an apartment and loved the area . Not crowded in May. Lots of cool architecture , shops all in a short walk. Harbor nearby,with a great market in the harbor full of food ,local craftsmen,music. Go eat,drink.
Nice neighborhood. I loved getting lost in these streets. Such a quaint little part of town. Nice plazas and everything just made me enjoy it.
Wonderful interesting old streets and buildings. it was fascinating to explore these old narrow streets and be surprised by little squares and markets and performing street acts in the process.

Get the feel of cities before cars. We loved our afternoon in the Gothic quarter, walking to and from the Picasso museum and avoiding the crowds on La Rambla. There are interesting shops, from high-end to junk, as well as a wide choice of eateries. Although the commercial aspects are clearly 21st Century, it is easy to imagine life in a city before the industrial revolution as you wander the narrow streets where the height of the buildings is 10 times the width of the walkways.
Attempted mugging. Take care as you get closer to the water. A young man attempted to snatch a chain from my neck. The area becomes unsafe as you get nearer the water heading to the triumphal arch.

A wonderful place to get lost for a few hours. As a solo traveller I made my way to the Gothic Quarter by metro and spent 3 hours wandering around taking photos, listening to musicians and slowly making my way to Las Ramblas. It's a lovely safe walk for a solo traveller to do. There are coffee shops, restaurants on the way into the main tourist areas, you have to pay to go into the cathedral or museum otherwise just enjoy it from the outside.
Great variety. Antique shops, book shops and restaurants abound - a must when visiting Barcelona, If any of these are of interest then visit this area - situated to the east side of the Ramblas.

Well worth a day to explore. There are some superb little streets to explore in the Barri Gotic and here you'll find smaller and more unique shops to visit. There are also some small but excellent cafes and bars to try, without the hustle and bustle of the adjacent La Rambla. The Cathedral is well worth a visit and especially on a Saturday night, when the locals build the human towers and dance the local dance. A rather excellent area of the city and worth strolling up and down all the streets to find a hidden treasure

Must see! Take a whole afternoon!. This is a must see in Barcelona. There are hundreds of small shops, bars and cafes that are in the small and narrow streets. A paradise for shoppers! Take a map and don’t get lost!
The Heart of old Barcelona. Along with the now hip Born section, these winding, narrow streets hold most of what's fascinating about Barcelona, from boutiques to churches to restaurants.

Well worth a lengthy visit. We really enjoy walking around the Gothic Quarter. There are interesting museums, beautiful churches, and great architecture to tempt you to spend time in the area. We also found some delicious tapas while walking around.

Wander around and get lost. After doing the touristy things in Barcelona, this is a great area to walk at your own pace and take in the shops, restaurants and sights. Beautiful architecture and lots of places to stop and refuel with tapas or sangria or both.

Brilliant 2 hours. We had a very knowledgeable English speaking Guide, although from our group of 16, we were the only English. The guide wore a headset and we all had earpieces so everyone heard every word she said all the time. We saw other groups of 20 - 30 people with a guide who only about 3 or 4 of the party could hear what was being said.We found it fascinating and learned both about Barcelona history from the Romans to present day, and the Catalan political situation today. Not sure about them having a red rose and St. George as their patron saint. The 2 hours sped by, and everyone in the group was amazed when the time was up.
unique. I would go back and spend more time. There are churches, castles, museums and wonderful history there.

Lots of tiny streets and small shops. Try to go when all the shops are open, it looks a bit grey on Sunday afternoon.Queue to the Gaudi museum was horrendous.There are plenty of very nice cafes and small restaurants where you can stop for excellent tapas and cava.We did an hour walking trip around Barri Gotic which took us away from the tourist routes, it was interesting.

Sardana Dance. Stop by and see the Cathedral. It is free to see after 5 pm. On the weekends, around 6 pm, plant yourself on the steps outside the church to see the locals circle up and do the Sardana (the everyone's welcome dance).

Walk it. We liked this area and walked it extensively looking at the shops navigating the narrow streets and stopping to eat gelato, pasteries and people watch. We did not venture this area at night but I am sure the lights would add to its character.

Start your day early. There's so much to see.. We loved making our way through the maze of shops, cafes, alleyways and squares. We got a gorgeous city scene from a shop in Carrer de Petritxol. Enjoyed an outside seat at the Bar del Pi. Browsed numerous shops in and around the Placa de Sant Josep Oriol getting some wonderful souvenirs. Really loved some of the old-fashioned toy stores. Would recommend trying a suizo at any of the granjas along the Carrer Petrixol.
Best Part of barcelona. Brilliant. Do not miss this if you got to Barceona. The small passageways with little tapas bars and cheap beer!

Take a tour, good area to eat. A beautiful area. Many buildings here were actually transferred from other areas, in order to create this one. It's a large area and you can easily get lost in one of the tiny streets which mostly even don't appear in maps.I suggest you take a tour to get to know the area and here about it's wonderful origins and history. In addition, there are good places there to eat lunch - mostly though not on Plaza Reial.

Just a beautiful place. We stayed here for a couple of days in early May 2013. What a beautiful place. We loved it so much we can't wait to go back and stroll the quaint alleyways. It is hard to believe such a place still exists.

Take a guided tour!. We took a guided walking tour with the Runner Been Tours co. lasted for 2.5 hours. To get the most of the area it is best to go with a guide. The next days we came alone to see the other parts and to walk slowly through the narrow streets of the quarter. An information office is located in the government square and you can fetch a map.
Great neighborhood to explore. the atmosphere of this part of Barcelona is everything it's cracked up to be. So much fun to just wander around and explore.
Super. Very nice little streets. Very nice atmosphere. This is SO European and I loved IT. Perfect to sit on a terrasse and eat some tapas !

Must do on more then one day!. I'm staying in the el born area which is very close to Gotic. My fiends who are historians here took me on the most magical walk ever. This place is so filled with history all the way througj to modern times. There are also hidden gems of shops specializing in artisan trades from centuries ago with crafts and drinks Yiu can buy and try that they have been doing for centuries passed down Yiu can picture yourself in the times when mid evil princes and courtly women walked their pce grounds , imagine yourself carrying on as the people of the era did and envision the dark courses if humanity during the revolution andthe inquisition. Definitely a must. Please note that even with my friends walking me through streets I their childhood and ancestral locals I was still so confused as everything either goes around in circles or backs up back where Yiu started from to go in another direction. So fascinating.
Definitely worth seeing!. Definitely worth wandering around this area of Barcelona - so much history and generally very well preserved too.
map will help. we walked there during the day and at night. It is lively (with music, dance and other performers, weddings, etc) and not very big for a little stroll.
Enjoyable, but not on the must do list.. We didn't see much to distinguish it from areas right around the Ramblas. But then again, they are very close.

Day or night it is the place to visit in Barcelona. A visit to gothic is essential . It's what Barcelona is all about. Walk through the narrow alley ways . Find a nice cafe in one of many squares to sit outside , relax and watch the world drift by. The alley ways are reminiscent of Venice At times. The architecture is nice and its pretty safe and hassle free. Drinks and indeed snacks are not particularly expensive in comparison to other European cities. Please take a stroll in the evening, like all cities they always look there best after sunset and Barcelona is no exception .

Download the map of the walk route from the BCNshop. Go to the barcelonaturisme.com/Barcelona-Walking-Tours site and download their Gotic map. It is a bit of a fiddle to follow, but worth the effort of sticking to it, provided you have a guide book so you know what you are looking at. Of course you could just pay and go on the tour, but we did it the cheap way! When you are in Plaça del Rei, don't miss the Palau del Lloctinent, a 16th century Gothic structure that was home to the viceroy or lieutenant of the Catalan Parliament. Its beautiful courtyard is publicly accessible and you can look down on its lovely tiled roof when you go up on the roof of the cathedral.

Great place to spend an afternoon!. Walking around the gothic quarter is a great way to spend an afternoon. The small winding streets, the restaurants, the architecture, everything about this area is just so engrossing!
hippy heaven. fantastic place winding streets lots of ethnic style shops selling a variety of hand made and stunning goods. Take a walking tour with Runner Bean tours. They are great.

Atmospheric - but tourists, tourists and more tourists. So difficult to criticise a place for being too touristy when you are one, but would strongly recommend visiting during the winter. Even In May, we hardly heard a Spanish (or indeed Catalan) voice, and such a beautiful city deserves quiet contemplation - impossible in the crowds. Having said that, if you like hustle and bustle with your meanderings, the Gothic quarter has it all!
Old town. Wonderful early architecture with many photo ops, and by the cathedral we stumbled upon a group busking who were so good we bought the CD.
NICE AREA. Vey nice area of Barcelona, the only downside are the pickpockets and the dirtiness in some areas. Police should control a little bit more to avoid vandalism & small crime in the area.
European out door museum. It's like walking in a museum ;o) I can highly recomment a walk where you loose you way in all the old streets
For old time sake. You cannot but go back in romantic history, small alleys, historical places dating back to Roman times. the Cathedral is a must see.

You have to see this neighborhood. The old narrow streets and old buildings and church in this area are so charming. There are outdoor cafes in quaint little squares a great place to dine and relax and just enjoy the surroundings.

Amazing Architecture. Spent part the day here and was really amazed at the sites. You can complete a self-guided tour very easily. Walked here from Las Rambla hotel in about 15 minutes. No problems on the streets as there were many tourist during the day. Only regret is that I didn’t have more time to see more.
a warren of streets!. be prepared to get lost in the warren of streets of barri gotic! great little bars, restaurants and interesting shops.
amazing. When in Barcelona get off Las Ramblas and get lost in the rambling narrow streets here. Its a day trip in itself and great wee bars and tapas everywhere!

Wonderful shopping area. If you like to wander around old streets and find quaint, unique shops then this a great area for you. Lots of old things to see, including churches, walls, fountains, etc. Also, some of the best tapas restaurants are in this area.

great place for food, shopping, drinks. We spent quite a bit of time roaming through the Gotic quarter. It's very cool, lots of great little places to have a drink & tappas, but it can be quite confusing. The best piece of advice I can give is get the Trip Advisor City guide. Just using the GPS function saved us from getting lost (and it doesn't cost anything).

Lost in Barcelona. It's so easy to get hung up and lost in the Gothic Quarter streets. Take advantage of the cathedral and of the shops and cafes here. Enjoy it while you're here, plenty to do and easy to connect with other quarters without knowing it!
Captivating. You can spend hours walking around, viewing the sights, drinking and eating tapas. This area is very captivating.
Interesting walk-about. It was fun to travel around in the winding narrow streets. Found a couple good streets to shop on. Very clean.

Great place to stay!!. We stayed in this area and only had a few days in Barcelona and staying here you have everything within walking distance to get a feel of what Barcelona is about. You are also close to Placa Catalunya to catch the hop on hop off buses which I recommend and the famous La Rumbla. Thoroughly enjoyed our stay and wish we had another few days.
Great area with plentys bars and restraunts. Stayed in this area both times we have stayed in Barcelona - handy for everything. Lots of great bars and restraunts
Old town. Good for a wander around and maybe stop for coffee or a beer in a tiny bar. Many boutiques for shopaholics
a trip into history. A fantastic area to explore, narrow streets crammed full of shops, bars and historic gems such as the basilica and the cathedral you can not fail to be enchanted by this area.
I just love getting lost here. I just love the labyrinth of old alley ways to get lost in this section of town. it is a special place
Bars. There are some great bars in this area,we just kept going down side streets and seeing what was around the corner

So. Freaking. Cool. Feels like you are walking back in time when you wander through the narrow streets and passages. Great architecture, great little bars and cafes, fun little pieces of history. I would encourage you to try and get lost in the maze, it is super safe and absolutely captivating.
Gothic Neighborhood. This is a place taken from the pages of history. Super place to see and feel a sense of an area that has not changed over the years. Well worth the walk!
A great walk. There are several areas worth strolling through in Barcelona - particularly on a nice day. This is one of them. Allow at least 2 or 3 hours so you aren't hurried.
ok. Quit okey quarter close to ramblan. Some ok bars and tapas place but to many tourist around here, look for other areas

Excellent Walk. We just walked around, using a Frommers walking tour and our own eyes. The printed tour had several errors (turn right instead of left) but that just led to more discoveries. Unlike Naples, all the back alleys felt fun and inviting, and there were many interesting plazas, churches, monuments, etc. There is a cafe/bar almost every 10 feet, to stop for a snack or full meal. But, you will get last. Twice.
Great place to visit.. Beautiful buildings, nice shops. Was able to find some unique items in some of the quaint shops. Beware some of the touristy, over-priced shops. Worth visiting.

Narrow streets and many shops. This is a really nice place just to go walkabouts, it is full of countless narrow streets and unique shops for everyone. bring water or drink with you as the prices do increase around this area.
www.earthbounds.com
Very intresting.. A very different side to Barcelona and worth spending a couple of hours just ambling through. some great bars, cafes and dont forget to look up lots to see.

Nice bars and squares to sit and people watch. Make sure you visit during the daylight as we were warned by many locals not to visit after 9pm!! The Cathederal is worth a look and free to go inside. Nice bars and shops to visit.

Rich in history. We loved walking around the Gothic Quarter. It is rich in history and the architecture is very beautiful. You can either join a tour or just lose yourself in the area and embrace what it has to offer.
The cathedral is obviously a must visit. I am not a religious person but it was very moving.
nice place to visit. very nice place to go. let yourself get lost in these wonderful small streets full of "tienditas". lovely

Very interesting history. This place has quite the history. I think you will get the most out of it by going guided tour. Travel bound has a free guided tour and if you are lucky enough to get a tour guide named Chris you will have a great experience . Even if you go solo, it is a remarkable section of town .

Different. We got here by accident - and a good one at that! We were looking for Pizza which we found at Pizza Pazza (oh YUM!!) and then walked into this quarter to find a spot to eat - and it was an enjoyable stroll, noting the difference in architecture from the other streets and these streets are narrow (easy to get lost!) we ended up getting "out" at the port. Nice stroll.

The place to stay in Barcelona. We stayed in the Gothic Quarter for 10 nights, and it was a really interesting area full of charm, although a little intimidating looking at night due to tiny unlit streets with gothic architecture, although we initially felt a little concerned, there really was no reason to worry in this area (anymore then others, as Barcelona is the pickpocket capital of Europe as we can attest first hand). I would have been disappointed if I had stayed in any other area as this area is so unique and full of cool bars, restaurants and close to great shopping.

Towering Gothisism. So... when you hear, "Gothic quarter," you can't imagine what it feels like to be on these narrow cobblestone streets with these dark towing buildings enclosing you in a time warp. but then you see glass windows full of sparkling jewelry and bright signage for a charming cafe and the space drawing you into an art gallery.. and it's"wow"...this is coll. this is beautiful." The contrast of dark and with bright and new is so charming and beautiful.old and new
Worth seeing. Beautiful Cathedral, definitely stop by and have a look. Its free of charge unless you select a tour with travel agent, etc. See my pictures for more details
Interesting Architecture. My advice is wander and get yourself lost around these interesting alleys. Very atmospheric at night. Beautiful gothic architecture and cathedrals and its all free.
Interesting area. Miles of narrow streets to explore with interesting little shops and a huge array of back street restaurants and bars.

Stunning area. Gorgeous streets and alleyways, open squares where the Catalan people expressed their outrage about too many tourists in the city, and their love for their football team. Interesting shops, lots of restaurants, a surprise around every corner.

Really great place to wander around. Really great place to wander around. Plenty of hidden gems to be found if you meander off the beaten path, which I highly suggest. Good place to revisit when you've had enough of La Rambla's overly touristic vibe.
Quite interesting. With narrow dark steets and rather high buildings. Looks very historically) But I didn't like walking there alone.
Architecturally interesting. Unfortunately it was wet and dull, but this has lovely little streets and interesting buildings. Check out the cathedral Le Seu it took my breath away.
FANASTIC. it was raining when we arrived so our beginning was not impressive but once the sun came out we were plesantly surprised.........planning another trip in november

One of the most beautiful neighborhoods I've seen. There is tons to do and see in this labyrinth of a neighborhood. The architechture, sightseeing, shopping, food, people, sights, sounds, smells- it's utterly delightful! We wandered around for hours, each little alley cuter and more interesting than the last.

Wonderful old European streets for wandering. What a great place to wander! Narrow, winding, cobbled streets lined with picturesque shops and cafes. I recommend wandering freely (without stressing too much over directions) and allowing yourself to stop here and there for a coffee or tapas with a glass of sangria.

Lovely area, great boutiques. This area has improved a lot since I was there last (ages ago). Now, you see many lovely little boutiques, galleries and tiny bars. Has a great relaxed and trendy feel to it. It does get very busy though.

Every corner a historical or gastronomical treat!. I am not sure what I enjoyed more staying in this area. The buildings and history of Gothic corner were astonishing. I could not stop taking pictures. When I stopped taking pictures there was always somewhere to have a great glass of wine and some awesome food to relax and recover our energy! The Roman history and preserved Churches were amazing.

A must see. This part of Barcelona is the oldest and is full of old Gothic design houses ,lots of small shops and cafes to sit and people watch also. If you love the old curvy narrow streets you must visit this part of the city.

What an amazing mixture !. An eclectic mix of shops, museums and restaurants, and the hidden little streets are so worth a wander. Crowded but take your time.....handbag shops are out of this world!!!

Get lost in dark alleyways ... intriguing. We wandered round this area for a long time. You never know what is round the corner ..... it is an atmospheric and fascinating warren of alleyways, and squares.

Trouble in gothic quarter. I was the victim of an attempted mugging. I had a plain gold chain round my neck and a young man tried to snatch it. I resisted. ( not wise but it was an automatic reaction)As one gets closer to the water this area is not so safe, be warned.

Great place to stroll again and again. You can go here numerous times, as I did, since I stayed in a hotel in the Barri Gotic and you will see different things every time. Different people, different things happening all the time. Very lively place with historic buildings.

A wonderful walk. Around every corner appeared another placa or square, either filled with artisans or performers or boutiques. The architecture is simply stunning. And the size of the Gothic quarter is much larger than the old towns of most other European cities we gave visited. IT was like Paris without the attitude.
Stayed in the Gothic Quarter. Lovely old city, interesting little nooks and streets to explore.Everything in walking distance. Architecture awesome.
Wonderful place to get lost in. Come here both during the day AND at night - small streets and beautiful buildings that are great for a photo op!
Great area.. Loads of lovely shops and a variety of restaurants. Always busy but is really bustling after dark. Behind the streets are several squares which contain nice restaurants and bars.

Fantastic area. Just back from a short stay in Barcelona, the Gothic Quarter was our favourite area of the city with its multitude of little side streets and bars tucked away here and there.
Some good shopping to be had too!!

Synagogue. Visited the oldest synagogue in all Europe, just two rooms, barely excavated, but amazing to hear the history behind it all. Then walked through the Jewish quarter to see what had been a mikvah. It is now just a room at the back of a store, but walking through the old narrow streets helps one to imagine what it must have been line to live there

Neat Place. We loved the age of this place, its narrow alleyways and the myriad of bars and restaurants intermingled amongst them. Many say that is easy to get lost in the area, but we found Barcelona as a whole very easy to find your way around and this quarter is no exception, providing you keep a sense of direction as to where the Las Ramblas is. The streets are well sign posted and wandering around in here is fun and every street seems to hold a new surprise. The streets are very clean and the city does a great job in ensuring they stay that way.Do your best to explore.
Easy to get lost. Lots of winding streets and interesting little shops. Access off Las Ramblas or from the Hop On Hop Off bus
superb location. great place to visit and chill. even in april23 was full of ppl lively and bustling! must visit area of barcelona. really nice during day and at evening!
So much to see. This is a very concentrated area of gothic architecture. I went on a Runner Beans free walking tour of the area, It was a lot more fun and informative than wandering around on my own.

Beautiful and interesting part of Barcelona. Winding streets and beautiful little squares with outdoor cafes around every turn, characterized this neighborhood. Many restaurants and stores of every kind. Some very intereting churches dating back centuries, as well.

Really Enjoyed This Area of Barcelona. In my opinion, this is the best part of Barcelona. The atmosphere is really interesting and there are a lot of great places to eat, drink, and shop. As other reviewers noted, one could spend a couple of days roaming around the Barri Gotic making discoveries. I felt less safe on Las Ramblas than I did here. Just like Rome, you do need to be aware of the possibility of pickpockets and prepare for that before you go.

Great entertainment and people watching. Impressively broad main streets - mostly tree-lines, and kept remarkably free of litter, dog mess and graffiti - complement the large & impressive squares but contrast delightfully with the narrow lanes and the tall buildings that edge them. Plenty of shade here, but sunshine is seldom far away.Friendly locals and throngs of tourists combine to make this ancient area a great place for ambling, eating, drinking and people-watching. There are some incredible buildings here too and one can explore for hours - without spending a fortune.

Worth spending a few hours. Amazing place to just wander about! Very old world charm. Don't try and use a map, juSt wander about and you will love it. Musicians in the street and the old architecture is a must if in Barcelona.
Worth!. Gothic is the oldest part of the city. Must visit! Many places to eat. Also you can just sit somewhere on the branch. Besides, the entrance is free)
Amazing atmosphere. Great visit to the Gothic Quarter. The cathedral was beautiful, definitely worth a visit. The ambience in the quarter was great.

A step back in time by centuries. Wander around and drink in the atmosphere. The lanes are so narrow in places that the pavement is always in shade. A sunny day is best for the ramble. The Barri Gotic and Las Ramblas are among the most pickpocket rich areas in the world. To avoid having the miserable experience of being among the victims, take these simple precautions: Do not bring all of your important stuff--passport, credit cards, big money, etc. while you are walking around. What you will need is one credit card, enough money for the day out, and your camera. If you can, leave the rest in the hotel safe in your room. If you don't have an in-room safe, next best option is using an under-the-clothing money belt. Wear it so it doesn't show--some models hang from your belt, some have waist belts (i wear mine against the small of my back, tucked inside my pants). Second, be sensible about not being a target--assume that commotions are a smoke-screen for a team pickpocketing effort. If somebody tries to thrust something into your hands--a petition, some bit of tat for sale, etc, refuse to take it and walk on. Be discrete about using your camera--leaning back for a couple of minutes looking through the viewfinder waiting for the perfect shot is an invitation to pickpockets to bump into you and relieve you of the contents of your pockets. I don't want to discourage you from visiting the Barri Goitic, but only to take reasonable steps to keep from having a cultural experience that in retrospect you would be happy to skip.

What a home for a week!. We stayed in the Barri Gotic for our week stay in Barcelona and couldn’t have picked a better location. Having been to the city a couple of times before I knew the area but had not stayed there before.... we will again. 10 mins walk from all the main areas around the old town with good access to the metro system and the beach (Barceloneta). It seemed that every other front was a bar, eatery or boutique shop with some wonderful squares to catch some sun and watch locals and fellow tourists alike. Gotic and El Born just next door is full of an eclectic mix of dreadlocks, funky fashion labels and skateboards along with couples walking around with the Time Out guide in a spare hand during the day, easily turning into an area where you barely have to step out of your apartment to find an interesting bar or restaurant that will keep you wined and dined until the early hours. Keep an eye out for the odd innocuous shop front later on as some of the small take away places are well worth it and you can grab amazing Schawarma or falafel wraps.Our apartment was on Carrer De La Merce near the post office and would highly recommend the wait to grab an amazing sandwich for lunch at ‘Bo de’ which is on the corner of the street. It usually takes 20mins but is well worth it. ‘Sensi’ on C.Ample was our favourite place to eat during a week’s stay and eating all around the city so I would highly recommend booking for a meal. The staff all speak English so booking from the UK is easily done. To sum up, if you want to experience Barcelona away from the ridiculously busy main attractions and still have access to everything you need, I couldn’t think of a better area.
OK. Like a lot of Barcelona, the place is getting quite run down. The buildings in this area are very pretty, especially when you look at the ornate windows and roofs.

Turn a corner and there is a new and beautiful view. The history and the mystery of the lanes and architecture, the funky shops and the amazing food. We wanderered through Gothic for days finding a new discovery each day.

Wonderful to Wonder. Lovely part of Barcelona to wander around on a hot and sunny day. Be careful of your wallet and cameras etc as the streets are narrow and easy for pickpockets when bustling. Many lovely shops and restaurants in various places. Some streets are dedicated to antiques, art, jewellery etc but just taking it as it comes would be my suggestion. A must see part of Barcelona and free to all.
A place to wander... Nice to wander around the streets and view the buildings. We found a delicious tapas restaurant here too. Definitely worth a visit.
Very Interesting. Wonderful area, so many different types of buildings, fascinating to go and see. Only problem we had is that to cut our trip short there as it started to pour with rain.
A lovely sunny day walk. Walk through the core of medieval Barcelona, down narrow lanes, across tiny plazas and past some of the city's oldest and most imposing palaces and religious centres.

Wander around. By day it's fine to just wander and night seemed ok too. Nt sure if I was single female I would feel so relaxed
Loads of places to eat and drink and quirky shops and sudden views of Spanish town life

A must-see in Barcelona. If you don't visit any other parts of Barcelona, you must visit this one. The buildings and streets and hidden treasures (like the Roman ruins at the City History Museum) are not to be missed.

new europe tour. This was an excellent tour and our guide Jaun Carlos was lots of fun, interesting to listen to and passed on his genuine love of Barcelona to everyone in the group. I hope anyone visiting goes along to this tour to enjoy some history that would be lost amongst the shops and restaurants.

Barcelona's Masterpiece. We knew nothing of this area before visiting but loved its narrow streets, wonderful squares and markets as well as the huge rage of little bars, cafes and restaurants. Picked up some real bargains in the shops.

Our Barcelona Hangout. Little winding lanes, quaint shops, artisan shops, bars, restaurants, cathedral. Lovely architecture, we love to sit somewhere and drink a glass of cava or three and people watch. No other barri in Barcelona have the same atmosphere.

A must see. A beautiful part of the city. Very busy place but the restaurants way nicer & a lot more options. A lot of the restaurants you see in Barcelona have a lot of the same looking menu's ( believe me you'll know when you see them) but the ones with all written menu's & not pic menus are way nicer & believe it much cheaper. I would highly recommend ye visit the Gothic Quarter.

Best Place To Get Lost In Barcelona. Stunning area of Barcelona, I spent a few days wondering around these narrow streets finding all sorts of curiosities, great food and bars. You'll always emerge in an area of town you'll recognise, so getting around is no problem at all.I don't really find La Rambla all that interesting, but this lively and vibrant area will always show you something new. Highly Recommended!

Great area with lots of old buildings. A nice area to explore. Very narrow streets with small shops and old buildings.The market (La Boqueria) is a great place to see.Caution may be needed in regard to thieves (the only place I spotted a group of thieves).

Excellent architecture, dining and shopping.. Intriguing narrow streets loaded with small specialty shops and small cafes and restaurants of all sizes. Checkout Caellum, a cafe and pastry shop. Go down to the basement for a real treat. All of the pastries are made by nuns.

Placa Real for the evening. Great for dinner and some dancing afterwards, everything can be found on the place! Make reservations or you will have to queue to get a place. Also great place for afternoon coffee the terraces are in the sun.
Quaint Section of Barcelona. This is a fun and lively area of town with lots of shops and tapas bars. It was decorated for the holidays.

Lovely afternoon in the Gothic Quarter. Whether you just wander around to take in the fantastic architecture or eat/ drink at one of the many restaurants/ cafes - the gothic quarter is a must. And a better option of the chaos that is La Rambla!
Do a Walking Tour. Was great to learn about the Roman history era of Barcelona. I would do a walking tour as I learnt so much. Highly recommend.
Old town is always a must :). This is old town area of the Barcelona. It has many great museums, churches and architectural sights. Doesn't take a long time to visit if you are in a hurry!

Fun but disappointing shopping. An interesting old city that's fun to walk through. There are nice cafes, patisseries and chocolate shops. However, the shopping wasn't good and a street of antique dealers was disappointing with mostly junky stuff.

Beautiful. Discovered the oldest synagogue in Europe, absolutely amazing!
Had a very interesting narration of the history of the building, extremely welcoming.

Nice relaxing atmosphere. If you go to the Gothic Quarter go and see the cathedral, amazing building.
Nice to gently stroll around the buildings and small alleyways taking in the atmosphere.
Quite a few souvenir shops to buy from and a few nice restaurants to choose from.

Simply stunning!. What more can I say? What a brilliant place. Beautiful buildings round every corner. Loved all the little narrow alleys - though perhaps might not have wanted to walk round them at night.Would have liked more time to walk round but we only had a few days and had lots of things we wanted to see. We'll have to go back!
A must-see when in Barcelona. Narrow streets, tiny shops, bars and restaurants are tucked away in the compact old town of Barcelona. Here you can find Segway tours and fish foot massage.
Atmospheric. Wonderful buildings fabulous artistic independent shops. Lots of tapas, bars or geltos. Well worth wondering around just soaking it all in.

Good walking tour. Even though it was raining, this was a nice walking adventure. We visited the church (another one!) and checked out the buildings. Also found a really good Tapas restaurant that was yummy and had great service.
nice walk in an ancient city.. nice walk seeing lots of old town & streets. Shops are more "tourist souvenir-ish" which is fine w/ me. It links all the way to Catalunya.

Must see!. A lot to see here. Beautiful buildings. A lot of restaurants and shops. The open market is located in this area. You'll find fresh fruits; vegetables; meats; cheeses and wines. There are several restaurants in the market. The Gothic Quarter is very crowded but it must not be missed. Make sure to wear good walking shoes.
Just fabulous !. A warren of alleyways lead to all kinds of Tapas bars and shops with lovely Plaza's to sit and watch the world go by

A must see when in Barcelona. This is definitely the most charming and attractive area of Barcelona - narrow Medieval streets, peaceful hidden away plazas and a wealth of museums and churches to satisfy all your cultural needs. You can easily spend all day here. I love how there is a street artist playing an instrument around almost every corner, and there was a refreshing lack of tacky souvenirs, at least on the streets themselves.I didn´t spot a single public toilet though :/

A wonderful place to explore. My friend and I spent four days in Barcelona. Everyday, we randomly chose a street/alley to explore and happily got lost. There is so much to see: interesting architecture, cathedrals, tapas places, cafes, bakeries and all kinds of interesting shops. We never got bored! I would love to come back again...next time, will opt for a walking tour to learn more about the history of the area. On Sundays, many of the shops are closed but it is still fun to wander around and look for interesting photo ops. So put on a pair of good walking shoes and enjoy exploring this great area of Barcelona.

the rain probably made it better. We had to wonder through the streets and ally ways of the Gothic Quarter in the rain. That probably would have really spoiled the fun in many other cities, but it kind of added to the atmosphere there. When you think "gothic", does gloomy weather over stone walled passage ways not come to mind? Also, the rain probably scared off a lot of the crowds, which meant more room for us! So, not only is the architecture worth a visit in it's own right, there are so many different cute/cool little shops, pubs and restaurants hidden inside. I'm a person who prefers to sit inside with hot tea and movies when it rains. But, we walked there twice (from our not so close hotel) in the rain over the course of our poorly weathered, three day weekend visit to Barcelona. I will definitely visit again.

So fun - even in the rain. Arrived at Barri Gotic after touring Sagrada Familia. Easy to get to via metro. Began to rain so we ducked into a lovely bar--great cheese platter, Gin Tonics and staff. Loved it - just wish I could remember the name of the bar!

Enchanting area of Barcelona. We loved the Gothic area. Lots of tiny streets interlinking, containing tapas bars, restaurants, shops of many kinds. Don't forget to look up! You will see balconies with washing and flowers etc, great photo opportunities. Museums and squares tucked away, churches and old buildings around another corner. It was delightful, we stayed in Barcelona for three nights and went back every night. It wasn't too busy though when we went (April 13), at the height of the season it would be maybe not so nice - too many people.

A great feel of Barcelona. You sure would get a great feel of Barcelona here from ancient buildings palaces museums,u name it u get it,give yourself good time to walk around and explore,it's just an amazing sight with the narrow streets and the ancient buildings.
very interesting. Some awesome small tight streets, just look up and some of the work on the buildings are simply beautiful. Walk around for a few hours and be amazed !!
History at it's best. This whole city is just gorgeous! The Gothic Quarter is a must see for any aspiring architecture student or lover of history.
Great part of the City to base your stay. Great area to wander around both during the daytime and at night. Plenty of splendid places to eat. Narrow streets are relatively traffic free.

A must if you go to Barcelona.. The place is a must to visit if you go to Barcelona. Dont go on Sunday because a lot of shops close. Other than that, its a nice pplace to rooming around, have a nice paella and coffee at the street. :)

A day of wandering. The alleys of the Barri Gotic are amazing, full of little bars, restaurants, boutiques, jewellers, clothes shops, book shops, etc. It's easy to get lost in the maze of back alleys which lead to little squares, the Cathedral, the Dali Museum and Restaurant, you can spend a whole day wandering about, Great fun!
Narrow streets are really interesting. This neighborhood really give you the flavor of old Barcelona. Very busy with tourists as everywhere so far in this beautiful city.

great place to explore. Suggest an overall walking tour first, then really explore the "old city" There is the palace, several beautiful churches and other interesting buildings. Also there are the usual vendors, & small places to eat.

Just wander around. Our hotel (Arai 4* Monument) is in the Barri Gotic and so we did not have far to go to get here.Everything is very close and it is very easy to amble around this delightful section of Barcelona - with any number of restaurants/tapas bars and boutique type shops to browse in, plus of course several soaring churches interspersed with Roman building/remains.Take a leisurely stroll and enjoy a beer/coffee/gelato at one or more of the many cares etc.

Wander worthy. So much goodness here, restaurants, bars, boutiques, museums, historic churches, ruins and a breath taking street scape at every little turn. This was my favorite area to just wander, observe and enjoy the day away in. Buy a hat, a pair of shoes, eat gelato, get a cappuccino and walk some more. Beautifully enjoyable meander in gorgeous Barcelona.
Beautiful. Fantastic area to roam around. Don't be afraid to get a bit lost. And take the time to stop and have a glass of Cava or grab a Gelato.
Such a great place to go. Loads of little places to eat and drink. Lovely Cathedral in middle. Lots of little shops, great place to get lost for a few hours.
Put the map & guide away, and just stroll!. Just a great place for a relaxed stroll, sit in a square with a drink, look in the shops, soak in the atmosphere!

Great Location...Close to Everything!. Our hotel, pre-cruise was located here. There are great restaurants, beautiful churches, market places, and it's close to Las Ramblas. It is easy to walk to most sights, and the HO HO bus is very close.
good for wandering. Narrow lanes with individual shops (clothes, crafts etc) and restaurants. Lovely squares. You can spend hours walkng around the Barri Gotic.

Gothic Quarter of Barcelona. We started out with a map for a walking tour in this part of the city. Although we did stick with the map most of the times, I could also see tossing the map out and just exploring their charming area on your own. Definitely a not to be missed area for Barcelona.

Travel back in time in Barri Gotic. Meandering through the streets, every building is a delight for the senses. The Cathedral is a must-see! And the Tapas in any of the squares is perfect for people watching. Also recommend the Picasso Museum located here.

***A new experience around every corner...***. El Gotic is a fabulous part of Barcelona to wander around in. You'll find little alleyways and corners that are steeped in historical archietecture (gothic mixed with art nouveau), there's something new around every corner. There are eateries aplenty (with many locals eating here) so take advantage. A word of caution...with narrow streets and small alleyways, take care with fast moving traffic, otherwise GO...!!!!
Amazing. Amazing historical quarter with so much to see and experience. Many little alley ways and squares as well as so many places to eat and drink.
2 Thumbs up. The Gothic Quarter is a must see. I recommend grabbing tapas and sangria and interacting with the locals. The most beautiful portion of a wonderful city!

pretty and really nice shops!. My friend took me to the area known as the Gothic Quarter. I was not sure that we were there or not as i did not see any signs to indicate that we were there. I did not see any information anywhere about the area either and i think that would have been nice. It was a lovely area with narrow streets and tall buildings with pretty balconies. There were lots of great shops that were not expensive at all and the cathedral was there too. We stopped at a nice cafe in a courtyard for some drinks and snacks. We decided to go back on another day as we loved the area there.
Loved it. Loved strolling through this quarter of Barcelona. Bubo was a lovelypatissierie. The chocolate devine.
Not to be missed. Yes, this was a very interesting area. Lots to see and charming, individual shops. Felt the atmosphere and nice to see old balconies etc.

Prettiest part of the city. You can walk around on your own and see so much architecture. It was my favorite part of the city. Churches are free to walk around, large squares with great restaurants and cafes. So beautiful. Loved the buildings. The tiny streets were my favorite part. Just walk to get lost. So much to discover.

Wow, classic Spain at it's best!. Get your walking shoes on! It is truely amazing to walk the long narrow streets and feel the history while marveling at the buildings. Photos and ratings do no justice to actually being in the mix.

Beautiful Buildings. Loved the buildings loved walking down Las Rambalas, loved the history on the tour bus, loved the squares and the pubs and the lovely food. Barcelona FC that was great!!. Disliked the high prices we could of had a week half board for what it cost us in 3 days there

Get lost in the past. Close enough to find your way back to la Rambla, the busiest quarter of Barcelona, and yet you can lose yourself in the tiny streets almost 1000 years which twist back into themselves seemingly forever, offering spots of shade, brilliant courtyards with sunlight, churches, outdoor cafes, indoor taverns, tapas, shopping, Roman ruins. For the true Europhile History Buff.

a great place to get lost in. day and night this area is fabulous, good little shops selling all manners of items from clothes, gifts, furnishings, puppets, and food as well as lots of bars and cafesjust wandering about is great fun, as you never quite know whats roundb the cornerwe had to go back to find the shop selling ice sorbets of wierd flavours, including liquorise - on a stick.

A must visit!. So many of Barcelona's must see attractions are contained within the Gothic Quarter! Get yourself a detailed map of this area and La Rambles and you will not go wrong exploring all of the streets and attractions.

Delightful Walk. Just walking around this area and getting lost in the beauty of the surprising streets and shops is a wonderful way to see the city. Just walk and look up and you will find beauty and fun everywhere.

thoroughly enjoyable. A wonderful area to lose an afternoon just walking and exploring - we followed a 3 hour walk recommended by frommers - really worth while as there are so many little sqaures and churches to stumble across and lovelly cafes to enjoy a cold drink and watch the world go by.

Always Good For A Wander. Filled with interesting shops and bars/restaurants, the Barri Gotic is a must in Barcelona. The only downside is that it is always heaving with tourists, but worth a wander nonetheless :-)

Windey streets galore.. This was great to just wander through the buildings have so many unexpected things to them and we got quite lost! Lots of little plazas to sit and either grab a drink or just take in the view.
Brilliant!. You can't not like it, not to be missed! New vistas around every turn. Watch out for cyclists and skateboarders!
Awesome. Incredible atmosphere, worth checking out? Gets very busy over weekends though so beware pickpockets
Old town. Barcelona old town where Picasso and Joan Miro used to live and work. Magical old buildings and cathedral clashing with modern neighbourhood. Must see.

Falling in love with Barcelona.. Forget spending time on Las Ramblas. Do yourself a favour and turn left as you walk down Las Ramblas and get lost in the quaint and interesting streets of the Gothic Quarter. There are interesting shops and restaurants at every turn. Getting lost is part of its charm. Just follow the streets and you will eventually end up in a sunny square somewhere in the middle of Barcelona.

Atmospheric.. We strolled around this area just before sunset. The architecture was intricate and stunning. The spires and gargoyles were so full of details. It was a quieter time to visit as we were after the main rush of the day. The Cathedral was beautiful and we took the rickety lift the the Cathedral roof. There was hardly anyone up there as we wandered around on the scaffolding path. I dont think we would have been able to do that in the UK. The views were exceptional and we took some amazing photos of all the sights we had seen during the two previous days. We were lucky because the sun had burnt off the haze which had been around earlier in the day.

Famous Area In The City Center Of Barcelona. Visit the Gothic Quarter in Barcelona (Barrio Gotico) and enjoy all the interesting sights like the Cathedral, the many shops and tapas bars or cocktail lounges. You need good footwear to make it all and then head to the Ramblas which is close by. O good choice is Mam i Teca, its not crowded and very cozy with Catalan specialties and great wines and spirits.
Get lost walking the Gothic Quarter. Wonderful area to walk around in and get lost. Look at the stones used to build the walls, meander through the various streets. Very old world
Lovely and quaint. Interesting little shops, winding streets, bars and restaurants - my favourite area of Barcelona, and in the centre the Placa Reial - lively and fun!
Great atmosphere. A great place just to wander around. Very atmospheric, especially at night when the lamps are lit. Some good little bars as well

Very atmospheric. What a beautiful area. Around every corner, you'll find something historic to discover. Great little shops as well, in both fashion, souvenirs and candy. We enjoyed our sangria on one of the squares, getting the total holiday feel.

new europe tours. Dear tourists (like me), use the new europe tours for such locations- (our guide Faser was really a good deal), he shared his positive energy and his knowledge :))) of this location and made everything so meaningful , he drew historic pictures in front of us ...and made us laugh , without him the Gothic quarter would have been full of tall buildings, narrow streets, churches, squares...thank you, FRASER and Graem:)

Very Tipical. The "Barrio Gotico" (Gothic Quarter) is one of the oldest Quarters in Barcelona.It is a quite big area running from plaza Catalunya down to the sea, and from la Rambla to Via Laietana.***LIKESA lot of history of Barcelona is found in this Quarter, with special attention to be drawn on the big Gothic Cathedral, very tipical, FREE to visit and very striking to visit.Also a lot of narrow little streets that intersect one another several times inside the same Quarter, at times making you feel lost but always bringing you to some nice and populated area where some people are most probably having a beer by the street and talking (or SHOUTING) to each other!Last but not least there are a lot of bars where you can have nice tapas, beers, cocktails of very nice quality for a usually relatively cheap price.***DISLIKESSometimes the streets are too much polulated, and for this reason, specially at night, a lot of foreigns tendo to pee and vomit in the streets like if they were not in the street.Although the Barcelona road cleaning service is very efficient, you can easily find yourself in the middle of a horrible smell, and you don't know how long will it still last for.As well this Quarter can be very dangerous when it comes to pickpockets.It is a fantastic place for them to rob people. My advise is not to apporach and embrace or have physical contact with Moroccan or similar race people, as 99% of pickpokets are from those areas.Obviously I am not saying that all of them are, but just be carefull with those you don't really know.As well in this Quarter there is not a proper market like in other Barcelona quarters, as well as the supermarkets are not always very close to your location.
