A Real Gem. We stumbled on this area by accident & went back for a second look. It was like going back in time. So quaint. Don't miss it.

Wonderful area to wander around and soak in the atmosphere.. We love traditional jazz and there was actually a group playing dixieland . They were pushing a piano down the narrow streets and busking, great. Great little places to sit and enjoy an expresso and "people watch". Don't forget to use common sense and keep an eye on your belongings.

Traditional old city. The Gothic quarter is a traditional old city quarter which takes you back several decades. It is very beatiful to wander in the side streets, away from the cars, the traffic and the noise. It is always full of tourists. There are many small places to get somethign to eat and drink. It would be exceptional if there wasn't the bad smell near the sewages... I really hated that and it's almost everywhere in Barcelona!
nice to see. It is a great work of Goudi so it is worth a visit. not a must but nice.The view from the roof great.
Wonderful. Great fun to wander and simply admire the buildings, architecture, placas - surprises around every corner.
Beatiful gothic area. What a beatiful area .Some very quaint little shops, some very unique.My favourite shop was 2 Bis, it was exquisit.You must visit.
Take a deep breath. Ignore the hotels and modern skyscrapers and just chill and admire stunning architecture. It does help of course when the sun is shining and it's a glorious day
Historical, well kept area of Barcelona.. Narrow, old streets with old buildings, interesting modern shops and lots of plazas to rest and do people watching.

Nice and well restored. absolutely to recomend.. extraordianry area of the city, with lots of ancient remainings. From the romans to the midle ages. Very in contrast with the modern areas and buildings of Barcelona.

Incredible. This was such a nice place to stroll down after a long day of site seeing. It's very relaxing but still has so much to take in visually. I highly recommend visiting even if you can only spend a short amount of time here.

One of those quaint places you get lost in.. I'm usually a fan of places with grid-system streets, mainly because it's easier to navigate so I don't miss anything, but the charming Gothic Quarter is the exception. What I like most about the narrow, winding alleys is that you can approach a plaza or an intersection from a different lane and it WILL look completely different from that angle. You got to spend at least 3 to 4 hours wandering in this atmospheric district.
Hidden gem next to the Rambla. Beautiful small streets with so many bars, restaurants and small shops. This is the place to visit, when in Barcelona.

Lose yourself here. The whole area known as the Barri Gotic is worth making time to visit. There is a maze of small streets filled with shops, cafes, bars, churches and museums and you can spend days wandering around and constantly find new places. There are numerous squares, some small, some large and most will have one or more cafes or restaurants which are generally much better value than those found on the Ramblas and a lot quieter too!
Atmospheric and charming. It was good to walk around here, unhassled and feeling quite safe. On a hot day there was plenty of deep cool shade and lots of individual shops and bars to explore

So cool. If you travel to Barcelona, make sure to spend time getting lost and exploring the Barri Gotic. The twisty streets are charming and sprinkled with a fascinating array of caves, churches, restaurants, shops and galleries. Be sure to carry a good map, because it is easy to get turned around, but if you revisit a couple of times, you'll get your bearings. Don't miss the Picasso Museum! This was our favorite area of Barcelona.

A walk worth taking. Wonderful little alleyways to discover by foot, great boutiques and restaurants. Our hotel was in the gothic part near the Cathedrale, and we spent hours just on our own looking at the architecture and discovered countless bars, restaurants and boutiques.

Great little cafes, narrow lanes, old buildings. Impressive Cathedral and museums, good eating and drinking, plenty of rubbish though. One of our cafe proprietors took car to point out who the pick pockets were!

Wander off La Rambla to explore. We saved the el Gotic for our last day in Barcelona and it was perfect. It was much quieter and more intimate than the area around La Rambla and some of the Plazas, but still quite busy. The streets are beautiful, with some nice restaurants to check out, an amazing cathedral, and old fort walls and gate. This area was such a pleasant surprise for us and a must to check out as it is so close to the center.
Quiet at night. we stumbled on the Gothic Quarter , it was past 6pm and it was very quiet and nealy deserted.Worth the look if you are not familiar with Medieval archtecture
Wonderful walk...great outdoor cafe's. Interesting little shops, fresh flower vendors and beautiful architecture. Nothing to dislike or change about this venue.

Pleasant. Very nice to wander around but not really interesting and not a lot of information provided. But the musicians etc add to the atmosphere and it is a pleasant half day. Take a very good detailed map as it's easy to get lost or miss things although if you do you'll inevitably stray on to a main road sooner or later.
Barcelona at it's best. Great atmosphere. Even after 4 days we hadn't seen everything. Small streets, shady squares and great terraces.
Great to wander around. Liked the historic buildings, shops and bars spent a couple of hours having lunch and the soaking up the atmosphere
A must see!. Walk all day and discover the old part of the city, free from cars and with lots of quirky shops, cafes, and bars
A MUST PLACE IN BARCELONA. A very beautiful place for traveling around, shopping and bars. Likked everything hate that I did not have more time to spend there
History Abounds. Spend the time here it is worth it. Great buildings, lots of activity and peole. Some Roman remains as well.

Gothic. I think this was my favorite place in Barcelona. We enjoyed getting away from the touristy Ramblas and winding our way through time in the Bari Gotic. We like getting off the beaten path, and tried to eat somewhere without hoards of tourists. We found Tacon Rojo and loved it! The jamon was incredible, the tomato bread was really flavorful and the service was perfect!

Great pic opportunities. Some wild and wonderful architecture, including Gaudi of course. A great place to wander around, although the cafés leave quite a lot to desire in their attitudes and attention to clients.
Ole Espana. The gothic tour takes you to some nice plazas, the Roman wall and a beatiful cathedral. The narrow streets are charming during the day but seedy at night.
A must see. The city has many faces and this quarter is worth exploring. If you plan your route right you can spend some time amongst the history before popping out at La Rambla to do some shopping.
interesting area, lots to look at. Lots to look at, wonderful little streets to explore, on every corner there seems to be a wonderful piece of architecture or design amid the ordinary
great to wander round. Did a self walking tour that I found on the web...lots of hidden gems in the narrow streets- courtyards, roman columns etc..

So much to explore!. I stayed in the Gothic Quarter a week and loved exploring all the little streets and squares and was in awe of the amazing buildings. Wandering through this area is a great way to see how modern life goes on within the ancient buildings. You'll see interesting shops, art galleries, small restaurants and surprising contemporary street sculptures. Slow down and take the time to really look at the detail on all the buildings, the windows, gargoyles, balconies. I didn't know where to aim my camera as there was so much I wanted to capture. Get off the crowded touristy Rambla and into the much more interesting and unique Gothic Quarter.
Unusual and beautiful. Good shops with cheaper ouvenier shops.Go during day time and busy times as t nighttime it may not beas safe
Bus Tourista Red Tour of city. The architecture was spectacular, the cafes and restaurants were very welcoming and even the traffic flowed quite well!

Freak in the begining. After sunset, Ghotic Quarte is full of old buildings and narrow streets. My first feeling was of get lost and afraid of violence. But I am glad that I was wrong!Elderly couples walking late night, plenty of restaurants and I felt like in a movie.

Lots of athmosphere. Narrow streets and alleys, beautiful squares, surprising courtyards. It's enjoyable just to take a walk in this area. Also don't forget to look up at the cast iron balconies with flowers. Many cute stores and tiny restaurants. We were warned before going of pickpockets, but didn't find this any scarier than many other European cities, especially during the day.

must visit in Barcelona. must visit in Barcelona
Time had stopped at a time you feel like you are walking past
Turn yourself half a day and stroll the alleys special
Great area to explore. This is a definite must for anyone visiting Barcelona. The architecture is amazing and little shops and restaurants abound. Take a map as it is easy to get turned around.

Great area, but watch your wallet. You can feel the centuries passing. Great shopping area. We wondered about an entered the Cathedral which was built during different times and which you can see by the layers of different stone/brick. Be sure to cover dress appropriately for a cathedral or you cannot get in. Shoulders covered, knee length attire, covered shoes.
bit creepy but charming. Old part of the city has a kind of charm. A part from drunk and drug addicted people its nice. Because of the heat it often smells in the streets.

So atmospheric and quite beautiful. Wander along small alley ways and soak up the atmosphere. Pop into one of the dozens of eateries for a snack or lovely little boutiques to pick up a souvenir. The architecture will amaze you: beautiful stone carvings; beautiful tiles; the odd fountain. And so much history. Not to be missed!

Take a Stroll. We spent several hours walking around the Gotico quarter and Ciutat Vella ( old town) which are all in the same area. You almost feel like you have traveled through time with the small narrow streets that wind around the main Cathedral. Little shops and tiny restaurants everywhere. Very charming. From here you can easily connect to Las Ramblas or the Port area.

Walk around and see.... You have to lose yourself in the narrow streets, without a guide, without a plan. Just enjoy the architecture and the lovely shops, some of them really unique in their design. Time really doesn't matter in the Gothic Quarter (Barri Gotic). Enjoy!!
gothic delights. really interesting area to walk around, lots to see and do, great atmosphere. be mindful of pickpockets this is a really busy area
Pretty area. Very pretty area. Just wish I could have checked out some of the shops and seen it at night. Barcelona is a very walkable city and it is close to Los Ramblas.

Romantic evenings. Wander around in the eve and you will come across buskers playing beautiful spanish guitar in small squares or on the steps of ancient buildings. The sounds bouce off the small alleys and it's just beautiful to sit and listen for a while.

Very interesting and romantic!!!. Narrow streets, romantic atmosphere, spanish cafes and small shops! I felt like I was in the ancient times! It is really very interesting to walk there and to explore the culture.
Beautiful. Great little back alleys with small shops and lovely tapas bars - seemed to be less crowded then the other side of the Ramblas.
Charming streets to walk. Gothic area is quieter and has narrow streets. Very interesting. A few musicians played guitar and sang. The architecture of the buildings is wonderful.
beautiful old town. narrow streets, atmospheric, great pleasure getting temporarily lost. I love to see neighborhoods where people live and work.

My favorite part of Barcelona. Without a doubt, whenever I am in Barcelona the most enjoyment I have is walking the quaint narrow streets of the Barri Gotic. If I were to live in this city, it would be somewhere charming in this area. I love exploring all the ins and outs, having a glass of cava in a cafe in any of the open plazas you stumble upon, and seeing all the unique shops. I always find either some super cool clothes or accessories I wouldn't see anywhere else. There are so many fine restaurants to choose from as well. The Picasso Museum is wonderful and there was another one close by showing Miro's work as well. To me, this is Barcelona.
sunday dancing. Don't miss the dancing in front of the cathedral, it is a wonderful experience and a great way to begin your exploration of the area.

Old Barcelona. This is a taste of old Barcelona - nice contrast with modern part of the city. Get a tour book before visiting to read about the attractions in the area or just walk around and enjoy old city.
The old city and narrow streets. Best seen with a guide or with a walking tour like Rick Steves. Lots of interesting buildings and many shops and restaurants.

Must see but beware the crowds. The gothic quarter was great to see but sometimes it wa difficult to get around due to the crowds.All in all, definitely worth seeing. The little alleys and stone streets gave the place a great atmosphere and every now and then we would stumble across some beautiful old buildings

I live here and love it!. I'm an American who has lived in the Barri Gotic from before the Olympics at which time the area, like the entire city, got cleaned up. Never a day goes by that I don't feel thankful for the opportunity to live in this funky, cosmopolitan, richly historical neighborhood. Things are always changing, but my favorite bar/cafe haunts for now are those around Plaza Traginers - Babel, Can Fly, Tres Flores and Andu. On Saturdays artists have permission to paint and display their paintings in the plaza, which sits in front of the old Roman Wall; it's a super lively and fun place to hang out, away from traffic. Babel and Can Fly and the fine restaurant El Salon all have seating in the plaza and there are usually some very good buskers around, too. Very near is the excellent restaurant L'Antic Bocoi del Gotic (reservations may be necessary). The only way to see the barrio is to walk - so forget a bicycle or a Segway. The beauty of the medieval buidlings is in the detail and you must walk to take it all in. Find a good guidebook and you're on your way. And if you're an art collector or simply appreciate local art, by all means don't miss the Sat. art fair at Traginers.

So fun to explore, a lovely place to walk around. I loved wandering through these little back streets of Barcelona. One, they provide shade from the sun, making it a little cooler (life saving!) but also it gives you a taste of the real Barcelona. Slightly quieter than the ramblas, we enjoyed going in little meat shops and fining small gardens and squares hidden away. A true gem.

I could live here...... winding narrow alleyways fabulous boutiques and quaint cofffee shopts. Utterly enjoyable. Sometimes crowded. Great funky fashion, often expensive. I could walk around here for days.

Loved this area. Loved wandering the narrow streets and seeing all the historic buildings. We spent a lot of time just walking around. Wish that the signage for the Picasso Museum was better so we could have toured this.

Loved the area. This neighborhood made me fall in love with Barcelona. Lots of cute shops and restaurants and I absolutely loved all of the architecture. It was hard to navigate at first but finally got the hang of it. We never felt unsafe here and walked around at night. We stayed on Las Ramblas so we went here a lot. The narrow winding streets really bring you back in time.

An ancient area of the city. Amazing buildings and side streets. Unless you are a young adult, avoid the late night as it's very noisy. Since there are so many young people who spend most of the night, just hanging out, they just use the nearest alley or sidestreet to urinate. And by morning it smells and looks like it. Definitely not a sanitary situation.

Gothic Quarter do not miss this slice of history. We stayed there Sept 2012. We actually had an apartment with a balcony, during our one week stay at gothic quarter. I can assure fellow travellers that we both felt safe. Locals were very friendly, and said hola whenever they saw us. Half the fun of the area is the getting lost. There are Gaudi sights in many of the squares. Look up to the sky to see his chimneys. Look out for the Secret Square. Cant tell you where this as we feel across it by chance. It is the site where many children were killed by a bomb. You can still see the damage on the walls. George Orwell Square is a great watering hole. We much prefered the narrow roads to the Rambla. Being so close to all human life certainly made our holiday. Once again felt very safe even at night.

Explore the Maze of Gothic Quarter. We just loved this part of town, the old Gothic Quarter.While we are on holidays we prefer to explore and get lost amongst the streets of a city and find suprises around every corner! Most of our time in Barcelona we spent here, either finding a new tapas bar for lunch, a quirky small bar to have a few drinks, a bit of shopping to find that special something or start off with dinner then bar hop from one end of the quarter to the other and enjoy the nightlife!I must say if you do not like walking for long periods of time then make sure to take a map and highlight your start and end otherwise you DO get lost. For us, this is part of the whole experience.....just don't do it while you are hungry and tired.There are many Placa's in the Gothic quarter and some you will find their own style and options of food and bars to relax at.Yes, at times you will feel like it is a dodgy part of town but it is the character of the Gothic Quarter so take it all in.I would say you need to look out more for pick pocketers on busy Las Ramblas more than anything.Enjoy and take it all in!

A great experience, thoroughly enjoyed exploring this area.. We walked through the various lanes and narrow streets. Lots to see, amazing little shops, bars, cafes. The streets are washed down every night so it is very clean. There is a lot of graffiti, however most of it is quite artistic. We found the quality of the food to be very good and the prices were reasonable . Barcelona is a great place to visit, especially do not miss this area.

Wonderful Old World Charm. We loved walking through the Gothic Quarter and on many occasions classical musicians were sitting in various places playing wonderful music. The high walls and narrow pathways provided a haunting sound to the music. You never were bored with the walkways and found numerous little shops and cafe's along the way. The area around the Cathedral is a must do. If visiting the cathedral, make sure you dress appropriately. Also, check the hours for mass because visitation will be limited.

Historical section. Nice section of town. Lots of history, monuments, churches, and tourist shops. The best was I know to see this area with NO touristy shopping hype is to do a Runner Bean walking tour.

Quaint local area. This area is near the Ramblas and well worth a visit. Nice little shops, beautiful squares and some nice buildings, churches, statues, etc. There are quite a lot of tourist places as well, which makes for nice shopping for souvenirs. We had some delicious tapas to eat near the Cathedral for an acceptable price. Definitely recommendable.

Loved this part of Barcelona!. I loved walking the small lanes of the Barri Gotic, we discovered new little shops and restaurants every time. At first we did a self guided walking tour with a Rick Steves guidebook and then went off on our own. Now in retrospect, I think that we should have done one of the guided tours of this area, because It is so easy to miss something. I loved this area more than Gracia.

Winding lanes, quaint shops, oldest synagogue. Loved wandering through areas not realizing what was down the next lane way. Came across street performers who were amazing. Found a very old synagogue which was discovered not that long ago and the story behind its discovery was very interesting.
The Joy of Wandering Here. The largest Gothic Quarter in all of Europe. Nothing else needs to be said to the lovers of Old World scenes and experiences.

A walk into the past. Walking through Barri Gotic was enjoyable and a very special way to end the day. La Seu Cathedral, named after Barcelona's patron saint Eulalia was stunning, and glistened in the setting sun.

Gothic quarter. Everyone should walk up and down the streets.....amazing what you can find. You just have to look at some of the old buildings and you will be amazed. Also follow the old Roman ruins around the area.

our favorite part of the city. the restaurants were great, the Catedral was fabulous. You have to pay to go through the abbey and garden but it was very worth the price (6 euros each). We went to a Spanish guitar recital in the chapel of the Catedral and loved it. We also bought ceramics in the Gothic Quarter and had them shipped home.

Lovely lanes. Fabulous, throw away the map and get lost in these lane ways and streets. Find a great place to eat, discover a unique cultural experience, buy a piece of handmade Spanish craft to take home
The most beautiful part of the city center. Even my impatient 13 old son loved the narrow streets and the wide plazas.... we spent a few hours there.
atmospheric. This area is a must visit, it has a lovely atmosphere and you can wander around it for ages, its a good place to linger and is full of interesting characters.

Interesting but noisy. I would recommend staying in the Gothic Quarter for a very short visit (2-3 days) but not longer. It is full of tourists and can be very noisy. Choose your accommodation carefully. For longer visits, I would seek out the Gracia neighbourhood of Barclona, with easy access to Park Güell and up-and-coming restaurants.

Great for an afternoon of exploring.. Lots of nifty little shops & places to eat. The streets are windy & crooked & narrow, and you really get a feel for a little of what it might have been like to live in the Barcelona of old.

Ancient Architecture. The buildings are just fantastic, with something new at every corner. You walk from narrow alleyways into large open squares which at the time of our visit were set up with stages for live entertainment, as it was the festival of Merce. They all lead to the stunning Cathedral.

So fun and interesting to walk around.. Every corner or street is an adventure. Lots to see and took many pictures. Fun little cafes, a great wine store and deli that we discovered. So much history! Don't miss this part of Barcelona!
like all gotic quartiers in europe. clean and nice, but nothing special if you have seen others...some nice restaurants and good pastries, gelatos, and of course, plenty of souvenir shops.

Get lost in Barri Gotic. Very fascinating old city with churches, restaurants, bars and boutiques. It is easy to get lost, but luckily it's surrounded with big streets so you will eventually find where you are. A must when you go to Barcelona. Placa Reial in a very lively square and nice place to have a drink. Cathedral in huge and gives a good view from the roof. Santa Maria del Mar is my favourite church there.
Traditional Area. A great are of Barcelona, lots of little lanes containing bars, tapas bars, restaurants and shops. Could spend ages just walking around.

Travel through time.... Walking there is like travelling to the past..Fantastic buildings,small and nice shops,cafes and restaurants and lots of museums(picasso,chocolate ,disseny hub,barbier-mueller etc).Usually overcrowded.A must for every visitor
So quirky. Loved walking around and occasionally sitting down in, or outside, one of the many, many bars. So much to see and take in.

Fascinating.... Amazing history...amazing architecture...you'd be hard pressed to find a place that is standing exactly as it was centuries ago...this is a must see if you're in Barcelona...My wife and I took a bike tour "Fat Tire Bike Tours" and it was brilliant. Great, relevant, informative, and a fantastic relaxing bike ride all at the same time. Wish I could do the tour again. I totally recommend the tour...and Barri Gotic
A perfect afternoon stroll. This is a very eclectic, laid back neighborhood, cafes at every corner with the winding happy to get lost in alleys. Picasso’s museum is the highlight in this district..

Historically beautiful and very unique. This is a fascinating area of Barcelona that shouldn't be missed. I would recommend spending all your time here exploring the sights, architecture, unique shops and great food/night life. Great place to stay in the city that's close to the beach and Gaudi's works via the metro.

A walk through history. We took a Free Walking Tour that met under the Columbus statue, I had heard how dangerous this area could be so I was thankful to have a knowledgeable guide. He was quite informative and he works for tips. It is a pleasant way to walk through the history of the old part of the city.

Almost a hidden gem. If you visit the cathedral (and you should) then you are in the Gothic Quarter of Barcelona. The narrow streets house some interesting shops nestling along with the usual tourist ones. We were there to see the Picasso museum, which is in the area. Although there are none of the major works (those are in museums with larger bank balances), there is plenty to see of his early works from when he was a child painting on small wood panels and canvases. There is also a very good collection of his pottery and of course a whole series of paintings that he did based on Velazquez "Las Meninas" which give you an insight into the way he developed ideas and themes.
Interesting. Quaint area with lots of meandering streets, you could spend a good day here just people watching and checking out the shops and architecture

Must see. Must see district if you like little shops and bars. Like in other big city's, there are a lot of night shops, but if you look true that, you can see the local shops, restaurants and gallery's.

Barri Gothic. Nice narrow streets with lots of shops that sell unique things. The streets could be tricky and pickpockets loom large, but non threatening. They just capitalize on carelessness. Try out the Barri Gothic it's worth it

Interesting to know about Barcelona history. I enjoyed walking on the narrow streets and admiring the old style architecture of the buildings.The jewish district worths visiting it.The cathedral is really beautiful.

Cool little quarter. Fun to check out if you have the time. We enjoyed wandering the streets for a few hours one day. We didn't enjoy the picasso museum. It's missing a lot of his better work...blue period selection really slim pickings

The perfect little neighbourhood. Such a well maintained area, many unique boutique style shops and fun little restaurants and bars. Seemed very safe but apparently they have a thief problem, Id say as long as you don't walk around with your bag half open and like any place, are wise about your money, no one will bother you.

Nice neighbourhood. Nice to stroll in the little streets of the Barri Gothic. The colour locale and the little shops are interesting to look at. Look to the right and the left and take an unusual little street.

Get a map. A great area to wander, unique shops and restaurants. If you like history and architecture this is the place. A map is necessary as street names are only posted on the sides of buildings and we found that some building numbers were missing.
old city. Nice narrow and old streets. many nice shops and restorances.there are good guided tours around.interesting Jewish quater.

Amazing. What a marvelous place to walk around and view history of this era. The gothic quarter is so well preserved and viewing the details up close and personal is all better. Well worth the time and energy to walk around.

beautiful cathedral. A gorgeous cathedral in a very interesting area of Gothic architeture. They do charge to go into the church so be prepared to pay 6 Euros. Also some nice restuarants out in front for a great lunch at the hotel.
Get lost in the Barri Gotic. We got thoroughly lost trying to find the Picasso Museum, but loved the quaint character and architecture. Good shopping but trust me the locals don't shop here.
Old European Area. Get lost in the winding towering back streets of the Gothic Quarter - a must to really experience an historical European city.

One great square after another. We used the Michelin walking tour and it helps to have a little structure to your trip. The cathedral is well documented (including some English) and they provide a map. It is well worth the visit for the great choir, crypt, and the gaggle of geese that have been here for centuries. The rest of the quarter has English signs and tons of atmosphere as well as excellent musician buskers to entertain you. Consider taking the elevator up to the top of the cathedral (about 2.5 Euros beyond the admission price to the cathedral). The view of the old town and some Barcelona towers is very good. Beware: restrooms are few and far between (find them in the cloister of the cathedral but without running water.)

See the old among the new. Took a "walking tour" of the Gothic Quarter. It was very informative and gave us an insight into what Barcelona is all about. Went back several times to visit the local shops, which are fantastic.

Shops galore !!. Excellent area for strolling and window shopping.
Very large variety of speciality shops and cafes.
Within an easy walk of Las Ramblas, too.

great place to hang out on a sunday and visit a great bakery and have a ice cream. a lovely venue to visit on a sunday.lots of bakeries,shops,ice cream parlors,street performers.the true beauty lies in the amazing architecture.very short walk from catalunya square.
Lots of well preserved buildings. Catherdral of Barcelona is one of the buildings in this area. Lots of small streets and passages to walk around to enjoy this style.
beautiful. A must see while you're in Barcelona. I would suggest the City tour bus to give you an opportunity to get on and off

The name says it all. This is exactly what I pictured of Spain. The winding, narrow, cobblestone streets, and restaurants buried deep in to the quarter. Do spend some time wandering around...We found a flamenco show here our first night and spent our last night at a great little restaurant, L'Antic Bocoi del Gotic. Very eclectic, romantic, mysterious neighborhood. Would not miss it!

Great sight seeing. I'm glad we didn't stay there. It is loaded with tourists. Many of the alley ways are dark and most are narrow. There's some great sight seeing, but if you want a good night's sleep, stay somewhere else!
Dont use a map.... Just wander around and enjoy yourself. Lots of neat places to see and eat. We stoppped at an outdoor coffee shop a just people watched.
Lovely little streets. As the title says lovely little streets to wander around and get lost ! Lots of little shops and cafes great way to spend a couple of ours.
Great shopping. Steer clear of the chains (H&M, Zaram etc.) and check out the wonderful boutiques in this maze-like quarter. You'll find stuff that you won't find anywhere else.
Take a walk. Alleyways, ancient streets, cathedrals, galleries, an ancient roman aquaduct, street musicians, restaurants... I could go on and on... just visit!

Truly Spain. Lovely place to just walk around and explore the lane ways, that lead to great Spanish squares with lively musicians. I really recommend doing some night exploring the Gothic Quarter has a completely different vibe. The tourists are gone and replaced by lively Spaniards and their musical instruments and candles. Magical in summer

Meander the streets. Make sure you have a map for this area, as there are lots of tiny meandering streets, with many unusual shops. stop in an original cafe for a beer, many are still original and staff do not speak english. a real experience of old barcelona
Absolutely beautiful. The nicest area of the city - beautiful buildings, lovely shops, bars and restaurants. Well worth a visit.

Nice to walk around. Nice to go and see it.
There is a free tour that you can join, we just walked around and it was nice, nothing more.

barri gotic. so nice to wander around, found a nice restaurant, ate inside (it's cheaper) saw the cathedral (from the outside) where Cristobol Columbus returned to from the new world. barri gotic makes a nice walk,even as the sun goes down.
Loved it!. I could spend hours wandering around the tiny streets. There something interesting around every twist and turn. Lots of quirky shops and cafes

A big place to take a walk. You should go there at night, it is more gothic this way and beautiful! it can take you half a day to walk there, but it is interesting in every place! you will see a lot of beautiful houses and a lot of stores.

One of the most fascinating areas in Barcelona!. Barri Gotic or the Gothic quarter is like a labyrinth of narrow streets and small squares where you will really feel the charm and the Medieval and Roman character of the city. Wandering through the area you'll come across some attractions like Palau de la Musica Catalana, the cathedral, placa Jaume and my favourite Placa Reial with all those amazing bars and restaurants. You'd better explore it during the day because it's a bit dark and scary in the evening! Enjoy all the street musicians and performers there as well as the cafes, tapas bars and restaurants!

Fascinating old quarter. Just take a couple of hours to walk through the oldest quarter in Barcelona and just wonder the small labyrinth like streets that will show you impressive and beautiful old buildings. My advice is to go there before noon or on a week day night, in order to avoid the huge number of tourists walking and shopping
Best Area. If you want character and off the beaten path surroundings, this is the place, it is safe, a little dingy, but that is part of its charm!

Venice on dry land!. I really liked the gothic quater, It reminded me on venice on dry land with its old twisting streets and high buildings. Beware that shops dont start opening until around 10am, but most do stay open until 9pm. However, i wouldnt advise to go wandering around them after 9 as they do get very dark once the sun goes down. However, its very nice to stroll around them in the afernoon. Some of the shops are amazing and you get all sorts of weird and wonderful things. If you go farther in, you will end up walking into a part of town called el bourne or something and thats also very nice with nice shops and restaurants. Dont be afraid to explore the gothic area or get lost down it streets, No matter where we wondered we always seemed to come back out onto Las Ramblas eventually or stumble upon one of the many metro stations.

Easy to get lost. I loved going from restaurant to restaurant indulging on tapas and soaking up the atmosphere. The architecture is very interesting and unique, there is no place like this anywhere else in the world... but I must admit, the narrow streets all look the same after a while, although the amount of alcohol consumed may have factored into that also

Thankful that things like this exist. Coming from the very young nation of USA it's amazing to see these building and plazas that are hundreds and hundreds of years old still in tact and as overwhelmingly grand as they ever were.

you can feel the history in the air. The buildings in this area make you feel the history in this place despite all the modernity that surrounds it. Buildings with intricate architectural elements and of course the Barcelona church which took 600 years to complete is a must see

My favourite area of the city. Love all the narrow streets with little individual shops and unique cafes but plent of open area squares too. Total mix of characters here. Can be a bit dark and scary though in the dark, especially if you do not know where you are going. Explore it through the day.

Don't get lost in Vencice! Get lost in Barcelona!!. I loved the Gothic Quarter! I found myself wandering in that direction everyday!! And everyday I found myself in another beautiful ornate street with beautiful Architecure and an array of wonderful places to eat. I would wonder as long as I could without even looking at a map! Found some great little treasures! Best places to eat here!!!

Small narrow streets. The Gothic Quarter stretches from La Rambla to Via Laietana and from the Mediterranean seafront to Ronda de Sant Pere. Many of the buildings still date from medieval times and to earlier Roman settlements.Barri Gòtic still has a labyrinthine street plan, with small streets opening out into squares leading to interesting architecture, a chance to get lost on the narrow streets leading to a discovery of interesting shops or buildings.

Intriguing - but beware. This is a fascinating area of the city, as is the adjacent area to the East bordered by the Arc de Triomphe and Parc de la Ciutedella. These districts are a maze of narrow (often pedestrianised) streets buzzing with shoppers and tourists taking in the atmosphere created by both the architectural delights and the myriad of small and unique shops. Squares filled with dining tables will suddenly appear, and performance artists can usually be found entertaining the crowds in front of the large cathedral. In terms of pure interest and atmosphere it puts the more famous Ramblas to shame. However (and this probably applies everywhere in Barcelona) it is very easy to become a victim of petty crime in these streets, either because you are caught up in throng and can get pickpocketed or (as in our case) you find yourself in a quiet sidestreet and fall victim to a snatch and run merchant. Don't let this put you off - but if possible do not wear jewellery or expensive watches or carry a handbag. Coming from the UK this seems over cautious - but it is a sad truth (in our experience, and having joined a queue of other "victims" the next day at the police station) that Barcelona's reputation for crime is valid.

Nice area to visit. Nice atmosphere with numerous tapas bars. Good to visit both during the day and at night. Found a couple of restaurants that were reasonably priced with good wine. Rioja was the house wine at one.

Easy walking area. I'll never understand why the Castilians are so rude. We are their bread and butter and I always swear I wont ever return. The Galacians and the Basques are amazingly kind and helpful. Catalans not so much.
great. wonderful walk through this neighborhood..excellent architecture in every corner.. great experience...
Dodgy. Watch your belongings seems to be a lot of characters about looking for a chance to snatch.Many shops selling usual bad quality items.

Walking tour of Modernism. Did a walking tour which included a certain portion of the Gothic Quarter. Architecture is simply wonderful and sights very memorable. A definite must do while in Barcelona.
The older part of town.... It was great to see the old Architecture and buildings. The Catherdal was amazing. The narrow streets full of shops were fun.

It's like going back in time... I loved the Gothic Quarter. Our hotel was in the area and everyday we'd find a new area to visit that was beyond our expectations. Just walking around and exploring the neighborhood will easily take up your whole day (if not more). I highly recommend that you stop by here at least once during your stay in Barcelona!

Another very historic place.. Barcelona is full of historic and artful places...and this one is one of the most important. Excellent restaurants and museums to visit.... For men: Try not to wear shorts.... I was "attacked" by an old man that did not care for me wearing shorts while walking around on a very hot and humid day... Luckily, I speak the language and by telling him to "^%$^ off" stopped him... haha!

nice walk and interesting streets and buildings. there on a Sunday and most were closed. didn't like having to pay to visit the Cathedral. Happened to be there for a Catalan Liberation Day event and found the people pleasant, informative and great to talk with.
Very cool!. You don't get to see areas like this everywhere. The Cathedral was stunning. The streets are old cobblestone and narrow.

Old but new. A wonderful area full of interesting buildings, great views, cafes with charm.Visit the cathedral, go to the roof an enjoy the views, We hasd an enjoyable evening at the Cafe Bernard, but there are plenty more to chose from, our favourite part of the city.

lovely. Lovely area where you'll love to wander and explore all little streets and corners. You´ll find magic little stores and cafe´s hidden in this neighbourhood and stumble into amazing architectural pieces.Located in the heart of Barcelona, there´s no excuse to miss it!
Fun, exciting, interesting. The area is excellent. Lots of shops selling unusual clothes, items. Lots to do. The La Rambla is touristy but still fun.

Soak up the atmosphere of the old Barcelona. Loved staying in a top floor bedsit off a cobble-stoned alleyway in Barri Gotic as felt like we were in the heart of the action, especially at night. Perfect access to Las Ramblas and all the hidden squares with alfresco cafes and gelati bars. Felt perfectly safe even with a young family and enjoyed access to local fruit shops and cafes for breakfast. This is the area to stay in for easy access to the vibes of Barcelona. Easy access to the waterfront too!
City Break. Spent every evening in the Gothic Quarter. Loved the dimly li narrow streets and the dozens of small and friendly tapas bars and pubs.
Must watch site. If you like architecture then this is a must see place. Easy to get to from anywhere in Barcelona. We preferred Metro.

not the place to be compared to the Ramblas. This is the old quarter of town and is pretty but it does not get the crowds like the pedestrian walkway, Ramblas or the Beach at Barcelonetta. Still a must see.
Unsure what was there. we went to the Gothic Quarter but couldnt really find many bars or squares to sit in to eat or drink - the taxi dropped us off but it was not clear where to go

It's not a meal, it's a seat for some street theatre. Beware any meal you eat here. You will have around four sets of street buskers play music or perform acrobatics for you. It quickly becomes a nuisance. My tip is to pop in, take pictures and eat somewhere off the beaten track.

Walkable History. Just start at the Plaza Catalunya and walk down toward the southeast from the corner of the big department store toward the cathedral. As you get closer the side streets get narrower and just explore. Don't miss what was once the palace where Columbus reported back to the king and queen. It is now a museum. After walking and soaking up the history you have earned some quality time at one of the many tapas bars. Hopefully the weather will be as good as we had and you can sit outside. Simply enjoy and feel fortunate to be able to travel and visit such a place.

One of my favorites!. If traveling to Barc, you cannot miss the Gothic Quarter! I actually recommend a walking tour. We did a free walking tour (tip only, really!) with Runnerbean tours for about 3 hours and it was really, really good. We learned a lot.

Surprisingly..... ....a bit creepy at night.I stayed in Bari Gothic, arriving at my apartment about 10 in the evening. The graffiti, young people obviously living on the street and groups of men trying to sell loose cans of beer was a bit off-putting at first. Ever-present but non-agressive - still they were a bit annoying, even for a New Yorker.The bars in the Bari were mostly empty at 11 or 12 at night - hard to find out where the "scene" was in that neighborhood. In the neighborhood on the North side of Placa Reiel, the establishment were a bit more accommodating and friendly.I recommend Sinatra for a civilized cocktail. The "Brit" pub just north of there was also a nice place to have a pint of Guiness.

Walk through time. It is very busy but so wonderful with the narrow streets and churches!
There are also little shops and lovely town squares to sit and eat, enjoy this authentic part of Barcelona
gothic quater. lots of history there and great architecture. But also lots of pickpockets. Saw men being chased a few times
cool area. this area was so cool. I loved the oldness of it all. the small streets were like nothing i have ever seen before. it was kind of creepy but it just added to the area.
Past life experience?. As you walk through the streets you are transported into another place and time and yet you are in the here and now. How cool is that!

interesting to visit, but save your souvenier money. historically it should have been more interesting for walking around. it's a popular place to do so, but this is a very congested area for tourists and shoppers and you have to get through a lot of junk to find the little shops worth time or money.

nice. very interesting area. hidden in the gothic quarter is what was once the jewish quarter and there is a little museum there for those who are interested in history in general and specifically Jewish history.
A great area with a gothic feel. Great for wandering around and looking at the buildings. Close to the Rambla and Barcelona Cathedral
Nice old town. A nice walk in narrow streets. I would recommend going here with a guide to get more info on the history, e.g. on of the free walking tours.
Amazing!. Spend time wandering through the maze of streets off La Rambla where you will come across unexpected squares full of bars, cafes and boutique shops. (Drinks much cheaper than on La Rambla!)
What a contrast!. A little gem in a big city with so much history. Wait until you see the inside of the cathedral and the "special" guests that inhabit it!

Absolutely breathtaking - you can wander for hours!. This is what makes Barcelona such a beautiful, captivating city. I walked by myself without a map and found the streets really breathtaking. It has a charming vibe, and there is a lot to see! The many cathedrals and historic sights make this a must-see. I visited the Picasso museum, which was worthwhile (although showcases his earlier work so not as 'iconic' as seeing Picasso artworks in MoMA, New York or Reina Sofia in Madrid). Had a lot of fun trying to find the Picasso museum as well, since street names aren't always clear and the streets are quite windy! A lot of cheap restaurants and cafes are in this area. Next time I will go on a walking tour to learn more about its history.

Go and Wander. I had a last minute business trip to Barcelona for my first time and didn't prepare for anything. I rode the subway into the Barri Gòtic area (Jaume I metro stop) and just wandered the area for hours. The narrow roads, the ancient walls, the Spanish architecture, the many shops and smells and sounds make this a great culture adventure. And LaRambla runs all along the western side of the area. So just go.
Old world charm. it has character and is a lovely way to chill in a cafe in a square away from the noise of the main streets

Lovely afternoon!!. I love walking around old fashioned kind of areas. I knew I would love the Gothic Quarter and it never failed to impress. You can go to the Picasso Museum, Barcelona Cathedral and other lovely places from here.Only negative is the volume of people who are walking around...
Brill place to stay. Streets are narrow with beautiful architecture opening into beautiful little squares, atmosphere is wonderful.

Beautiful. Seriously just walk!! Walk around here down all the little alleys and stop for coffee in the squares. Listen to the beautiful musicians and look at the amazing architecture. It really is the most beautiful area in Barcelona.

Beautiful old buildings well preserved and accessible. We've just had a few days in Barcelona and spent most of our time in this area. We wandered the pretty streets and did walks we found in guide book but the highlight of our stay was our visit to the amazing museum of the foundations of Barcelona. I'll do a separate review of the museum in detail. But it can be found just beside Placa del Rei. We found lovely restaurants and cafes here too and I'll review them separately as well. But for anyone who has any interest in history, shopping, eating or just absorbing this wonderful city, this is the place to be.

Want a wander then take a walk around here. You really need a travel guide or something to tell you all about the history of this area to get the best out of it. We were thinking of finding the free walking tours at the Travellers Bar (search for it) but ran out of time. Any good map will do to get you around the area which is not that large but you will need something else to fully apreciate its rich history.

Great. Really cool shops and streets, go get lost in them! Most of the tourist maps don't show the names of the streets in this area,main streets are close by and you will find one if you walk in one direction long enough!
Great place to wander around. Spent some time in this area every day of our trip. It's a lovely place just to hang around with something around every corner to see.
You can get lost here.... Twists and turns and back alleys, but you also get to see neighborhoods and local lifestyles. Great way to get a feel for the city.
Something new every turn. Tapas, pinchos, shopping, historical landmarks and more. Getting lost in Gothic Quarter is a ton of fun.
The kind of evening you dream of.... It was really fun to roam around through the narrow streets and look at things in the shops and stop for a glass of wine at a street cafe.
Lovely place to wander and eat. Great to wander around in day or at night - great shops/cafes and restaurants here - go and see and explore. It is a must see.

Interesting area. One feels like in a Medina, including the smell (gutter). This can only be compensated by the lovely old houses, the feeling and life as is in the quarter. Shops are open til late, a bottle of water can always be found. Music here, a painting there. One has to be ware of pick-pockets, as this is a big problem all over. Experiencing it means having a lot of time on hand but it is worth it.
Las Ramblas. Fascinating district. Great for people watching. Never tire of visiting this area but never again in August. Far too hot.

Buildings and Boutiques. Small alley ways with various buildings of different designs with loads of small coffee shops, restaurants and boutiques. Worth a visit for sure, more women orientated from a boutique perspective, so the males need to be prepared to be going in in boutique after boutique. Good visit moving around all the back streets, safe place as well.
So old. This area is so old and amazing really old buildings. Its like been in a different city again. Tour bus passes through here so you can get off and check it out
great for a wander. lovely atmosphere, great buildings, lots of cafes and bars and little boutique shopshad a very enjoyable time just wandering through

Suprises. As I strolled thru Barcelona with only a map for direction, I had no particular place to go, I stumbles on the best spots and one of them was the Gothic Quarter. I remain in awe of the quiet surprises this city has to offer for the non-scripted traveler. Love it!

Beautiful and Historic. If you love hearing about history and seeing architecture, then take a guided tour. These are sold in the street in the large, clean "Info" tourist kiosks.
You can also simply walk it, but take a map--those small streets diverge all over the place!

Interesting. Great little area with lots of unique shops, fountain and Gothic Church. There is also a little playground called George Orwell Square with a sculpture of a big eye looking over it (Big Brother?)

Such a crazy maze. Have fun getting lost and finding your way back out again. This is a must see and you can accidentally wander out to Las Ramblas, tons of little shops and lots of good food everywhere.

Good history location conviniences. What made the Gothic Quarter nice is that it is that it is next to La Ramba which means close to almost everything, the port, shops, food, attractions, and the night life, yet you can still appreciate the old structures and history. In the immediate area, transportation is easy, so even if you are not staying in the area, find a hop-on hop-off bus or city bus and spend some time walking the area. The old church and Roman wall is worth seeking out. See pictures.

Great to wander in the oldest part of Barcelona. This is a good area to wander with many places to see such as Cathedral, Museu d'Histoira (underground Roman ruin), Museu Picasso, Centre Excursionista de Catalunya (Roman columns). Don't forget to look up, we spot many interesting gargoyles. When we were there in the morning (~9am), it was quiet with not many tourists.

Great area to wander, shop, and snack. There aren't any spectacular landmarks but this area is a lot of fun, with many pedestrian shopping streets, interesting back alleys, and small restaurants and bars for tapas or a meal.
Gothic Quarter. It was my favorite place in Barcelona. The narrow streets, cobblestones gives one a sense of history.

Atmospheric. This maze of little medieval streets surrounding the cathedral is the perfect place to wander around and soak up the feeling of the history of the city, however this also makes it the perfect place for opportunistic thieves to snatch valuables and sprint off up an alley. Enjoy the atmosphere but watch your back, front and sides, particularly after dark.
Enjoyed!. nice to see the oldest area of Barcelona, saw it for just 30 mins. Would have loved to spent more time in this area

Great atmosphere. Beautiful old streets, with traditional and tourist shops. If travelling with children, don't miss the sweetie shop called "Happy Pills" on Calle de L'Arc (bottom RH corner of the cathedral square, as you face the main entrance).

The heart of Barcelona, unchanged. This is the way Barcelona was as a Medievl city. Narrow alley ways and little stores. Its fabulous to walk around and to see the unchanged arcutecture. amazing.. .and safe!!!! And alive well into the night

Timeless. This is a wonderfully well maintained part of Barcelona that helps one experience some of the history of this city. It would be helpful to have a guide to ensure that you truly appreciate all you are seeing.

lots to see. great to spend sometime walking
many cafes
interesting architecture
lots of small shops and interesting art

Fascinating area. We loved to walk around this area, stopping at bars, restaurants and shops. There are lots of warnings about crime in Barcelona, but taking sensible precautions with your bags,money and any phones/Ipods etc seemed sufficient and we never felt threatened, nor did we witness any crime. You could spend weeks wandering this area and still come upon streets and squares you hadn't been down. We preferred the Gothic Quarter to La Rambla - much more relaxed and frequently very elegant. Restaurants near the cathedral offered variety and reasonable prices. We enjoyed two evening meals there.

Go back in time. A brilliant hour or so spent exploring the little streets of the Gothic Quarter. It's easy to get lost but then you stumble upon some fabulous little shops like a sweet shop which is called 'Happy Pills' a must visit for young and old or even the Cathedral hidden away. It's shaded and has live music along the streets and water fountains round the corners, it's great to go to on a sunny day when you want some shade and some streets which aren't bustling with people. A real taste fo spanish and spanish culture!
Very nice walk. This is nice walk in the city if not during hot summer days. Possible early morning or evening if summer days. But April or May, October are much better for this

interesting. interesting to see with a walking tour, we did ours through travel bound free walking tours in barcelona and saw the sights that we wouldnt have if we walked it alone, something to see while in barcelona for sure.

Quintessential old Europe. This is a fabulous place to get lost, but don't do it at night - the streets are narrow (kind of alley-like) and the buildings are tall, so it's difficult to keep a point of reference. I'm really glad that I spent some time here, but was super-diligent about (a) having a way to get out of the narrow streets and (b) watching my purse.

Free Walking Tour through the Gothic quarter. We recently took the Travel Bar free walking tour through the Old City and enjoyed it immensely. It provided a good overview of the Gothic part of Barcelona and its history presented with a sense of humor that made it interesting.
loved this charming area. meander through the streets and feel the neighborhood. Charming and quaint....don't miss it! Shops, restaurants and beautiful photo opportunities!

Amazing place during the daytime. The Barri Gotic can be a little dodgy at night if you are on your own but during the day its just incredible. There seems to be a speciality shop for EVERYTHING! masks, magic, candles.... amazing stuff - window shopping is a real treat. add to this the amazing architecture and getting some shade on a hot day in the narrow streets and its a real gem
Go there. Nice area to eat and drink at night.Some decent bars and restraunts.Though watch your pockets as there are pickpockets about.

Wonderful atmosphere. I love walking around this area there are so many wonderful buildings. There are some many shops to browse in and countless places to eat and drink. I seem to find something new every visit and have been coming to Barcelona regularly for over 20 years. A great time to visit is around Christmas where the strees and alleys around the Catedral areare filled with stall selling nativity scene artefacts

Beautiful. Definately need to have a wander around here - very pretty & lots of nice shops! Good to have a look at night too, looks great by street light. Shade of the old buildings is very welcome on a hot day too!!
Gargoyles and angels. Loved the selection of gargoyles and characters! Amazing scenes and definitely worth a visit. We rode through it on the hop-on-hop-off tour bus

Moody, glorious and special. Whilst steeped in history and worth visiting watch out for tiny restaurants that serve amazing food here. Paved narrow streets that criss cross each other amidst stunning medieval buidings.
architectural treat. Great place to wander around, explore and soak up Barcelona. Narrow streets with surprises around every corner. Real atmosphere, interesting sights - even my children loved it!
Middle ages. Great just wandering around, getting lost in the alleyways and finding great little bars and restaurants tucked away from the hustle.

La Ramblas. Really surprised by how much this side of the city has changed. Gone are the street entertainers, we never seen one whilst we we there and we visited a couple of times. Lots of police presence but I think this is due to the historical problem of pickpockets etc. Very pleasant to walk around now and feels safe.

Best part of the Barcelona. We stayed in an apartment in the heart of the Barri Gotic, so we got to know our way around it very well. The buildings have such character and i love the maze of little streets. There are also lots of nice squares in the area, such as Plaza del pi, and the square with the cathedral. Make sure you make time to explore this area fully.
Excellent place to wander. We wandered for ages around the little streets. It almost seemed as if time had stood still. Felt really safe here and loved the old buildings. Definitely a place to visit.

too turisty. This is actually not a Gothic Quarter, most of the "gothic" constructions were done or rebuild for the 1929's Universal Exposition. Anyway there are still some Roman heritage and several building and places from the medieval splendor of Catalonia when was one of the powerful countries in the Mediterranea.
great history!. We stayed near this area, incredible winding streets with small boutiques and shops. Amazing collection of graffitti on shutters of even the most expensive shops!
very cool. loved walking around here. It is quite the maze of streets. Grab a drink to go and get lost in the streets! lots of cool little places to see and check out.

gothic quarter. Lots of narrow winding streets, easy to get lost - make sure yiou have a map with you. After the first day we found it easy to navigate through the maze of streets that often open into a square with a market or reataurants.

Recommended (quiet and peaceful ). The Gothic Quarter is relatively quiet and peaceful compare to the 'crazy' Ramblas St.
very nice and narrow.
Recommended

Worth Wandering. The Gothic Quarter is just off the main promenade and well worth wandering. Feel free to get "lost" since you are certain to run into interesting architecture, places, shops, and restaurants. The first time I explored the area I was looking specifically for the main cathedral but got sidetracked a bit with other interesting places. I had been told by someone in my home town about a restaurant in the Gothic Quarter that was frequented by Salvador Dali, but I had no idea how to locate it. I found it my last full day in Barcelona by accident (but just after I had eaten lunch), so I would have needed another day to sample it--IF I could have repeated whatever route I had taken.But that's no big deal. It's fairly simple to locate the large cathedral in the heart of the Gothic Quarter, but everything else you find is a pleasant bonus.
Don't want to miss. Barri Gotic is fun to just stroll down one evening. Beautiful architecture and always some street dance performers in the squares.

Everything about this area is a must see.. Stayed in this area, and wandered around everyday. There were always different sights to see, outdoor concerts going on, a very busy place in the evening. This area really gives you a feeling of what Barcelona is like.
Get lost. Just start walking and get lost i this great place. Each time you make a turn your gonna find something new and beautiful.

Friendly neighborhood and cool shops.. The narrow streets in the Gothic Quarter didn't make me claustrophobic like narrow streets usually do. I was told to be on alert for pickpockets but I didn't notice anyone having a problem. Laid back atmosphere as long as there is not a car trying to pass, although that not being a problem.
brilliant. side streets are awsome - like going back in time, lot of morrocan style houses. Great shops and cafes

Where the cool kids hang. It was pretty much where all the bars and restaurants that were worth your time were. I enjoyed my time over there, but was happy I had directions to my restaurant as it would be easy to get confused on where your going. Take your iPhone! :-)
Take a Walk. Easy to get lost but interesting walks about. Can look a bit dingy compared to newer areas of the city but lots of good food and interesting things to see.
Old!. It's nice to see all the ancient buildings and the city wall. Don't miss the cathedral. On the weekends people dance Sardanas in front of the cathedral
quaint. Quaint winding streets, however it felt a bit touristy. Having read that it was the heart of the foody section of Barcelona society, it fell a bit flat.
Breathtaking. I loved the whole ambience of this district. The winding streets show the original character of the city. The Cathedral is awesome.

Worth a visit. These little streets were near our hotel and we spent many evenings browsing in the little shops and eating at the numerous restaurants. There are museums and churches of interest hidden away in the labrynth of streets.

Well worth a morning visit.. We went on a walking tour of this area of Barcelona, our tour guide was informative and the buildings are magnificent. A trip to the Barcelona Cathedral, Leftenants house and the churches and chapels is definately worth the effort. Be sure to dress respectfully. The cathedral requires that you cover your shoulders before they allow you entrance and if you go in before 1pm its free entry.

Walking Tour was easy and excellent!. We used a mini-pocketsized travel guide / book to help us decide on where and when to walk for personal touring. We started with a quick and delicious breakfast (expresson and fresh croissants) near the Picasso Museum then went in to see the artist's works. Enjoyed the rest of the tour through and around cathedrals, Roman ruins, placas, and more.

Fun to walk around. It is fun to see the old town. You can walk around easily without getting lost. There are a lot of things to see on your walk, including the church and the market. Spend time going into the shops on the side streets.

You have to go .... It's not as dark and dank as the word "Gothic" might seem, it is an architectural extravegance that people live and work in.
Amazing place and so much to see ... each time you look somewhere there is more to see.

Don't miss it!. If your in Barcelona make sure you don't miss a visit to the Gothic Quarter (Barri Gotic). The more time you have the better to wander and visit the plethora of side streets and squares stuffed with the most intriguing of shops and architecture. Stop and people watch from one of the many cafe's and you'll see life pass you by in many guises. We loved it and re-visited a number of times.

great place to stay. Our hotel was actually in the Gothic Quarter which was bang in the middle of everything...loved this....we were able to stroll around the shops and restaurants without having far to go to our hotel....
Loved the shops more than the sightseeing. Lots of second hand shops, trinkets, souvenirs and delicious fruit juices here. Loved walking around here with the family. We all shopped a lot.

Adventures Around Every Corner. This is an older part of town, near the original town center. The streets are something that you picture in your mind when someone says, "Mediterranean". Pick a street, take a walk, turn left, turn right, have a bite here, stop there for a drink, check out that shop. We really loved just wandering, and we spent several days doing just that. The area is not packed with tourists, nor is it so off-the-main-beat as to be seem vacant. Without exception, the shop-keepers, bartenders, and waiters (not many waitresses in those older places) were exceptionally friendly.
Very old world. Loved it. Lots of quaint, narrow, cobblestone streets with shops. The Cathedral is nice too though we didn't spend too much time.
Stunning. Just walking around the gothic area I was lost for words at every turn, it's as stunning as venice. And we found an excellent little tapas place on Carrer di Pi. Well worth a visit.

FULL of history!. If you love history and architecture then you will love the Gothic Quarter it's a fantastic area and one of my favourites! There is an amazing restuarant in the centre that we went to on our first visit to Barcelona and we are excited about going back but for the life of me I cannot remember it's name!!! Anyway great place lots to do and see and great atmosphere!
Lovely buildings. What a lovely atmospheric area ! I felt like I was a time traveller. I hope the residents of Barcelona realise that they are very blessed to have access to such a lovely city.

Great place to stroll.... We enjoyed wandering through the alleys and the buildings are awesome. Popping out into the wide boulevards with modern stores was a great contrast. Lots of little surprises...

Quaint and beautiful. We did a commercial two hour walking tour. Old Barcelona is very interesting....lots of fascinating stories and terrific architecture. Go with a guide, it is a great way to learn some great history.

Barcelona's Old World.. We stayed in Hotel Neri, once a Medieval palace, in the middle of the Gothic Quarter. The maze of winding alleys between the Medieval buildings have many shops and makes one feel as if you are in The Old World. Truly European!

Barri Gotic. We stayed near here see my previous review on H10 Universtat - I loved this area of Barcelona, lots to see, shop and eat. Amazing back streets leading to more exciting buildings or little shops not just for tourists!
great stroll. make sure you take your time to cover this historic part of Bafrcelona - with some hidden gems and small streets!
fantastic. i just love the Gothic quarter at night . with markets and and artist on the street , plenty to see . make sure your arms a covered before you go into charch
Go to the Gotic. Great atmosphere, with winding alleys contrasting with the wide boulevards and open squares of Barca. Easy to find a friendly little bar offering fantastic local food and drinks.

More street cleaning please. Fabulous Picasso Museum and fascinating streetscape but lots of young party folks at night means stinky streets and vomit stains in the morning. More street washing by town or by each business would make a morning stroll more pleasant. More upscale as you head into the Borne area.

Very atmospheric. This is a very hauntingly atmospheric place to visit on an evening. We ran out of time on our last visit to Barcelona so this was on the top of our list to see this time around and we weren't disappointed! Some lovely little bars, tavernas and shops and the amazing buildings and narrow echoey streets reminded us a bit like the back streets of Venice (without the water). Well worth a visit both in the evening and in the day for two very different experiences.
A great place.. Lots of shopping, avoid the resturants that are tourists traps, the best time to visit is at the afternoon, when it not so hot.
bizarre but cool. the area is cool and hip but very unlikely the other areas of the city. seems like you need a few days to enjoy all the area has to offer. highly recommend
Medieval. there are many shops, bars and interesting restaurants, everything enter medieval streets. I loved!! the best of the city!
old bit. Short walk from Rambla and well worth it. Loads of restaurants and plenty to look at. Take a look inside the Cathedral females must cover their shoulders to get in
Love this place. Great combination of medieval (Barcelona Cathedral) and contemporary (museums featuring modernistic art). A treat for the senses.
Barri Gotica. Stroll along barri gotica and take time to go into the cathedrals and small boutiques. Remember girls to cover your shoulders and knees when going into the cathedrals and churches.
Interesting place to wander.. Shopping good and interesting attractions to see. Good places to eat and sit watching the world go by!

Nostalgic. I came in August where many things were closed for their holiday. That was a pity, but many things were still open and the area is great. When in Barcelona, this is one of the areas t visit. It has a little bit of everything. Just stay away in August or you may be disappointed by all the shutters on th stores. Still, are is quite nice.

A great place to wander. This is a great part of the city not to be missed. If you like wandering around stopping for the occasional drink, doing a bit of people watching then this is the place. Filled with lots of interesting mostly independent craft shops together with many restaurants bars and cafe's there is something to see wherever the streets take you.

Don't miss it!. The architecture is amazing and it's great to get lost on the narrow streets and discover new buildings, interesting shops or churches. Look at the details of the architecture, take a moment and admire the surroundings. We were also lucky to bump into a group of street musicians that were fantastic! Just stop, listen and enjoy.

The best place to stay and visit. We stayed in the heart of the Gotic area and we were glad we did. Not many places in the world where you can walk through medieval walls and narrow streets and imagine life so many years ago. Tons of shopping, churches, food, museums etc. Always felt safe even walking back to hotel in the middle of night.

Enchanting and full of atmosphere. This is the oldest quarter of the town, with medieval and renaissance palaces, narrow cobbled stones, a very beautiful Cathedraland a gorgeous museum on the story of the town, which I highly recommend to visit.
Just stroll along the streets to soak up the beautiful atmosphere of the most authentic Barcelona!

Just meander. Didn't do anything special here but I'd say this is a newer area for tourism, seemed more full of twenty somethings (with all due respect...) and great opprotunity for boutiques and such.
Give it a walk, close enough to subway stations and the water, why not ??

A True Gem. This is a place that needs many visits to appreciate. Streets and buildings from the middle ages. I found the Jewish "EL CAL" Neighborhood to be very interesting, there is a two Euro donation to go into the museum. I spent hours and hours in the neighborhood visiting the many shops, small bars and small restaurants.

Getting lost in the Barri Gotic. You should spend at least half a day exploring this area. There are some great places to eat and shop. Just bring your best walking shoes and get lost in one of the bylanes. That's the true way to enjoy a city as a tourist in my opinion. Pretty long queue to get inside the cathedral, but it was August, so expected.

Character plus. Definitely worth a stroll if you like old cities (I do). There are all sorts of interesting shops and museums. If you're there on a Sunday at midday you can see locals dancing outside the main cathedral after Mass
Charming,. you must wander, just wander through the Gothic quarter..Great stores, Great Shopping, museums, churches, food..Worth doing twice

Worth exploring. The Gothic Quarter contains a few parts which are really old in a negative sense, as in a bit crumbling, narrow and smelly. However, you must take time to explore and find all the beautiful, romantic and historical corners and you will be rewarded!

The biggest concentration of Gothic buildings in Europe. Go with a guide as there are so many easy to miss subtleties, that it may be impossible to notice and comprehend everything by yourself. We went with runnerbean tours, which were good, but I can see how this tour could have been better. Still, very informative and colorful tour of the darkest and brightest times of Barcelona! Has many interesting buildings and history left from the former Jewish quarter as well.
Gothic Quarter a tight squeeze. Narrow alleys and old architecture are cool. Wander the ancient streets and visit historic sights in this vibrant city.
Interesting. We had dinner here one night... it's an eclectic neighborhood with lots of restaurant options and great cafes with al fresco seating.

The oldest part of Baracloa. This is the oldest part of the city. Take a guide with you so that you can see how they make their paper mache statues and visit Papabubble to see how they make hand made sweets.
Nostalgia!. The narrow streets,little shops,open air bars and restaurants ,all make the pleasant sens from the old time of Barcelona. Nostalgia! You should get lost in the past.

Beautiful at night. Travelling back from a lovely tapas; we walked through the Gothic centre at night which was beautifully light up and very pretty.Please do not walk down darkly light areas as pick pockets and muggers are present in Barcelona.However we happily walked around churches and cathedrals, pretty streets and fountains at night time - where police kept an eye out on motor cycles.

Amazing. Get lost for hours wandering around the Gothic Quarter, every street you turn down is different, interesting and filled with unique shops, cafe's and people. Spend a day walking around and then go back for dinner and Sangria at night

Lost? Not really.. The narrow streets and almost complete absence of motor traffic make walking around both safe and pleasant. Surprising number of little shops of all descriptions, and, of course, open air restaurants.Slight downside is that the standard Barcelona maps apparently don't show every one of these little streets and you're never certain of where you will emerge on the Ramblas.

To taste its unique atmosphere. Barri gotic is time resistant - it probably felt the same years ago. Very narrow streets providing shadow when its hot, little shops with souvenirs, clothes, candies and ice creams ('gelaati' are the best). There are a lot of tiny hostels in this area, but it does not feel safe after dark in there.
guided walking tour. We could never have navigated the narrow twisiting lanes ourselves. It was from the city of Barcelona

A short walk but you will miss the essence of Barcelona if you don't visit here.. Great shops and eateries etc, buskers and lots of life but a real understanding of how Barcelona has grown from a tiny town to a sprawling city in a relatively short space of time, once you've visited here. Pity there weren't more general info displays for tourists.

my favorite place in BCN!. Unforgettable tangle of labyrinth-like narrow streets filled with great shops, bars, restaurants and nightlife!! Want to return just to spend more time here. Cool boutiques with one of a kind dresses, scarves, etc, and as you wander around the quarter you run into great little plazas enclosed by tall buildings, and amidst the old, modern sculptures to wander at.

Too much to see in one visit. The Gothic area is teaming with shops, tapas bars, historic sites and close to a wonder park. Even the port is just a short walk. While not in the plan, we were tempted too many times with treasures to bring home to family. Not the typical tourist stuff from Las Ramblas, but quality gifts. As to places to eat, too many to describe.
Barri Gotic. As per my El Born review - lots of small shops and plenty to see. The Urban Police are very visible but the scooters, bikes and taxis seem to 'own' what should be a pedestrian area.

Architectural gem. The old quarter of Barcelona with tiny, narrow streets and stunning architecture. Cathedral La Seu - unless you are an ardent fan of cathedrals, I would give this one a miss - it's very dingy and the statuary was positively filthy - not very inspiring. Plenty of little cafes and gorgeous shops and on certain days a street antique market. Try not to miss the Picasso frieze opposite the cathedral on the Collegi d'Arquitectes building - truly fab!

Beware of Pick Pockets. Keep your valuables in a zipped purse or pocket, including your cell phone. Keep your purse/backpack in the front of you - or leave it locked up at the hotel. A deep pocket does not protect you. The pick pockets do not know your purse is zipped, so they may reach for it from behind. A pick pocket slid in next to me as my daughter moved away from me to look at something. I thought he was her - and when I turned to look at her and saw him, it was an awful feeling. At least my purse was in front and zipped!The area is interesting - but shops do close for most of the afternoon. The door/window barriers/gates make it look depressing.YOU SHOULD go to the market right off of Las Ramblas and the Liceau metro stop - buy lunch there!
The historical heart of Barcelona. Be sure to walk through this quarter during your visit to Barcelona. Visit the Cathedral and Picasso Museum, or just simply stroll.
