atmosphere and beautiful buildings, tiny little cafes and bars!. love cafe gaudi best for snacks ad good breakfasts if you are self catering in an apartment.cross the ramblas and walk down Hospital and visit the cat shelter behind the market Cute! walk down the ramblas to Nou de ramblas and go and see the biggest fattest tomcat in the world! brilliant! el born is beautiful but el ravel has a much better atmosphere very multi cultural and friendly!
Best part of Barcelona!. Put your map away and just wander the lanes. Great architecture, great art, great vibe, no Gaudi!
STROLL TO YOUR HEART'S CONTENT. Find a guided walk on the Internet or in a travel book and explore, explore, explore.
Have to see. Everytime I went to BCN, I do a walk through barri gotic, its amazing place, the architecture, the atmosphere
Great Location. Stayed in the Gothic Quarter. It is the best area to stay when in Barcelona.
impressive Barcelona and cute elborn. itt because it is lts a little district and it is wonderful it is the Soho of Barcelona with nicest little design shops

Barri Gotic = Barcelona. Well, almost.. If you are a tourist and you are going to Barcelona, you MUST visit the Barri Gotic. You'd have no other option, for most of the really significant monuments/churches/museums in Barcelona are located in this district. This includes the Catedral, City history museum (roman city), the Las Ramblas and the piece de resistance, Playa del Rei.This should be the first place you visit in Barcelona. Depending on your level of interest in history, I recommend that you assign between 25% and 50% of your time in Barcelona to walking around and visiting the monuments in Barri Gotic.

My favourite part of Barcelona. The Gothic Quarter of Barcelona was my favourite. You can truly lose yourself in it and what’s more, you should. Just allow these little streets to take over. Let them be your guide and leader. Allow some time and just stroll around breating in its magic atmosphere. And when you get hungry just pop into one of many little tapas bars.

The most interesting part of Barcelona. When you have done all your touristic sightseeing, then put away the map and get lost in the quarter. We found quite interesting streets, bars, houses, churches, street musicians, etc. Leave the valuables in the hotel, then you do not have to worry about the pick-pocketing.
Gothic Quarter. Fantastic to see, beautiful architecture. Very enjoyable.
Nice streets for walking. You should hang out in Bari Gothic area. Walking inside the narrow streets is fantastic. You can see lot of boutiques and cafes around. This is the real Barcelona.
Lovely area!!. Great to wander around during the day and good restaurants and bars for nightlife!!!!
very good ...BUT. very good but late at night got a bit scary what with the pickpockets etc this is a big problem they have to get sorted..
Stinky. At 1 in the afternoon the streets smelled like pee.

get lost here. totally the best part of town for a sunday stroll
can happen upon the most random places - perfect
love the ancient buildings, you can just imagine artists and philosphers wandering about the place

Interesting but wet!. Unfortunately most of the shops were closed as we visited during the Easter period... and it was raining. I guess it would be completely different wandering around in sunshine and stopping off for the coffee and tapas outside. Will have to return....

Rich in history, architecture and cuisine. Tapas, tapas, tapas! Amazing food and cava! Gorgeous architecture from Roman walls to La Familia Sagrada. Walk, eat and drink your way through exploring this amazing neighborhood. Tip: eat and shop as far from La Rambla as possible. Definitely leave enough time to walk it but it is way overdeveloped and not as authentic of an experience.
Good atmosphere. Loved the musicians, dancers and slightly bohemian atmosphere

A 'must do' when in Barcelona. I get pleasantly lost every time I walk round the Barri Gotic which is great because I always discover something different, be it bars, restaurants or shops. The down side is finding these same places the next time I'm here!!!
H10 Montcada. Great location. Small rooms by USA standards but we weren´t in the room that often. Would stay here again.
Barcelona 2012. Very atmospheric areaof Barcelona. Lots of tourists, shops, things to see and eat.

Pick a random direction and just walk. The area has a wonderful feel to it. There are surprises around every corner. The area is bounded on all sides by major thoroughfares so you can't get too lost although you may get a little confused at times. I don't think there is much risk of wandering into a bad area as might be the case in some large cities.We stumbled on Plaza del Rei where Columbus is supposed to have reported back to Queen Isabella on what he did with her money in the new world. We wandered into a wonderful outdoor tapas restaurant in Placa Reial just west of Las Ramblas.Most of the fun was in just being there and looking around.
Area full of little streets and eateries. Lovely old area that is a joy to wander around. Go through all the little alleys as there are many things to be seen.

Historic. It was great to be able to wander along the narrow streets popping out from time to time into more major thoroughfares. We enjoy finding small bars and restaurants that are more locally authentic and away from the usual tourist traps. It's a great pity about the extensive grafiti which is everywhere

Interesting surprises around each corner. For those you like to stroll and let the streets surprise you rather than plan out your trips down to the minute, I recommending allocating a half-day or more to just walk the streets of the Gothic Quarter randomly. Let each block and turn you make surprise you with cafes, museums, history (roman ruins), Churches, shops, and potentially more risque things as well depending upon where/when you go. It was extremely safe and clean when I walked alone, although it was day-time when there were other walking around. Keep a map handy as the streets are not always in a grid pattern, so you can make a quick escape to a Metro stop or main street if needed. If you start at Placa Catalunya, it is all downhill through the quarter down to the water front where you can walk parallel to catch a subway ride back up to the Placa, hotels, etc.
Gorgeous. A fantastic place to amble around Barcelona, including walking into and around neighbouring El Born neighbourhood as well.

History, hot chocolate and tapas!. The shops, cafes and the streets have all been reborn! This was our 2nd visit after 20 years. The area used to be dirty and scary now it is full of chic shops and botique hotels and a lot of charm. It breathes history and culture.

The essence of Europe. An American, I went on a long journey through Europe, with Barcelona as my unexpected first stop. I loved the city, and walking through the gothic quarter was really just intoxicating; that feeling of being somewhere so exotic and different than where you are from. There were many tourists in the area, so it's not lonely and you don't feel too out of place, also there is a nice market, and plenty of great architecture. The old cathedral was being repaired and partly hidden by scaffolding, but its beauty still seeped through. This place is simply magical!
So cosy to have diner. Plenty of cosy restaurants. One of my favorite neighbourhoods in Barcelona because of the small streets and authentic atmosphere.

Great nightlife. Very cool pedestrian area in Barcelona. Tons of shops and restaurants to check out. Several nice cathedrals and pieces of the old roman wall to check out. Be sure to come by in the evening. The main Cathedral is free to enter then.
Barcelona backstreets. Gothic quarter is like the rest of Barcelona - cool, old, twisting streets and fabulous shops. Make sure you hit the attractions before siesta time.
Wonderful area to walk around, so many old buildings....shopping , flowers, .Never been anywhere quite like Barcelona in. The Rambla, The Cathedral , many museums., eateries, flower shops,
Interesting. Great for evening wanders. interesting architecture
Beautiful.. Architecture at it's best. So interesting with a wonderful atmosphere. Just look around and absorb the art and history: the Brighton Lanes Medieval, Gothic alter ego. .

a place to trace the ancient heart of modernist Barcelona. The Gothic quarter is a compact precinct to walk around and seek out the ancient heart of Barcelona. Barcelona is best known for assertive modernism, but it is also an ancient city. It is actually pre-Gothic: the Phoenicians, Carthaginians, and Romans were here – although distinguishing old stones from new ones in this area is a matter of heated scholarly and aesthetic debate. Much that looks old here was built in the 20th century, but the area is genuinely very old.Look at downtown Barcelona in a street map, Google Maps or Google Earth, and you might notice something you've seen before in other old cities – a rounded lobe-shaped warren of narrow streets and tiny squares right in the heart of the city, adjoining the port. The approximate boundaries are the popular tourist promenade of Las Ramblas in the west; Carrer de Fontanella in the north; Vía Laietana in the east; and the port in the south. These are "tree rings" marking the growth and outline of the oldest part of the city, the traces of long demolished ancient city walls and the layers of more than two thousand years of habitation, building and rebuilding.The area is only about 1.6km long and little more than 550m wide, so it is easy to walk around.What to do and see in the Gothic Quarter:• Barcelona Cathedral (a major sight in the Gothic tradition in its own right, with great views over the quarter from the roof);• The City History Museum of Barcelona in Palau Reial Mayor, former residence of the kings of Cataluña and Aragon, in Plaça del Rei (another significant sight in its own right);• Visit Plaça Sant Jaume in the centre of the quarter, where Casa de la Cuitat (Town Hall) and the Palau de la Generalitat (regional government offices) are located; and• Just wander around the narrow streets, following your instincts and curiosity, enjoying the random happenings and discoveries of the day.• Link your visit in the Gothic Quarter with nearby sights, such as Palau Güell and the St Joseph's Market, off Las Ramblas on the western side; the Palau de la Música Catalana, Museu Picasso and Church of Santa María del Mar which are just a few blocks east of the quarter; or, to the south, the Museu D'Història De Catalunya and the old harbour and yacht basin area, with its many bars and seafood restaurants.

Romans to Picasso the Gothic Quarter has it all!. The old city [ Gothic Quarter] was in the medieval period behind walls with entry gates. The names of the gates still remain. The Roman walls and a Roman Cemetery are there, as is Santa Maria del Pi which is an architectural wonder. The old streets and closed views to the sky which are in Picasso's early works are taken from his life here. The 4cats still serves good food and a copy of their original menu designed by Picasso is on display. There is the cathedral, St. Anne's church and cloister which is well worth the visit, many european shops such as H&M, and finally the Picasso Museum all in this small quadrant. Take a morning just to tour it and then come back later to really start seeing it.
Fantastic place to visit. This place is magical, great tapas restaurants, wine shops etc.

Getting lost and loving it!. Throw away your map, only if it is daytime, and wander to your heart's content. At any turn you might find an exquisite mini- altar to a neighborhood saint, subterranean remains of a 13th century Jewish synagogue, an archway of detailed Moorish design, a bike rental place owned by an American ex-pat, school children playing in a walled mini-park bearing pockmarks in the buildings of a long ago bombing, alleyways so narrow people can practically lean out their windows and touch their neighbors' hand across the street, a couple holding hands hurrying to the Cathedral. You won't see much sky, but you will marvel at unexpected wonders, curiosities, ancient stonework, and witness Barcelona's living history.

Favorite part of Barcelona. Getting lost in the Gothic Quarter was my favorite part of my honeymoon in Barcelona. We were so glad to see a city that appreciated it for what it is- art.

Our favorite part of the city!. We fell in love with the Gothic Quarter, ended up spending time there almost every day while in Barcelona.You can just walk around, shop, relax, eat, have coffee, tappas, wine - whatever. We took a Wine and Tappas walking tour one of our first days - it was extremely helpful. Not only did we learn the history of the Gothic Quarter, the Las Ramblas and other important sites within - we learned how to order tappas!There are several museums (Picasso and others) in this section of Barcelona - and it's expectionally easy to get around - we never once felt crowded or hustled.Also took a Fat Tire bike tour from the center of the Gothic Quarter - one of our highlights!And don't miss the Food Market - amazing!Great memories from the Gothis Quarter.... :-)

we lost there and we felt happy. I suggest to hide the map and just lose yourself in Barri Gotic.

Loved wandering round this place. I loved exploring all the winding streets with the hope of getting lost......this is unlikely to happen though as we seemed to keep stumbling across shops we recognised! I loved seeing the little shops and cafes/restaurants. TripAdvisor have a great half day tour round the gothic quarter or if you fancy like we did, just take a wander round.On the first night, we ended up at a restaurant that looked very enchanting from the outside. The smell of incense hit you when you walked past, the dark red interior looked very mysterious and intriguing, almost Moroccan/Turkish inspired. I wish I knew the name of the place so I could recommend people NOT to go there for food!!! We went in, the only people in there but then it was early. We went for the set menu and as we were choosing, realised we could see the chef in the kitchen.....something we wished we couldn't see. He was coughing all over the place, the kitchen didn't look appealing at all and I saw him put something in the microwave. It was then I realised why the set menu had been so cheap compared to the other restaurants.... Our starter came out, fried potatoes with a spicy sauce, what turned out to be a common tapas dish in Barcelona. However, it was nothing more than chip oily scrappings we could've got from a kebab shop in the UK - complete with sauce out a squeasy bottle. We ate what we could, the wine and beer were awful so we decided to leave. To avoid arguments, we offered to pay for the menu (15 euros each) just so we could get out of there. The waitress was shocked at us leaving. I'm not a food snob at all but I do have a limit with what is edible! If you happen to pass a restaurant which smells of incense - avoid at all costs!!We took a walk down for a meal one night and came across a lovely restaurant, best meal of the trip. 3 course meal with wine set us back 80 euros but it really was a lovely little place

Simply a Must See. In depth!!. If you don't roam around the streets of the Gothic Quarter you haven't been to Barcelona. Find the remains of the old walls of the city and once you find one part it has a map that tells you where to find the rest; it is a very interesting tour. Try and get lost because it is easy to find a way out afterwards, you'll be amazed how many charming and even magical little corners and squares you will find on the way.

a magnificent step in time. the old cathredral walls, cloisters, courtyard, roman towers, and coblestones make one's blood run cold with a sense of history and monumental events. one courtyard in particular begged for a beheading, and the cloister witht its pond, palms, and serenity was an absolute trip into the middle ages. nothing fake, nothing simulated, this is the old old stuff. limited access on monday unfortuately but lovely loneliness in february. we were away from the 21st century. then the quarter itself outside of the ancient places is full of shops, cafes, tapas, etc. a lovely side trip for us but one of our favorite memories.
