Lovely. Went to the Gothic Quarter and the christmas market was up and beautiful. Loved the feel of the small roads and old buildings. There were lots of lovely bars and cafe to explore as well as the cathedral
includes ancient cultures, and vitality of today. very significant old cathedral architectures, museums, including extensive Picasso, get a real feeling of Catalonia among the touring and party crowd
Worth walking around. interesting architecure and individual shops. Cathedral is undergoing restoration.
Expected more. Actully I expected more, something larger, more complex or so. The place is very clean as well as the whole city.
A must for those wanting to see the bast of Barcelona. A true surprise after the touristy La Rambla, we have enjoyed loosing ourselves in the small streets.

Busy. We loved the hustle and bustle of las rambles.
People everywhere, we were trying to look up to see the magnificent arcitechture, but it was difficult.
Loads to see and do, pop down a side street now and again, you can find lovely cafe's hidden away.
Atmospheric Gothic Quarter. Like walking in the middle ages with music and street performers. Visit the churches.

Beware the pickpocketers. Nice quartier to stroll, but have your belongings close to you and under constant control or you will leave our city with a bad story to tell.
Not saying you must avoid the quarter AT ALL, just be vigilant.
Check blog Robbed in Barcelona for details.
History Throughout. The architecture here is stunning. Well worth getting off the bus and having a wander around - you won't be disappointed!
Beautiful. Great to just walk around. Don't need to buy anything or go to any museum hence it's perfect for those like me who are very tight with their wallet.

Wonderful to wander. We spent many hours wandering through the Gothic Quarter taking slightly different routes each time over various days. There are so many hidden gems to find - just beware of the cars coming down lanes that don't look wide enough, it can be a challenge to get out of the way!

Like wandering back in time. A walking trip around the Barri Gotic igives you a fascinating insight life in Barcelona many hundreds of years ago. The narrow streets and full of beautiful buildings and pretty little plazas.

Wonderful Atmosphere. Just got back from a weekend stay in the Bari Gotic quarter. It was a facinating place to stay with something interesting to see around every corner and a wonderful atmosphere, especially at night when the place comes alive. I would recommend oyu avoid too much of the Ramblas (too touristy), and go and explore!

Barri Gothic Ambles. I loved walking about in Barri Gothic both during the daytime and in the evenings. The shops are fun to browse. Many good places to have a quick meal. The buildings are fascinating to look at. The museums are world-class. It is so nice to see people out and about in such a setting.

A must see. This Gothic quarter gives such an insight to the history of Barcelona. There is a cathedral and a basilica
both worth seeing. It is history at its best.

Atmospheric. I love to wander around the Gothic Quarter. Cobbled, narrow streets, full of great little boutiques, hidden bars and restaurants, it's a great place to spend a few idle hours. It's especially good in the evening, when it really seems to come to life!

A rainy day in Barcelona!. What to do when it rains? Go see the Picasso Museum in the Gothic Quarter. So many beautiful paintings, some of Picasso's first, delight the eye. Outside one walks through mysterious, narrow alley ways, visits Santa Maria Cathedral, which is so utterly beautiful, and feasts on Mediterranean food in fine restaurants. What more do you want from a visit to Catalunya?

Beautiful sights. Your camera will thank you for visiting the Barri Gotic. WIth The Church of Santa Maria del Pi, Plaça Sant Jaume, Plaça Reial, and Carrer del Bisbe Irurita, you cannot go wrong. I downloaded a free walking tour of Barcelona on my iPhone and it took us through the requisite sights and more.

Awesome history and architecture. Although I didn't follow any tour when visiting the gothic quarter with the aid of maps and brochures, I was able to learn about all the different areas of the quarter. Well worth a visit to the Barcelona museum as part of the day.
Relaxing boutiques restaurtants and more.. Great restaurants, boutiques, cafes museums and more. Really like the born district as it is the place to be when you visit barcelona.

Barri Gotic: Avant Garde!. We fell in love with Barri Gotic's narrow meandering alleys, where shop doors are covered with bright, artistic grafitti that could form the background for a fashion shoot. Up above, laundry hangs from some of the balconies, reminding us of West Side Story. Artists and fashion designers seem to be joining the many unique shops and restaurants. We loved this part of Barcelona, and kept being drawn back to it. Bring a camera!
DIFFERENT. Great buildings, awesome facades. facinating, colourful
Gothic Quarter. Would not go back in a hurry. Felt uneasy the whole time we were there as it is int he middle of Las Ramblas - a notorious have for pick pockets.
fantastic place to visit. great for walking around and finding new things around every corner x

so quaint, worth a stroll and a trip to the top of the church. Such a cute part of the city, i went at the end of the day, it was quiet and the light was fading. my pictures from the top of the cathedral are fantastic in this light, lovely little shops, very pretty, must visit!!!
like a labyrinth!. with all the tiny alleys and little shops you could easily get lost in this great place!
The Gothic quarter is lovely. Long winding alleyways full of shops, eateries and other interesting stuff
A must to see when in Barcelona. This is a wonderful part of the City - lots of interesting architecture, shops and restaurants !

Beautiful area!. This has to be one of the most beautiful areas from Barcelona. Very old and stylish and the atmosphere was great!
There's a ton of stuff to see here, lots of shops.
Downside is the huge amount of people selling stuff on the streets which after a while can become annoying.

The Heart of Barcelona. Wander the streets, get lost, and enjoy this wonderful neighborhood dating from the Middle Ages. Avoid mediodia when the shops are closed, as the shops are part of the attraction. Where is can you find a store that only sells hangers? Or hats? Or just one style of shoe (but in hundreds of colors)? Or masks? Or marionnettes? Yes, the neighborhood is filled with tourist shops, too, but it is not all bad to be able to buy some good gelato in every block!

Wonderful architecture and cute alleys of shops, tapa bars, and history. Love exploring. Be prepared to walk. Wear good walking shoes so you don't mind wandering and getting lst in this maze of streets and cobbled stone alleys of cute interesting shops, tapa bars, and pastry shops. The architecture is beautiful, and it's Loaded with history

Beautiful. Lovely area of narrow lanes and alleys. Lots of restaurants and shops. Sadly it is a bad city for pickpockets. Do not put wallets etc in pockets. Wear a shoulder bag with the bag in front and pockets zipped up.

beautiful. A beautiful old part of town... beautiful old streets and buildings ... to watch and admire ... a lot of small boutiques, local restaurants and cafes to relax and drink coffee. A beautiful night for a romantic walk.

Lovely!. Barcelona is beautifull town but Barri Gotic is the best part!Lot of nerrow streets,bars,restaurants arround Cathedral.We were 4 days in Barcelona and we didn't miss one day to visit BG again and again :)
Ineresting walkabout. Good area to visit with lots of quaint shops and a sense of character.

Was there at christmas. all of the belenes were just beautiful. We wandered for hours and saw the fresh mistletoe and moss. They are beautiful with so much emphasis on the nativity. It was just so much fun. Only wish we were there when the lights were lit, but we were too early
Just so interesting!. We just loved wandering these most enchanting laneways with their interesting bars shops and people
A trip to the past. Nice places, surprising spots, cute shops. An afternoon program that you will like.

Favorite neighborhood in Barcelona. Very strong sense of place here - steeped in hundreds of years of history, but also very alive both day and night with shopping venues, professional-grade street musicians, and countless eating & drinking places for the complete experience. Our favorite area in Barcelona, definitely.

too many tourists but still a must. Probably the most famous 'barrio' in BCN, it's the heart of the city and is the place to go. Shops, bars, restaurants and hotels are here in huge number, but also tourists. Don't miss: plaza del Pi with a small produce market and artists.
Loved it there!. Loved the sights, sounds, smells and taste of Barri Gotic. Great food and culture.
Nice walking in historic surrounding. We liked walking in the Barri Gotic. History all around you, although lots of tourists go around, one can always find a nice place of rest.

it's fun to get lost.. For an American looking to experience old European charm,
narrow little alleys, churches, cafes, etc. this is as good as it gets.

Fun to roam. This area is really cool. The alleyways are really narrow and you feel like you have gone back in time. At night it is really neat. Lots of people walking around so no need to feel unsafe.
Beautiful. Creepy but still fascinating, boheme atmosphere. Starts right behind the Rambla, or the harbor.

Medieval. One can really get the feeling that they are in medieval times while walking through the tight alleys that make up the Barri Gotic. Lots of little boutiques and a really nice are to spend half a day just walking around
the place to stay in Barcelona. Find a nice hotel in the quarter and then just walk around aimlessly for days (and nights). The whole quarter is one huge gallery of art, architecture and fine food.
Excellent. A must in Barcelona, you will love the atmosphere, the buildings and the place itself
Great Place to visit. Great place to feel Barcelona's architecture and its day to day life
nice. I like the breath of history and the painter market on the square
Beware gypsy pickpockets.. Gypsies attempting to pickpocket me put a dampener on the area. Watch out and tell them to get lost if they approach you.

A night time of joy. I think the Gothic quarter, and especially the markets at night time brings out an unique flavour of Barcelona.
There's something special when you have all the families descend into the markets to look at antiques, with the large Barcelona Gothic Cathedral as a backdrop. It's just one of those great flavours around.

Go there. Great place to wonder around, eat and drink.
Barcelona as it ones was. ... felt like in old movie.

great but felt neglected. think recession may be affecting how well populated and used this part of town is as many closed down places - although we were very off season, felt like so many other old european cities - has seen better days - but lots of intersting bits to look out for in the architecture and don't miss the cathedral and the geese in the cloisters

Must see for Barcelona. Lots of shops, beautiful old buildings with narrow streets. So many things to look at, don't forget to look up-some of the best features on a building are up higher than the first floor. Don't forget to take a map, it's easy to get lost here. The buildings are tall, so you can't often find a landmark.

Definitely take free walking tour!. I tooke the Barcelona Free Walking Tour, leaving from Travel Bar, and it was one of the best tours I've done. Our guide (who is Australian) was extremely knowledge, told stories very well and was hilarious! The tour is meant to be 2hrs, but it went for about 3. He gives a very good history of Spain/Catalunya! HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

Great to explore. Spend a day exploring the cute alleyways, shops and cafes. Relaxing and inspiring and you can chat with some great people in this area. The tourist trap pressure is off and the laid back welcoming atmosphere is on.
Don't miss it!. this is an old rambling series of corridors- lots to see and do for hours on end

Walking the Old City Maze. Don't miss out on spending time walking through Barri Gotic, especially if you are trying to find some sights listed in your guide book. The narrow, winding, crossing little streets have an intriguing array of shops, placas with bars and restaurants, churches and historic landmarks. The Cathedral was beautiful and the Roman square was a perfect rest stop. Try to schedule a night guitar concert at the church of Santa Maria del Pi for a special thrill.

Wander. Wander through the Barri Gotic and find old Barcelona. It makes for a fabulous day. The Picasso Museum, the shops, the churches. Everything is so close together you can wander this quarter and then go to the waterfront, and then find yourself once again on your way to a market.
Old town quaint in Barcelona. Get lost in Barrio Gotic and enjoy every bit of it. Lots of Cafes, Restaurants and you are never far away from the new city, it just feels like it
nice. there are some improvised markets of antiques there
Old meets New. A complicated series of streets / alleys with some amazing buildings yet housing some shops with everday items

Really Wanted to see this. And I wasn't disappointed. We visited in late Dec 2011/Jan 2012 for a few days and made several visits to the Gothic Quarter - every time found something different! The narrow passageways, quirky shops, boho district, little churches and big cathedral, cafes & bars, tapas bars (Venus is a really good one) were a fascination for me and a different tempo of Barcelona which of course is a city of several tempos & plenty going on. Loved the Bocqueria market & pretty square to the side of it. Even managed to find a specialised shop (Ingenio) which I had read about in a magazine. It was really special to see it for real. We have to do this again - soon!We felt safe enough walking about even after dark, but as always it pays to stay aware & take precautions to keep yourself safe from crime which could spoil your visit.
Could've spent more time here. We loved this area of town. It had small streets where we could get lost. We found a great family owned restaurant to hang out.
Get lost!. One of the most things about visiting Barcelona is wandering the Gothic Quarter and getting yourself lost. Find a bar or cafe on a darkened street and enjoy the ambiance!

A neighborhood with a beautiful style. You will like very much a walk in this neighborhood with the narrow streets and the buildings from an other era. You will find many attractive monuments with gargoyles and statues on the roofs
fun area to explore, lots of touristy stuff though. I would have liked to have taken a guided tour of this area to understand the area better & avoid some of the touristy shops

Interesting!. This is very interesting place to visit. There are a lot of narrow alley ways and I had a guide book so was able to find my way around a bit. I found some very interesting shops where you can browse and bought some souveniers. My son and I did the DIY tour initially and later joined one of the free walking tours - Runner bean tours.
Great for walking and discovering Barcelona. This is a great place to walk and see really old and conserve arquitecture.

Fun to explore. The Barri Gotic is delightful to explore on foot. You'll enjoy great people watching as well as interesting architecture and plenty of sites. We preferred staying in quieter Eixample, which is a short walk from the Barri Gotic.

Lovely Streets, Interesting Shops. We went to the archeological museum under the Cathedral Square and it was fascinating to see the evidence of the historical development of the city. It felt more real given our experience of the living city above. The Gothic Quarter has interesting architecture and lots of shops for everything from sausages, to toiletries, to craftwork, to clothing. We didn't feel very safe walking the streets at night though, and finding the restaurant we were looking for proved impossible.

amazing to walk through. The gothic quarter is probably the best area of Barcelona to walk through. Filled with fantastic, narrow alleys with lots of shops, tapas bar, small markets, impressive churches and buildings and lots of people everywhere, it is so lively. The best thing is to walk there and get lost for some time to discover new streets and new places to see!
Beautiful. Between the Gothic buildings and the Jamon stores, what is there not to love?

Amazing neighborhood!. Get lost in the beautiful streets of the gothic quarter! Lots of things to see, restaurants, shops, museums, churches, and amazingly beautiful buildings. One advice, be aware of pick pockets.
Labyrinth of Fun. Terrific to get lost in! Spend hours there...it will be worth it!
amazing sights around every corner. the Roman wall was one of the highlights of my strolls around this fascinating precinct.
Cozy Tapas Bars. Windy alley ways where you can easily get lost but might not mind with all the cozy shops and tapas bars you never run out of places to duck into.
Juts a Great Place To Wander. Shopping Restaurants and a lovely atmosphere just enjoy on foot

Charming but missable. I really enjoyed the other parts of Barcelona much more than the Barri Gotic. This area was run down, not too interesting, and has few attractions that are not tourism central. I recommend the newer parts of town for a true taste of Barcelona.
Loved this area. Picasso museum in the area, lovely. Lots of shops and stores, found am amazing shushi spot too

Awesome area to walk around and discover treasures. You will find little streets in this old part of town twisted and with so many stores, bars, old churches, cafes and lots of people, not just tourists, walking and enjoying the area.
Great sightseeing and people-watching!. The sense of history is palpable and you truly feel immersed in Barcelona's history!
Beautiful to walk around. Be aware of your surroundings and bring a good pair of walking shoes!
Less Traveled. Fewer people seen down these side streets. There are a number of small local shops where you can find true treasures not seen on Las Ramblas.

One of my favorite place to walk through!. The Gothic Quarter was definitely one of the neighborhoods I made sure I visited every day I was in Barcelona. The little shops and the architecture was just amazing. I fell in love with Barcelona when I visited the Barri Gotic!
Worth a walk around. Go to the cathedral after 5pm when entrance is free
Old city at it's best. The heart of all activity. Like stepping into the Middle Ages.

Great place to wander. Very beautiful buildings, full of history. Don't use a map, just wander, and wander, and wander... You will eventually arrive, but not before you know every corner of this fantastic place.
Just wonderful!. The architecture, the shopping, the food - what fun. could have stayed much, much longer.

I spent 8 days here. Out of the 12 in Barcelona, most were spent here. THis is an interesting place, especially I think for Americans/Australians.. people who are unused to medieval anything. The center, is extraordinarily crowded, and I come from New York. That should tell you something. I would definitely try to find out when OFF season is, and go then, but nevertheless, one does not go to a big city to escape people. Everyone wants to see the same things you do ! I liked the ancient streets, and stayed in apartments there. One of them had 90 steps to the apartment. ( who knew?) I was freaking out out one day when I had to do it three times.I liked that I could walk everywhere although it is easy to overdo...and I did not like that taxis couldn't come on those streets easily or private cars. If you have heavy suitcases, that's a consideration.I will say that some of them early morning are shockingly noisy if you have an apt facing the street, and late nights as well with rowdy tourists..so I would think carefully about staying there. Also, walking the isolated curly winding medieval ..almost alleys? If your instincts are telling you not to when it is ..say late, or early ? follow them. Dec 26 early morning (8:30) I took a short cut through them and saw what is probably a pretty typical theft in progress..it was jarring. The Gothic quarter has a very diff appeal from the others.

Dangerous by night. watch out for pick pockets. by day visit the Plaça Reial and the cathedral. by night avoid and if you must visit with only the money needed for the night, leave all cards, phones and other items of value behind.
atmospheric. Love to walk around this place with the tiny shops and the different architecture. Just different from main tourist roots.
Romantic and evocative. The Barri Gotic is transportive and exotic. Even when considered within the context of Europe, the architecture and conditions of this quarter are atmospheric and exciting.

loved it. this town is full of surprises, you feel on the air the artistic way,i loved the walks and enjoyed everything. definetely worths a walk to barri gotic.a visit to the past,wow! have a break on a cafe and just watch the buildings and the paths!

Fabulous place just to amble around.. Lots to see and do. I'm a beader, making jewellery from beads I pick up on my travels and Bari Gothic had a whole street of bead shops HEAVEN. Be aware of those around you as some streets are dark and I would imagine a pick pocket paradise. Don't eat at the first place you see as the tourist places are expensive ( 2 pizza's, 1 coffee and 1 glass of house wine cost us 45 euro's !!) Find eateries off the beaten track. Take time to wander and appreciate the surroundings. I LOVED it.

Beautiful old part of the city. Narrow winding streets, trendy cafes and boutiques, modern craft galleries all make this a great area of the city to wander through. It is also home to the Picasso Museum (located ina a beautiful old house) and some great tapas bars - plenty to see and do for a the whole day.
very nice. highly recommended for tourists
Nice walk. This was a relaxing walk through some lovely old buildings and cool little shops. It was easy to navigate through using the gps on our phone to get around to the different sights.
Loved it!. This is a cool place to walk around in. Architecture and history!

Atmospheric. Great to wander around, although its probably very crowded in summer and not so pleasant -we were there over Xmas. great museum of eccentric collector called Frederic Mares next to cathedral is worth a look.

guided walking tour with Travel Bar. Excellent architecture, atmosphere and historical interest. We walked with a Travel Bar guide (Duncan , a young Irishman) who was incredibly informative. So on this trip (they run most days at 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. and are featured on their Facebook page) we discovered the signifivcance of the city's relationship with such luminous figures as Christopher Columbus, Picasso, Miro, Dali, Gaudi, Ernest Hemingway and George Orwell and were shown scenes where they socialised. we also found out about the relationship between Catalan Barcelona and the rest of Spain and also something about the Spanish Civil War. Excellent value, travellers merely tip the guide whatever they feel the tour was worth !

Wonderful place. I loved the Gothic Quarter from the minute I got into it. It really gives you an idea of how a town looked in medieval times with its narrow streets and beautiful old buildings. Most of these streets are packed with tourists and, as I hear, pickpockets, though I have not encountered any during my stay in Barcelona. But one might easily get lost in Gothic Quarter
Good atmosphere. Going back to Barcelona I still think this area is the nicest area for an evening walk.
Took my breath away. I fell in love. So much history, absolutely amazing!!!!! (Despite walking into a tramp urinating)
a must see. its beautiful,the architecture and the foliage were very lovely

Great but a bit dangerous.. It is cool and authentic. The small shops and restaurants are great but the streets are narrow and it gets too much when there are thousands of tourists. The pickpockets are a huge problem! You need to be alert in order to enjoy it!
Good. We enjoyed this area. Spent a whole afternoon exploring this area and admiring the buildings.

cobbled streets....smaller than i expected-good ice cream. was a little disappointed by the old town but as was smaller that i had hoped so not that many restaurants et etc, in fact i don't think we ate in ant in that area in the end. It is cute though, cobbled streets with ice-cream shops everywhere so definitely worth a visit.
Very interesting. Great place to walk around in. I did a bicycle ride and loved it. Amazing architecture to take in and a photographers delight.

Just walk around and get lost. Great area to stay and walk around to take in the architecture, culture, Tapas and Sangria.
Enjoy.
Great shopping. Great shopping possibilities, for as long as you avoid the Ramblas-end of the area. Get lost in the narrow side streets and you'll find more unique shops and bars.
Great to explore!. Saw this area on a tour and it was fasinating! Later we went back many times to explore and expore more, a fun place!
day, night, anytime it s great. great food, galleries, shopping all around. good barcelona vibe.

get lost in medieval times. it's easy the get lost in all the little streets and squares but in my opinion that 's the whole idea of this dark and cosy part of the city. interesting shops, good food, beautiful churches...
a must. strolling the quarter and finding the oldest synagoge of europe is an touching experience in the Call area of the quarter

Wonderful part of Barcelona. Just wander and soak up the atmosphere, especially at night. The area is full of places to eat, bars, and numerous shops. Felt totally safe and busy early evening.
Narrow streets sometimes the width of just a few people, few cars, full of history, with museums and churches.
Just wander and let yourself immerse in it all.
The Gothic Area. Wonderful area to stroll around either by day or in the evening. Some nice restaurants to try.
Fun!. Just walk around the small streets and at night there are many places to go out and eat!

Enjoy it day and night. We were there at the end of November and Christmas market in front of the Barcelona Cathedral was just starting. Very lively and busy at the market. The Gothic quarter was crowded as well but, it was nice and quiet before 9am. It was nice to wonder around and get lost with a cup of cafe in the morning. Gothic quarter in the evening had whole different atmosphere. It was very romantic. Day and night, you can hear live music and singing from every corner. One day we did self guided tour visiting Placa Nova(Christmas market in front of the Cathedral), Cathedral(many works were undergoing), Placa de sant Felipe Neri(you can still see some bomb damage on the wall from civil war), Casa de l'Ardiaca(Deacon's house, don't miss the post box with doves and turtles in front of the building. small courtyard and upstairs terrace are nice and quiet), Temple d'Augustus(you can see Roman pillars), Placa del Rei, Placa de Sant Just, Pati de Llimona, Roman walls. We had couple of nice cafe and sweets at Meson del Cafe on Carrer de la Liibreteria. It was a charming old cafe. Also, I bought some Jamon Iberico at the local meat shop on Carrer de la Ciutat and got a fresh baguette from the bakery right next to the meat shop.
A nice walk from the Ramblas. This is a very unique part of the city. We enjoyed beer and wine at a bodega at a very reasonable cost. We enjoyed looking in the few antique store we found.

Old World atmosphere. All the streets in the Gothic area are narrow, dark and full of character. During the day it's a very busy place, lots of small hidden restaurants and bars, people milling around doing their shopping, everyone looking up at all the fantastic architecture and you get the feeling of being back in the middle ages just strolling around. At night it's a different world, I would not walk there on my own. Unfortunately prostitution has taken over in some areas of Barcelona at night time, and this is one.
Wonder around the streets. A lot to see and do, great buildings, food and little shops. Definitely worth wondering around the streets for a day or two.
My favorite part of Barcelona!. Quaint lanes and squares make for wonderful surprises and discoveries. There are great little restaurants and hip l boutiques.
"Must see". This is a "must see" in Barcelona, but you need a good guide book to know what you're seeing

Beautiful place for a day out. Really great area to just walk around the little streets to see what you can find. Some areas are a bit too touristy but there are a lot of good local shops where you can pick up a bargain.
Heart of the city. An eclectic collection of architecture with wonderful hidden squares with atmospheric bars and restaurants.

vibrant!. what can i say that will do it justice? We stayed in the heart of the gothic quarter and it was just fabulous - loads to see and do. Yes, there is the problem of pickpocketing and opportunistic theft - but there is in any city. If you are savvy and aware of your belongings, you will have a great time.

A truely great area to stay. We did not know anything about the Barri Gothic area of Spain before our trip to Barcelona. It is one of the older areas of the city and a true treasure trove of small streets that contained a lot of cafe's and shops to 'trap' you in the area. the whole area is full to the brim with history, you walk down a lot of the streets, and can not help but think who else had walked these streets before, one of course was Christopher Columbus. I would highly reconmend this area to stay.
Good restaurants in interesting quarter. Enjoyed touring this area by foot. Many good restaurants.

A Great Place to Wonder. This is an ancient place with narrow streets that house the new and old shops that are uniquely Spanish. There are shops that have been there for centuries, one specifically charming that sells typical straw sandals that Spaniards have been using for centuries. The presentation of the stock in the shops is done with originality and creativity so one feels that they like to go into all of them. Additionally, there are scores of tapas bars, champagne bars, and cafes where one can rest and people watch.. its really one of the best ways to spend an entire day or evening in Barcelona
A trip back in time in the Gothic Quarter. A beautiful part of the city with the cathedral providing a stunning centre piece well worth seeing during the day and night.

Perfect place to stay. We stayed in the Barri Gotic and we're glad we did. It was close to all of the tourist areas without being smack in the middle of it. Everything was within walking distance; food, sites, shopping!

A new discovery around every corner.. We walked the Gothic Quarter for hours, finding little shops & restaurants in the most out of the way places. We had a great time. If you can find someone familiar with the area, that's even better.
Sunday Gothic. Full of essential little squares with leafy cafes, reasonable tapas no cars.
Great atmosphere. Catherdal, Palau de Musica and a lovely restaurant called CHEESEME - ideal for lovers of cheese, everything cooked with a multitude of varietoes of cheese.
Wander for hours. This is such a lovely part of the city. Wander around during the day and discover so many lovely restaurants, shops and markets. Not to be missed!

Magical moments. Wandering these narrow streets and alleys by night bestowed a magical sense of medieval mystery and delight. Here's where you'll also find the best tapas bars in town, particularly close to the cathedral.

Can go there everyday. Lively place, walking around and watching all the people shopping for CTX, to get lost in the narrow lanes and listen to the music in the building corners. Having "cortado" or "cerveca" in the bars.
Lovely oldie worldie. Love this area, full of gorgeous buildings, and oldie worldie charm, a strong smell of urine tho,
Interesting. Nice scenery and buildings to appreciate but shopping is lousy, just the run of the mill type merchandise.
Great history. Really enjoyed a 2.5 hour walking tour to get some very interesting history
Great Gothic quarter. I am an art historian who studies medieval and early renaissance art. Much of the city is modern, and this is wonderfully old with narrow streets, churches, and a cathedral.

Go ahead...get lost!. You simply can't go wrong. Take a left OR a right, or even go straight an you're bound to stumble on. Good tapas bar, clothing shop, museum, shoe store,etc. Before too long you are bound to see the big M indicating a metro stop in case your feet are starting to fail you. Be aware that Barcelona is definitely a city for walking and walking and eating and walkin!
Whateeeever. All of Barcelona feels/looks like this area. Nothing special, IMO.
You can spend the whole day here. Don´t miss the small synagoue in the Call Mayor and all the small shops, galleries and familly restaurants
Gothic quarter. Interesting area, much to see and easilly accessible from the hotel

HIstoric architecture. The most interesting part of Barcelona. A network of small narrow streets with interesting shops and bars. The main cathedral and public buildings. The Plaza Real. Great atmosphere and history. Best on Good Friday when the procession comes through after the blessing at the cathedral.
Fascinating. Take a good look at the shops, some bargains to be had here
Architecture!!. Amazing buildings. Great little neighborhood. Lots of people. Great food. During Fiesta La Merce there was lots to do.

wow on every turn. we loved this area. one minute your the only people on narrow streets, then with the next turn we were in the bustleing square outside the cathedral. Pop in to one of the small deli s, bought 100g of ham, then bought fresh bread. made sandwich and soaked up the atmosphere. Beautiful!
Greak for a walk. Get lost in this quarter. Imagine it many centurys ago. Walk arround and see the musicians in the streets the shops. Just walk arround

Beautiful and Elegant. Historic, but fresh, with beautiful shops and coffee and cake houses. Interesting buildings, iron work, wall tiling in narrow streets. But also by Santa Maria Church a beautiful square.

Lovely. This area holds character with it's great old buildings. The Gothic Catherdral is worth a visit to view it's art work. Pablo Picasso paintings hang in a gallery in a little side street. There's lots of little resturants and cafe's which we found reasonable.
Mysterious. Getting lost in these tiny streets is what I want to do all day every day in Barcelona. Each one hides a new wonderful experience. Very romantic!
Very commercial. We were disappointed because it was too commercial with retail shops all over.

Enchanting. This was the first trip my husband and I took without our children, they are grown now. What a perfect place to spend together. The Gothic Quarter felt romantic,exciting and felt very safe day and night. There 's many places to shop,eat or just people watch. What a place,I could just feel the history. Loved it and all of Barcelona. Yolandanola
Great area to wander. Lots of interesting buildings and cafes. Try the cava sangria near the Cathedral:)
Be careful. Some bits were scarey, but on the whole it was worth visiting

Old Europe Feel. When looking back at my pictures of this neighborhood, it feels like I'm looking back hundreds of years ago. It was so fun to travel to another time and feel intimate with the city in the small alleyways. Not to mention as much shopping as you could want!
Very special. very unique, nice atmosphere, nice shops.Very crowded on Saturday night
Great to wander around. Check times carefully and you might get in for nothing. Lovely area to wander around and lots ot retaurants with great value menu del dia

Calm & Relaxing. I never stay out late when I am on holiday alone but Barcelona is an exception. I walked around for hours and felt the night was too short. It’s such calm and relaxing place... normally I hate when I get lost in a strange city but I did loose myself in Gothic quarter on purpose because every time I got lost I discovered something new and interesting, the adventure seemed never end....

lovely area. My other half loves the gothic era so we spent half a day wondering around this beautiful area, lots to see, lovely tapas restaurants and bars, I managed to get some beautiful photos here.

Wonderful Christmas Fair !. We only had one full day in the city so we headed over to the Gothic Cathedral as it's a really nice part of the city. It was the first day of the Fira Santa Llucia which was great. There were lots of stalls selling Christmas items in particular nativity figures and stables. Basically you can customize your own nativity with fountains, lights, animals - anything you like. I hand carried my wooden stable on the plane as it wouldn't have lasted in a suitcase. I'll be going back again to get even more. It's just so lovely and atmospheric !

Get lost. Just dive in and drift you might find something you enjoy and then you might not. I havent found a map the would be useful to orientate with and what existed today closes and disapears or opens elsewhere. Not the place to go late at night.
Great area to stroll through. Picasso museum is well worth a visit. Surrounding streets very picturesque.
Stroll the streets of this unique city. Aimlessly wandering through the streets of Barcelona is near the top of the let of things to do in this great city.
Amazing architecture. Amazing architecture, Awesome views, rich in history, just amazing!

nice walk. it was raining when i had chance to walk around the gothic quarter. that was too bad since i would have wanted to stroll more. i saw a biscuit/candy store which i thought i could go back to but did not get chance again.

Beautiful to wander the streets. The best part of the city ... apart from the larger buildings that the tourist buses stop at, wander the streets and stop in at the little bars and shops. A must do but beware the reasonably obvious shops targeting tourists for a quick scam.

Favourite place. This is one of my favourite areas of Barcelona. The winding streets hide some hidden gems in terms of restaurants, shops etc. Part of the of the fun is getting lost down down the narrow streets as you never know what you might stumble across. A must visit

great entertainment.... be aware that there are lot of people are smoking grass... but there are a lot of things to see and look for! go at the day light time, when you can see a lot of beautiful things

Feels like Italy. This area gave you a feeling of being in Italy (Venice) as the alleyways turn in all different directions, and you round a corner and end up in a wonderful courtyard with restuarants all around. Lots of fun to get lost in!

You just have to see it!. Hi! Just wanna say, look not only to yor left or right,look also up and down!!! There are so many beautiful decor and statues everywhere!!! For people who like architect Barcelona is heaven!)))

Great place to walk. Like much of Spain, this is a great area to just walk around with no destination in mind. I would give it 5 stars if I hadn't gone to Sevilla and Granada before. I could spend days wandering those cities aimlessly, but Barcelona's gothic quarter is nice as well.

Great for Strolling. This intriguing maze of streets is easily accessible from the Hop On, Hop Off bus stop. There are plenty of wonderful little shops. Don't miss the Picasso Museum. You may have to ask someone because it isn't well-marked.

Changing fast. Barri Gotic used to be a great neighborhood with lots of artisans and crafts people working in their studios. Now all the artisans have been replaced by cheesy, expensive tourist shops selling shoes and cheap jewelry.
Loved it. So many little streets and alleys, something new around every corner...so much fun.
Amazing buildings everywhere. Never have seen so many imaginative surfaces and exterior treatments so closely packed together. Wonderful food shops, bakeries, markets scattered along the way.

Unbelievably beautiful!. The Barri Gótic reminds me of Bairro Alto in Lisbon. I know that those tiny and endless streets can be hard to figure out but for us - used to Bairro Alto - the confusing streets turned out to be familiar. Everything is small but huge at the same time. There you can breathe centuries and centuries of History! Barri Gótic is magical, is another Barcelona inside the contemporary Barcelona. You have all you want and need there: monuments, bars, restaurants, hotels, hostels, shops, etc. You will be enchanted by this area, it is so inspiring. I loved when we saw a crew of b-boys dancing in this old area, it was like mixing this comtemporary urban culture with the History ambience that this area offers you. Perfect!
Like a Fairyland. Delicious restaurants, bars, shops with narrow and quaint streets. Absolutely beautiful area of Barcelona.
Sightseers paradise. There are numerous squares, boutique shops and catherdrals hidden away for you to explore. This city has so much charm and character.

Favorite place in Barcelona. The streets are old and very gothic. You have to visit the Picaso museum. His artwork starts at about age 12 and shows his progression. The entire area is very cool with great little shops and places to eat.
Barri Gothic. Get lost in the heart of Barcelona - shopping, cafe's and great people watching abound - be careful of beggars and pick pockets.
Unmissable. Wonderful area, gothic, heaving with history. Small shops, lots of patisseries, lovely unexpected squares, my favourite place in Barcelona.
Confusing streets!. The area is beautiful but very easy to get lost in. The old ruins are facsiintaing. The street musicians added a nice ambience.
Medieval charm. Nice change from the posh surroundings of Passeo de Gracia. Narrow medieval streets, beautiful architecture and interesting shops, cafes, restaurants and bars.

Lots of shopping. You have to wonder around here if you are in Barcelona. The area is mostly a lot of shops, bars and restaurants now but there are many unique little places. Very lively in the evening.

European Charm. I feel like Barri Gotic is the quintessential european walking tour that Americans are looking for. Narrow crooked streets. Very old buildings. Cool and odd shops and markets all over the place. We loved it.

Barri Gothic. This is like a tourist wonderland with beautiful little lanes filled with Ancient Buildings and interesting little stores. Try to follow an tour map so you see all the quirky Buildings located in this Area. It ii wonderful to walk through during day and night

restaurents. the restaurants in this area were lovely food good service great.
do not get cought out by the back street ones, as we did on our first night.

Barri Majic. If you really want to dive into another world visit the Barri Gotic. It's just if you'd turned back time and returned to the middle ages, but you still have all the amenities the civilazation has to offer. Stroll around the winged roads, find your own perfect places and visit some of its amazing museums and public palaces, including the Ajuntament (City Hall). And if you're lucky enough you may find some Catalans (and tourists) dancing the sardanas. Best time of the year: around St Jordi's fiestas, the patron saint of Catalunya

Great area to explore!. There are a bunch of historic sights and cool restaurants and shops in this area. It's definitely worth exploring. We walked around this maze of streets our first day there and found some great cafes, bars, etc.

Interesting!. A fastinating, yet hard to figure out, part of otwn. We were lucky to do it with a tour company, otherwise we would have walked right past most of the places and not even known what we were looking at. its a beautiful part of town in the morning and at night!
Interesting place. This is a quieter place in the city with beautiful buildings and streets. The cathedral is a must see - the architecture inside is breathtaking!

Wander around...enjoy a cafe!. My daughter and I wandered around, had lunch in a little courtyard cafe and just walked down little streets. Also visited the cathedral, which she loved...swans were a big hit! Get lost and have fun!
very atmospheric. lots of character and wonderful seedy little bars with great ambience

Wear comfortable shoes!. We spent hours and hours getting lost in the winding alleyways and streets of the Barri Gotic. Great restaurants and shops, if you're looking for that - but if you're into photography, this area will keep you busy all day! The only bad thing I can say is that bathrooms are incredibly hard to find - avoid beer! ;)

Grab you walking shoes. Here you will need good walking shoes as this entire area is not handicap friendly and the cobble stones will quickly trip up heels. This is a great place to pocket your guide book and just let the intrigue of the narrow winding lanes beckon to your curiosity. The Romans were here and some of their walls and towers are still standing and incorporated into buildings. We thoroughly enjoyed walking about this area and “discovering” the remaining 2000 year old columns of the Temple of Augustus. And once you are exploring the Cathedral and its adjoining cloister courtyards, take time away from listening to the geese and the small fountain of St George to look down at your feet. You are walking on the tombstones of some of Barcelona’s early leading families. Several days a week there is an outdoor market in front of the Cathedral and on Saturdays at 12 noon you can see the intricate footsteps of the Sardana dancers. As you walk about, you will hear musicians playing in various courtyards---stop, relax and enjoy. But make sure you toss in some euros for the entertainment. Finally, while walking about this delightful area, try to find Casa de l’Ardiaca. If it is open, walk into the courtyard and up the stairs to the open second floor. And on you way out, look for the marble sculpture of swallows and a turtle designed by Lluis Montaner who conceived of the Music Palace.

Nice for a stroll. Reminded me of Camden Market - lots of shops for younger people and some chains (Body Shop etc). Lovely, narrow lanes; the old Barcelona. Bit creepy at night though so take care (also lots of rubbish). Went for dinner at one of the restaurants recommended in a guide book - terrible. Choose your eating place carefully as those with 'atmosphere' can be short on quality.
nice place. to see the old barcelona cathedral and other building
Wonderful!. We stayed in the Barri Gothic. Loved it! Will definately return again. Lots of beautiful buildings and history.
beautiful and must visit site. just wander aimlessly in these streets and admire the gothic architecture everywhere...
Atmospheric alleys. Loved wandering through the alleys of this quarter. Labyrinth of narrow alleys that take u back in time.
Beautifull old town. You will enjoy walks, restaurants and shoping in this area. Lovely atmosphere...
Really interesting area. If you like mooching around back alleys for cafes, bars then this is the place for you

Lots of lovely little restaurants and tapas bars. This seems to be the oldest part of Barcelona, with parts dating back to Roman times. There are some great little tapas bars and restaurants that have an authentic Catalan 'feel' to them. ITs quite a contrast to the Gaudi eccenricity, being more typical Mediterranean medieval. Great place!

Nice atmosphere, great shopping!!. I always visit the gothic quarter when I go to Barcelona. The narrow streets are always full with people, lined with small shops and restaurants. Lost of very unique, very reasonably-priced merchandise.!! Highly recommend!!
A fascinating walk into the past.. An area of Barcelona occupied continuously since Roman times.
Great fun exploring. It was really enjoyable wandering through the small streets and winding paths. We didn't manage to fit it going at night but that would have been fantastic.

Cathedral and area around. It is absolutely fantastic both during the day and at night.MUST do when you're in Barcelona. Coming back from a restaurant after midnight, there was this classic guitar player on one of the super narrow little alleys around the cathedral, he was playing a classical Segovia piece and the accoustics in the open air space were out of this world... A memory that will stay with us forever.
Something going on everywhere. This a great area for wondering around and finding places to eat and drink and just relax,

Just have a stroll around. Inside our Barcelona guide we had some routes for walking. We used the one to discover the gothic quarter. We saw nice local streets where you normally won't come. Squares and churches. We didn't visit any but you can if you like. Juest take a map and stroll around in this area, get 'lost' and you will see the real barcelona.
Interesting small streets and restaurants. Liked the tapas and pinchos. Disliked the Ramblas, hold on to your wallet/bag!

Barri Gotic worth a stroll!. Fun tapas bars, wine bars, the Picasso museum, and many othe sights. It gets crowded on weekends, and we were told by Catalan friends to watch out for pickpockets, but we had no problems whatsoever there.
The Picasso Museum is not to be missed.
Great food and history. We stayed in the heart of the Gothic Quarter, which had a very energetic vibe with great restaurants, shopping and bars.
Shopping and great eats. nice area to walk around and enjoy the local flare. Be careful with your bags of course but enjoy walking the small streets and boutique shopping
fantastic visit. Great! and different visit, explaining the locations, culture and language
must visit!. Historic and a must see when you visit Barcelona! Careful, gets very crowded all year round.
Quaint. loved walking around the narrow alleys ...full of character....interesting shops. The Placa Saint Jaume, Placa Reial, the Cathedral all were great places to roam around ...
Just Get Lost. Roam the Gothic Quarter and then settle in for a nice fruit drink at La Boqueria.
Loved this area!. We saw this area via a tour, which is the best way because it really comes to life that way! We were amazed by the Roman walls, ruins, old 15th cent buildings and plazas!!
beautiful area. great to walk around the small streets, nice shops and places to eat

Loved the area. I loved the area. Good walk and lots to appreciate - both sights and food. Everything seems to congregate around the church and not easy to lose your way. A number of tourist information counters to ask around if you need help.
explore and you will love it. look around at every building and you will be mesmerized, enjoy every bit of it walk around and explore

Narrow little streets that go from one century to another like a flowing stream.. The colors and artistry of the shop displays are like Gaudi's mosaics. Little markets that spring out at you, a wealth and variety of eateries. Clothing shops that are original and diverse. Music filtering through everywhere. The churches and facades all blend together in a sumptuous meal for the eyes.
Loved it. The architechture was awesome, the restaurants and shops perfect, the artists impressive, the sites well worth finding your way through, and you won't be disappointed.

Ancient buildings and great night life!. The Gothic quarter is a fascinating place to walk around, as you see a complete mixture of old and new. The cathedral is immense and worth seeing if you like that sort of thing. There are street performers in the squares and you are surrounded by small shops and restaurants. Seeing the underground ruins was very interesting and worth seeing. There are some really good restaurants all around you and we even found a couple of jazz clubs that we loved. You do have to look hard as most are hidden in the tiny alleys. Just be aware that nobody even thinks about dinner before 8-8.30pm.It is a great place to visit.

Hidden Barcelona. This is just off of Las Ramblas and offers a vast array of bars and tapas restaurants. These are also great value as they are cheaper than the touristy places on Las Ramblas. It is the old part of town and is quite compact and you definately get a feel for the gothic architecture of the cathedral as well as the narrow pedestrian only streets with a number of shops and exciting avenues to explore.
A Great Place to Stroll. It is really very Gothic, and quaint. We enjoyed strolling through the many small streets

Anywhere you look is a picture!!. This whole area was my favorite place to see in Barcelona. Food from all over the world, pretty outdoor cafes, great shopping. Beautiful buildings to see. Just grab your camera and an appetite and you will be happy!
very historic. lots of people and pedestrian traffic, excellent area

Charming. Great for a wander, for something to eat or a bit of shopping. The streets are really charming and have loads of character. Easy to lose your orientation so best to have a detailed map with you!

Walking tour. Take the walking tour at 10am for English version, get 30% discount with voucher in discount book received on tour bus. Guide excellent, 2 hrs perfect for stroll after breakfast, meet at City Hall tourist info office

A fun area to cruise around. Just do not stick to Las Ramblas . The streets just off it are far far nicer particularly if you head off towards Born. El Raval on the south side is more gritty but there are great bars and places to hang out. It is safer than most other world cities so explore.............go off the beaten track. It is very hard to get lost for long
Gothic Quarter. Lovely to spend a morning/afternoon. Great atmosphere... lots of places for drinks/food... historic and interesting.
Great Architecture. Take the Runner Bean Walking Tour to get an informative and thorough tour of the gothic quarter
Step back in time. A great way to experience the history of Bacelona away from the hustle and bustle of the modern day La Rambla.
Have to be there. It was great to walk around amongst all the people and see the different shops. Around each corner was something different!

Wonderful strolling area. This was my favorite area in Barcelona. We strolled thru the little pedestrian byways which opened into beautiful little courtyards. Lots of little shops to browse. We ate Tapas in an outside courtyard with street music playing- wondeful day.
Ride the Trixie. The Trixie is a 3 wheeled pedi-cab...hire one and ride thru those magnificent ancient streets and absorb the culture of Catalonia!!
Interesting. Narrow passages, great cathedral, wonderful architecture.
fun area. Wonderful area to wander with shopping, attractions, cafes; just a fun place to hang out.

Wonderful atmosphere, day and night. Many interesting sites - the Cathedral, the city's archive and museum.
The only downside is that it is toooo crowded...
Fantastic area to explore. Loved the little streets, and individual shops. Wandered round and round both during the day and night times. Have the blisters to prove it!
Wonderful for shopping!. Just amazing shops and little allys or streets. Full of character and great for everyone!
The Cathedral. Enjoyed the visti to the Cathedral especially when Mass was in progress. It was truly a magnificient building.
Most interesting area. Windy streets, very atmospheric! The church is stunning. La Rambla is a bit overrated; hawkers everywhere trying to sell you stupid stuff.

Fabulous !! Just wander through it and take it all in.... We simply wandered through the streets and did not study the map to find where we were. This way we simply stumbled upon surprise after surprise !
Visit also in the evening. There is a lot of things going on, have a stroll around and you may listen to opera singers, jazz bands, pianists, great athmopshere.

Barrio Gotico. Get lost in the streets, find a cafe you like and stop for a beverage, and try to not use your map.
Stroll over to Born/Ribera and find quaint shops
Ava Maria in the Cathedral. We were fortunate to arrive to tour the Cathedral while young magnificent men with operatic voices were singing the Ava Maria

Barcelona's historic quarter. The Barri Gotic is not to be missed when in Barcelona. The winding and sometimes narrow streets abound with incredible architecture and beauty. The Cathedral is definitely worth a visit. We were fortunate to be there on a Sunday evening and hear an amazing vocalist singing within the Cathedral. Be sure to stop for a drink and/or dinner at 4Gats (Quatro Gatos) and experience the haunt of influential artists and thinkers of the early 20th century. Picasso had the first exhibition of his art in this beautiful space.

The Gothic Quarter Has Plenty of Atmosphere. First we start with the Cathedral. The façade has recently been cleaned and it looks very good now. The cloisters are beautiful. They are still working to restore the interior of the church. There is a Cathedral Museum that is quite good, although you have to go up many steps because there are so many levels. Plenty of art work in this museum. There is a Neo-Gothic bridge on Bisbe Street that calls attention because it passes over the narrow street and yet the bridge is covered with a structure that looks like part of a Cathedral, with its pointed arch windows. There is a wonderful museum called the Frederic Mares Museum that has plenty of Gothic art. I saw so many large sculptures of Christ on the crucifix hanging on the walls of the museum. The Church of Santa Maria del Mar is a wonderful Gothic church. It is too bad that the retables of the chapels were destroyed during the Spanish Civil War.Another wonderful museum is the small Barbier-Mueller Museum of Precolumbian Art, showing art of the Inca Trail of South America. Opposite it is the famous Picasso Museum. The Gothic Quarter is filled with beautiful old buildings that have reached our time and are still in use. This is really amazing.
Charming and intriguing. Easy to get lost in it but charming and fun none the less. Easy to find a good restaurrant-there are so many!Thankfully was not bothered or a victim of the petty thieves

More interesting than La Rambla.. Lots of little shops and with more character than La Rambla. Watch out for pick pockets, especially in small shops. We had a close call in a scarf shop where the trick is to hide what they are trying to do under the scarves so that you don't notice hands opening your bag!

Just walk around and explore. The is a really neat area. You really just have to walk around and explore. You can round a corner and find a courtyard with old architecture and very old cathedrals and churches. You can find all sorts of shops and restaurants as well. The atmosphere is just really neat.

I go here every time I am in Barcelona!. Old, old, old! Take pictures of the cobble stone streets upto the gargoyle downspouts on the roof. This place is magical and you will feel like you stepped back in time. Spanish restaurants, street performers, outdoor market, and fresh produce is everywhere in Barri Gotic, and my favorite place to shop for Spanish items to take home. Many of the churches here are free to come in and see the religous history and take pictures. But be respectful, they are often having a service. Beautiful history.
Las Ramblas. Las Ramblas, can't see what all the fuss about it is

Fascinating history. Booked this 2 hour walking tour prior to departure and loved it. Sunday morning was quiet, our guide Oliver spoke perfect English and wore a microphone (we had amps to pick up sound). Really recommend this!
Gothic Beauty.. Such a joy to wander around the area. The balconies are amazing and must have some great stories to tell! Take time to walk talk stand and stare!
Spooky and fun. For readers of Shadow of the Wind - a must see area.

Lose yourself in history. There is a magic in losing yourself in the narrow back streets that make up the gothic quarter. Close your eyes and imagine all of humanity who have inhabited the streets as you walk through them. Sit at a table and soak up the culture while people watching. Absolute magic! Do however be vigilant that you don't fall foul of the local pickpockets.
Wow. The Gothic quarter took me back in time! Beautyful builings, nice small shops/cafe/bars. Well worth a visit!
Busy but beautiful. Even in October, the narrow streets were very crowded making it difficult to really enjoy a walk-through. However, it was a beautiful part of town and worth the visit.

Fun Maze of Streets. This area was great! There was plenty to see, although I often didn't know exactly what I was looking at (it may be best to take a tour book with you). The Barcelona Cathedral was amazing and free, and there were locals doing a traditional dance in the square!

Lose an afternoon wandering the narrow streets. Half a day just disappears when wandering around here. Feet getting tired just thinking about it? Sit down at one of the plentiful cafes and watch the world go by.

noisy. this is where i stayed. there is always something going on here . there are great shops, restaurants and quaint little alley ways that lead onto the rambles and other great areas. a must visit.
fabulous architecture. roam at leisure, round every corner will be a new place to explore, quirky shops, excellent restaurants and street entertainers.

a must see. great area to wander the streets. very interesting buildings with a lot of
character.
Interesting piece of history. Enjoyed the eccentricity of gothic architecture but easy to get lost from street to street
Delightful old Spain. Certainly not as charming as all of Sevilla, nor Madrid; still exudes old world charm.
great to walk around. nice to wander and have lunch or dinner, very atmospheric.

A great area to wander and explore-great atmosphere. Lovely area, beautiful buildings, interesting histor, I loved wandering about here and taking it all in. There are remains of roman walls, some nice museums and the lovely cathedral-worth a look and the lift to the top for 2 euros has lovely views.
Lovely. Beatiful area with the lovely cathedral, shops and restaurants

The real Barcelona. The real BARCELONA starts here, just wander around the narrow lanes,lots of little shops and cafes.Very clean and the police there very quick to stop any drinking in the streets.We watched as 5 boys were moved on.Its unspoilt you can easy go back in time .Just sit an relax in one of the plazas, its much calmer than the Rambals for a drink,.Read a guide book before so you are aware of all its history

A peak into the past. Great area to explore, did it at night too on Tapas tour. I would really suggest just wandering through, not worrying about getting lost because you will always come out to recognizable street. Felt absolutely safe there!
The real Barcelona. Lots of really good tapas bars, restaurants and boutique shops. Highly recommended area.

Festive at night and fun shops. This is a must see for any tourist. It's fun at night since there are so many people. Walk around the area and see all the beautiful churches. They just look so cool at night.
Quintessential Barcelona. Wander around, get lost, find your way back to the cathederal, eat/drink in any of the outdoor cafes, and a thousand photo ops. Enjoy.
Walk and enjoy. My favorite thing to do in Barcelona. Some of the stores are tourist traps, but the walk among the buildings is great.

Worth Walking around. We enjoyed walking through the Gothic Quarter and found the 6 Euros to go into the Gothic Cathedral very worthwhile! I would skip the Ramblas next time I'm in Barcelona, though. Nothing to see there except lots of tourists. DO NOT EAT at any of the restaurants in the Ramblas the food is horrendous. It was the only bad food we ate on our entire trip through Spain. In a city full of culinary genius its a shame the Ramblas area doesn't have better restaurants.

Take the Touristic Walking Tour. Take the Touristic Walking Tour, buy your tickets at the information booth in the Barri Gotic. Very knowledgeable guides and access where others can't go. Takes about 2 hours.

Great Area to Wander Around. Put your map away and enjoy getting lost in the winding streets of the Gothic Quarters, just behind La Catedral. It is the best way to discover all the hidden corners. The Cafe d' Estiu in the Frederic Mares Museum is a great place to rest your feet and have a drink. Check out more MUST SEE spots in Barcelona here: http://www.barcelonaforbeginners.com/top-10-must-see/

Loved the Gothic Quarter!!!. We were here for a 1 day cruise stop. We taxied to the Quarter at about 8:00. It was so early no one was around. We visited the old Barcelona Cathedral because it oped early. Don't miss the Cloister behind the church.Next we wondered the streets. We even saw a 2nd Bridge of Sighs. We felt we stood out like tourits too much because a few guys were following us. From here take the metro to See Gaud's famous houses.

Barrio Gotico. Is one of the most oldest neighborhood of barcelona if not the most, is a kind of maze full of shops, bar`s, alleys and squares, you can find, corious goods, antiques, even young fashion, one of the most crowded places in barcelona, and offers many things to see, i like it...and there`s one named carred palla if i remember, full of typical food....tasty, come to visit, you`ll like it..

Barcelona a Beautiful city!. I think Barcelona is one the most beautiful cities I have visited.The little streets, all these beautiful old buildings, the people singing and dancing on the street. very nice.My niece took me walking around the Gothic Quarter, we sat and had a beer on a little plaza, the atmosphere was great, you could feel that everybody was having a great time!A city not to be missed!

My favourite part of town.. This is what I imagine when I think of Spain. Lots of incredible tapas restaurants and bars, incredible old buildings, lots of alleys and streets that you can spend hours wandering through (and getting lost). The first time I came here it was on recommendation of a local who said this is where the best tapas can be found, and it was terrific! You'll find yourself bumping into an incredible old church and then around the corner find the best waffles you've tasted. Get lost in Barri Gotic for a few hours and you'll definitely want to come back for a second look.

Very nice to stroll around in the evening. It's very mystic and nice in the evenings, i loved to walk around here and look at the buildings and embracing the athmosphere!If you have an hour or so an evening, please do yourself a favor and stroll around here, it will be worth your time :)

Great base for Barcelona. You have everything here. Atmospheric, narrow streets, neat cafes, falafels, tapas, beer, protests, celebrations, noise, sanctuary. Everything is going on around here. Just get yourself lost in the maze of streets.Others have said they prefer the night but I actually preferred the day time, as that way I could see all the cool buildings and shops and cafes much clearer. There is a Metro stop (Jaume I) on the north end of the Barri Gotic and the other end brings you onto Las Ramblas. The squares inside the Barri Gotic are stunning; you can find as much quiet or noise as you like in here.It is also close enough to walk to Pl. Catalunya and also the coast. we had some good drinks and food up near Pl. Catalunya.All sorts of food can be found in the Barri Gotic, an eclectic mix.Even if you do not stay here, it is worth a visit.

faery tale. Bary Gothic is a fantastic place. I wasn`t a big fan of gothic architecture, but this place has an amazing atmosphire of some faery tale. Narrow strrets, beatifull churches, very old building (some of them were built in Roman`s time). I spent there almost all day just walking among this medieval buildings. Barselona is the beautifull city and Gothic quarter is the most amazing place in this city.

The Atmosphere in the Quarter Wonderful, Especially at Night. We visited the trip to the Palace of Catalan Music (ticket costs 12 euros), she goes to minute 50. Unfortunately, within a strictly not allowed to photograph.I went to the Cathedral as the time we got there during the service-the sight was amazing, upset only candles in the form of light bulbs. There is also a patio with palm trees, fountains, and 13 white geese, do not miss. Generally, the atmosphere in the quarter wonderful, especially at night, when open for dinner numerous tapas bars, pubs and restaurants. Everywhere you hear loud talk Spaniards, fun strolling tourists wandered the winding streets, where one can not get lost. Almost every building is preserved antiquity, and is simply amazing, with what solicitude is stored in its history! There is the Palace of the Catalan government and the City.

Gothic quarter, yes; City History Museum, no. We booked a tour of the Barri Gotica with “Hi! This is Barcelona” (because of so many glowing recommendations on this website) and while it certainly wasn’t cheap, it was well worth the money. Our guide Angel is a fountain of interesting information about history, architecture, people and current customs and opinions. We paused often to admire a small garden, architectural detail, etc and enjoyed a refreshing iced tea at one spot and some delicious tapas at another. After he left us, we walked in circles trying to find the City History Museum. A hint is to have the name of what you’re looking for written out because I think we would have had better luck if we could show our destination to someone rather than them trying to interpret our twisted Canadian way of saying the Spanish words!! In addition, there are MANY museums, so you have to be very specific with what you’re looking for. Anyway, the City History Museum shows ancient Roman ruins that were discovered under the current city. It was interesting, but wouldn’t be high on my list of recommendations.

Great place to explore - narrow streets, shops, fabulous churches. Bordered by the ocean to one side and Las Ramblas on another, the Gothic area is a terrific place to spend an afternoon exploring. We found the Cathedral as well as the Church of Santa Maria by the Sea. There is the plaza with the Mayor's house there as well. Lots of shops and cafes can be found.The Royal Palace where Isabella met Columbus upon his return can be found there.

Our favorite part of the city...very interesting maze of shops and restaurants. Just visited last week and our hotel was very close to this area. My husband and our two teen daugthers loved the Barri Gottic with an array of great shops and restaurants. Feel like you stepped into another world with the narrow cobblestone streets. Great little restaurants to discover. Loved having a beer or sangria in the afternoon on the Placa Real square just to relax and enjoy the ambience.

A journey through time and history. Enchanting quarter. The labyrinth of narrow streets makes us walk through time and history. Some streets are more appealing than others. Some are full of life, tourism, commerce, others are taken by “the dark forces”, if you know what I mean. Never the less, is a must do when in Barcelona. Take a map if you want, but it’s easy to walk through if you have two or three main references…

Great tour with Barcelona walks. We did a great tour of the Gothic quarter with Barcelona Walks. Only 10 Euro for two hours of fascinating information. We saw so much more with our guide Oliver. Next time I am in Barcelona I will certainly take their other tours. Top class.

A Laberinth. Narrow streets filled with sudden turns of various angles, passegways that at first look like spaces between buildings until you realize they are actually streets. And of course, Gothic architecture that nearly succeeds in convincing you that you're back in time (the gift shops and modern botiques snap you back to reality). The Gothic Quarter is absoutely worth a stroll of anywhere from a half hour ot three or four hours, depending on how long you like to linger. Because of the narrowness of the streets, it's also very possible to remain in the shade as you walk, a necessity if you visit this area during the daytime in the very hot summer.

Truly the heart of Barcelona. Spent eight days in Barcelona in early May and while each sector of the city has its own charm, there's something unique about Barri Gotic. If you enjoy seeing and experiencing history, you will love this part of the city -- from the remnants of the old Roman walled city to Roman graves to the spot where Columbus reported after his first voyage of exploration in the 1400s. One tip: take a map and guide book with you, otherwise you'll likely get lost amid the maze of narrow streets and alleys.

Another side to Barcelona. We enjoyed walking through all the streets around this quarter. Worth a walk around, it's not far off Las Ramblas, and is quite a contrast to all the modernist architecture else where. Some great little pastry shops around this area. I’d recommend having a walk around, we didn’t have a guide, we just wandered (though we did have a map!) It wasn’t as packed full of tourists as other parts which was a nice change after the hustle and bustle of Las Ramblas, though you could still find somewhere to eat or drink.

Beautiful. Discovering the Barrio Gotico was the highlight of my stay in Barcelona, one of my favourite destinations in Europe (actually it is my current favourite). I am biased as I have a passion for medieval architecture and honestly, it surpassed my expectations. The Cathedral with its courtyard was a treat, as was seating outside a café, looking at the many buskers & dancers on the square. I am looking forward to a return trip.

Underrated day out - Fantastic!. I am not a walky type person! I enjoy culture, history and getting to the genuine 'roots' of a place but do not normally feel I need to walk for an hour and half to get that! However, in Barcelona a walk round Barri Gothic is the ONLY way to do it! This really was the best day I had there; better than sagrada familia and las ramblas, probably on a par with park guell. The atmosphere of the place just screams authenticity (whether this is true or not I don't really care!) and the roman temple ruins tucked away in a quiet corner of an inauspicious street are unreal! There are probably loads of guided walks avaible on the net and in other guide books but we followed the one in the Time Out guide and it prooved to be really good; handily enough it ends at the Piccaso Museum so if you haven't had enough culture for the day you can pop in there or (as we did) simply visit their fantastic restaurant/bar for a great glass of wine!

Loved It!!!. We loved walking in this area of the city. The Cathedral almost brought a tear to my eyes. Simply incredible. We loved the little shops and all the beautiful old buildings. So much character and soul. I never found it creepy at all and we were never worried about the much touted pick pockets. We never had a problem, as a matter of fact we found the people there so very friendly.

oldest Barcelona. I thought the Barri Gotic was a nice counterbalance to Las Ramblas and the Gaudi sights. The cathedral is awe-inspiring, the surrounding neighborhood is straight out of medieval history. The have kept a lillte bit of the original city wall and one arch from a Roman aquaduct, cloisters, etc. I can see where someone might find it creepy (especially on a rainy day) but I thought it was beautiful.
Creepy. Creepy and dark winding streets. It was easy to get lost in and not that great a neighborhood
